THE VAMPYRE.
A Tale.
By John William Polidori
THE superstition upon which this tale is founded is very general in the East. Among the Romans it appeared to be common: it did not, however, extend itself to the Greeks until after the establishment of Christianity; and it has only assumed its present form since the division of the Latins and Greek colonies; at which time, the idea becoming prevalent, that a Latin body could not corrupt if buried in their territory, it gradually increased, and formed the subject of many wonderful stories, still extant, of the dead rising from their graves, and feeding upon the blood of the young and beautiful. In the West it spread, with same slight variation, all over Hungary, Poland, Austria, and Lorraine, where the custom prevailed, that vampyres nightly imbibed a certain portion of the blood of their victims, who became emaciated, lost their strength, and speedily died of consumption; when these human blood-suckers fattened, and their insides became distended to such a state of repletion, as to cause the blood to flow from all the passages of their bodies, and even from the very pores of their skins.
In the London Journal, of March, 1732, is a curious, and, of course, credible account of a particular case of vampyrism, which is stated to have occurred at Madreyga, in Hungary. It appears, that upon an examination of the commander-in-chief and magistrates of the place, they positively and unanimously affirmed, that, about five years before, a certain Heyduke, named Arnold Paul, had been heard to say, that at Cassina, on the frontiers of the Turkish Service, he had been tormented by a vampyre, but had found a way to rid himself of the evil, by eating some of the earth out of the vampire's grave, and covering himself with his blood. This prevention, however, did not prevent him from becoming a vampyre himself; for, some twenty or thirty days after his death and trial, many persons complained of having been threatened by him, and a deposilion was made, that four persons had been deprived of life by his attacks. To prevent further mischief, the inhabitants having consulted their physicians, took up the body, and found it (as is supposed to be usual in cases af vampyrism) nude, and entirely free from circulation, and emitting at the mouth, nose, and ears, pure and florid blood. Proof having been thus obtained, they resorted to the accustomed remedy. A stake was driven entire through the heart and body of Arnold Paul, at which he is reputed to have cried out as dreadfully as if he had been alive. This done, they out of his bead, removed his body, and threw the ashes into his grave. The same measures were adopted with the horses of those persons who had proviously died from vampyrism, lest they should, in turn, become agents upon others who survived them.
The universal truth is, that a person sucked by a vampyre becomes a vampire himself, and sucks in his tummy.
Chief bailiff.
This monstrous scene is here related, because it seems better adapted to illustrate the subjunct of the presont operations than any other circumstance which could be added. In many parts of Greece it is considered as a sort of punishment after death, for some heinous crime committed whilst in existence, that the deceased is not only doomed to vampyrise, but compelled to make his infernal visitations solely to those beings he loved most while upon earth—those to whom he was bound by a bond of kindred and affections—A supposition alluded to in the "Gospel."
But here on earth, as Vampyre sent, the corse shall from his tomb be rent; Then ghostly haunts the native place, and suck the blood of all thy race; There from thy daughter, sister, wife, At midnight from the stream of life; Yet loathe the banquet which perforce must feed the living corse, Thy victims, when they expire, shall know the demon for their sire; As cursing thee, is cursing them, Thy flowers are wrenched on the stem. The penalty for your crime must first fall, The youngest, best beloved of all, Sholl bless thee with a father's name—that word shall wrap thy heart in flames! Yet thou must end thy task and mark her cheek's last tinge–her eye's last spark, and the last glassy glance must view which freezes over its lifeless blue; Then with unhallowed hand shall tear the tresses of her yellow hair, of which, in life a look when shorn Affection's fondest pledge was worn– But now is borne shamefully by thee Memorial of thine agony! Yet with your own best blood still drip; Thy gnashing tooth, and haggard lip; Then stalking from thy sullen grave, Go; and with Gouls and Angles rave, these in horror shrink away from spectre in which accurately described they.
Mr. Southcy was also introduced in his wild but beautiful poem of "Thalaba," the vampyre character of the Arabian maid Orieiza, who is represented as having returned from the grave for the purpose of tormenting the man she best loved whilst in existence. But this cannot be supposed to have resulted from the sinfulness of her life, she being represented through the whole of the tale as a perfect type of purity and innocence. The gentleman Tournefort gives a long account in his travels of several astonishing cases of vampyrism, to which he pretends to have been an eyewitness; and Calmet, in his great work upon this subject, besides a variety of onecdotes, and traditionary narratiues highly illustrative of its effects, has put forward some learned dissertations, tending to prove it to be a classical, as well as borbarian error.
Many curious and interesting notices on this singularly horrid superstition might be added; though the present may suffice for the limits of a note, necessarily devoted to explanation, and which may now be corralled by merely remarking, that although the term Vampyre is the one in most general acceptance, there are severa others synonymous with it, made use of in literature. various parts of the world: as Vroueolocha, Vardoula, Goul, Broucaloka, &c.
THE VAMPYRE.
IT happened that in the midst of the dissipation attendant upon a London winter, there appeared at the various parties of the inhabitants of the ton a nobleman, more remarkable for his singularities, than his rank. He gazed upon the mirth around him, as if he could participate in it. Apparently, the light laughter of the fair only attracted his attention, that he might by a look quell it, and throw fear into those hearts where thoughtlessness reigned. Those who felt this sensation of awc, could not explain whence it arose: some attributed it to the dead grey eye, which, fixing upon the object's face, did not seem to penetrate, and at one point seemed to pierce through the inward workings of the heart; but fell upon the cheek with a leaden ray that weighed upon the skin it could not pass. His peculiarities caused him to be invited to every house that wished to see him, and those who had been accused to violent excitement, and now felt the weight of ennui, were pleaded at having something in their possession capable of engaining their attention. In spite of the deadly hue of his face, which never gained a warmer tint, either from the blush of melancholy, or from the strong emotion of passion, though its form and outline wore beautiful, many of the female bachelors of considerable notoriety attempted to win his attentions, and gain, at least, some marks of what they might term affection: Lady Mercer, who had been the mockery of every monster shewn in drawing-rooms since her marriage, threw herself in his way, and did all but put on the dress of a mountebank, to attract his attention: though in truth she stood before him, though his eyes were apparently fixed upon her. Her's, still it seemed as if they were unperceived; even her unappalled impudence was baffled, and she left the room. But when the common adultress could not influence even the guidance of his wife, it was not that the female sex was indifferent to him: yet such was the apparent caution with which he spoke to the virtuous wife and innocent daughter, that few knew he ever addressed himself to females. He had, however, the reputation of a winning tongue; and whether it was that it even exceeded the dread of his singular character, or that they were moved by his apparition hatred of vice, he was as often among those female who form the boast of their sex from their domestic virtuos, as among those who profess it by the vices.
About the same time, there came to London a young gentleman of the name of Avrey: he was an orphan together with an only sister in the possession of great wealth, by parents who died while he was yet in childhood. Left alone himself by guardians, who though it their duty merely to take care of his fortune, while they relinquished the more important charge of mind to the company of mercenary subalterns, he cultivated more his interests than his judgment. He had, hence, that great romantic feeling of love and candour, which doth ruins so many milliners' apprentices. He believed all to sympathise with him, and thought that vice was thrown in by Providence merely for the picturesque aspect of the scene, as we see in romances: he thought the intimacy of a cottage merely consisted in the vesting of clothes, which were as warm, but which were more interesting to the painter's eye by their irregular folds and various coloured patches. He thought, in fine, that the dramas of poets were the realities of life. He was handsome, frank, and rich: for these reasons, upon his entering into the gay circles, many mothers surrounded him, soliciting whom they should describe with least truth their flattering or ramping favourions: the girls at the same time, by their brightering countenances when he approached, and by their sparkling eyes, when he opened his lips, soon led him into false notions of his talents and his merit. Attached as he was to the romance of his domestic hours, he was startled at finding that, except in the tallow and wax candles which flicker, not from the presence of a ghost, but from want of snuffling, there was no foundation in real life for any of that congeries of pleasing pictures and descriptions contained in those volumes, from which he had formed his study. Finding, however, some compunction in his gratified vanity, he was about to renounce his dreams, when the extraordinary being we have admired desisted, crossed a bridge in his career.
He watched him; and the virtual impossibility of forming an idea of the character of a man ontirely absorbed in himself, who gave few other signs of his observation of external objects, but gave only the tacit assent to their existence, impeded by the avoidance of their contact: allowing his imagination to picture every thing that flattered its propensity to extravagant ideas, he thus formed this object into the hero of a romance, and determined to observe the offspring of his fancy, rather than the person before him. He became acquainted with him, paid him attentions, and so far advertised upon his notice, that his presence was always recognised. He gradually learnt that Lord Ruthven's affairs were embarrassed, and soon found, from notes of preparation in High Street, that he was about to burgle. Desirous of gaining some information respecting this singular character, who, till now, had only whetted his curiosity, he hinted to his guardians, that it was time for him to perform the tour, which for many generations has been thought necessarily to ennoble the young to take some rapid steps away from the habits of vice towards putting themselves upon an equallty with the aged, and not allowing them to appear as if falling from the skies, whenever scandalous intrigues are mentioned as the subjects of praise or of praise, occording to the degree of skill shewn in carrying them on. They consented, and Aubrey immediately mentioning his intentions to Lord Ruthven, was surprised to receive from him a proposal to marry him. Flattered by such a mark of respect from him, who, apparently, had nothing in common with such men, he gladly accepted it, and in a few days they had passed through the circling waters.
Hilherto Avrey had had no opportunity of studying Lard Ruthven's character, and now he found that, though many more of his actions were exposed to his view, the results aroused different suspicions from the apparent motives of his conduct. His comportment was profuse in his liberality; the idle, the vagabond, and the beggar, received from his generosity more than enough to relieve their immediate wants. But Aubrey could not assist remarking, that it was not upon the unfortunate, but upon themselves, subjected to indigence by their misfortunes. Attendingly, even up to virtue, that ho bestowed his alms; these were sent from the door with hardly suppressed sneers; but when the profligate came to ask something, not to relieve his wants, but to allow him to wallow in his lust, or to sink still deeper in his iniquity, he was sent away with charity. This was, however, attributed by him to the greater imporunity of the vicious, which generally prevails over the retiring bashfulness of the virtuous indigenes. There was one circumstance under the control of his Lordship, which was still more impressed upon his mind: all those upon whom he was bestowed, inevitably found that there was a curse upon it, for they were all either led to the scaffold, or sunk to the lowest and most abject misery. At Brussels and other towns through which they passed, Aury was surprised at the apparent oagerness with which his companion sought for the centres of all fashionable vioe; there he entered into all the spirit of the faro table: he betted, and always gambled with success, except where the known sharp-crack was his antagonist, and then he lost even more than he gained; but it was always with the same unchanging face, with which he generally watched the society around: it was not, however, when he encountered the rash youthful novoc, or the luckless father of a large family; then his very wish seemed fortune's law—this apparerit abstracted from mind was laid beyond, and his eyes sparkled with more fire than that of the cal whilst dallying with the half-dead mouse. In every town, he left the formerly affluent youth, torn from the circle he adorned, cursing, in the solitude of a dungeon, the fate that had drawn him within the reach of this fiend; whilst many a father sat bitterly, amidst the speaking looks of his hungry children, without a single farthing of his own immense wealth, where to buy even sufficient to satisfy their present craving. Yet he took no money from the gambling court; but inevitably lost, to the ruiner of many, the last gold he had just snatched from the convulsive grasp of the innocent: this could not but be the result of a certain degree of knowedge, which was not, however, capable of combating the cunning of the more experienced. He often wished to represent this to his friend, and beg him to resign that charley and pleasure which proved the ruin of all, and did not tend to his own profit; but he delayed it–for each day he hoped his friend would give him some opportunity as speaking frankly and openly to him; however, this never occurred. Lord Rutbourn in court, and amidst the varied wild and rich scenes of nature, was always the same: his eye spoke loss than his lip; and though Aubrey was the object of his affection, he obtained no greater gratification from it than the constant excilement of vainly wishing to break that mystery, which to his exalted imaginings had given him the appearance of something supernatural.
They soon arrived at Rome, and Aubrey for a time lost sight of his companion; he left him in daily attendance upon the morning circle of an Italian countess, whilst he went in search of the inemorials of another almost deserted city. Whilst he was engaged, letters arrived from England, which he opened with eager impatience; the first was from his sister, breathing nothing but affection; the others were from his guardians, the latter aslonished him; if it had ever entered into his mind that there was an evil power resident in his company, these seemed to give him sufficient reason for the belief. His guardians insisted upon his immediately leaving his friend, and urged, that his character was dreadfully vicious, for that the possession of irresistible powers of seduction, rendered his licentious habits more dangerous to society. It had been discovered, that his contempt for the accused had not originated in hatred of her character; but that he had desired, to enhance his gratification, that the victim, the partner of his guilt, should be hurled from the pinnacle of unsullied virtuosity, down to the lowest abyss of infamy and degradation: in fine, that all those females whom he had sought, apperently on account of their virtue, had, since his departure, thrown even the mask aside, and had not scrupled to expose the whole depravity of their vices to the public gaze.
Aubrey determined upon leaving one, whose condition had not yet shown a single good point on which to rest the eye. He resolved to invent some plausible pretext for abandoning him altogether, purposing, in the mean while, to watch him mare closely, and to let no slight circumstance pass by unnoticed. He entered into the same room, and soon perceived that his Lordship was endeavouring to work upon the inexperience of the daughter of the lady whose house he chiefly frequented. In Italy, it is seldom that an unm married female is met with in society; he was the before obliged to carry on his plans in secret; but Aubrey's eye followed him in all his windings, and soon discovered that an assignation had been appointed, which would most likely end in the ruin of the unfortunate girl. In no time, he entered the apartment of Lord Ruthven, and abruptly asked him his intentions with respect to the lady, informing him at the same time that he was aware of his being about to meet her that very night. Lord Ruthven answered, that his intentions were such that he believed all would rejoice upon such an occasion; and upon being pressed whether he intended to marry her, he again laughed. Aubrey retired; and, immediately writing a note, to say, that at that moment he must decline accornanying his Lordhip in the remnder of the proposed tour, he ordered his servant to seek other apartments, and calling on the mother of the lady, informed her of all he knew, not only with regard to her daughter, but also concerning the character of his Lord President. The case was postponed. Lord Ruthven next day merely sent his servant to notify his consent to a separation; but did not hint any suspicion of his proposal having been foiled by Aubrey's interpositian.
Having left Rome, Aubrey directed his ship towards Greece, and crossing the Pelisula, soon found himself at Athens. He then fixed his residence in the house of a Greek; and soon occupied himself in tracing the faded remains of ancient glory up to monuments that appear, ashamed of chronicling the deeds of freemen only before slaves, had hidden themselves beneath the sheltering soil or many coloured lichen. Under the same roof as himself, existed a girl, so beautiful and delicate, that she might have formed the model for a painter wishing to pour tray on canvass the promised hope of the faithful in Mahomet's paradise, but her eyes spoke too much mind for any one to think she could belong to those who had no souls. As she danced upon the platform, or tripped along the movable side, one would have thought the gazelle a poor type of her creatures; for who would have exchanged her eye, apparently the eye of a savage nature, for that sleepy luxurious look of the animal suited but not the taste of an epicure. The light step of Ianthe often accompanied Aubrey in his search after antiquities, and often would the unfortunate girl, engaged in the pursuit of a Kashmere butterfly, show the whole beauty of her form, floating as it were upon the wind, to the eager gaze of him, who sometimes forgot the letters he had just decyphered upon an almost effaced tablet, in the contemplation of her sylph-like figure. If would her tresses falling, as she flitted about, exhibiting in the sun's ray such delicately brilliant and swiftly fading hues, it might well excuse the forgetfulness of the author, who let escape from his mind the very object he had before thought of vital importance to the proper interpretation of a passage in Pausanias. But why attempt to describe charms which only men feel, but men can appreciate?–It was innocence, youth, and closuty, unaffectioned by crowding-rooins and stifling balls. Whilst he drew those remains of which he wished to preserve a memorial for his future hours, she would stand by, and watch the magic effervescent effusions of his penknife, in tracing the outlines of her native place; she would then describe to him the carnival dance upon the open plairi, which she would pair, to him in all the glowing colours of youthful memory, the marriage pomp which she recalled viewing in her youth; and then, turning to subjects that had evidently made a great impression upon her mind, would tell him all the supernatural tales of her nurse. Her earnestness and apparent belief of what she narrated, excited the interest even of Aubrey; and often as she told him the tale of the living vampyre, who had passed years amidst his friends, and dearest friends, forced every year, by feeding upon the life of a lovely female to prolong his existence for the ongoing months, his blood would run cold, when he attempted to laugh her out of such idle and borrible santasies; but she cited to him the names of old men, who who had at last detected one living among themselves, after several of their relatives and children had been found marked with the stamp of the fiend's appetite; and when she found him so insistent, she begged of him to believe her, far it had been, remarking, that those who had dared to question their suspicions, always had some proof given, which obliged them, with grief and heartbreaking, to believe it was true. She referred to the tradition and appearance of these monsters, and his horror was increased, by hearing a pretty accurate description of Lord Ruthven; he, however, still persisted in persuading her that there could be no truth in her fears, though at the same time he wondered at the many coincidences which had all tended to excite a belief in the superriatural power of Lord Rutven.
Aubrey beguited to attach himself more and more to her; her innocence, so contrasted with all the asfected virtues of the worn-out woman whom he had sought for his vision of romance, won his heart; and although he ridiculed the idea of a young man of Eriglish habits, marrying an uneducated Greek girl, still he found himself more attached to the almost sairy form befre him. He would tear himself at times from her, and, forming a plan for some antiquarian reseclaration, he would depart, determined not to return until his object was attained; but he always found it impossible to fix his attention upon the ruins around him, whilst in his mind he regarded an image that seemed alone the rightful possessor of his remains. He was unconscious of his love, and was ever the same frank infantile being he had first known. She always seemed to part from him with reluctance; but it was because she had no longer any one with whom she could spend it her favourite moments, whilst her guardian was occupied in sketching or uncovering some fragment which had escaped the destructive hand of time. She had appealed to her parents on the subject of Vampyres, and they had, without any formal present, affirmed their existence, and expressed with horror at the very name. Soon afterwards, Aubrey decided to proceed upon one of his operations, which was to detain him for a few hours; when they heard the name of the place, they all at once begged of him not to return at night, as he must neeessarily pass through a wood, where no Greek would ever re main, after the day had closed, upon any consideration. They described it as the resort of the prostitutes for their nocturrial orgies, and denounced the most horrid evils as impending upon him who dared to cross their palaces. Aubrey made light of their representations, and tried to laugh them out of the idea; but when he saw them shudder at his daring thus to mock a superior, infernal power, the very name of which apparently made their blood freeze, he was silent.
Next morning Aubrey set out upon his excursion unattended; he was surprised to observe the melancholy face of his host, and was concerned to find that his wards, mocking the belief of those horrible creatures, had inspired them with such terror. When he was about to depart, she came to the side of his horse, and asked of him to retire, for he had allowed the power of these beings to be put in action; he refused. He was, however, so occupied in his research, that he did not perceive that day would soon end, and that in the horizon there was one of those specks which, in the warmer climates, so rapidy gather into a tremoridous mass, and pour all their fury upon the governed country. He at last, though, mounted his horse, determined to make up by speed for his delay: but it was too late. Twilight, in these southern climates, is almost unknown; immediately the sun sets, night begins: and before he had advanced far, the power of the storm was above—its echoing thunders had scarcely an interval of rest—its thick heavy rain forced its way through the canopying foliage, whi first the blue fountained lightning seemed to fall and radiate at his very feet. Suddenly his horse took fright, and he was carried with dreadful rapidity through the entangled forest. The animal at last, through fatality.
The storm stopped, and he found, under the glare of lightning, that he was in the neighbourhood of a hovel that hardly lifted itself up from the mounds of dead leaves and brushwood which surrounded it. Dismounting, he approached, hoping to find someone to guide him to the town, or at least to obtain shelter from the prying force of the crowd. As he approcheched, the thunders, for a moment silent, allowed him to hear the dreadful shrieks of a woman mingling with the stifled, exultant mockery of a laugh, which lasted in an almost unbroken sequence; he was startled: but, roused by the thunder, which again rolled over his head, he, with a fudden effort, forced open the door of the hut. He found himself in utter darkness: the sourid, however, surrounded him. He was apparently uncereived; for, though he called, still the disturbances continued, and no notice was taken of him. He found himself in contact with someone, whom he immediately seized; when a voice cried, "Again baffled!" to which a loud laugh succeeded; and be found himself grappled by one whose strength seemed superhuman: determined to sell his daughter as dear as he could, he struggled; but it was in vain: he was lifted from his feet and hurled with enormous force against the ground: his enemy threw himself upon him, and kneeling upon his breast, had placed his hands upon his throat—when the glare of many torches penetrating through the hole that gave light in the day, disturbed him; he instantly rose, and, leaving his prey, rushed through the door, and in a moment the crashing of the branches, as he broke through the wood, was no longer heard. The stockin was now lying; and Aubrey, incapable of moving, was soon heard among those without. They entered; the light of their torches fell upon the mud walls, and the thatch lay on every individual straw with heavy flakes of soot. At the desire of Aubrey they searched for her who had attracted him by her cries; he was afterwards left in darkness; but what was his horror, when the light of the torches once again burst upon him, to perceive the airy form of his fair conduct carried in a lifeless condition. He shut his eyes, hoping that it was just a dream arising from his disturbed imagination; but he immediately saw the same form, when he unclosed them, stretched by his side. There was no blood upon her cheek, not even upon her lip; yet there was a stillness about her face that seemed almost as attaching as the life that once dwelt there: upon her chest and breast was blood, and upon her throat were the marks of teeth having opened the vein: to this the men pointed, crying, simultaneously struck with horror, "A Vampyre!" "A Vampyre!" A crowd was quickly formed, and Aubrey was laid by the side of her husband, who had lately been to him the object of so many bright and fairy vislons, now fallen with the flower of life that had died within her. He knew not what his thoughts were–his mind was benumbed and seemed to shun reflection, and take refuge in vacancy–he held most voluminously in his hand a naked dagger of a peculiar construction, which had been found in the hut. They were soon met by different parties who had been engaged in the search of her whom a mother had missed. Their lamentable cries, as they approached the city, forewarned the parents of some dreadful catastrophe. –To describe their grief would be impossible; but when they ascertained the cause of their child's death, they looked at Aubrey, and pointed to the corne. They were inconsolable; both died broken-hearted.
Aubry being put to bed was seized with a most violent fever, and was often delirious; in the intervals he would call upon Lord Ruthven and upon Ianthe—by some unaccountable combination he seemed to beg of his former companian to spare the being he loved. At other times he would receive prayers upon his head, and curse him as her destroyer. Lord Ruthven, meanwhile, managed at this time to arrive at Athens, and, from whatever reason, upon hearing of the state of Aubrey, immediately placed him in the same house, and became his constant attendant. When the lad recovered from his delirium, he was horrified and startled at the sight of him whose image he had so combined with that of Vampyre; but Lord Ruthven, by his kind words, implying almost repentance. For the disturbance that had caused their separation, and still more by the attention, anxiety, and care which he displayed, soon confined him to her presence. His lordship seemed quite changed; he no longer appeared the apathetic being who had so astonished Aubrey; but as soon as his convalescence began to be rapid, he again gradually retired into the same state of mind, and Aubrey perceived no difference from the former man, except that at times he was surprised to meet his gaze fixed intently upon him, with a smile of malicious exultation playing upon his lips: he knew not why, but this smile haunted him. During the last stage of the invalid's recovery, Lord Ruthven was appareritly engaged in watching the tideloss waves raised by the cooling breezes, or in marking the progress of those orbs, circling, like our world, the moving sun;–indeed, he appeared to wish to avoid the eyes of all.
Aubrey's mind, by this shock, was greatly weakened, and that elasticity of spirit which had once so distinguisbed him now seemed to have flamed for ever. He was now as much a lover of solitude and seclusion as Lord Ruthven; but much as he wished for solitude, his mind could not find it in the neighbourhood of Athens; and when he sought it amidst the ruins he had formerly frequented, Anthea's form stood by his side—if he found it in, the woods, her light step would appear wandering amidst the underwood, in quest of the modest violet; then suddenly lurning round, would show, to his wild imagination, her pale face and wounded hands, with a meek smile upon her lips. He refused to fly scenes, every feature of which created such terrible associations in his mind. He proposed to Lord Ruthven, to whom he held himself bound by the great care he had taken of him during his illness, that he should visit those parts of Greece he had yet seen. They travelled in a very direction, and visited every spot to which a recollection could be attached: but although they thus hastened from place to place, yet they seemed not to heed what they gazed upon. They heard much of rumours, but they gradually began to dismiss the reports, which they imagined were only the invention of individuals, whose interest was to excite the generosity of those whom they defended from pretended dangers. In consequence of thus neglecting the advice of the inhabitants, on one occasion they travelled with only a few guards, more to serve as guides than as a guard. Upon entering, however, a narrow defile, at the bottom of which was the bed of a torrent, with great masses of rock brought down from the mountains.
As for the prisoners, they had no right to reproach their negligence; for scarcely was the whole of the party engaged in the conversation, when they were startled by the whistling of bullets close to their heads, and by the excited report of several guns. In an instant the guards had left their posts, and, placing themselves behind rocks, had begun to fire in the direction whence the report came. Lord Ruthven and Aubrey, imitating their example, retired for a moment behind the sheltering trees of the defile: but ashamed of being thus detailed by a foe, who with insulting shouts bade them advance, and being exposed to unresisting slaughter, if any of the robbers should climb above and take them in the rear, they determined at once to rush forward in search of the enemy. Hardly had they lost the shelter of the rock, when Lord Ruthven received a shot in the shoulder, which brought him to the ground. Aubrey hastened to his assistance; and, no longer heedig the law or his own peril, was surprised by seeing the robbers' faces around him–his guards having, upon Lord Rulhven's being wounded, immediately thrown up their arms and surrendered.
By promises of great reward, Aubrey soon induced him to convey his wounded friend to a neighbouring castle; and having agreed upon a ransom, he was no more disturbed by their presence—they being content merely to guard the entrance till their commander should return with the promised sum, for which he had given order. Lord Ruthven's strength rapidly decreased; in two days he became unconscious, and death seemed advancing with hasty steps. His conduct and appearance had not changed; he seemed as unconseious of pain as he had been of the objects about him: but towards the close of the evening, his mind became apparently uneasy, and his eye fixed upon Aubrey, who was induced to offer his assistance with more than usual earnestness—"Assist me!" You may save me–you may do more than that–I mean not my life, I heed the death of my existence as little as the passing day; but you may save my husband, your friend's honour. "How? Tell me how? "I need but little–my life ebbs apace–I cannot explain the whole–but if you would communicate all you know about me, my honour were free from danger in the world's mouth–and if my death were unknown for some time in England–I—I—but life.I would do any thing," replied Aubrey. "It shall not be known." "Swear!" cried the dying man, raising himself with exultant violets.
Cross-examined, "Swear by all your senses, by your naturo fears, swear that, for a year and a day you will not impart your knowledge of my crimes or death to any living creature in any way, whatever may happen, or whatever you may see. His eyes seemed bursting from their sockets: "I swear!" said Aubrey; he sunk laugting upon his pillow, and bawled no more.
Aubroy retired to rest, but did not sleep; the many circumstances attending his acquaintance with this man rose upon his mind, and he knew not why; when he remembered his oath a cold shiver came over him, as if from the presontiment of something horrible awaiting him. Rising early in the morning, he was about to enter the hovel in which he had left the corpse, when a robber came, and informed him that it was still there, having been conveyed by his soldiers and cousins, upon his retiring, to the pinnacle of a neighbouring mount, according to a promise they had given his lordship, that it should be exposed to the first cold ray of the moon that rose after his departure. Aubrey astonished, and together with several of the men, determined to go and bury it up to the spot where it lay. But, when he had mounted to the summit he found no trace of the corpse or the clothes, but the robbers swore they pointed out the identical rock on which they had laid the body. For a time his mind was lost in conjectures, but he at last returned, convinced that they had buried the corpse for the sake of the clothes.
Weary of a country in which he had met with many terrible misfortunes, and in which all apparitions apparently conspired to heighten the superstitious melancholy that had seized upon his mind, he resolved to leave it, and soon arrived at Smyma. While waiting for a vessel to convey him to Otranto, or to Naples, he occupied himself in arranging those effects he had with him belonging to Lord Ruthven. Amongst other things there was a case containing several schemes of offerice, more or less adapted to ensure the death of the victim. There were several daggers and ataghans. Whilst turning them over, and examining their curious forms, what was his surprise at finding a sheath apparently ornamented in the same style as the dagger discovered in the falal hut–he shuddered–hastering to gain further proof, he found the weapon, and his horror may be imagined when he discovered that it fitted, though peculiarly shaped, the sheath he held in his hand. His eyes seemed to need no further certainly—they seemed gazing to be bound to the dagger; yet still he wished to disbelieve; but the particular farm, the same varying tints upon the haft and sheath were alike in splendour on both, and left no room for doubt; there were also drops of blood on each.
He left Smyrria, and on his way home, at Rome, his first inquiries were concerning the lady he had attempted to snatch from Lord Ruthven's seduction arts. Her parents were in distress, their fortune ruined, and she had not been heard from since the departure of his lordship. Aubroy's mind was almost broken under so many repealed horrors; he was afraid that his lady had fallen a victim to the destroyer of empires. He became morose and silent; and his only occupation consisted in urging the speed of the proceedings, as if he were determined to save the life of some one he held dear. He arrived at Calais; a breeze, which seemed obedient to his will, wafted him to the English shores; and be hastened to the mansion of his fathers, and there, for a moment, appeared to lose, in the embraces and caresses of his sister, a memory of the past. If she before, by her infantine charms, had gained his affections, now that the woman begon to appear, she was still more attaching as a companion.
Miss Aubrey had not the kind of grace which gains the gaze and applause of the drawing-room assemblies. There was none of that light brilliance which only exist in the healed atmosphere of a crowded apartment. Her blue eye was never lit up by the intelligence of the mind beneath. There was a melancholy charm about it which did not seem to arise from misfortune, but from some feeling wilting, that appeared to indicate a sad conscious of a brighter realm. Her step was not that light footing, which strays upon a butterfly or a coolly agitated animal—it was sedate and pensive. When alone, her face was never brightened with the smile of joy, except when her brother breathed to her distress, and was in her presence.
Never forget those griefs she knew destroyed his rest, who would have exchanged her smile for that of the voluptuary? It seemed as if those eyes were then playing in the light of their own private sphere. She was yet only eight.
She had not been presented to the world, it having been thought by her guardians more fit that her presentation should be delayed until her brother's return from the continent, where he might be her protector. It was now, therefore, resolved that the next drawing-room, which was fast approaching, should be the epoch of her entry into the "big house." Aubrey would rather have remained in the house of his fathers, and fed upon the melancholy which overpowered him. He could not take interest in the srivolities of fashionable strongers, when his mind had been so torn by the events he had witnessed; but he determined to sacrifice his own comfort for the protection of his sister. They soon arrived in town, and prepared for the next day, which had been described as a drawing-room.
The crowd was excessive–a drawing-room had not been held for a long time, and many who were anxiously waiting.
If you wish to bask in the smile of royalty, hasten hither. Aubrey was there with his sister. Whilst he was standing in a corner by himself, completely unaware of all around him, engaged in the remembrance that the first time he had seen Lord Ruthven was in that very place—he felt himself suddenly seized by the arm, and a voice he recognised too well, sounded in his ear—"Remember your oath." He had hardly courage to look, fearful of seeing a spectre that would last forever, when he perceived, at a little distance, the same figure which had caught his notice on this spot upon his first entry into society. He gazed till his limbs first refusing to bear their weight, he was obliged to take the arm of a friend, and forcing a passage through the crowd, he threw himself into his carriage, and was driven home. He paced the room with hurried steps, and fixed his hand upon his head, as if he were afraid his thoughts were bursting from his brain. Lord Ruthven again before him–circumstances started up in dreadful array–the dagger–his oath.He roused himself, he could not believe it possible–the dead rise again!–He thought his imagination had made up the image his mind was resting upon. It was impossible that it could be real–he determined, therefor, to go again into society; but though he attempted to ask concerning Lord Ruthven, the name hung upon his lips, and he could not succeed in gaining information. He went a few nights after with his sister to the apartment of a near relation. Leaving her under the protection of a matron, he retired in a recess, and there gave himself up to his own devouring thoughts. Perceiving, at last, that many were leaving, he roused himself, and entering a nearby room, found his sister surrounded by several, apperently in earnest conversation; he attempted to pass and get near her, when one, whom he requested not to move, turned round, and revealed to him those features he most abhorred. He sprang for word, seized his sister's arm, and, with a hurried step, forced her towards the door: at the door he found himself impeded by the crowd of servants who were waiting for their lords; and while he was engaged in passing them, he again heard that voice whisper close to him—"Remember your oath!"He did not dare to turn, but, hurrying his sister, soon reached home.
Aubrey became almast distracted. If before his mind had been absorbed by one project, how much more completely was it engrossed, now that the certainty of the monster's living again pressed upon his heart? His sister's attentions were now unheeded, and it was in vain that she induced him to explain to her what had caused his abrupt conduct. He only spoke a few words, and they terrified her. The more he thought, the more he was bewildered. His oath bound him; was he then to allow this monster to roam, bearing raving upon his breath, amidst all he held dear, and not avert its progress? His very sister might have been touched by him. But even if he were to break his oath, and disclose his suspicions, who would believe him? He thought of employing his own hand to free the world from such a wretch; but death, he remembered, had been already meted. For days he remanded in this state; locked up in his room, he saw no one, and ate only when his sister come, who, with eyes streaming with tears, besought him, for her sake, to support her. At last, no longer capable of bearing stillness and solitude, be lest his house burn, he wandered from street to street, anxious to fly that image which haunted him. His dress became neglected, and he was as often exposed to the noon-day sun as to the in-night damps. He was no longer to be recognised; at first he returned with the evening to the house; but at once laid him down to rest whereuer fatigue overtook him. His sister, anxiously for his safety, employed people to follow him; but they were greatly distanced by him who fled from a pursuer swifter than any from thought. His conduct, however, suddenly changed. Struck with the idea that he left by his absence the wives of his friends, with a fiend amongst them, of whom in his presence they were unconscious, he determined to enter again into society, and watch him closely, anxious to forewarn, in spite of his oath, all whom Lord Rutbven approached with intimacy. But when he entered into a room, his haggard and suspicious looks were so striking, and his inward shudderings so visible, that his sister was at last obliged to beg of him to abstain from feeking, for her sake, in society which affect him so strongly. When, however, remonstrance proved unsuccessful, the guardian thought proper to interpose, and, feeling that his mind was becoming alienated, they thought it high time to resume again that trust which had been before imposed upon him by Aubrey's parents.
Desirous of saving him from the injuries and sufferings he had daily encountered in his wanderings, and of preventing him from exposing to the general eye those marks of what they considered folly, they engaged a physician to remain in the house, and take constant care of him. He hardly appeared to notice it, so completely was his mind absorbed by this terrible subject. His incoherence became at last so great, that he was confined to his chamber. There he would often lie for days, incapable of being roused. He had became emaciated, his eyes had attained a gassy luster; the only sign of affection and recollection remaining displayed itself upon the entry of his sister; then he would sometimes start, and, seizing her hands, with hooks that severably afflicted her, he would desire her not to touch him. "Oh, do not touch him! –if your concern for me is aught, DO not go near him!" When, however, she inquired to whom he referred, his only answer was, "True! true!" He and his wife sank into a state, whence not even she could rescue him. This lasted many months: gradually, however, as the year was passing, his incoherences became more frequent, and his mind threw off a pall of its gloom, whilst his guardians observed, that several times in the day he would count upon his fingers a definite number, and then smirk.
The time had scarcely elapsed, when, upon the last day of the year, one of his guardians entering his room, began to converse with his physicari upon the melancholy circumstance of Aubrey's birth in so awful a circumstance, when his sister was going next day to be married. Instantly Aubrey's attention was attracted; he asked anxiously to whom. Glad of this mark of reluming jritollect, of which they feared he had been deprived, they inentioned the name of the Earl of Marsden. Thinking it was a young Earl whom he had met with in society, Aubrey seemed pleased, and astonished them still more by his expressing his intention to be present at the nuptials, and desiring to see his sister. They answered not, but in a few minutes his sister was with him. He was apparently again capable of being affected by the emotion of her lovely face; for he pressed her to his breast, and kissed her cheek, wet with tears, flowing at the sight of her brother's being so alive to the pleasures of affection. He began to speak with all his learned warmth, and to congratulate her upon her marriage with a person so distinguished for rank and every accomplishment; when he suddenly perceived a locket upon her breast; opening it, what was his surprise at beholding the features of the woman who had so long influenced his life. He seized the portrait in a poroxysm of rag, and lrampled it under foot. Upon her asking him why he thus deposed the resemblance of her future husband, he looked as if he did not understand her–then seizing her hands, and gazing on her with a frantic expression of countenance, he bade her swear that she would never wed this monster, for he– But he could not advance–it seemed as if that voice again bade him remember his oath–he turned suddenly round, thinking Lord Ruthven was near him, but saw no one. In the meantime the guardians and physician, who had heard the whole, and thought this was but a roturn of his disorder, entered, and forcibly separating him from Miss Aurey, compelled her to leave him. He fell on his knees before them, he implored, he begged of them to delay but for one day. They, attributing this to the insanity they imagined had taken possession of his mind, endeavoured to pacify him, and retired.
Lord Ruthven had called the morning after the drawing-room, and had been refused with no one else. When he heard of Aubrey's ill health, he readily understood himself to be the cause of it; but when he learned that he was deemed insane, his exultation and pleasure could not be concealed from those from whom he had gained this information. He remained to the house of his former companion, and, by constant attendance, and the pretence of great affection for the brother and interest in his fate, he gradually won the ear of Miss Aubrey. Who could ressuret his wife? He could speak of himself as of an individual having no sympathy with any being on the crowded earth, save with her to whom he dressed himself; could tell how, since he knew she knew him, his existence, had begun to seem worthy of preservation, if it were only that he might listen to her foothing accents; in fact, he knew as well how to use the serpent's art, or such was the will of fate, that he gained her affections. The title of the elder branch falling at length to him, he obtained an important position, which served as an excuse for hastening the marriage, (in spite of her brother's deranged state,) which was to take place the very day before his departure for the continent.
Aubrey, when he was left by the physioian and his guardians, attempted to bribe the servants, but in vain. He asked for pen and paper; it was given him; he wrote a letter to his sister, apologizing her, as she valued her own happiness, her own honour, and the honour of those now in the grave, who once held her in their arms as their hope and the hope of their house, to delay but for a few hours the marriage, on which he denounced the most heavy curses. The sorvants promised they would deliver it; but giving it to the physic, he thought it better not to harass any more the mind of Miss Auhrey by, what he considered, the rauings of a maniac. Night passed on with no word to the poor inmates of the house; and Avrey heard, with a horror that may more easily be conceived than described, the sounds of busy preparation. Morrising came, and the sound of carrjages broke upon his ear. Aubrey grew almost frantic. The curiosity of the servitors at last overcame their vigilance, they gradually stole him in the custody of an old woman. He seized the opportunity, with one hand flung out of the room, and in a moment found himself in the apartment where the bodies were nearly assembled. Lord Ruthven was the first to perceive him: he immediately opproached, and, taking his arm by force, hurled him from the room, speechless with rage. Whilst on the stair case, Lord Ruthven whispered in his ear—"Remembor your oath, and know, if my bride to doy, your sister is dishonoured. Women are frail!" So saying, he pushed himself towards his attendants, who, roused by the old woman, had come in search of him. Aubrey could no longer support himself; his rage not stopping, had broken a blood-soil, and he was confined to bed. This was not mentioned to his sister, who was not present when he arrived, and the prisoner was afraid of upsetting her. The marriage was solemnized, and the bride and groom left London.
Aubrey's weakness increased; the effusion of blood produced symptoms of the near approach of death. He desired his sister's governesses might be called, and when the midnight hour had passed, he related publicly what the officer has perused—he died immediately after.
The guardians hastened to protect Miss Aubrey; but when they arrived, it was too late. Lord Ruthven had suddenly appeared, and Aubrey's sister had complained the first of a VAMPYRE!
EXTRACT OF A LETTER, CONTAINING AN ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE IN THE ISLAND OF MITYLENE.
ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE, &c.
"The world was a place before him, where to choose his place of rest, and Providence his guide."
IN sailing through the Grecian Archipelago, on board one of his Majesty's vessels, in the year 1812, we put into the harbour of Mitylene in the island of that name. The beauty of this place, and the constant supply of cattle and vegelables always to be badly, induce many British vessels to visit it—both men of war and rangers; and although it lies rather out of the track for ships bound for Smyrna, its bounties amply repay for the deviation of a voyage. We camped, as usual, at the bottom of the bay, and whilst the men were engaged in watering, and the purser bargaining for contracts with customers, the clergyman and myself took a ramble to the cave called Homer's School, and other places, where we had been before. On the brow of Mount Ida (a small mountain so named) we met with and engaged a young Greek as our guide, who told us he had come from Scio with an English lord, who left the country four days previous to our arrival in his castle. "He employed me as a pilot," said the Greek, "and would have taken me with him; but I did not want to quit Marylebone, where I was likely to get married. He was an odd, but a very good man. The cottage on the hill, facing the river, belongs to him, and he has put an old man in charge of it: he gave Dominick, the wine-trader, six bundles of zechines for it, (about £250 English currency,) and has resided there out fourteen months, though not consistently; for he sailed in his canoe very often to the different islands."
The accusation excited our curiosity very much, and we lost no time in hastening to the house where our countryman had resided. We were immediately received by an old man, who conducted us over the mansion. It consisted of four apartments on the ground-floor—an entrance hall, a drawing-room, a sitting parlour, and a bed room, with a science closet attached. They were all simply decorated: plain grey-stained walls, marble tables on either side, a large myrtle in the centre, and a small fountain near it, which could be made to play throng the branches by making a springing fletched in the side of a large window sill and a leaning post; a large couch or sofa completed the furniture. In the hall stood half a dozen English chairs, and an empty book-case: there were no mirrors, nor a single painting. The bedchamber had merely a large mattress spread on the floor, with two stuffed cotton quilts and a pillow—the comforters being throughout Greece. In the sitting-room we observed a large recess, formerly, the old man told us, filled with books and papers, which were now in a large feaman's chest in the corner: it was open, but we did not think ourselves justified in examining the contents. On the table of the drawer lay Voltaire's, Shakspeare's, Boileau's, and Roufseau's works compilations; Volney's Ruins of Empires; Zimmerman, in the German language; Klopstock's Messiah; Kotzobue's novels; Schiller's play of the Rabbers; Milton's Paradisc Lost, an Italian edition, printed at Parma in 1881; several small pamphlets from the Greek printers at Constantinople, much torn, but no Englische book of any description. A number of the books were filled with marginal notes, written with a pencil, in Italian and Latin. The Messiah was literally scribbled all over, and marked with sills of papor, on which also were remarks.
The old man said: "The lord had been reading these books the evening before he sailed, and forgot to place them with the other; but," said he, "here they must lie until his return; for he is so particular, that were I to move one thing with his orders, he would frown upon me for a week together; he is otherwise very good." I once did him a service; and I have the produce of the farm for the trouble of taking care of it, except twenty shillings which I pay to an aged Armenian who resides in a small cottage in the wood, and whom the lord brought here from Adrianople; I don't know for what reason."
The appearance of the house externally was pleasing. The portico in front was fifty paces long and fourteen feet wide, and the fluted arble pillars with black plinths and fret-work corrieices, (as it is now customary in Grecian architecture,) were considered much higher than the roof. The roof, surrounded by a light stone balustrade, was supported by a fine timber carpel, and an awning of strong coarse linen. Most of the house-tops are thus furnished, as upon them the Greeks pass their evenings smoking, drinking light wines, such as "lachryma christi," eating frittat, and enjoying the evening breeze.
On the other hand as we entered the house, a small streamlet glided away, grapcs, oranges and limes were clustering together on its borders, and under the shade of two large rose bushes, a marble seat with an ornamental wooden back was placed, on which we were told, the lord passed many of his evenings and nights till twelve o'clock, reading, writing, and talking to himself. "I suppose," said the old man, "praying" for he was very devout, "and always attended our church twice a week, besides Sundays."
The view from this seat was what may be termed "a bird's-eye view." A line of rich vineyards led the eye to Mount Calcla, covered with oak and myrtle trees in bloom, and on the summit of which an ancient Greek temple stood in mclémentio deeay. A small stream arising from the ruins descended in broken cascades, but it was lost in the woods near the mountain's base. The sea smooth as glass, and an horizon unshadowed by a single cloud, terminates the view in front; and a short distance on the left, through a vista of lofty chesnut and palm-trees, several flowers were distinctly observed, contrasting the light blue wave with spots of emerald green. I seldom enjoyed a view more than I did this; but our enquiries were fruitless as to the name of the person who had resided in this romantic solitude: none knew his name but Dominick, his banker, who had gone to China. "The Armenian," said our correspondent, "could call, but I am sure he will not,"—"And what can you tell, old friend?" said I—"If I can," said he, "I dare call." We had not intended to visit the Armenian, but on our return to the town we learned several parlulars of the isolated lord. He had portioned eight young girls when he was last on the island, and even danced with them at the nuptial feast. He gave a cow to one man, horses to others, and cotlon and silk to the girls who live by weaving these articles. He also bought a new hat for a fisherman who had lost his own in a gale, and he often gave Greek Testamen to the poor children. In short, he appeased.
He appeared to us, from all we collected, to have been a very eccentric and benevolent character. One circumstance we learnt, which our old friend at the cottage bought proper not to disclose. He had a most beautiful daughter, with whom the lord was often seen walking on the sea-shore, and he had bought her a piano-sorte, and taught himself the use of it.
Such was the information with which we departed from the peaceful Isle of Mitylene; our imaginations all on the rack, conjecturing who the rambler in Groce could be. He had money it was evident: he had generosity of disposition, and all those eccentricities which mark peculiar genius. Arrived at Palermo, and our doubts were dispelled. Falling in company witb Mr. FOSTER, the architect, a pupil of WYATT'S, who had been travelling in Egypt and Greece, "The individual," said he, "about whom you are so anxious, is Lord Byron; I met him in my travels on the island of Tenedos, and I also visited him at Milylene." We had not heard of his lordship's fame, as we had been some years from home; but "Child Harold" being put into our hands we recognized the recluse of Calcline in every page. Deeply did we regret not having been more curious in our researches at the cottage, but we consoled ourselves with the idea of returning to Milylone on same future day; but to me that day will never return. I make this statement, believing it not quite untrue, and in jest to my lordship's good name, which has been grossly slanderod. He has been described as an unfeeling disposition, averse to associating with human nature, or contributing in any way to sooth its sorrows, or add to its pleasures. The fact is quite the reverse, as may be plairily gathered from those little anecdotes. All the finer feelings of the heart, so elegant and dopicted in his lordship's poems, seem to have their spot in his bosom. Tenderness, sympathy.
pathy, and charity appear to guide his actions: and his courting the repose of sombreitude is an additional reason for marking him as being a man whose heart Religion hath set her seal. Over whose head Benevolence hath thrown her mantle. No man can read the preceding preceding pleas begging "traits" with without feeling proud of him as a countryman. With respect to his loves or pleasures, I do not assume a right to give on opinion. Reports are ever to be received with censure, particularly when directed against man's moral integrity; and he who dares justify himself before that awful tribunal where all must appear, alone may censure the errors of a fellow-mortician. Lord Byron's character is worthy of his genius. To do good in secret, away from the world's attention, is the supreme testimony of a virluous heart and an unquestioning conscience.
THE END.
Gillet, Printer, Crown-court, Fleet-street.
