The character of a man entirely abused in himself, who gave few other signs of his observation of external objects, than the tacit assent to their existence, informed him of the avoidance of them altogether: allowing his imagination to picture every thing that flaunted its propensity to extravagant ideas, he formed this object into the hero of a romance, and determined to observe the springs of his fancy, rather than the person before him. He became acquainted with him, paid him compliments, and so far advanced upon his career, that his presence was always recognised. He subsequently learnt that Lord Ruthven's affairs were bankrupt, and found, from the notes of preparation in Stretton, that he was about to travel. Desirous of gaining some information respecting this singular character, who, till now, had ony whetled his curiosity, he hinted to his friends, that it was time for him to perform the duty, which for many generations had been thought necessary to enable the young to take a rapid advance in the career of vice, by placing themselves upon an equality with the aged, and not allowing them to appear as if distant from the fold, whenever scandalous intrigues are mentioned as the subjects of pleasantry or of praise, accarding to the degree of skill shewn in carrying them on. They consented, and Aubrey immediately declaring his intentions to Lord Ruthven, was surprised to receive from him a proposal to join him. Flattered by such a mark of esteem from him, who, apperently, had nothing in common with other men, he gladly accepted it, and in a few days they had passed through the circling waters.
Hitherto, Aubrey had had no opportunity of studying Lord Ruthven's character, and now he found, that, though many more of his associates were exposed to his view, the results of a subsequent commission contradicted the apparent motives to his conduct. His conduct was profuse in his liberallty; the idle, the vagabond, and the beggar, received from his hand more than enough to relieve their immediate troubles. Mr. Aubrey could not avoid remarking, that it was riot upon the virtuous, reduced to indigence by the misfortunes attendant even upon virtue, that he stowed his articles; these were removed from the door with hardly suppressed sneers; but when the prosecutor came to ask something, not to relieve his wants, but to allow him to wallow in his lust, or to sink him still further in his iniquity, he was sent away with rich charity. This was, however, attributed by him to the greater portability of the vicious, which generally prevails over the retiring bashfulness of the virtuous. There was one circumstantial about the charity of his Lordship, which was still more pressing upon his mind: all those upon whom it was bestowed, inevitably felt that there was a curse upon them, for they were all either led to the scaffold, or sunk to the lowest and the most abject misery. At Brussels and other towns through which they passed, Aubrey was surprised at the apparent eagerness with which his companion saught for the pleasures of all fashionable vice; there he entered into all the spirit of the faro table: he betted, and always gambled with success, except where the known sharper was his antagonist, and then he lost even more than he gained; but it was always with the same urbane face, with which he generally watched the society around: it was not, however, so when he ennobled the rash youth of a particular neighbourhood, or the luckless fatality of a numerous families; then it very much seemed fortune's law—this abstractedness of mind was laid aside, and his eyes sparkled with more fire than that of the cot whilst dallying wit the half-dead mouse. In every town, he left the formerly affluent youth, torn from the habits he adorned, cursing, in the throes of a dungeon, the fate that had drawn him to the roach of this fiend; whilst many a father sat frantic, amidst the speaking looks of mute hungry children, without a single farthing of their late immense wealth, wherewith to buy even sufficient food to feed their preferent children. Yet he took no money from the gambling table; but immediately lost, to the surprise of many, the very gold he had just snatched from the convulsive grasp of the innocent: this could but be the result of a certain degree of knowledge, which was not, however, capable of combatting the cunning of the more experienced. Aubrey often wished to represent himself to his friend, and beg him to resign that charity and pleasvre which proved the ruin of all, and did not tend to his own profit; but he dared not do it–for each day he hoped his friend would give him some opportunity of speaking frankly and openly to him; however, this never occurred. Lord Ruthven, in his carriage, and amidst the various wild and rich scenes of nature, was much the same: his eye poked less than his lip; and though Aubry was near the object of much curiosity, he obtained no greater gratification from it than the constant excitement of those wishing to break that mystery, which to his exhausted imagination began to assuage the appearance of something unnatural.
They soon arrived at Rome, and Aubrey for a time lost sight of his companion; he soon found him in daily attendance upon the marriage commission of an Italian countess, which he went in fear of the memorials of another infamous city. Whilst he was thus engaged, letters arrived from England, which he opened with eager impatience; the first was from his sister, breathing nothing but affection; the others were from his guardians, the latter astonished him; if it had hefore entered into his imagination that there was an evil power resident in his comportment, the circumstances seemed to give him sufficient reason for the belief. His guardians urged upon him immovably leaving his friend, and urged that his character was dreadfully vicarious, for that the possession of revolting powers of seduction, rendered his licentious habits more dangerous to society. It had been discovered, that his passion for the adultross had not originated in hatred of her character; but that he had required, to enhance his reputation, that the victim, the partner of his career, should be hurled from the pinnacle of unsullied virtue, down to the lowes abyss of infamy and degradation: in fine, that all those females whom he had sought, apparently on account of their virtue, had, since his departure, thrown the mask aside, and had not scrupled to expase the whole extent of their vices to the public gaze.
Aubrey descended upon leaving one, whose character had not yet shown a single bruise on which to rest the eye. He resolved to invent some plausible pretext for abandoning him altogether, purposing, in the mean while, to watch him more closely, and to let no slight circumstances pass by unnoticed. He entered into the same circle, and soon received, that his Lordship was endeavouring to work upon the inexperience of the daughter of the lady whose house he chiefly frequented. In Italy, it is seldom that an unmarried female is met with in society; he was therefore able to carry on his plans in secret; but Avrey's eye followed him in all his windings, and soon discovered that an assignation had been arranged, which would most likely end in the ruin of an innocent, though thoughtless girl. Losing no time, he entered the apartment of Lord Rulhven, and abruptly asked him his intentions with respect to the lady, informing him at the same time that he was aware of his being about to marry her that very night. Lord Ruthven answered, that his intentions were such as he supposed all would bear upon such an occasion; and upon being pressed whether he intended to marry her, merely laughed. Aubrey retired; and, immediately sending a note, to say, that from that moment he must decline accompanying his Lordship in the remainder of his proposed tour, he ordered his servant to seek other apartments, and calling upon the mother of the lady, informed her of all he knew, not only with regard to her daughter, but also concerning the character of his Lord President. The assignation was prevented. Lord Ruthven next day merely asked his servant to secure his completeness to effect a separation; but did not hint any suspicion of his plans having been foiled by Aubrey's interposition.
Having left Rome, Aubrey directed his sleps through Greece, and crossing the Peninsula, soon found himself at Athens. He fixed his residence in the house of a Greek; and soon occupied himself in tracing the faded records of ancient glory upon monuments that apparently, ashamed of chronicle the deeds of freemen only before slaves, had hidden themselves beneath the sheltering soil or monochrome lichen. Under the same roof as himself, existed a being, so beautiful and deceased, that she might have formed the model for a painter wishing to paint upon canvas the promised hope of the faithful in Mahomet's paradise, save that her eyes spoke too much inind for any one to think she could belong to someone who had no salvation. As she dancod upon the plait, or tripped upon the mountain's side, one would have seen the gaze of a poor type of her friend; for whom would have observed her eye, opparently the eye of animated nature, for that sleepy luxurious look of the animal suited but to the taste of an epicure. The light breeze of the day accompanied Aubrey in his search after antiquities, and often would the unconscious girl, engaged in the pursuit of a Kashmere butterfly, show the whole beauty of her form, floating as it were upon the wind, to the eager gaze of him, who forgot the letters he had decyphered upon an almost effaced tablet, in the contemplation of her sylph-like figure. Often would her trosses falling, as she flitted about, exhibit in the sun's ray delicately brilliant and fiftily fading hues, which might well excuse the forgetfulness of the antiquary, who let escape from his mind the very object he had before thought of vital importance to the proper interpretation of a passage in Pausanias. But why attempt to describe charms which all feel, but none can appreciate?–It was innocence, youth, and beauty, unaffected by crowded drawing-rooms and stifling balms. Whilst he drew the remains of which he wished to preserve a memorial for his future hours, she would stand by, and witness the magic effects of his pencil, in tracing the scenes of her native place; she would describe to him the circling dance upon the open plain, would point, to him in all the glowing colours of her youthful memory, the marriage window she remembered viewing in her infancy; and then, turning to matters that had evidently made a greater impression upon her mind, would tell him all the supernatural tales of her nurse. Her story, and apparent belies of what she narrated, entertained the interest even of Aubrey; and often as she told him the tale of the living vampyre, who had passed years amid his friends, and dearest ties, forced every year, by feeding upon the life of a young female to prolong his existence for the ensuing months, his blood would run cold, whilst he attempted to laugh her out of such idle and horrible fantasies; but she cited to him the names of old friends, who, having at once detected one living among them, after several of their relatives and children had been found marked with the slamp of the fiend's appetite; and when she found him so incredulous, she begged of him to believe her, for it had been, remarked, that those who had dared to question its existence, always had some proof giving, which obliged them, with grief and heartbreaking, to confess it was true. She detailed to him the tradional appearance of these monsters, and his horror was increased, by bearing a precise description of Lord Ruthven; he, however, still persisted in persuading her, that there could be no truth in her fears, but at the same time he wondered at the many coincidences which had all tended to excite a belief in the supernatural power of Lord Routhven.
Aubrey began to attach himself more and more to her innocence, so determined was he that all the affected virtues of the women among whom he had sought for his vices of romance, won him heart; and while he ridiculed the idea of a young man of English habits, marrying an uneducated Greek girl, he found himself more attached to the almost fairy form before him. He would tear himself at times from her, and, forming a plan for some antiquarian rescarch, he would depart, determined not to return until his object was attained; but he always found it impossible to fix his attention upon the ruins around him, whilst in his mind he retained an object that seemed alone the rightful possessor of his thoughts. He was incapable of love, and was ever the same frank infantile being he had first known. She always seemed to part from him with reluctance; but it was because she had no longer any one with whom she could visit her favourite haunts, whilst her guardian was occupied in sketching or uncovering some fragment which had yet escaped the destructivo band of time. She had appealed to her parents on the subject of Vampyres, and they both, with several present, affirmed their existence, pale with horror at the very idea. Soon afterwards, Aubrey determined to proceed on one of his excursions, which was to detain him for. Sometime in the future. When they heard the name of the place, they all at once begged of him not to return at night, as he must necessorily pass through a wood, where no Greek would remain, after the day had passed, upon any consideration. He described it as the resort of the vampyres in their nocturnal orgies, and denied the vile evils of them upon him who dared to cross their path. Aubrey made light of their reprobation, and tried to laugh them out of the idea; but when he saw them shudder all his hair thus to mock a superior, immortal power, the very name of which apparently made their blood free, he was silent.
Next morning Aubrey set off upon his excursion unassisted; he was surprised to observe the melancholy face of his host, and was dismayed to find that his words, mocking the belief of these terrible fiends, had inspired them with such terror. When he was about to depart, she came to the side of his horse, and earnestly begged of him to return, for night allowed the power of the supernatural beings to be put in action; he promised. He was, however, so excited in his research, that he did not perceive that day-light would soon arrive, and that in the horizon the sun was one of those specks which, in the warmer climatic conditions, so rapidly gather into a tremendous mass, and pour all their fury upon the devoted crowd. He at last, though, mounted his horse, determined to make up by speed for his delay: but he was too late. Twilight, in these southern climatics, is almost unknown; immediately the sun sets, night begins: and before he had advanced far, the power of the storm was above—its echoing thunders had soared above an interminable hour of rest—its thick heavy rain forded its way through the canapying foliage, whilst the great forked ligaments seemed to fall and radiate at his very feel. Suddenly the prisoner took fright, and he was carried with dreadful rapidity through the enclosed forest. The animal at last, through fatigue, stopped, and he saw, by the glare of lighting, that he was in the neighbourhood of a bovel that hardly lifted itself up from the masses of dead leaves and brushwood which surrounded it. Dismounting, he approached, hoping to find someone to guide him to the town, or at least trusting to obtain shelter from the pelting of the storm. As he approached, the thunder, for a moment silent, allowed him to hear the dreadful shrioks of a woman mingling with the fifled, exultant mockery of a laugh, continuod in an almost urbane sound; he was startled: but, roused by the thunder which again rolled over his head, he, with a sudden effort, forced open the door of the hut. He found himself in total darkness: the sound, however, guided him. He was apparently unperceived; and, though he called, still nothing transpired, and no notice was taken of him. He found himself in contact with someone, whom he immediately alarmed; when a voice cried, "Again baffled!" to which a loud laugh succeeded; and he felt himself grappled by one whose strength seemed superhuman: determined to save his life as dearly as he could, he struggled; but it was in vain: he was lifted from his feet and hurled with tremendous force against the ground: his enemy threw himself upon him, and kneeling upon his back, had placed his hands up to his throat; but the glare of many torches penetrating through the hole that gave light in the day, dislurbed him; he instantly rose, and, leaving his prey, rushed through the door, and in a moment the crashing of the branches, as he broke through the wood, was no longer heard. The storm was now still; and Aubrey, incapable of moving, was soon heard by those without. They entered; the light of their torches fell upon the mud walls, and the thatch loaded on every individual straw with heavy flakes of soot. At the desire of Aubrey they searched for her who had attracted him by her cries; he was again lest in darkness; but was his horror, when the light of the torches once again burst upon him, to perceive the arms of his fair conductress brought in a lifeless state. He shut his eyes, hoping that it was just a vision rising from his disturbed imagination; but he again saw the same form, when he unclosed them, slretched by his side. There was no colour upon her cheek, not even upon her lip; yet there was a stillness about her face that seemed most as attaching as the life that once dwelt there:–upon her neck and breast was blood, and upon her throat were the marks of teeth having opened the vein:–to this the men pointed, crying, simultaneously slunk with horror, "A Vampyre!" "A Vampyre!" A litter was quickly formed, and Aubrey was laid by the side of her who had lately been to him the object of so many joyful and fairy visions, now fallen with the flower of life that had died within her. He knew not what his thoughts were–his mind was benumbed and seemed to shun recollection, or take refuge in vacancy–he had almost unconsciously in his hand a naked dagger of some particular construction, which had been found in the hut. They were soon met by different parties who had been engaged in the search of someone whom a mother had missed. Their lamentable cries, as they approached the court, forewarned the parents of some dread cataclysm. –To describe their grief would be impossible; but when they reached the corner of their chamber's room, they looked at Aubrey, and pointed to the corner. They were inconsolable; both died broken-hearted.
Aubrey being put to bed was seized with a first violent fever, and was often delirious; in the latter intervals he would call upon Lord Ruthvon and upon Ianthe; by some unaccountable combination he seemed to beg of his master company to spare the being he loved. At other times he would imprecisely place maledictions upon his head, and wese him her deserter. Lord Routhven, chanced at this time to arrive at Athens, and, from whatever motive, upon hearing of the state of Aubrey, immediately placed him in the same house, and became his constant attendant. When the latter recovered from his delirium, he was horrified and staggered at the sight of him whose image he had now combined with that of a Vainpyre; but Lord Ruthven, by his kind words, implying almost repentance for the fault that had caused their separation, and still more by the affection, anxiety, and care which he showed, soon reconciled him to his presence. His lordship had quite changed; he no longer appeared that apathetic being who had so astonished Aubrey; but as soon as his condition began to be ropid, he again gradually relired into the same state of mind, and Aubrey perceived no difference from the former man, except that at times he was surprised to meet his gaze fixed intently upon him, with a smile of malicious exultation playing upon his lips: he knew not why, but this smile haunted him. During the last stage of the invalid's recovery, Lord Ruthven was apparently engaged in watching the tideless waves raised by the cooling breeze, or in marking the progress of those orbs, circling, like our world, the moveless surface;–indeed, he appeared to wish to avoid the eyes of all.
Aubrey's mind, by the shock, was greatly weakened, and that elasticity of spirit which had once so dispelled him now seemed to have fled for ever. He was now as much a lover of seclusion and silence as Lord Mayor; but much as he wished for solitude, his mind could not find it in the neighbourhood of Atheris; if he sought it amidst the rivins he had formerly frequented, Anthe's form stood by his side—if he sought in the woods, her light step would appear wandering amidst the underwood, in quest of the modest violet; her suddenly turning round, would flash, to his wild imagination, her pale face and wounded throat, with a meek smile upon her lips. He determined to fly scenes, every one of which created such bitter associations in his mind. He proposed to Lord Rulhveri, to whom he held himself bound by the tender care he had taken during his illness, that they should visit those parts of Greece neither had yet seen. They travelled in every direction, and sought every spot to which a recollection could be attached: but though they thus passed from place to place, yet they seemed not to heed what they gazed upon. They heard much of robbery, but they gradually began to hear slight reports, which they imagined were largely the work of individuis, whose object it was to expunge the generality of those whom they defended from preterided dangers. In consequence of thus neglecting the advice of the inhabitants, on one occasion they travelled only a few guords, more to serve as guides than as a defence. Upon entering, however, a narrow defile, at the bottom of which was the bed of a torrent, with large masses of rock brought down from the neighbouring precipices, they had reason to repent their negligence; for scarcely half the party engaged in the narrow pass, when they were startled by the whistling of bullets close to their heads, and by the echoed report of several shots. In an instant their guards had reached them, and, placing themselves behind rocks, had begun to fire in the direction wherice the report came. Lord Ruthven and Aubrey, imitating their example, retired for a moment behind the sheltering turn of the defile: but ashamed of being thus detained by a foe, who with his threatening shouts had them afraid, and being exposed to unresisting slaughter, if any of the robbers should climb up and take them in the rear, they determined at once to rush forward in search of the enemy. Hardly had they left the shelter of the rock, when Lord Ruthven received a shot in the shoulder, which brought him to the ground. Aubrey hastened to his assistance; and, no longer heeding the contest or his own peril, was soon surprised by seeing the robbers' faces upon him–his comrades having, upon Lord Ruthven's being wounded, immediately thrown up their arms and surrendered.
By promises of great reward, Aubrey soon induced them to convey his wounded friend to a neighbouring cabaret; and having agreed upon a ransom, he was no more compelled by their promise–they being content merely to guard the entrance till their comrade should return with the promised sum, for which he had an order. Lord Ruthven's strength rapidly decreased; in two days considerable intractability ensued, and death seemed inevitable with hasty steps. His conduct and appearance had not changed; he seemed as unconscious of pain as he had eighteen of the objects about him: but towards the close of last evening, his mind became apparently uneasy, and his eye often fixed upon Aubrey, who was induced to offer his assistance with more than usual earnestness—"Assist me!" You may save me–you may do more than that–I mean not my life, I heed the death of my existence as little as that of the passing day; but you may save my honour, my father's honour. "How? Tell me how? "I would do anything," replied Aubrey. "I need but little–my life ebbs apace–I cannot exploit the world–but if you would communicate all you know of me, my honour were free from stain in the world's mouth–and if my death were unknown far some time from England–I—I–but not now." "It shall not be known." "Swear!" cried the dying man, raising himself with exultant violence, "Swear by all your foul reveres, by all their nature fears, that, for a year and a day you will not part your knowledge of my crimes or death to anyone living being in any way, whatever may happen, or whatever you may see. His eyes seemed bursting from their sockets: "I swear!" said Aubrey; he sunk laughing upon his pillow, and breathed no more.
Aubrey retired to rest, but did not sleep; the many circumstances attending his illness.
Inance with this man rose upon his mind, and he knew not why; when he remembered his oath a cold shivoring came over him, from the presentiment of something horrible awaiting him. Rising early in the morning, he was about to enter the hovel in which he had left the corpse, when a robber met him, and informed him that it was no longer there, having been conveyed by himself and comrades, upon his retiring, to the pinnacle of a neighbouring mount, according to a promise he had given his lordship, that it should be exposed to the first cold ray of the moon that rose after his death. Aubrey appalled, and taking several of the men, determined to go and bury the body upon the spot where it lay. But, when he had mounted to the summit he found no trace of either the corpse or the clothes, though the robbers swore they pointed out the identical rock on which they had laid the body. For a time his mind was bewildered in conjectures, but he at last returned, convinced that they had buried the corpse for the sake of the children.
Weary of a life in which he had met with such terrible misfortunes, and in which all apparently conspired to beighten that superstitious molancholy that had seized upon his mind, he resolved to leave it, and soon arrived at Smyrna. While waiting for a vessel to convey him to Ortranto, or to Naples, he occupied himself in arranging the effects he had with him belonging to Lord Routh. Amongst other things there was a case containing feveral symptoms of offence, more or less adapted to ensure the death of the victim. There were several daggers and ataghans. Upon turning them over, and examining their curious forms, what was his surprise at finding a sheath apparently ornamented in the same style as the daggers discovered in the fatal hut–he shuddered–hastening to gain further proof, he took the weapons, and his horror could scarcely be contained when he discovered that they fitted, quite peculiarly shaped, the sheath he held in his hand. His eyes seemed to need no further certainly—they seemed gazing to be bound to the dagger; yet still he wished to believe; but the particulate form, the same varying tints upon the haft and sheath were extraordinary in splendour on both, and left no room for doubt; there were also drops of blood on each.
He left Smyrna, and on his way home, at Rome, his first inquiries were concernig the lady he had attempted to snatch from Lord Ruthven's seductive arts. Her parents were in disgrace, their livelihood ruined, and she had not been heard of since the departure of her lordship. Aubrey's mind became a little broken under so many repeated horrors; he was afraid that this lady had fallen a victim to the deceased of Harithe. He became morose and silent; and his melancholy occupation caused in speeding the speed of the proceedings, as if he were going to save the life of some one he hold dear. He arrived at Calais; a breeze, which seemed obedient to his will, wafted him to the English shores; and he hastened to the mansion of his father, and there, for a moment, appeared to lose, in the embraces and caresses of his sister, all memory of the past. If she before, by her inferential caresses, had gained his affection, now that the women began to appear, she was still more attendant.

Miss Aubrey had that winning grace which went with the gaze and a pause of the drawing-room audience. There was a kind of light brilliancy which could only exist in the heated atmosphere of a crowded apartment. Her blue eye was constantly lit up by the intelligence of the mind beneath. There was a melancholy charm about it which did not seem to arise from misfortune, but from some feeling within, that appeared to indicate a soul conscious of a brighter realm. Her step was not that lazy footing, which strays where a butlerfly or a colossus may attract—it was sedate and pensive. When she was alone, her face was never brightened by the smile of joy; but when her brother breathed to her his last breath, and would in her presence forget those griefs she knew destroyed his rest, who would have exchanged her smile for that of the voluptuary? It seemed as if those eyes on that face were then playing in the light of their own native sphere. She was yet only eighteen, and had not been exposed to the world, it having been bought by her guardians morefit that her present confinement should be delayed until her brother's return from the service, when he might be her protector. It was now, therefore, resolved that the next dancing-road, which was fast approaching, should be the occasion of her entry into the "busy scene." Aubrey would rather have remanded in the custody of his friends, and dwell upon the melancholy which overpowered him. He could not feel interest in the frivolities of fashionable strongers, when his mind had been so torn by the events he had witnessed; but he determined to sacrifice his own comfort to the protection of his sister. They soon arrived in town, and prepared for the next day, which had been advertised as a drawing-room.
The crowd was extraordinary–a drawing-room had not been held for a long time, and all who were anxious to bask in the smile of royalty, hastened to attend. Aubrey was there with his sister. While he was standing in a corner by himself, heedless of all around him, engorged in the remembrance that the first time he had seen Lord Ruthven was in that very place—he felt himself suddenly seized by the arms, and a voice, which he recognized too well, sounded in his ear—"Remember your oath." He had hardly courage to turn, fearful of seeing a spectacle that would blast him, when he perceived, at a little distance, the same figure which had attracted his notice on this spot upon his first entry into society. He struggled till his limbs almost refusing to bear the weight, he was obliged to take the arm of a friend, and forcing a passage through the crowd, he threw himself into his carriage, and was driven home. He paced the room with hurried steps, and fixed his hands upon his head, as if he were afraid his thoughts were bursting from his brain. Lord Ruthven standing before him–circumstances started up in dreadful array–the dagger–his oath–He rushed himself, he could not believe it possible–the dead rise again!–He thought his imagination had made up the image his mind was dwelling upon. It was impossible that it could be real–he determined, therefore, to go again into society; for when he attempted to ask concerning Lord Ruthveri, the name hung up from his lips, and he could not succeed in gaining information. He went a few days ago with his sister to the assembly of a near relation. Leaving her under the protection of a ruffian, he retired into a room, and there gave himself up to his own devouring thoughts. Perceiving, at last, that many were leaving, he roused himself, and entering another room, found his sister surrounded by several, apparently in earnest conversation; he endeavoured to pass and get near her, when one, whom he compelled to move, turned round, and revealed to him the features he most abhorred. He sprang forward, seized his sister's arm, and, with a hurried step, forced her down the street: at the door he found himself impeded by the crowd of servants who were waiting for their lord; and while he was engaged in passing them, he again heard that voice which came to him—"Remmber your oath!"–He did not dare turn, but, hurrying his sister, soon reached home.
Aubrey became extremely distracted. If before his mind had been absorbed by one subject, how much more completely was it engrossed, now that the certainty of the monster's living again pressed upon his thoughts. His sister's attentions were now unhealed, and it was in vain that she induced him to explain to her what had caused his abrupt conduct. He only uttered a few words, and those terrified her. The more he thought, the more he was bewildered. His oath startled him; was he supposed to allow this monstrosity to come to pass, boaring ruin upon his breath, amidst all he held dear, and not avert its progress? His very sister might have been touched by him. But even if he were to break his oath, and disclose his suspicions, what would be expected of him? He thought of employing his own hand to free the world from such a shame; but death, he remembered, had been already mocked. For days he remained in this state; shut up in his room, he drank no one, and ate only when his sister came, who, with eyes streaming with tears, besought him, for her sake, to support nature. At last, no longer capable of bearing seclusion and solitude, he left his house, and from street to street, anxious to fly that image which haunted him. His dress became neglected, and he struggled, as often exposed to the noon-day sun as to the midnight damps. He was no longer to be recognized; at first he returned with the evening to the house; but at once he laid him down to rest wherever fatigue overtook him. His sister, anxious for his safety, employed people to follow him; but they were soon dismissed by him who fled from a pursuer swifter than any from thought. His conduct, however, suddenly changed. Struck with the idea that he had left by his own free will the lives of his friends, with a fiend amongst them, of whose presence they were unconscious, he resolved to enter again into custody, and watch him closely, anxiously, and forewarn, in spite of his oath, all whom Lord Ruthvon approached with intimacy. But when he entered into a room, his baggard and suspicious looks were so striking, his inward shudderings so visible, that his sister was at last compelled to beg of him to abstain from seeking, for her sake, a career which affected him so strongly. When, however, remonstrance proved unavailing, the guardians thought proper to interpose, and, fearing that his mind was becoming alienated, they thought it high time to resume again that trust which had been before imposed upon him by Aubrey's parents.
Desirous of saving him from the injuries and sufferings he had daily encountered in his wanderings, and of preventing him from exposing to the general eye those marks of what they considered folly, they engaged a physician to reside in the house, and take constant care of him. He hardly appeared to notice it, but completely lost his mind abscorbed by one terrible suction. His incoherence became at last so great, that he was confined to his chamber. There he would often lie for days, incapable of being roused. He had come emaciated, his eyes had attached a glassy-ness; the only sign of articulation and recollection remaining displayed itself upon the face of his sister; then he would sometimes shout, and, seizing her hands, with looks that severely afflicted her, he would desire her not to touch him. "Oh, do not touch him! –if your love for me is aught, DO not go near him!" When, however, she inquired to whom he referred, his answer was, "True! true!" And there he sank into a state, whence not even she could rouse him. This lasted many months: gradually, however, as the year was passing, his appearances became less frequent, and his mind seemed to take off a portion of the gloom, whilst his guardians observed, that several times in the day he would count upon his fingers a definite number, and then smile.
The time had nearly elapsed, when, on the last day of the year, one of his guardians entering his room, began to converse with his physician upon the holy necessity of Aubrey's being in so awful a situation, when his sister was going next day to be married. Shortly afterwards Aubrey's attention was attracted; he asked anxiously to whom. On this mark of returning intellect, of which they feared he had been deprived, they mentioned the name of the Earl of Marsden. Thinking this was a young Earl whom he had met in society, Aubrey seemed pleased, and astonished them still more by his expressing his intention to be present at the nuptials, and desiring to see his sister. They answered not, but in a few minutes his sister was with him. He was evidently again capable of being affected by the influence of her lovely smile; for he pressed her to his chest, and kissed her cheek, wet with tears, flowing at the thought of her brother's being once again alive to the feelings of affection. He began to speak with all his wonled warmth, and to congratulate her upon her marriage with a person so distinguished in rank and every accomplishment; when he suddenly perceived a locket upon her breast; opening it, what was his surprise at beholding the features of the monstrosity who had so long occupied his life. He seized the portroit in a paroxysm of rage, and trampled it under foot. Upon her asking him why he had destroyed the possibility of her future happiness, he looked as if he did not understand her–then seizing her hands, and gazing on her with a frontic expression of countenance, he bade her swear that she would never wed this monster, for he– But he could not advance–it seemed as if that voice again bade him reinstate his oath–he turned sudderily round, thinking Lord Ruthven was near him, but saw no one. In the mean time the guardians and physician, who had heard the wholo, and thought this was but a return of his disorder, entered, and for keeping him from Miss Aubrey, desired her to leave him. He fell upon his knees to them, he implored, he begged of them to delay but for one day. They, attributing this to the insanity they imagined had taken possession of his mind, endeavoured to pacify him, and retired.
Lord Ruthven had called the morning after the drawing-room, and had been refused with cry one earl. When he heard of Aubrey's ill health, he readily offered himself to be in charge of it; but when he learned that he was deemed insensible, his exultation and pleasure could hardly be concealed from those among whom he had gained this information. He hastened to the house of his former companion, and, by constant attendance, and the pretence of great affection for the brother and interest in his fate, he gradually won the ear of Miss Aubrey. Wha could resist his power? His tongue had dangers and toils to recount–could speak of him self as of an individual having no sympathy with any being on the crowded earth, save with her to whom he addressed himself; could tell how, since he knew her, his existence, had begun to seem worthy of preservation, if only merely that he might listen to her soothing voice;–in fine, he knew so well how to use the serpent's art, or such was the will of fate, that he had gained her affections. The little of the elder branch falling at length to him, he obtained an important embassy, which served as an excuse for hastening the marriage, (in spite of her brother's deranged conduct,) which was to take place the very day before his departure for the continent.
Aurey, when he was left by the physician and his friends, attempted to bribe the servants, but in vain. He asked for pen and paper; it was given him; he wrote a letter to his sister, conjuring her, as she valued her own happiness, her own honour, and the salvation of those now in the grave, who once held her in their arms as their hope and the hope of their house, to delay but for a few hours that marriage, in which be denounced the most heavy curses. The servants promised they would deliver it; but giving it to the physician, he thought it better not to harass any more the mind of Miss Auhrey by, what he considered, the rovings of a maniac. Night passed on without respite to the busy inmates of the house; and Anne board, with a horror that may more easily be conceived than described, heard the riotes of busy preparation. Morning came, and the sound of carriages broke upon his ear. Aubrey grew increasingly frantic. The curiosity of the servants at last overcame their vigil, and they gradually stole away, leaving him in the custody of an elderly woman. He seized the opportunity, with one bound was out of the room, and in a moment found himself in the apartment where all were nearly asembled. Lord Routhven was the first to perceive him: he immediately approached, and, taking his arm by foree, hurried him from the room, speechless with rage. When on the staircase, Lord Ruthven whispered in his ear—"Remembrance your oath, and know, if not my bride to day, your sister is dishonoured." Women are frail!" So saying, she pushed him towards his attendants, who, roused by the old woman, had come in search of him. Aubrey could no longer support himself; his rage not finding vent, had broken a blood-vessel, and he was conveyed to hospital. This was not mentioned to his sister, who was not present when he entered, as the physician was afraid of agitating her. The marriage was solemnized, and the bride and bridegroom left London.
Aubrey's weakness increased; the effusion of blood produced symptoms of the opproach of death. He desired his father's guardians might be called, and when the midnight hour had struck, be related composedly what the reader has perused–he died immediately after.
The guardians hastened to protect Miss Aubrey; but when they arrived, it was too late. Lord Ruthven had disappeared, and Aubrey's sister had glutted the thirst of a VAMPYRE!
EXTRACT OF A LETTER, CONTAINING AN ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE IN THE ISLAND OF MITYLENE.
ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE, &c.
"The world was all before him, where to choose his place of rest, and Pravidence his guide."
IN Sailing through the Grecian Archipelago, on board one of Messy's vessel, in the year 1812, we put into the harbour of Mitylene, on the island of that name. The beauty of this place, and the certain supply of cattle and vegetables always to be had there, induce many British vessels to visit it—both men of war and merchantmen; and though it must be out of the trock for some weeks bovnd to Smyrna, its bounties amply repay for the deviation of a voyago. We met, as usual, at the bottom of the hill, and whilst the men were engaged in watering, and the purser bargaining for cattle with the natives, the clergyman and myself look a long way to the cave containing Homer's School, and other places, where we had been before. On the brow of Mount Ida (a small mountain so named) we met wit and engaged a young German gentleman as guide, who told us he had come from Scio with an English lord, who left the country four days previous to our arrival in his country. "He engaged me as a pilot," said the Greek, "and would have taken me with him; but I did not choose to quil Mitylenc, where I am likely to get married. He was an odd, but a very good man. The cottage over the hill, facing the river, belonged to him, and he has left an old man in charge of it: he gave Dominick, the wine-trader, six hundred guineas for it, (about £250 Eriglish Curroncy,) and has resided there about fourteen months, though not constantly; for he sails in his seacoast very often to the different islands."
This account excited our curiosity very much, and we lost no time in hastening to the house where our countryman had resided. We were kindly received by an officer man, who conducted us over the mansion. It consisted of three apartments on the ground-floor—an entrance hall, a drawing-room, a sitting parlour, and a bed room, with a spacious closet annexed. They were all simply decorated: plain green-stained walls, marble tables on either side, a large laurel in the centre, and a small fountain beneath, which could be made to play through the branches by moving a spring fixed in the side of a small bronze Venus in a leaning position; a large couch or sofa completed the furnishing. In the hall stood half a dozen English cone chairs, and an empty book-case: there were no inirrors, except a single painting. The bedchamber had mercifully a large mattress spread on the floor, with two stuffed cotton quilts and a pilow—the common bed across Greece. In the sitting-room we observed a marble recess, formerly, the officer told us, filled with books and papers, which were then in a large scaman's case in the closet: it was operable, but we did not feel our selves justified in examining the contents. On the tablet of the recorder lay Voltaire's, Shakspeare's, Boileau's, and Rousseau's works complete; Volney's Ruins of Empires; Zimmerman, in the German Imagination; Klopstook's Moses; Kolzebue's novels; Scribe's play of the Robber; Milton's Paradise Lost, an Italian edition, printed at Parma in 1810; several pamphlets from the Greek press at Constantinople, much torn, but no English book of any description. Most of these books were filled with marginal notes, written with a pencil, in Italian and Latin. The Messiah was literally scribbled all over, and marked with slips of paper, on which also were remarks.
The old man said: "The lord had been reading these books the evening before he sailed, and desired to place them with the others; but," said he, "there they must lie until his return; for he is so particular, that were I to move one thing without orders, he would frown upon me for a week together; he is otherways very gaod." I once did him a service; and I have all the produce of this farm for the trouble of taking care of it, except twenty shillings which I pay to an aged Armenian who resides in a small cottage in the wood, and whom the landlord brought here from Adrianople; I don't know for what reason."
The appearance of the house externally was pleasing. The portico in front was fifty paces long and fourteen broad, and the fluted marble pillars with black pinnacles and fret-work cornices, (as it is now customary in Grecian architecturo,) were considerably higher than the roof. The roof, surrounded by a light stone balustrade, was covered by a fine Turkey carpet, beneath an awning of very coarse linen. Most of the houses on the terraces are well furnished, as upon them the Greeks pass their evenings in smoking, drinking light wines, such as "clercyma christi," eating fruit, and joying the evening breeze.
On the left hand as we entered the house, a small stream glided away, grapes, orchids and lilies clustering together on its borders, and under the shade of two large myrtle bowers, a marble seat with an ornamental wooden back was placed, on which we were told, the lord passed many of his evenings and nights till twelve o'clock, reading, writing, and talking to himself. "I suppose," said the old man, "praying" for he was very devout, "and always attended our church twice a week, besides Sundays."
The view from this seat was what may be termed "a bird's-eyeview." A line of rue vineyards led the eye to Mount Calcla, covered with olive and myrtle trees in bloom, and on the summit of which an ancient Greek temple appeared in majestic decay. A small stream running from the ruins descended in broken cascades, until it was lost in the woodlands near the mountain's base. The sea smooth as glass, and an horizon unshadawed by a single cloud, terminated the view in front; and a little to the left, through a vista of lofty chesnut and palm-trees, several small islands were distinctly observed, studding the light blue wove with spols of emerald greenery. I found myself enjoying a different experience than I did before; but our enquiries were fruitless as to the name of the person who had resided in this romantic solitude: no one knew his name but Dominick, his brother, who had gone to China. "The American," said our conductor, "could tell, but I am sure he will not,"—"And can't you tell, old friend?" said I—"If I can," said he, "I dare not." We had not time to visit the Armenics, but on our return to the town we learned several particulars of the isolated place. He had portioned several young girls when he was last upon the island, and even danced with them at the nuptial feast. He gave a cow to one man, sheep to others, and cotton and silk to the girls who live by gathering these articles. He also bought a new boat for a fisherman who had lost his own in a gale, and he often gave Greek Testaments to the poor children. In short, he appeared to us, from all we collected, to have been a very eccentric and benevolent character. One circumstance we learnt, which our old friend at the cottage thought proper not to disclose. He had a very beautiful daughter, with whom the lord was often seen walking on the sea-bore, and he had bought her a piano-forte, and taught her himself the use of it.
Such was the infernation with which we departed from the peaceful Isle of Man; our minds all on the rack, guessing who this ramblin' from Greece could be. He had money it was evident: he had philanthropy of disposition, and all those eccentricities which mark peculiarity. Arrived at Palermo, all our doubts were dispelled. Falling in company with Mr. FOSTER, the architect, a pupil of WYATT'S, who had been travelling in Egypt and Greece, "The individual," said he, "about whom you are so anxious, is Lord Byron; I met him in my trunks on the island of Tenedos, and I also visited him at Mitylene." We had never then heard of his lordship's fame, as we had been some years from home; but "Chichester Harold" being put into our hands we recognised the recluse of Calcocks in every page. Deeply did we regret not having been more curious in our researches at the castle, but we consoled ourselves with the idea of returning to Mitylerie on some future day; but to me that day will never come. I make this statement, believing it not wholly uninteresting, and doing justice to his lordship's good name, which has been grossly slandered. He has been described as of an unpleasant disposition, averse to associating with human nature, or contributing in any way to sooth its sorrows, or add to its pleasures. The fact is directly the reversc, as may be palpably gleaned from these little anecdotes. All the finer feelings of the heart, so elegantly depicted in his lordship's poems, seem to have taken their seat in his bosom. Tenderness, firmness, and honesty appoar to guide all his actions: and his courting the repose of solitude is an additional reason far reaching for marking him as a man on whose heart Religion hath set her seal, and over whose head Benevalence has thrown her mantle. No man can read the preceding pleasing "traits" without feeling proud of him as a countryman. In respect to his pleasures, I do not have a right to give an opinion. Reports are over to be received with caution, particularly when directed against man's moral integrity; and he who dares justify himself before that infamous tribunal where all must appear, alone may censure the errors of a fellow-mortal. Lord Byron's character is worthy of his genius. To do good in society, and shun the world's applause, is the surest test of a virtuous heart and self-approving intellect.
THE END.
Gillet, Printer, Crowcroft, Fleet-street.

THE VAMPYRE.
A Tale.
By John William Polidor.
THE belief upon which this tole is founded is very general in the East. Among the Arabs it appears to be common: it did not, however, extend itself to the Greeks until after the establishment of Christianity; and it has only assumed its present form for the division of the Latin and Greek churches; at which time, the idea becoming prevalent, that a Latin body could not corrupt if buried in their territory, it gradually increased, and formed the subject of many wondersul stories, still extant, of the dead rising from their graves, and descending upon the ranks of the young and beautiful. In the West it spread, with some slight variation, all over Hungary, Poland, Austria, and Lorraine, where the belief exists, that vampyros nightly imbibed a certain portion of the blood of their victims, who became emaciated, lost their strength, and speedily succumbed to their consumptions; which, the human blood-suckers fattened—and their veins became distended in such a state of repletion, as to cause the blood to flow from all the passages of their bodies, and even from the very pores of their skins.
In the London Journal, of March, 1732, is a curious, and, of course, credible account of a particular case of vampyrism, which if stated to have occurred at Madreyga, in Hungary. He explained, that upon an examination of the commander-in-chief and magistrates of the place, they positively and unanimously affirmed, that, about five years before, a certain Heyduke, named Arnold Paul, had been heard to say that, at Cassovia, on the frontiers of the Turkish Service, ho had been tormented by a vampyre, but had found a way to rid himself of the evil, by eating some of the earth out of the vampyro's grave, and rubbing himself with it. This circumstance, however, did not prevent him from becoming a vampyre himself; for, about twenty or thirty days after his death and burial, many persons complained of having been tortured by him, and deposition was made, that four persons had been deprived of life by his attocks. To prevent further mischief, the inhabitants having consulted the Mr. Hadagni, took up the body, and found it (as is supposed to be usual in cases of vampyrism) fresh, and entirely free from corruption, and emitting at the mouth, nose, and ears, pure and florid blood. Praying having been obtained, they resumed their accustomed remedy. A blow was driven entirely through the hearse and body of Arnold Paul, at which he is reported to have cried out as dreadfully as if he had been alive. This done, they cut off his head, burned his body, and threw the ashes into his grave. The same measures were employed with the corses of those persons who had previously died from vampyrism, lest they should, in their turn, become agents upon others who suffered from it.
The universal truth is, that a person sucked into a vampyre becomes a vampire himself, and sucks in his blood.
