Aubrey was at once discharged. If before his mind had been absorbed by one subject, how much more completely was it engrossed, now that the certainty of the monster's living again presed upon his thought? His father's alteritions were now unheedable, and it was in consequence that she intreated him to explain to her what had caused his abrupt conduct. He only uttered a few words, and those terrified her. The more he thought, the more he was bewildered. His oath slurred him; was he really to allow this monster to roam, bearing ruin upon his back, amidst all he held dear, and not avert its progress? His very sister might have been touched by him. But even if he were to break his oath, and disclose his suspicion, who would believe him? He thought of employing his own band to free the world from such a wretch; but death, he remembered, had been already mocked. For days he remained in this state; shut up in his room, he saw no one, and ate only when his sister came, who, with eyes streaming with tears, besought him, for her sake, to support nature. At last, no longer capable of bearing stillness and solitude, he left his house, roamed from street to street, anxious to fly that image which haunted him. His dress became ragged, and he wandered, as often exposed to the noon-day sun as to the midnights damps. He was no longer someone he recognized; at first he returned with the deceased to the house; but at last he laid him down to rest when fatigue overtook him. His sister, anxious for his safety, employed people to follow him; but they were soon distanced by him, who fled from a pursuers closer than any could be thought. His conduct, however, suddenly changed. Struck with the idea that he left by mistake the whole of his friends, with a fiend amongst them, of whose presence they were unconscious, he determined to enter again into society, and watch him closely, anxious to forewarn, in spite of his oath, all whom Lord Ruthven approached with intimacy. But when he entered into a room, his haggard and suspicious looks were so striking, and his inward shudderings so visible, that his sister was at last obliged to beg of him to abstain from seeking, for her sake, a society which affected him so deeply. When, however, remonstrance proved unavailing, the guardians thought proper to interpose, and, believing that his mind was coming alienated, they thought it high time to resume in that regiment which had been hefore imposed upon them by Aubrey's parents.
Desirée of saving him from the injuries and suspicions he had daily encountered in his wars, and of preventing him from exposing to the general eye those marks of what they considered folly, they engaged a physician to reside in the house, and take consular care of him. He hardly appeared to notice it, so completely was his mind absorbed by one terrible subject. His incoherence became at last so great, that he was confined to his chamber. There he would often lie for days, incapable of being roused. He had been emaciated, his eyes had attained a glassy luster; the only sign of affection and recollection remaining displayed itself upon the appearance of his sister; then he would sometimes start, and, scizing her hands, with looks which had evidently afflicted her, he would desist her not to touch him. "Oh, do not touch him–if your love for me is aught, DO not go near him!" When, however, she inquired to whom he referred, his only answer was, "True! true!" Once again he sank into a state, whence not even she could rouse him. This lasted many months: gradually, however, as the year was passing, his incidences became less frequent, and his mind began to take off a portion of its guard, when his guard observed, that several times in the day he would count upon his friends a definite number, and then miss.
The time had nearly elapsed, when, on the last day of the year, one of his guardians entering his room, began to confer with his physician upon the melancholy circumstance of Aubrey's being in so precarious a situation, when his sister was going next day to be married. Instantly Aubrey's attention was attracted; he asked anxiously to whom. Glad of this mark of returning intellect, of which they feared he had been deprived, they mentioned the name of the Earl of Marsden. Tinking this was a young Earl whom he had met with in society, Aubrey seemed pleased, and astonished them all by his expressing his intention to be present at the nuptials, and desiring to see his sister. They answered not, but in a few minutes his sister was with him. He was apparently again capable of being affected by the influence of her lovely smile; for he pressed her to his breast, and kissed her cheek, wet with tears, flowing at the thought of her brother's being once more alive to the feelings of affection. He began to speak with all his wonted warmth, and to congratulate her on her marriage with a person so distinguished for rank and exceedingly accomplished merit; when he suddenly perceived a locket upon her breast; opening it, which was his surprise at beholding the face of the monster who had so long occupied his life. He seized the portrait in a paroxysm of rage, and trampled it under foot. Upan her asking him how he could recognize the resemblance of her future husband, he looked as though he did not understand her–then seizing her hands, and gazing on her with a frantic expression of countenance, he bade her swear that she would never wed this monster, far he– But he could not agree–it seemed as if that voice again bade him repeat his oath–he turned suddenly round, thinking Lord Ruthvon was near him, but saw no one. In the meantime the guard and policeman, who had heard the whole, and thought it was but a return of some disorder, entered, and forcing him to look at Miss Aubrey, desired her to leave him. He fell on his knees to them, he pleaded, he begged of them to delay but for one day. They, attributing this to the insanity they imagined had taken possession of his mind, endeavoured to pacify him, and retired.
Lord Ruthven had called the morning after the drawing-room, and had been dismissed with every one else. When he heard of Aubrey's ill health, he understood himself to be the cause of it; but when he learned that he was deemed insane, his exultation and pleasure could hardly be concealed from those among whom he had gained this inforination. He returned to the house of his former companion, and, by cousin attendance, and the pretence of great affection for the brother affected in his fate, he gradually won the ear of Miss Aubrey. Who could restore his power? His tongue had dangers and troubles beyond count; could speak of himself as the son of an individuol having no sympathy with any being on the crowded earl, so with her to whom he addressed himself; could tell how, since he knew her, his existence, had beguiled to seem worthy of preservation, if merely that he might listen to her soothing accents; in fact, he knew so well how to use the serpent's tongue, or such was the will of fate, that he gained her affections. The little of the elder branch falling at length to him, he obtained an important embassy, which served as an excuse for haretening the marriage, (in spite of her brother's degraded state,) which was to take place the very day before his departure for the continent.
Aubrey, when he was left by the prisoner and his guardians, attempted to bribe the servants, but in vain. He asked for pen and paper; it was given him; he wrote a letter to his sister, corijuring her, as she valued her own hoppiness, her own happiness, and the honour of those naw in the grave, who once held her in their arms as their hope and the hope of their house, to delay but for a few hours their marriage, on which he denounced the first heavy curses. The servants promised they would deliver it; but giving it to the physician, he thought it better not to harass any more the mind of Miss Avrey by, what he considered, the raving of a maniac. Night passed on without rest for the busy inmates of the house; and Aubrey read, with a horror that may more easily be described than described, the notes of busy preparation. Morning came, and the sound of carriages broke upon his ear. Aubrey grew most frantic. The curiosity of the servants at last overcame their vigil, they gradually stole away, leaving him in the custody of an elderly woman. He seized the opportunity, with one hand was out of the room, and in a moment found himself in the apartment where all were nearly assembled. Lord Rutbven was the first to perceive him: he immediately approached, and, taking his arm by force, hurled him from the room, seething with rage. When he reached the staircase, Lord Rulbourn whispered in his ear—"Remember your oath, and know, if not my bride to day, your sister has dishonored. Women are frak! So saying, he pushed him tawards his attendants, who, roused by the old woman, had come in search of him. Aubrey could no longer support himself; his rage not finding vent, had broken a blood vessel, and he was conveyed to bed. This was not mentioned to his sister, who was not present when he entered, as the prisoner was afraid of claming her. The marriage was solemnized, and the bride and bridegroom left Lorond.
Aubrey's weakness increased; the effusion of blood produced symptoms of the near approach of death. He desisted his sister's guineas might be called, and when the midnight hour had struck, be related composedly what the reader has perused–he died immediately after.
The guardians hastened to protect Miss Aubrey; but when they arrived, it was too late. Lord Routhven had disappeared, and Aubrey's sister had complained the day of a VAMPYRE!
EXTRA RACT OF A LETTER, CONTAINING AN ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE IN THE ISLAND OF MITYLENE.
ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE, &c.
"The world was all before him, who had to choose his place of rest, and Providence was his guide."
IN Sailing through the Grecian Archipelago, on board one of his Majesty's vespers, in the year 1812, we put into the harbour of Mitylene in the island of the same name. The beauty of this place, and the certain supply of cattles and vegables to be had there, induce many British vessels to visit it—both men of war and merchantmen; and since it lies rather out of the track for ships bound to Scotland, its bourities amply repay for the cost of a voyage. We landed, as usual, at the bollom of the bay, and whilst the men were employed in watering, and the purser bargaining for cattle with the natives, the clergyman and me took a ramble to the cave called Homer's School, and other places, where we had been before. On the brow of Mount Ida (a small mountain so named) We met with and engaged a young Greek as our guide, who told us he had come from Scio with an English lord, who left the island four days previous to our arrival in this felucca. "He engaged me as a pilot," said the Greek, "and would have taken me with him; but I did not choose to go to Mitylene, where I am likely to be married. He was an odd, but a very good man. The cottage over the head, facing the river, belongs to him, and he has left an old man in charge of it: he gave Dominick, the wine-trador, six hundred zecines for it, (about £250 English currency,) and has resided there about fourteen years, though not constantly; for he sails in his felucca very often to the different islands."
This account excited our curiosity very much, and we lost no time in haftening to the house where our cousin had resided. We were kindly received by an old man, who conducted us into the mansion. It consisted of four apartments on the ground-floor—an entrance hall, a drawing-room, a sitting parlour, and a bed room, with a spacious closet annexed. They were all perfectly decorated: pale green-stairied walls, marble tables on either side, a large fireplace in the centre, and a small fountain basin, which could be made to play through the branches by moving a spring fixed on the side of a large bronze Venus in a leaning posture; a large couch or sofa completed the furniture. In the hall stood half a dozen English cane chalks, and an empty boak-case: there were no mirrors, nor a single painling. The bedchamber had merely a large mattross spread on the floor, with two stuffed cotton quilts and a pillow—the common fare throughout Grange. In the sitting-room we observed a marble chest, formerly, the old man told us, filled with hooks and papers, which were then in a steward's chest in the close: it was open, but we did not think ourselves justified in opening the compartments. In the bottom of the recess lay Voltaire's, Speare's, Boileau's, and Roussoff's works complete; Volney's Ruins of Empires; Zimmerman, in the German language; Klopstock's Messiah; Kotzebue's novels; Schiller's play of the Romans; M'Ton's Paradise Los, an Italian edition, printed at Parma in 1810; several small pamphlets from the Greek press at Constantinople, much torn, but no English book of any description. Most of these books were filled with memoirs, written with pencil, in Italian and Latin. The Messiah was densely seribbled all over, and marked with slips of paper, some of which also were remarks.
The old man said: "The lord had been reading these books the evening before he sailed, and forgot to place them with the others; but," said he, "there they must lie until he returns; for he is so paralular, that were I to move on anything with his orders, he would frown upon me for a week together; he is otherways very good." I once did him a service; and I have the produce from this farm for the trouble of taking care of it, including twenty shillings which I pay to an aged Armenian who resides in a small cottage in the wood, and whom the lord brought here from Adrianople; I don't know for what reason."
The appearance of the house externally was pleasing. The portico in front was fifty paces long and fourteen broad, and the fluted marble pillars with black plinths and fret-work cornices, (as it is customary in Greciari architecture,) were considerably higher than the roof. The roof, surrounded by a light stone balustrade, was supported by a fine Turkey corpet, beneath an awning of strong coarse linen. Most of the house-tops are thus furnished, as upon them the Greeks pass their evenings in smoking, drinking light wines, such as "Ichryma christi," and enjoying the evening breeze.
On the left hand as we entered the house, a small stream flowed away, grapes, oranges and limes were clumping together on its borders, and under the shade of two large myrtle bushes, a rambling seat with an ornamenal wooden back was placed, on which we were told, the lord passed many of his evenings and nights till twelve o'clock, reading, writing, and talking to himself. "I suppose," said the old man, "he was praying" for he was very devout, "and always attended our church twice a week, except Sundays."
The view from this seat was what may be termed "a bird's-eye view." A line of rich vineyards led one eye to Mount Carmel, covered with live and myrtle trees in bloom, and on the summit of which an ancient Greek temple appeared in majestie decoy. A small stream issuing from the ruins descended in broken cascades, until it was lost in the woods near the mountain's base. The sea smooth as glass, and an horizon unshadowed by a single cloud, dominates the view in front; and a little on the left, through a vista of lofty ohesnut and palm-trees, several small islands could distinctly observed, studding the light bluewave with spots of emerald green. I suppose he enjoyed a view more than I did this; but our inquiries were fruitless on the name of the person who had resided in this romanlic solitude: none knew his name but Dominick, a banker, who had gone to China. "The Armenian," said our conductor, "could tell, but I hope he will not,"—"And cannot you tell, old friend?" I said, "If I can," said he, "I dare not." We had not time to visit the Armenian, but on our return to the town we found several parliculars of the isolated lord. He had portioned several young girls when he was last upon the island, and exchanged dances with them at the nuptial feast. He gave a cow to one man, horses to others, and cotton and silk to the girls who live by weaving these articles. He also bought a new boot for a fisherman who had lost his arm in a gale, and he often gave Greek Testaments to the poor children. In short, he appeared, from all we collected, to have a very ecclesiastical and bonevolent character. One circumstance we learnt, which our old friend at the cottage thought proper to close. He had a most beautiful daughter, with whom the lord was often seen walking on the sea-shore, and he had bought her a piano-forle, and taught her himself the use of it.
Such was the informatjon with which we departed from the peaceful Isle of Man; ovrimaginations all on the rack, guessing who the rambler in question could be. He had money it was evident: he had philanthropy of disposition, and all those eccentricities which mark a liar were gone. Arrived in Palermo, all our doubts were dispelled. Falling in company with Mr. FOSTER, the archect, a pupil of WYATT'S, who had been traving in Egypt and Greece, "The individual," said he, "of whom you are so curious, if Lord Byron; I met him in my travels on the island of Tenedos, and I have since visited him again." We had never then heard of his lordship's fame, as we had been some years from home; but "Catherine Harolde" being put into our hands we recognized the recluse of Calcla in every way. Neither did we regret not having been more curious in our researches at the cottage, but we consoled ourselves with the idea of returning to Marylene on some future day; but to me that day will never return. I make this statement, believing it not quite uninteresting, and in justiceto his lordship's good name, which has been grossly slandered. He has been described as of an unfeeling disposition, averse to associating with human nature, or contriving in any way to sooth its sorrows, or add to its pleasures. The fact is directly the contrary, as can be plainly gathered from those little anecdotes. All the finer feelings of the heart, so elegantly depicted in his lordship's poems, seem to have their seat in his bosom. Tendemess, sympathy, and charity appear to govern all his actions: and his courting the repose of Solitude is an additional reason for marking him as a being on whose heart Religion hath set her seal, and over whose head Christianity hath thrown her mantle. No man can read the preceding pleasing "traits" without feeling proud of him as a countryman. With respect to his loves or pleasures, I do not consider a right to give an opinion. Reports are supposed to be received with caution, particularly when directed against man's moral integrity; and he who dares justify himself before that awful tribunal where all must appear, alone may censure the errors of his fellow-mortal. Lord Byron's character is worthy of his praise. To keep a good secret, and shun the world's applause, is the surest testimony of a virtuoso heart and self-approving consciences.
THE END.
Gillel, Printer, Crown-court, Fleet-street.

THE VAMPYRE.
A TRAGEDY.
By John William Polidori
THE superstition upon which this tale is faunded is very general in the East. Amnesty for the Arabians. It appears to be common: it did not, however, extend itself to the Greeks until after the establishment of Christianity; and it has only maintained its present form since the division of the Latin and Greek churchef; at which time, the idea becoming prevalent, that a Latin body could not corrupt if buried in their territory, it gradually extinct, and formed the subject of many wonderful legends, still extant, of the deceased rising from their graves, and feeding upon the blood of the young and beautiful. In the West it occurred, with some slight variation, over Hungary, Poland, Austrla, and Larraine, where the lies existed, that vampyres nightly imbibed a certain quantity of the blood of their victims, who became emaciated, lost their strength, and speedily died of consumption; when these human blood-sucker's fattened their veins became distended to such a state of repletion, as to cause the blood to flow from all the passages of their bodies, and even from the very pores of their skin.
In the London Journal, of March, 1732, is a curious, and, of course, credible account of a particular occurrence of vampyrism, which is stated to have occurred at Madreyga, Hungary. It appears, that upon an examination of the commander-in-chief and magistrates of the place, they positively and unanimously affirmed, that, about five years before, a certain Heyduke, named Arnold Paul, had been heard to say that, at Cassovia, on the frontiers of the Turkish Service, he had been tormented by a vampyre, but had found a way to rid himself of the evil, by eating some of the earth out of the vampyr's grave, and rubbing himself with his blood. This precautious conduct, however, did not prevent him from becoming a vampyre himself; for, about twenty or thirty days after his death and burial, many persons complained of having been tormented by him, and a deposition was made, that several persons had been deprived of life by his attacks. To prevent further mischief, the inhabitants having consulted the doctor Hadclgni, took up the body, and found it (which is supposed to be usual incases of vampirism) fresh, and entirely free from corruption, and emaciated at the mouth, nose, and ears, pure and florid blood. Proof having been thus obtained, they resorted to the accustomed recourse. A stake was driven entirely through the heart and body of Arnold Pavl, at which he is reported to have cried out as dreadfully as if he had been struck. This done, they cut off his head, burned his body, and threw the ashes into his grave. The same measures were adopted with the exception of those persons who had previously withdrawn from vampyrism, lest they should, in their turn, become agents upon others who had survived the disease.
The universal belief is, that a prisoner sucked up a vampyre, becomes a vampire himself, and sucks in his turn.
Chief clerk.
This remarkable occurrence is particularly related, because it soems better adapted to illustrate the subject of the penal servations than any other instance which could be adduced. In many parts of Greece it is considered a sort of punishment after death, for some heinous crime committed whilst in existence, that the deceased is not only doomed to vampyrise, but compelled to confine his infernal visitations solely to those beings he loved most while upon earth—those to whom he was bound by ties of kindred and affection.A supposition aluded to in the "Gospel."
But first on earth, as Vampyre sent, Thy corse must be rent; Then ghastly haunt the notive place, and suck the blood of all thy race; There from thy daughter, sister, wife, at midnight drain the stream of life; Yet from the blood which perforce must feed thy livid living corse, Thy victims, when they yet open their mouths, shall know the mercy for their sire; As cursing thee, thou cursing them, Thy flaw shall be writhed on the stem. But one that for thy crime must fall, The youngest, best beloud of all, Shall bless thee with a father's name— That word will wrap your heart in flame! Yet thou must end thy task and mark Her eye's last tinge—her eyes's last spark, and the last glassy glance must view her freckles of light blue; Then with unhallowed hand must tear the tresses of her yellow hair, of which, in life, was a lock when her Affection's fondest pledge was worn; But now is borne away by the Memorial of the loss of your life! Yet with your own best blood still flow; Thy gnashing teeth, and haggard lip; Then stalking to thy sullen grave, Go, and with Gouls and Angles rave, Till these in horror shrink away from spectre more accursed than they.
Mr. Southey has also produced in his wild but beautiful prose of "Thalaba," the vampyre cousin of the Arabian maid Oneiza, who is reputed as having returned from the grave for the purpose of tormenting the man she best loved whilst in existence. But this cannot be supposed to have resulted from the sinfulness of her life, being poured throughout the whole of the tale with a complete type of purity and innocence. The veracious Tournefort gives a long account from his travels of several astonishing cases of vampyrism, which he pretends to know.
He was to have been an eyewitness; and Calmet, in his great work upon the subject, besides a variety of anecdotes, and traditionary narratives illustrative of its effects, has put forward some learned arguments, tending to prove it to be a classical, as well as barbarian error.
Many more interesting notices on this singularly horrible superstition might be added; but the present may suffice for the limits of a note, necessarily devoted to ecclesiastical matters, and which may best be concluded by merely remarking, that although the term Vampyre is the one in most general acceptation, there are several terms synonymous with it, made use of in various parts of the world: as Vroucoocha, Vardoulacha, Goul, Broucoloka, &c.
THE VAMPYRE.
It happened that in the midst of the dissipations attendant upon a London winter, there appeared at the pleasure parties of the leaders of the ton a nobleman, more remarkable for his singularities, than his rank. He gazed up at the mirth about him, as if he could not participate therein. Apparently, the light laughter of the fair only attracted his attention, that he might by a look quell it, and throw fear into those breasts where thoughtlessness reigned. Those who felt his sensation of awe, could not explain why it came on: some attributed it to the dead grey eye, which, fixing upon the object's face, did not desire to penetrate, and at one point seemed to pierce through to the inward workings of the heart; but fell upon the cheek with a leaden ray that weighed upon the skin it could not pass. His reputation caused him to be invited to every house; all wished to see him, and those who had been accustomed to violent excitement, and now felt the welght of ennui, were pleased at having something in their presence capable of engaging their attention. In spite of the deadly hue of his face, which never seemed to take a warmer tint, either from the blush of modesty, or from the strong motion of passion, though its form and appearance were beautiful, many of the female hunters after notoriety attempted to win his attentions, and gain, at first, some measure of what they might call affection: Lady Morcer, who had made a mockery of every monster she had seen in drawing-rooms since her marriage, threw herself in his way, and did all but put on the dress of a merchant, lo attracl notice:–though in vain:–when she stood near him, though his eyes were apparently fixed upon her's, still gazed as if they were regarded;–even her unappalled impudence was baffled, and she left the field. But when the common adultross could not influence him even the guidance of his eyes, it was not that the female species was indifferent to him: yet such was the apparent caution with which he spoke to the virtuous wife and intelligent daughter, that few know he ever addressed himself to females. He had, however, the repulsion of a winning tongue; and whether it was that it evor overcame the dread of his singular character, or that they were moved by his apparent hatred of vice, he was as often among those females who form the boost of their society from their domestic virtues, as among those who sully it by their vices.
About the same time, there came to London a young gentleman of the name of Aubrey: he was an orphan left with an only sister in the possession of considerable wealth, by parents who died while he was yet in childhood. Left also to himself by guardians, who thought it their duty merely to take care of his fortitude, while they entrusted the more important charge of his management to the care of mercenarian subalterns, he cultivated more his imagination than his judgment. He had, hence, that high romantic feeling of banour and candour, which daily ruins so many milliners' apprentices. He wished all to sympathetically.
He thought that the misery of a cottage merely consisted in the vestiges, which were as warm, but which were better adapted to the painter's eye by their irreducible follicles and other coloured patches. He regarded them with virtue, and thought that ice was thrown in by Providence inerely for the picnuresque effect of the scene, as we see in romances. He thought, in fine, that the dreams of poets were the necessities of life. He was handsome, smart, and rich: for various reasons, upon his entering into the gay circles, many mothers surrounded him, striving which should describe with least truth their languishing or romping favourites: the daughters at the earliest time, by their brightering countenance when he approclched, and by their sparkling eyes, when he opened his lips, soon led him into false notions of his talents and his meril. Attached as he was to the romance of his solitary hours, he was surprised at finding, except in the tallow and wax candles that flickered, not in the presence of a ghost, but from want of snuffing, there was no foundation in real life for any of that congeries of pictures and descriptions contained in those voluminous books, from which he had formed his study. Finding, however, some compensation in his gratified vanity, he was about to relinquish his dreams, when the extraordinary being was above described, crossed him in his career.
He watched him; and the very impossibility of forming an ideo of the character of a man entirely absorbed in himself, who gave few other signs of his observation of external objects, than the lax assent to their absence, implied by the avoidance of their contact: allowing his imagination to picture every thing that flattered its propensity to extravagant ideas, he soon formed this object into the hero of a romance, and determined to observe the offspring of his fancy, rather than the person before him. He became acquainted with him, paid him attentions, and so advanced upon his notice, that his presence was always recognised. He gradually learned that Lord Ruthven's affairs were embarrassed, and soon learned, from the notes of preparation in Baker's Street, that he was about to travel. Desirous of gaining some information respecting this peculiar character, who, till now, had only expressed his eurjosity, he hinted to his guards that it was time for him to perform the tour, which for many generations has been thought necessary to enable the youth to take some rapid steps in the career of vice towards putting themselves upon an equality with the aged, and not allowing them to appear as fallen from the skies, whenever scandalous intrigues are presented as the subjects of pleasantry or of praise, according to the degree of skill shewn in carrying them on. They communicated, and Aubrey immediately mentioning his intentions to Lord Richmond, was surprised to receive from him a proposal to join him. Flattered by such a man of character from whom, apparently, had nothing in common with other men, he gladly associated it, and in a few days they had passed the circling waters.
Hitherto, Aubroy had had no opportunity of slagging Lord Ruthven's character, and now he found, though many more of his actions were expased to his view, the result yielded different conclusions as to the parent motives to his conduct. His company was profuse in liberallty; the idle, the vagabond, and the beggar, received from his hand more than enough to satisfy their daily needs. But Aubrey could not avoid remarking, that it was riot upon the virluous, reduced to indigence by the misfortunes of life, and even upon virtue, to which he bestowed his alms; these were sent from the door with hardly suppressed resentment; but when the profligate came to ask something, not to satisfy his wants, but to allow him to wallow in his lust, or to sink him still deeper in his iniquity, he was scorned away with rich charms. This was, however, attributed by him to the greater importunity of the vicarious, which generally prevails over the retiring bashfulness of the virtuous individual. There was one circumstance about the charity of his Lordship, which was even more impressed upon his mind: all those persons upon whom it was bestowed, inevitably found that there was a curse upon them, for they were either led to the faff, or sunk to the lowest and the first abject misery. At Brussels and other towns through which they passed, Aubrey was surprised to the apparent eagerness with which his companion sought for the cudgels of all fashable vice; there he engaged into a game in the spirit of the far table: he betted, and always gambled with success, except where the known sharper was his adversary, and then he lost ever more than he gained; but he was always with the same unchanging face, which he gerrily wagged the fociety around: it was not, however, so when he encountered the rash youth of a young man, or the luckless falher of a nmerous family; the very wish of fortune's law—this abstractedness of mind was laid aside, and his eyes sparkled with more fire than that of the cat whilst lying with his dead mouse. In every town, he left the former affluent youth, torn as the circle be adorned, cursing, in the solitudes of a dungeon, the fate that had drawn him within thereach of his fiend; whilst many a father sat frantic, amidst the speoking looks of mute hungry children, without a single farthing of their late masters we were with to buy even sufficient to satisfy their present craving. Yet he took no money from the gambling table; but immediately lost, the ruiner of many, the last gilder he had just snatched from the convulsive grasp of the innocent: this might but be the result of a certain degree of knowledge, which was not, however, capable of combating the cunning of the more experienced. Aubrey often wished to represent this to his friend, and beg him to resign that charity and pleasure which proved the ruin of all, and did not tend to his own profit; but he delayed it–for each day he postponed his friend would give him an opportunity of speaking frankly and openly to him; however, this never occurred. Lord Rutledge in his carriage, and amidst the many wild and rich scenes of nature, was always the same: his eye spoke less than his lip; and though Aubrey was near the object of his curiosity, he obtained no greater gratification from it than the childish excitement of vairily wishing to solve that mystery, which to his exalted imagination seemed to assume the appearance of something supernatural.
They soon arrived at Rome, and Aubrey far a time lost sight of his companion; he left him in daily attendance upon the morriing circle of an Italian countess, whilst he went in search of the memorials of an important event in the city. Whilst he was thus engaged, letters arrived from England, which he opened with eager impatience; the first was from his sister, breathing nothing but affection; the other's were from his guardians, the latter astonished him; if it had before entered into his imagination that there was an evil power residont in his comportment, these seemed to give him sufficient reason for the belief. His guardians insisted upon his immediately leaving his friend, and urged, that his character was dreadfully vicious, for that the possession of irresistible powers of seduction, considered his licentious habits dangerous to society. It had been proved, that his contempt for the adultress had not originated from his hatred of her characler; but that he had required, to enhance his gratification, thathis victim, the partner of his guilt, should be hurled from the pinnacle of vullied virtue, down to the lowest abyss of infamy and degradation: in fine, that all those females whom he had sought, apparently on account of their virtue, had, since his departure, thrown even the mask aside, and had endeavoured to expose the whole deformity of their vice to the public gaze.
AUBREY DEFEATED.
Crushed upon leaving one, whose character had not yet shown a single bright spot on which to rest the eye. He resolved to invent some plausible pretext for abandoning him altogether, promising, in the mean while, to watch him more closely, and to let no slight circumstantial pass by unnoticed. He entered into the circle, and soon perceived that his Lordship was endeavouring to work upon the inexperience of the daughter of the lady whose house he chiefly visited. In London, it is seldom that an unmarried female is met with in society; he was therefore obliged to carry on his plans in secret; but Aubrey's eye followed him in all windings, and soon discovered that an assignation had been appointed, which would most likely end in the ruin of an innocent, thoughtless girl. Losing no time, he entered the apartment of Lord Ruthven, and abruptly asked him his intentions with respect to the lady, informing him the same thing that he was sure of being about to meet her that very night. Lord Ruthven answered, that his intentions were merely as he supposed all would have upon such an occasion; and upon being pressed whether he intended to murder her, he again laughed. Aubrey retorted; and, immediately writing a note, to say, that from that moment he must decline accompanying his Lordship in the remand of their proposed marriage, he ordered his serjeant to seek other employment, and, calling upon the mother of the lady, informed her of all he knew, not only with regard to her daughter, but also concerning the character of his lordship. The assignation was deferred. Lord Ruthven next day merely sent his servant to notify his complete assent to a separation; he did not hint any fuspicion of his parties having foiled Aubrey's interposition.
Having left Rome, Aubrey directed his steps towards Greece, and crossing the Peninsula, soon found himself at Athens. He then fixed his residence in the house of a Greek; and soon occupied himself in tracing the faded records of ancient glory up into monuments that apparently, ashamed of chronicling the deeds of freemen only before slaves, had hidden themselves beneath the sheltring soil or many cured lichen. Under the same roof as herself, occupied a being, so beautiful and delicate, that she might have formed the model for a painter wishing to pour out on canvases the promised hope of the salvation in Mahomct's paradise, save that her eyes spoke too much inind for any one to think she could belong to those who had no souls. As she danced upon the plain, or tripped along the mountain's side, one would have thought the gaze a poor type of her beauties; for who would have exchanged her eye, apparently the eye of animal nature, for that sleepy luxurious look of the eye suited but to the tasto of an epicure. The light step of the girl often accompanied Aubrey in his search after antiquities, and often would the uncorruptous girl, engaged in the pursuit of a Kashmere butterfly, show the remarkable beauty of her form, floating as it were upon the wind, to the eager gaze of Aubrey, who forgot the letters he had just decamped upon an almost effused tablet, in the contemplation of her sylph-like figure. Often would her tresses falling, as she flitted around, exhibit in the sun such delicately brilliant and swiftly fading colours, it might well excuse the forgetfulness of the antiquary, who let escape from his mind the very object he had before thought of vital importance to the proper interpretation of a passage in Pausanias. But why attempt to describe characters which all fancy, but none can appreciate?–It was innocence, youth, and beauty, uninfluenced by crowded drawing-rooms and stifling balls. Whilst he drew the remains of which he wished to preserve a memorial for his future hours, she would stand by, and watch the magic effects of his pencil, in tracing the scenes of her native place; she would then describe to him the curious dance up on the open plain, would paint, to him in all the glowing colours of youthful memory, the marriage pomp she remembered viewing in her infancy; and then, turning to subjects that had evidently made a greater impression upon her mind, would tell him all the supernatura tales of her nurse. Her carnestness and apparent belief in what she narrated, excited the imagination even of Aubry; and often as she told him the tale of the living phantom, who had passed years amidst his friends, and dearest ties, forced him, last year, by striking upon the life of a young female to prolong his imprisonment for the ensuing months, his blood would run cold, whilst he attempted to laugh her out of such idle and horrible fantasics; but she cited to him the names of old men, who, when last detected one living among themselves, after several of their near relatives and children had been found marked with the slamp of the fiend's appetitc; and when she found him so incredulous, she begged of him to believ her, for he had been, remarked, that those who had dared to question their accusation, always had some proof given, which obliged them, with grief and heartbreaking, to confess it was true. She described to him the tremendous opposition of these monsters, and her horror was increased, by hearing a pretty accurate description of Lord Ruthven; he, however, still persisted in persuading her that there could be no truth in her fears, though at the same time he wondered at the many coincidences which had all lended to excite a belief in the supernatural power of Lord Russell.
Aubrey began to attach himself more and more to Ann; her loyality, so contrasted with all the affected virtues of the women whom he had sought for his vision of romance, won his heart; and while he ridiculed the idea of a young man of English habits, marrying an educated Grek girl, still he found himself more attached to the almost fairy form before him. He would learn something at once from her, and, forming a plan for serious antiquarian research, he would depart, determined not to return until his object was attained; but he always found it impossible to fix his attention upon the ruins around him, while in his mind he retained an acquaintance who seemed alone the rightful possessor of his thoughts. He was unashamed of his love, and was ever the same frank informer. Being he had first known. She always seemed to part from him with reluctance; but it was because she had no longer any one with whom she could visit her favourites, whilst her guardian was occupied in sketching or uncovering some fragment which had yet escaped the destructive band of time. She had appealed to her parents on the subject of Vampyres, and they both, but several present, affirmed their existence, pale with horror at the very name. Soon after, Aubrey proceeded to perform upon one of his excursions, which was to detain him for a few hours; when they heard the name of the policeman, they all at once begged of him not to return at night, as he must necessarily pass through a wood, where no Greek would ever remain, and the day had closed, without any consideration. They described the resort of the vampyres in their nocturnal orgies, and denounced the most unholy evils as proceeding upon those who dared to cross their path. Aubrey made light of their representations, and tried to laugh them out of the idea; but when he saw them shudder at his daring to mock a superior, inserrial power, the very name of which appeared to make their blood freeze, he was saddened.
Next morning Aubrey set off upon his excursion unattended; he was surprised to observe the melancholy face of his companions, and was concerned to discover that words, mocking the belies of their human fiends, had inspired them with such terror. When he was about to depart, she came to the side of his horse, and earnestly begged of him to return, since night allowed the power of these beings to be put in action; he promised. He was, however, so occupied in his research, that he did not perceive that day-light would soon end, and that in the horizon there was one of those specks which, in the warmer months, so rapidly gather into a great and murderous mass, and pour their rage upon the devoted country. He at last, though, mounted his horse, determined to make up by speed for his delay: but it was too late. Twilight, in the southern climates, is almost unknown; immediately the sun sets, night begins: and before he had advanced far, the power of the storm was almost overwhelming–its echoing thundors had scarcely an interval of respite–its thick heavy cloud forced its way through the conopying foliage, whilst the great forked lightning seemed to fall and strike at his very feet. Suddenly his horse took fright, and he was carried with dreadful rapidity through the entangled forest. The animal at last, through fatigue, stopped, and he found, under the glare of lightning, that he was in the neighbour's yard of a hovel that bardly listed itself up from the remains of dead trees and brushwood which surrounded it. Dismounting, he approached, hoping to find someone to guide him to the town, or at least trusting to obtain shelter from the pelting of the starm. As he approached, the thunders, for a moment silent, allowed him to hear the dreadful shriek of a woman mingling with the suppressed, almost mockery of a laugh, continued in one almost broken sound; he was startled; but, roused by the thunder which had rolled over his head, he, with a sudden effort, knocked on the door of the hut. He found himself in utter darkness: the sound, however, guided him. He was apperently unperceived; and, though he called, still the sounds continued, and no notice was taken of him. He found himself in contact with someone, whom he immediately seized; when a voice cried, "Again baffled!" He heard a loud laugh succeeded; and he felt himself grappled by one whose strength seemed superhuman: determined to save his life as dearly as he could, he struggled; but it was in vain: he was lifted from his feet and hurled with enormous force against the grate: the enemy threw himself upon him, and kneeling upon his breast, he placed his hands up to his throat—when the glare of many torches penetrating through the hole which gave light in the day, disturbed him; he immediately rose, and, loaving his prey, rushed through the door, and in a moment the crashing of the brims, as ho broke through the wood, was heard. The storm was now raging, and Avrey, incapable of moving, was soon heard by those without. They entered; the light of their torches fell upon the mud walls, and the thatch loaded on every individual straw with heavy flakes of soot. At the desire of Aubrey they searched far her who had attracted him by her cries; he was again left in darkness; but what was his horror, when the light of the torches suddenly burst upon him, to perceive the airy form of his fair conductress brought him to a life-changing position. He shut his eyes, hoping that it was but a vision arising from his disturbed imagination; but he again saw the same form, when he unclosed them, stretched by his side. There was no colour upon her cheek, not even upon her lip; yet there was a stench about her place that seemed almost as attaining as the life that once dwelt there:–upon her neck and breast was blood, and upon her throat were the marks of someone having opened the vein:–to this the woman pointed, crying, simultaneously struck with horror, "A Vampyre!" "A Vampyre!" A litter was quickly formed, and Aubrey was laid by the side of her who had lately been to him the object of so many bright and fairy visions, now falling with the flower of life that had died within her. He knew not what his thoughts wore–his mind was benumbed and seemed to shun reflection, and take refuge in vacancy–he held almost unconscienciaably in his hand a naked dagger of a peculiar construction, which had been found in the hut. They were soon met by different parties who had engaged in the search of her whom a mother had misidentified. Their frequent cries, as they approached the city, forewarned the public of some dreadful catastrophe. –To describe their grief was impossible; but when they ascertained the cause of their child's death, they looked at Avrey, and went to the corse. They were inconsolable; both died broken-hearted.
Aubrey being put to bed was seized with a most violent fever, and was often delirious; in these intervals he would call upon Lord Ruthven and upon Ianthe; by some unaccountable occurrence he seemed to beg of his former companion to spare the being he loved. At other times he would imprecate maledictions upon her head, and curse him as her destroyer. Lord Ruthven, chanced at this time to arrive at Athens, and, from whatever motive, upon hearing of the state of Aubrey, immediately placed himself in the same house, and became his constant attendant. When the latter recovered from his delirium, he was horrified and startled at the sight of him, whose image he had now confused with that of a Vampyre; but Lord Rutbven, by his kind words, implying almost reparation for the fault that had caused their separation, and still more by the attentiveness, anxiety, and care which he showed, soon reconciled him to his presence. His lordship seemed suddenly changed; he no longer appeased that apathetic being who had so astonished Aubrey; but as soon as his convalescence began to be rapid, he again produced into the same state of mind, and Aubrey received no different treatment from the former man, except that at times he was surprised to meet his gaze fixed intently upon him, with a smile of ralicious exultation playing upon his lips: he knew not why, but the sensation startled him. During the first stage of the invalid's recovery, Lord Ruthven was apparently engaged in watching the tideless waves raised by the cooling breezes, or in following the progress of the moving orbs, or, like our world, the moveless sun;–indeed, he appeared to wish to clear the eyes of all.
Aubrey's mind, by his own account, was much weaker, and that elasticity of spirit which had once so distinguished him now seemed to have deserted him for ever. He was now as much a lover of solitude and silence as Lord Ruthven; but as much as he wished for solace, his mind could not find it in the neighbourhood of Athens; if he sought it amidst the ruins he had formerly frequented, Anthe's form stood by his side; if hc sought it in, the woods, her foot would appear warring across the underwood, in quest of the modest violet; and then suddenly turning raund, would show, to his wild imagination, her pale face and wounded hands, with a meek smile upon her lips. He determined to fly scenes, every feature of which created such bitter associations in his mind. He proposed to Lord Ruthven, to whom he held himself bound by the loan he had taken of him during his illness, that they should visit those parts of Glasgow no one had yet seen. They travelled in every direction, and sought every spot to which a recollection could be attached: but though they thus hastened from place to place, yet they seemed not to know what they gazed upon. They heard much of robbers, but they gradually began to light these reports, which they imagined were only the inattentions of individuals, whose interest it was to impress the generosity of those whom they defended from pretended dangers. In consequence of thus neglecting the advice of the inhabitants, on one occasion they travelled with only a few men, more to serve as guides than as a guard. Upon entering, however, a narrow defile, at the bottom of which was the bed of a torrent, with large masses of rock brought down from the neighbouring precipices, they had reason to repent their negligence; so scarcely were the whole of the party engaged in the narrow pass, when they were startled by the whistling of bullets close to their heads, and by the echoed report of several guns. In an instant their guards had reached them, and, placing themselves bohind rocks, had begun to fire in the direction whence the report came. Lord Ruthven and Aubrey, imitating their example, retired for a moment behind the sheltering turn of the defile, but ashamed of being distracted by a foe, who with insistent shouts bade them advance, and being exposed to unresisting suspicion that any of the robbers might climb up and take them in the rear, they determined at once to rush forward in search of their enemy. Hardly had they lost the shelter of the rock, when Lord Ruthven received a shot in the shoulder, which brought him to the ground. Aubrey hastened to his assistance; and, no longer heeding the contest or his own peril, was soon surprised by seeing the robbers' faces around him–his guards having, upon Lord Russell's being wounded, immediately thrown up their arms and surrendered.
By promises of great reward, Aubrey induced them to convey his wounded friend to a neighbouring cabin; and having agreed upon such terms, he was no more disturbed by their presence–they being contracted merely to guard the entrant till their comrade should return with the promised sum, for which he had an order. Lord Rutledge's strength rapidly decreased; in two days mortification ensued, and death seemed certain with hasty steps. His conduct and appearance had not changed; he seemed as unconscious of pain as he had been of the objects about him: but towards the close of the last evening, his mind became apparently uneasy, and his eye often fixed upon Aubrey, who was inclined to offer him assistance with more than usual earnestness—"Assist me!" You may savo me–you may do more than that–I mean not my life, I heed the death of my existence as much as the passing day; but you may savor my honour, your friend's honour. "How? Tell me how? "I would do anything," replied Aubrey. "I need but little–my life ebbs and flows–I can't explain the whole–but if you would conceal all you know of me, my life were free from stain in the world's mouth–and if my death were unknown for any time in England–I—I–but life. "It shall not be known." "Swear!" cried the dying man, raising himself with exultant vigour, "Swear by all your soul reveres, by every your nature fears, swear that, for a year and a day you will not impart your knowledge of my crimes or death to any living being in any way, what may happen, or whatever you may soe. His eyes seemed bursting from their sockets: "I swear!" said Avrey; he sunk laughing upon his pillow, and breathed no more.
Aubrey retired to rest, but did not sleep; the many circumstances attending his acquaintance with this man rose upon his mind, and he knew not why; when he remembered his oath a cold shivering came over him, as if from the pre sentiment of something terrible horrible awaiting him. Rising early in the morning, he was about to enter the hovel in which he had left the corpse, when a robber met him, and informed him that it was no longer there, having been conveyed by him and his comrades, upon his retiring, to the pirinacle of a neighbouring mount, according to a promise he had given him in loyalty, that it should be exposed to the first cold ray of the moon that rose after his death. Avrey astonished, and taking several of the men, determined to go and bury it upon the spot where it lay. But, when he had mounted to the summit he found no trace of the corpse or the clothes, though the rabbers swore they pointed to the ideritical rock on which they had laid the body. For a time his mind was bewildered in conjectures, but he at last returned, convinced that they had buried the corpse for the sake of the clothes.
Weary of a country in which he had been acquainted with such terrible misfortunes, and in which all appareritly conspired to heighten the superstitious rarities that had seized upon his mind, he resolved to leave it, and soon arrived at Smyrna. While waiting for a vessel to convey him either to Otranto, or to Naples, he occupied himself arranging those effets he had with him belonging to Lord Ruthven. Amongst other things there was a case containing several weapons of violence, more or less intended to ensure the death of the victor. There were several daggers and ataghans. Whilst watching them over, and examining their curiaus forms, what was his surprise at finding a sheath apparently ornamented in the same style as the dagger discovered in the kitchen hut—he shuddered—hastening to gain further proof, he found the weapon, and his horror may be imagined when he discovered that it was filted, and peculiarly shaped, the sheath he held in his hand. His eyes seemed to need no further certification–they seemed gazing to be bound to the dagger; yet still he refused to disbelieve; but the particular form, the same colours upon the haft and sheath, were alike in splendour on both, and left no room for far doubt; there were also drops of blood on each.
He left Smyrna, and on his way home, at Rome, his first inquiries were concerning the lady he had attempted to snatch from Lord Ruthven's seductive arts. Her parents were in distress, their fortune ruined, and she had not been heard of since the departure of his lordship. Aubrey's mind was almost broken under so many repeated horrors; he was afraid that this lady had fallen a victim to the destroyer of India. He was morose and silent; and his only occupation consisted in bidding the speed of the proceedings, as if he were going to save the life of some one he hold dear. He arrived at Calais; a breeze, which seemed obedient to his will, soon wafted him to the English shores; and there he hasteried to the mansion of his fathers, and there, for a moment, appeared to lose, in the arms and coresses of his sister, all memory of the past. If she before, by her infrequent engagements, had gained much affection, now that the woman began to appear, she was still more attaining as a companion.
Miss Aubrey had not that winning grace which garners the gaze and opplause of the drawing-room assemblies. There was none of that light brilliancy which only exists in the heated atmosphere of a cremated apartment. Her left eye was red lit up by the levity of the mind beneath. There was a melancholic charm about it which did not seem to arise from misfortune, but from some feeling within, that appeared to indicate a foul consciences of a brighter realm. Her step was not that light footing, which strays where a butterfly or a colour may attract—it was sedate and pensive. When alone, her face was never brightened by the smile of joy; but when her brother was near, he gave to her his affection, and would not in her presence forget those griefs. She know destroyed his rest, who would have exchanged her smile for that of his voluptuary? It seemed as if those eyes on that face were then playing in the light of their own native sphere. She was yet only eighteen, and had not been married.
She addressed to the world, it having been thought by her friends more fit that her presentation should be delayed until her brother's return from the Continent, when he might be her principal. It was, therefore, resolved that the next drawing-room, which was fast approaching, should be the epoch of her entry into the "busy scene." Aubrey would have remained in the mansion of his fathers, and fed upon the melancholy which overpowered him. He could not care intornoost about the frivolities of fashionable strangers, when his mind had been so torn by the events he had witnessed; but he determined to sacrifice his own comfort to the protection of his wife. They soon arrived in town, and pro-rated.
pared for the next day, which had been announced as a drawing-room.
The crowd was excessive–a drawing-room had riot been held for a long time, and all who were anxiously to bask in the smile of royalty, hastened to see it. Aubrey was there with his sister. While he was standing in a corner by himself, heedless of all around him, engaged in the remembrance that the first time he had seen Lord Ruthven was in that very place—he felt himself suddenly seized by the arm, and a voice he recognized too well, sounded in his ear—"Remember your oath." He had hardly courage to turn, fearful of seeing a spectre that would blast him, when he perceived, at a little distance, the same flure which had attracted his notice on this spot upon his first introduction into society. He gazed till his limbs almost refusing to bear his weight, he was obliged to take the arm of a friend, and forcing a passage through the crowd, he threw himself into his carriage, and was driven home. He paced the room with hurried steps, and fixed his hands upon his head, as though he were afraid his thoughts were bursting from his brain. Lord Ruthven again before him–circumstances started up in dreadful array–the dagger–his oath–He roused himself, he could not believe it possible–the dead rise again!–He thought his imagination had made up the image his mind was resting upon. It was impossible that it could be reversed; he determined, therefore, to go again into society; for when he attempted to ask concern of Lord Ruthven, the name hung upon his lips, and he could not succeed in eliciting insolation. He went a few nights after with his sister to the assembly of a near relative. Leaving her under the protection of a matron, he retired into a recess, and there brought himself up to his knees devouring tumblers. Perceiving, at last, that many were leaving, he rushed himself, and entering another room, found his sister surrounded by several persons, apparently in earnest conversation; he attempted to pass and get near her, when one, whom he requested to move, turned round, and revealed to him the features he first abhorred. He sprang forward, seized his sister's arm, and, with hurried step, forced her towards the street: at the door he found himself impeded by the crowd of servants who were waiting for their lords; and while he was engaged in passing them, he again heard a voice whisper close to him—"Remember your oath!"–He did not dare to turn, but, hurrying his sister, soon reached home.
Aucy became almost distracted. If before his mind had been absorbed by one subject, how much more completely was it overwhelmed, now that the certainty of the monster's living again pressod upon his thoughts. His sister's attentions were now unheeded, and it was in vain that she intreated him to explain to her what had caused his abrupt conduct. He only uttered a few words, and those terrified her. The more he thought, the more he was bewildered. His oath startled him; was he then to allow this monster to roam, bearing ruin upon his breath, amidst things he held dear, and not avert its progress? His very sister might have been touched by him. But even if he were to break his oath, and disclose his suspicions, who would believe him? He thought of employing his own hands to free the world from such a shame; but he must, be remmbered, had been already mocked. For days he remained in this state; shut in his room, he saw no one, and ate only when his sister came, who, with eyes streaming with tears, besought him, for her sake, to support nature. At last, no longer capable of bearing spirits and folitude, he left the house, roamed from street to street, anxious to fly that iron which haunted him. His dress was collected, and he wandered, as often exposed to the noon-day sun as to the midnigh damps. He was no longer to be recognized; at first he returned with the deceased to the house; but at last he laid him down to rest wherever danger overtook him. His sister, anxious for his safety, employed people to follow him; but they were constantly distanced by him, who kept from a pursuer more than any one from thought. His conduct, however, suddenly changed. Struck with the idea that he left by his absence the happiness of his friends, with a fiend amongst them, of whose protection they were unconscious, he determined to enter again into society, and watch him closely, anxiously to forewarn, in spite of his oath, all when Lord Ruthven approached him in earnest. But when he entered into a room, his haggard and suspicious look was so striking, his inward shudderings so visible, that his sister was first obliged to beg of him to abate from seeking, for her sake, a society which affected him so strongly. When, however, remarriage appeared providential, the clergymen thought proper to interpose, and, fearing that his mind was becoming alieriated, they thought it high time to resolutely enforce that rule which had been before imposed upon him by Aubrey's parents.
Defirous of saving him from the injuries and sufferings he had so recently encountered in his wanderings, and preventing him from exposing to the general eye those marks of what they considered folly, they engaged a physician to reside in the house, and take immediate care of him. He hardly appeared to hear it, so completely was his mind absorbed by one terrible subject. His indiscretion became at last so great, that he was confirmed to his chastisement. Then he would of lie for days, incapable of being roused. He had became emaciated, his eyes had attained a glassy lustre; the only sign of affection and recolection remaining displayed itself upon the entry of his sister; then he would sometimes start, and, seizing her hands, with looks which severely afflicted her, he would desire her not to drop him. "Oh, do not touch him! Is your love for me is aught? Do not go near him!" When, however, he inquired to who in he referred, his only answer was, "True! true!" Again he sank into a state, when not even she could rouse him. This last occurrence occurred several months ago, but, as the year was passing, such incidences came more frequent, and hence threw off a portion of its gloom, whilst his guard observed, that several times in the day he would count upon his fingers a definite number, and then forget them.
The time had already elapsed, when, upon the last day of the ear, some of his friends entering his room, began to confer with his physician upon the strange circumstance of Aubrey's being in so awful a situation, when he was going next day to be married. Instantly Aubrey's attention was attracted; he asked anxiously to whom. Glad of the mark of retaining intellect, of which they feared he had been deprived, they mentioned the name of the Earl of Marsden. Thinking this was a young Earl whom he had met with in company, Aubrey seemed pleased, and astonished them still more by his pressing his intent to be present at the nuptials, and desiring to see his sister. He answered not, but in a few minutes his sister was with him. He was apparently in a state of being affected by the influence of her presence; for he pressed her to his breast, and kissed her cheek, wet with tears, slowing at the thought of her brother's being once more alive to the seelings of affection. He went to speak with all his wonled warmth, and to congratulate her on her marriage with a person so distinguished for rank and illustrious accomplishment; when he suddenly perceived a locket upon her breast; upon seeing it, what was his surprise at beholding the features of the monster wha had so long influenced his life. He seized the portrait in a paroxysm of rage, and trampled it under foot. Upon her asking him why he thus destroyed the reputation of her future husband, he looked as if he had not understood her–then seizing her hands, and gazing on her with a frantic expression of countenance, he bade her swear that she would never wed this man, for he–When he could not advance–it seemed as if someone's voice again bade him remember his oath–he turned suddenly round, thinking Lord Ruthven was near him but saw no one. In the meantime, one of the guardians and physicall, who had heard the whole, and thought this was but the return of his disorder, entered, and, upon learning him from Miss Aubrey, desired her to leave him. He fell upon his knees to them, he impored, begged of them to delay but for one day. They, attributing this to the insanity they imagined had taken possession of his mind, endeavoured to pacify him, and retired.
Lord Ruthven had called the morning after the drawing-room, and had been refused with every one else. When he heard about Aubrey's ill health, he readily assumed himself to be the cause of it; but when he learned that he was diagnosed insane, his exultation and pleasure could hardly be concealed from those among whom he had gained this information. He hastened to the house of his former companiori, and, by constant attentions, and the pretence of great affection for the brother and interest in his fate, he gradually won the ear of Miss Aubrey. Who could resist his power? His tongue had had years and toils to recover; could speak of himself as of an individual having no sympathy with any boing on the crowded street, save with her to whom he addressed himself; could telegraph. How, since he know her, his existence had begun to seem worthy of preservation, if it were merely that he might listen to her soothing accents; in fine, he knew so well how to use the serpent's art, or such was the will of fate, that he gained her affections. The title of the elder brother falling at length to him, he obtained an important embassy, which served as an excuse for securing the marriage, (in spite of her brother's deranged state,) which was to take place the very day before his departure for the continent.
Aubrey, when he was left by the physician and his guardians, attempted to bribe the servants, but in vain. He asked for pen and paper; it was given him; he wrote a letter to his sister, conjuring her, as she valued her own happiness, her own honour, and the happiness of those now in the grave, who had held her in their arms as their hope and the hope of their lives, to delay but for a few hours that marriage, on which he declared his most heavy conviction. The seruants promised they would deliver it; but giving it to the physician, he thought it best not to harass any more the mind of Miss Aroy by, what he considered, the ravings of a maniac. Nigbt passed without reply to the busy inmates of the house; and Aubrey heard, with a horror that may more easily be comprehended than described, the notes of busy preparation. Morning came, and the sound of carriages broke upon his ear. Aubrey grew almost frantic. The curiosity of the servants at last overcame their vigilance, they gradually stole away, leaving him in the custody of an helpless young woman. He seized the opportunity, while one bound was out of the room, and in a moment found himself in the aparlent where all were nearly assembled. Lord Ruthven was the first to perceive him: he immediately approached, and, taking his arm by force, hurried him from the room, struggling with him. When on the staircase, Lord Ruthven whispered in his ear—"Remember your oath, and know, if my bride dies on this day, your sister is dishonoured." "Women are frai!"
