THE VAMPYRE.
A Tale.
By John William Powell
THE circumstance upon which this tale is founded is vory general in the East. For the Arabs it appears to be common: it did not, however, extend its reach to the Greeks until after the establishment of Christianity; and it has only assumed its present form since the division of the Latin and Greek churches; at which time, the idea becoming prevalent, that a Latin body could not corrupt if buried in their territory, it gradually incased, and formed the subject of many wonderful stories, still extant, of the dead rising from their graves, and feeding upon the blood of the living and beautiful. In the West it spread, with some slight variatiori, all over Hungary, Poland, Austria, and Lorraine, where the belief existed, that vampyres nightly imbibed a certain quantity of the blood of their victims, who became emaciated, lost their strength, and speedily died of consumptions; whilst these human blood-suckers fattened, and their flesh became so saturated to the point of repletion, as to cause the blood to flow from all the passages of their bodies, and even from the very pores of the skins.
In the London Journal, of March, 1732, is a curious, and, of course, credible account of a particular case of vampyrism, which is said to have occurred at Madreyga, in Hungary. It appears, that upon an examination of the committee-in-chief and magistrates of the place, they positively and unanimously affirmed, that, about five years before, a clergyman Hiscock, named Arnold Paul, had been ho to say that, at Cassini, on the frontiers of the Turkish Service, he had been tormented by a vampyre, but had found a way to rid himself of the evil, by eating some of the earth out of the vampyr's grave, and rubbing himself with its blood. This prevention, however, did not prevent him from becoming avamparre himelf; for, about twenty or twenty-three days after his death and burial, many persons complained of having been assaulted by him, and a deposition was made, that four persons had been deprived of life by his attacks. To prevent further mischief, the inhabitants having consulted their physicians, took up the body, and found it (as is supposed to be the case in cases of murder) fully formed, and entirely free from corruption, and emitting at the mouth, nose, and ears, pure and florid blossom. .Proof having been thus obtained, they resorted to the accustomed remedy. A stake was driven entirely through the heart and body of Arnold Paul, at which he is reported to have cried out as drearily as if he had been drowned. This done, they cut off his head, burned his body, and threw the ashes into his grave. The same measures were adopted with the children of those persons who had previously died from vampyrism, lest they should, in their turn, be agents upon those who survived them.
The universal belief is, that a person sucked by a vampyre becomes a vampire himself, and sucks in his victims.
Chief bailiff.
This remarkable circumstance is here related, because it seems more adapted to illustrate the gravity of the present observations than any other circumstance which could be adduced. In many parts of Greece it is considered as a sort of punishment aftor death, for some heinous crime committed whilst in existence, that the deceased is not allowed to vampyrise, but compelled to confine his irreligious visitations solely to those beings he loved most while upon earth—those to whom he was bound by ties of kindred and affection.A supposition alluded to in the "Gospel."
But first on earth, a Vampyre sent. Thy corse shall from its tomb be rent; Then ghastly haunt the native place, and suck the blood from all thy ranks; There from thy daughter, sister, wife, and children drain the stream of life; Yet loathe the banquet which perforce must flow from thy living corse, Thy victims, whose lives yet expire, shall know the demon for their sins; As currying thee, thou cursing them. The flowers are withored on the stem. But one that for thy crime must not fall, The youngest, best behaved of all, Shall bless thee with a father's name—That word shall wrap thy heart round! Then thou must end thy task and mark her cheek's last tinge–her eye's last spark, and the last glassy glaze must view Whither she sways on its lifeless blue; Then with unhallowed hand shall trace the trescles of her yellow hair, of which, in life a lock when shorn Affection's fondest pledge was worn– But now is borne away by the Memorial of thine agony! Yet with your own best blood still drip; Thy gnashing loath, and haggard lip; Then stalking to thy wretched grave, Go, and with Gaulf and Afrits rave, Till these in horror shrink away from spectre more accursed than they.
Mr. Sime was also introduced in the wild but beautiful guise of "Thalaba," the vampyre cousin of the Arabian maid Oneiza, who is represented as having returned from the grave for the purpose of tormenting him. She was never loved whilst in existence. But this crime seemed to have resulted from the sinful habits of her life, she being represented throughout the whole of the tale as a complete type of purity and innocence. The veracious Tournant gives a long account in his travels of several astonishing cases of vampyrism, to which he pretends to have been an eyewitness; and Calmet, in his great work upon this subject, comprising a variety of anecdotes, and traditionary narrative highly substantiated of effects, has put forth some learned dissertations, tending to prove it to be a classical, as well as barbarian error.
Many curious and interesting notices on this singularly horrible superstition might be added; though the present will suffice for the effect of a note, previously devoted to explication, and which may now be concluded by merely remarking, that though the term Vampyre if the one in most general acceptation, there are several others similar to it, made use of in various parts of the world: as Vroucolocba, Vardouocha, Goul, Broucoloka, &c.
THE VAMPYRE.
It happened that in the midst of the dissipations attendant upon a London winter, there appeared at the various parties of the leaders of the parties a nobleman, more remarkable for his singularities, than his rank. He gazed up at the millers around him, as if he could not participate there. Apparently, the light laughter of the fair only attracted his attention, that he might by a look quell it, and throw fear into those breasts where thoughtlessness reigned. Those who fell this sensation of awe, could not explain whence it arose: some attributed it to the dead grey eye, which, fixing upon the object's face, did not seem to pulse, and did not one glance to pierce through to the inward workings of the heart; but fell upon the cheek with a leaden ray that weighed upon the skin it could not pass. His peculiarities caused him to be invited to every house; all wished to see him, and those who had been accustomed to violence and excilement, and now felt the weight of ennul, were pleased at having something in their presence capable of engaging their attention. In view of the deadly hue of his face, which never gained a warmer tint, either from the blush of modesty, or from the strong emotion of passion, although its form and out-look were beautiful, many of the female hunters of notoriety attempted to win his attention, and gain, at least, some marks of what they might term affection: Lady Mercer, who had been the companion of every minister shewn in drawing-rooms since her marriage, threw herself in his way, and did all but put on the dress of a merchant, to attract his notice:—though in question when she stood before him, though his eyes were apparently fixed upon her's, still it seemed as though they were unperceived;–cven her unappalled impudence was baffled, and she left the field. But though the common adultress could not influence him from the guiness of his eyes, it was not that the female sex was indifferent to him: such was the apparent conduct with which he spoke to the virtuous wife and innocent daughter, that few knew he ever addressed himself to females. He had, however, the reputation of a winning tongue; and whether it was that it even overcame the dread of his singular character, or that they were moved by his apparent hatred of vice, he was as much among those females who could form the boast of such scruples from their domestic habits, as among those who swore it by their vicars.
About the same time, there came to London a young gentleman of the name of Aubrey: he was an orphan with an only sister in the possession of great wealth.
By parents who died while he was yet in childhood. Lest also to himself by guardians, who thought it their duty merely to take care of his fortune, while they relinquished the more important matters of his mind to the care of mercenary subalterns, he entertained more his imagination than his judgment. He had, hence, that most romantic feeling of honour and candour, which daily filled so many railway' apprentices. He believed all to sympathise with virtue, and thought that vice was thrown about by Providence merely for the picturesque effluence of the scene, as we see in romances: he thought the misery of a cottage merely consisted in the vesting of clothes, which were as warm, but which were better adapted to the prisoner's eye by their irregular folds and various coloured patches. He thought, in fine, that the dreams of pets were the realities of life. He was good-looking, frank, and rich: for these reasons, upon his entering into the gay circles, many mothers surrounded him, striving which should describe with all truth their languishing or romping favourite daughters: the daughters at the same time, by their brighlening appearances when he approached, and their penetrating eyes, when he opened his lips, soon led them into false notions of his talent and his merit. Attached as he was to the romance of his solitary hours, he was surprised at finding, that, except in the tallow and wax caridles that flickered, from the presence of a ghost, or from want of snuffing, there was no foundation in real life for any of that congeries of pleasurable pictures and descriptions contained in those volumes, from which he had formed his study. Finding, however, some compensation in his gratified vanity, he was about to relinquish his domains, when the extraordinary being we have above described, crossed him in his career.
He watched him; and the very impossibilily of forming an idea of the character of a man entirely absorbed in himself, who showed no other signs of his obscenity of extemal objects, than the tacit assent to their existence, implied by the avoidance of conflict: allowing his consciousness to picture every thing that flaunted its propensity for extrovagant ideas, he so formed this object as the hero of a romance, and determined to observe the offspring of his fancy, more than the person before him. He became acquainted with him, paid him attentions, and so far advanced upon his notice, that his presence was almost recognised. He gradually learnt that Lord Ruthven's affairs were embarrased, and soon found, from the notes of preparation in Bow-street, that he was aboul to treason. Desirous of gaining some information respecting this singular character, who, till now, had ony whetted his curiosity, he hinted to his guardians, that it was time for him to perform the task, which for many generations has been necessary to enable the young to take some rapid steps in the career of violets towards putting themselves upon an equality with the aged, and not allowing them to appear as if falling from the skies, when such candalous intrigues are mentioned af the pretexts of pleasantry or of prudence, according to the degree of skill shewn in carrying them on. They consented, and Aubrey immediately merging his intentions to Lord Ruthven, was surprised to receive from him a proposal to join him. Flooded by a mark of recognition from him, who, apparently, had nothing in common with other men, he gladly accepted it, and in a few minutes they had passed the circling waters.
Hitherto, Aubrey had had no opportunity of meeting Lord Ruthven.
He knew his character, and now he found, that, when many more of his actions were exposed to his view, the results offered different concusions for the apparencies to his conduct. His companion was profuse in his liberality; the idle vagabond, and the beggar, received from his hand more than enough to relieve their immediate wants. But Aubrey could not avoid remarking, that it was not upon the virtuous, reduced to indignity by the misfortuncs attending even upon virtue, that he bestowed his alms; these were scouted from the door with hardly suppressed sneers; but when the profligate came to ask something, not to relieve his wants, but to allow him to wallow in lust, or to sink him further in his iriquity, he was sent away with rich charity. This was, however, attributed by him to the greater importunality of the vicious, which generally prevails over the retirring bashfulness of the virtuous indigent. There was one circumstance about the charity of his Lordship, which was still more impressed upon his mind: all those upon whom it was bestowed, however, found that there was a curse upon it, for they were all either led to the scaffold, or sunk to the lowest and the most abject misery. At Brussels and other towns through which they passed, Aubrey was surprised at the apparent eagerness with which his companion sought for the centres of all fashionable vice; there he entered into all the spirit of the faro table: he betted, and always gained with success, except where the known sharper was his antagonist, and then he lost more than he gained; but he was constantly with the same uncharitable face, with which he generally watched the society about him: it was not, however, so when he accompanied the rash youthful novice, or the luckless fatber of a large family; then his very wish seemed for fortune's law—this abstractedness of mind was laid aside, and his eyes sparkled with more fire than that of the cat whilst lying with the half-dead mouse. In very town, he left the formerly affluent youth, and from the oakle he adorned, cursing, in the solitude of a dungoon, the fate that had drawn him with them into the reach of this fiend; whilst many a father sat frantic, amidst the speaking looks of mute hungry children, without a single farthing of his late inheritance, wherewith to buy even sufficient to satisfy their present craving. Yet he took no money from the gambling table; but immediately lost, to the ruiner of many, the last gilder he had first snatched from the convulsive grasp of the innocent: this might but be the result of a certain degree of knowledge, which was not, however, capable of combating the cunning of the robbers experienced. Aubrey often wished to represent this to his friend, and beg him to resign that charity and pleasure which proved the ruin of all, and did not lend to his own profit; but he delayed it–for each day he hoped his friend would give him some opportunity of speaking freely and only to him; however, this never occurred. Lord Ruthven in his carriage, and amidst the various wild and rich scenes of nature, was always the same: his eye spoke less than his lip; and though Aubrey was the object of his curiosity, he obtained no greater gratification from it than the constant excitement of vainly wishing to break that mystery, which to his excited imagination began to assume the appearance of something supernatural.
They soon arrived at Rome, and Aubrey for a time lost sight of his companion; he left him in daily attendance upon the morning circuit of an Italian castle, whilst he went in search of the memorials of another most deserted city. Whilst he was engaged, letters arrived from England, which he read with eager impatience; the first was from his sister, bearing nothing but affection; the others were from his friends, the latter astonished him; if it had before entered into his imagination that there was an evil power resident in his companion, these seemed to give him sufficient reason for the belief. His guardians insisted upon his immediately leaving his friend, and urged, that his companion was dreadfully vicious, for that the possession of irresistible powers of seduction, rend him with licentious habits more dangerous to society. It had been discovered, that his contempt for the adultress had not originated in hatred of her character; but that he had required, to cance his gratification, that the victim, the partner of his guilt, should be hurled from the pinnacle of unsullied vendor, down to the lowest abyss of infamy and degradation: in consequence, that all those females whom he had sought, apparently on account of their vices, had, since his departure, thrown off the mask aside, and had not scrupled to exposit the whole deformity of they vices to the public gaze.
Aubrey determined upon leaving one, whose character had not yet shown a single bright point on which to rest her eye. He resolved to invent some plausible pretext for abandoning him altogether, purchasing, in the mean while, to watch him more closoly, and to let no slight circumstances pass by unnoticed. He entered into the same circle, and soon perceived that his Lordship was endeavouring to work upon the inexperience of the daughter of the lady whose house he chiefly frequented. In Italy, it is seldom that an unmarried female is met with in society; he was therefore obliged to carry on his plans in secret; but Aubry's eye followed him in all his windings, and soon discovered that an assignation had been arranged, which would most likely end in the ruin of an innocent, but thoughtless girl. Losing no time, he entered the apartment of Lord Ruthven, and abruptly asked him his intentions with respect to the lady, informing him at the same time that he was aware of his being about to meet her that very evening. Lord Ruthven answered, that his intentions were such as he supposed.
He asked why she would look upon such an officer; and upon being asked whether he intended to marry her, merely laughed. Aubrey retired; and, immediately writing a note, to say, that from that moment he must cease accompanying his Lordship in the remonstrance of their proposed tour, he ordered his servant to seek other instructions, and calling upon the mother of the lady, informed her of all he knew, not only with regard to her daughter, but also concerning the character of his Lordhip. The assignation was prevented. Lord Ruthven had that day merely sent his serjeant to notify him of his complete assent to separation; he did not hint any suspicion of his plans having been foiled by Aubrey's jealousy.
Having left Rome, Aubrey directed himself towards Greece, and crossing the Peninsular, soon found himself at Athens. He then fixed his residence in the house of a Greek; and occupied himself in tracing the faded records of antiquity upon moraines that apparently, as a result of concentrating the deeds of freemen only before slaves, had hidden themselves beneath the sheltering soil or many coloured lichen. Under the same roof as himself, existed a being, so beautiful and delicate, that she might have formed the model for a painter wishing to pour tray on canvas the promised hope of being faithful in Mahomet's paradise, save that her eyes spake too much nonsense for any one to think she could belong to those who had no souls. As she danced upon the plain, or tripped along the mountaintop's side, one would have thought the gait a peculiar type of her beautios; for who would have exchanged her eye, apparently the eye of an animated nature, for that sleepy luxurious eye of the animal? But to the tasto of an epicure. The light of day often accompanied Aubrey in his search after antiquities, and often saw the unconscious girl, engagod in the pursuit of a Kashmere butterfly, show the whole beauty of her form, floating as it were upon the wind, to the eager gaze of him, who forgot the letter's he had decyphered upon an almost effaced tablet, in the contemplation of her sylph-like figure. Often would her tresses falling, as she flitted about, exhibit in the sun's ray a delicately briliant and swiftly fading appearance, it might well excuse the forgetfulness of the antiquary, who could escape from his mind the very object he had before thought of vital importance to the proper interpretation of a passage in Pausanias. But why attempt to describe charms which all see, but none can appreciate?–It was innocence, you see, and beavty, affected by crowded drawing-rooms and attending balls. Whilst he drew the pictures of which he wished to preserve a memoranda for his future hours, she would stand by, and watch the magic efflections of his penknife, in tracing the streets of her native place; she would then describe to him the curious dance upon the open plain, would paint to him in all the glowing colours of youthful excitement, the marriage pomp she remembered viewing in her infoncy; and then, turning to subjects that had evidently made a great impression upon her mind, would tell him all the supernatural tales of her nurse. Her earnestness and apparencence of what she narrated, exited the interest even of Aubrey; and often when she told him the tale of the living vampyre, who had populated years among his friends, and whose ties, forced every year, by foeding upon the life of a recently female to prolong his existence for the ensuing months, his blood would run cold, whil he attempted to keep her out of such idle and horrible fantasies; but she cited to him the names of old men who had at once deceased one living person themselves, after several of their near relatives and children had been found marked with the marks of the creature's affliction; and when she found him so irreducible, she begged of him to believe her, for he had been, remarked, observed, that those who had dared to question their accusation, always had some proof given, which obliged them, with grief and heartbreaking, to confess it was true. She detailed to him the traditional appearance of these monsters, and his horror was increased, by hearing a pretty accurate description of Lord Ruthven; he, however, still persisted in persuading her that there could be no truth in her fears, though at the same time he wondered at the many coinoidences which had all tended to expiate of belief in the supernatural power of Lord Rutherven.
Asrey began to attach himself more and more to the girl, her beauty, so contorted with all the asfected virtues of the women whom he had sent for his vision of romance, won his heart; and while he ridiculed the idea of a young man out of English habits, marrying an uneducated German girl, still he found himself more attached to the almost fairy form before him. He would learn himself at times from her, and, saving a portion for some antiquarian research, he would depart, determined not to return until his object was attained; but he always found it impossible to fix his attention upon the ruins around him, whilst in his mind he retained an image of himself alone as the rightful possessor of his treasures. He was uncanscious of his love, and was ever the same frank and honest being he had first known. She always seemed to part from him with reluctance; but it was hecause she had no other close one with whom she could vivit her favourite baunts, whilst her guardian was occupied in skelling or uncovering some frogment which had escaped the deftness of time. She had appealed to her parents on the subject of Vampyros, and they both, with severance present, affirmed their belief, but with horror at the very name. Shortly after, Aubrey determined to proceed upon one of his excursions, which was to detain him for a few hours; when they heard the name of the place, they all at once begged of him not to return at night, as he must necessarily pass through a wood, where no Greek would ever remain, after the day had closed, upon any consideration.
On. They described it as the return of the vampyres in their nocturnal orgies, and denounced the most heavy evasions as impinging upon him who dared to cross their path. Aubrey made light of their representations, and tried to laugh himself out of the idea; but when he saw them shudder at his daring thus to mock a superior, infernal power, the very name of which apparently made their blood freeze, he was silent.
Next morning Aubrey set off upon his journey unattended; he was surprised to behold the meloncholy face of his host, and was concerned to find that his words, mocking the belief of those horrible fiends, had inspired them with such terror. Whon he was about to depart, she came to the side of his horse, and earnestly begged of him to return, before he allowed the power of these beings to be put in effect; he promised. He was, however, so occupied in his research, that he did not perceive that day-light would soon come to an end, and on the horizon there was one of those specks which, in the warmer climates, so rapidly gather into a tremendous mass, and pour all their rage upon the devoted country. He at once, howevr, mounted his horse, determined to make up some speed for his delay: but it was too late. Twilight, in these southern climes, is almost unknown; immediately the sun sets, night begins: and before he had advanced far, the power of the storm was above—its echoing thunders had scarcely an interval of rest—its thick heavy rain forced its way through the canopying foliage, whilst the blue fountains seemed to flow and ripple at his very feet. Suddenly his horse took fright, and he was carried with dreadful reluctance through the entangled forest. The animal at once, through fatigue, stopped, and he found, by the glare of lightning, that he was in the neighbourhood of a house that hardly lifted itself up from the masses of dead leaves and brushwood which surrounded it. Dismounting, he approached, hoping to find someone to guide him to the town, or at least trusting to provide shelter from the pelting of the storm. As he approached, the thunders, for a moment silent, allowed him to hear the furious shrioks of a woofer, mingling with the stifled, exultant mockery of a laugher, continued in one loud, unbroken sound; he was startled: but, roused by the thunder which again rumbled over his head, he, with a sudden effort, forced open the door of the hut. He found himself in utter darkness: the sound, however, guided him. He was apparently unperceived; for, though he called, still the sounds continued, and no notice was taken of him. He found himself in conflict with someone, whom he immediate seized; when a voice cried, "Again baffled!" to which a loud laugh succeeded; and he felt himself grappled by one whose strength seemed superhuman: determined to sell his life as dearly as he could, he struggled; but it was in vain: he was lifted from his feet and hurled with enormous force against the ground:–his assailant threw himself upon him, and kneeling upon his breast, had placed his hands up to his throat–when the glare of any torches penetrating through the hole that gave light in the day, disturbed him;–he immediately rose, and, leaving his prey, rushed through the door, and in a moment the crashing of the branches, as he broke through the wood, was no longer heard. The storm was raging still; and Aubrey, incapable of moving, was soon heard by those without. They entered; the light of their torches fell upon the mud walls, and the fire loaded on every individual straw with heavy flakes of soot. At the desire of Aubrey they searched for her who had accompanied him by her cries; he was again left in darkness; but what was he to do, when the light of the lantern once more came upon him, to perceive the curious form of the fair conductress brought in a lifeline. He shut his eyes, hoping that it was but a vision arising from his disturbed imagination; but he again saw the same form, when he uncloshed them, stretched by his side. There was no blood upon her cheek, not even upon her lip; yet there was a stillness about her face that seemed almost as attaching as the life that once dwelt there: upon her neck and breast was blood, and upon her throat were the marks of teeth having opened the vein: to this the men replied, erring, somewhat struck with horror, "A shot!" "A Vampyre!" A litter was quickly formed, and Aubrey was laid by the side of her, who had lately been to him the object of so many bright and fairy visions, now fallen with the flower of life that had died within her. He knew not what his troubles were–his mind was fatigued and seemed to be in reslection, and he took refuge in vacuums–he held almost unconsciously in his hand a naked dagger of a particular construction, which had been found in the hut. They were soon met by different parties who had been engaged in the search of her whom a others had missed. Their lamentable cries, as they approached the city, warned the public of some dreadful catastrophe. –To describe their grief would be impossible; but when they ascertained the causality of their child's death, they looked at Aubrey, and patted him on the chest. They were consolable; both died broken-hearted.
Aubrey being put to bed was seized with a most violent fever, and was often delirious; in these circumstances he would call upon Lord Ruthven and upon Lord Horsley–by some unocountable occurrence he seemed to beg of his former companion to spare the being he loved. At other times he would imprecise maledictions upon his head, and curse him as her destroyer. Lord Ruthven, called at this time to arrive at Athens, and, from whatever motive, upon hearing of the state of Aubrey, immediate placed himself in the same house, and became his constant companion. When the prisoner recovered from his delirium, he was horrified and starstruck at the sight of him whose image he had now associated with that of a Vampyre; but Lord Ruthven, by his kind words, indicating almost repentance for the folly that had caused their separation, and still more by the attention, anxiety, and care which he showed, soon reconciled him to his present condition. His demeanor seemed quite changed; he no longer appeared the apathetic being who had so upset Aubrey; but as soon as his consciousness began to be rapid, he again gradually retired into the same state of mind, and Aubrey perceived no distinction from the former man, except that at times he was surprised to meet his gaze fixed intently upon him, with a smile of monumental exultation playing upon his lips: he knew not why, but this smile haunted him. During the last stage of the invalid's recovery, Lord Routhven was apparently engaged either in watching the tideless waves raised by the cooling breezes, or in marking the progress of those orbs, circling, like our world, the moving sun;—indeed, he appeared to wish to avoid the eyes of all.
Aubrey's mind, by this blow, was much weakened, and that elasticity of spirit which had once so distinguished him now seemed to have fled him for ever. He was now as much a lover of solitude and silence as Lord Ruthven; but as much as he wished for solitude, his mind could not find it in the neighbourhood of Athens; if he sought it amidst the rivins he had formerly frequenled, Anthea's form stood by his side; if be sought in the woods, her light step would appear wandering amidst the underwood, in company of the modest violets; then suddenly turning round, would show, to his wild imagination, her pale face and wounded throat, with a meek smile upon her lips. He determined to fly scenes, every detail of which created bitter associations in his mind. He proposed to Lord Ruthven, to whom he held himself bound by the tendor care be had taken of him during his illness, that they should visit those parts of Greece no one had yet seen. They travelled in every direction, and sought every spot to which a ballot could be conveyed: but as they thus hastened from place to place, yet they seemed not to heed what they gazed upon. They heard much of robbers, but they gradually learned to slight these reports, which they imagined were only the invontion of indivisible men, whose interest it was to excite the generality of those whom they defended from preterided dangers. In consequence of thus neglecting the advice of the inhabitants, on one occasion they travelled with only a few guards, more to serve as guiders than as a defence. Protesting, however, upon reaching a narrow defile, at the bottom of which was the bed of a torrent, with large masses of rock brooding down from the neighbouring precipices, they had reason to repent their error; for scarcely were the whole of the party engaged in the narrow pass, when they were startled by the whistling of bullets close to their heads, and by the echoed report of several shots. In an instant the guards had removed them, and, placing themselves behind rocks, had begun to search in the direction whence the report came. Lord Rulhven and Aubry, imitating their example, retired for a moment behind the sheltorig turn of the defile: but ashamed of being thus degraded by a foe, who with insulting shouts bade them advance, and being exposed to unresisting soldiers, if any of the robbers should come near and attack them from the rear, they decided at once to rush forward in search of the enemy. Hardly had they lost the hold of the rock, when Lord Ruthven received a shot in the shoulder, which brought him to the ground grateful. Aubrey hastened to his assistance; and, no longer beeding the contretemps or his own peril, was soon surprised by seeing the robbers' faces around him–his guards having, upon Lord Ruthven being wounded, immediate thrown up their arms and surrendered.
By promises of great reward, Aubrey soon induced them to carry his wounded friend to a neighbouring cabin; and having agreed upon a ransom, he was no more disturbed by their presence–they being content merely to guard the entrance till his comrade should return with the promised sum, far which he had an account. Lord Ruthven's strength rapidly decreased; in two days mortification ensued, and death seemed dancing with basty slops. His conduct and appearance had not changed; he seemed as unaffected of pain as he had been of the objects about him: but towards the close of the last evening, his mind became apparently uneasy, and his eye often fixed upon Aubrey, who was inclined to offer his assistance with more than usual earnestness—"Assist me!" You may save me–you may do more than that–I mean not my life, I heed the call of my existence as little as that of the passing day; but you may save my honour, your father's honour. "How? Tell me how? "I would do any thing," replied Aubrey. "I need not much–my life ebbs apace–I cannot explain the whole–but if you would conceal all you know of me, my honour were free from stain in the world's mouth–or if my death were unknown for some time in England–I—I–but life. –"It shall not be known." "Swear!" cried the dying man, rousing himself with exultant violence, "Swear by all your soul reveres, by all you nature fears, swear that, for a year and a day, you will not impart your knowledge of my curses or death to any living creature in any way, whatever may happen, or what you may see. His eyes seemed bursting from their sockets: "I swear!" Aubrey; he sunk laughing upon his knees, and breathed no more.
Aubrey retired to rest, but did not sleep; the various circumstances attending his acquaintance with this man rose upon his mind, and he knew not what to do. When he resumed his oath a cold shivering came over him, as if from the presentiment of something horrid awaiting him. Rising early in the morning, he was about to enter the hovel in which he had left the corpse, when the robber met him, and informed him that it was no longer there, having been conveyed by him and comrades, upon his retiring, to the pirinacle of a neighbouring mount, according to a promise they had given his lordship, that it should be exposed to the first cold ray of the moon that rose after his death. Aubrey astonished, and taking several of the men, determined to go and bury it upon the spot where it lay. Bt, when he had mounted to the summit he found no trace of either the corpse or the clothes, though the robbers swore they had picked out the identically rock on which they had laid the body. For a time his mind was bewildered in conjectures, but he at last returned, convinced that they had buried the corpse for the sake of the clothes.
Weary of a country in which he had met such terrible misfortunes, and in which all apparently seemed to heighten that superstitious melancholy that had seized upon his mind, he resolved to leave it, and soon arrived at Smyrna. While waiting for a ship to convey him to Ortranto, or to Naples, he occupied himself in arranging those effibles he had with him belonging to Lord Ruthver. Amongst other things there was a chest containing several weapons of execution, more or less adapted to ensure the death of the victim. There were several daggers and ataghans. Whilst turning them over, and examining their curious forms, what was his surprise at finding a sheath appurtenantly ornamented in the same style as the dagger discovered in the fatal hut–he exclaimed–hastening to gain further proof, he found the weapon, and his horror may be imagined when he discovered that it fitted, though peculiarly shaped, the sheath he held in his hand. His eyes seemed to need no further certainty–they seemed to be bound to the dagger; yet still he wished to disbelieve; but the particular form, the fame varying colours upon the blade and sheath were alike in splendour on both, and there was no room for doubt; there were also drops of blood on each.
He left Smyrna, and on his way home, to Rome, his first inquiries were concerning the lady he had attempted to snatch from Lord Ruthven's seductivc arts. Her parents were in disgrace, their fortune ruined, and she had not been heard of since the departure of his lordship. Aubrey's mind became almost broken under so many repeated horrors; he was afraid that this country had fallen a victim to the destroyer of India. He became morose and silenseless; and his only occupation consisted in urging the speed of the proceedings, as if he were going to save the life of some one he held dear. He arrived at Calais; the breeze, which seemed obedient to his will, soon wafted him to the English shares; and he hastened to the mansion of his fathers, and there, for a moment, appeared to him, in the embraces and caresses of his sister, all memory of the past. If she before, by her infantine caresses, had gained his affection, now that the woman began to appear, she was still more alluring as a companion.
Miss Aubrey had not that winning character which gains the gaze and applause of the drawing-room assemblies. There was none of that light brilliancy which only exists in the healed atmosphere of a crowded apartment. Her blue eye was never lit up by the levity of the proceedings. There was a melancholy charm about it which did not seem to arise from misfortunes, but from some seeling within, that appeared to indicate a being conscious of a darker realm. His step was not that light footing, which strays where a butlerfly or a colour may attract—it was sedate and pensive. When alone, her face was never brightened by the smelt of joy; but when her brother breathed to her his affection, and would not let her forget the griefs she knew destroyed his rest, who would have exchanged her smile for that of the voluptuous? It seemed as if those eyes on that face were then playing in the light of their own native spectacles. She was yet eighteen, and had not been presented to the world, it having been thought by her guards more fit that her presentation should be delayed until her brother's return from the continent, when he might be her prime minister. It was now, therefore, resolved that the next drawing-room, which was fast approaching, should be the epoch of her entrance into the "busy scene." Aubrey would rather have remained in the mansion of his fathers, and fed upon the melancholy which overpowered him. He could not feel sorry about the habits of fashionable strangers, when his mind had been so torn by the events he had witnessed; but he resolved to sacrifice his own comfort to the protection of his sister. They soon arrived in town, and prepared for the next day, which had been announced in a drawing-room.
The crowd was excessing–a drawing-room had not been held for a long time, and all who were anxious to bask in the smile of royalty, hastened thither. Aubrey was there with his sister. While he was standing in a corner by himself, heedless of all around him, engaged in the remembrance that the first time he had seen Lord Ruthven was in that very place—he felt himself suddenly seized by the arm, and a voice he recognized too well, sounded in his ear—"Remembrance your oath." He had hardy refused to look, fear of seeing a spectre that would frighten him, when he perceived, at a little distance, the same figure which had attracted his notice on this spot upon his first entry into society. He gazed until his legs almost refused to bear their weight, he was obliged to take the hand of a friend, and forcing a passage through the crowd, threw himself into the carriage, and was driven home. He paced the room with hurried stops, and kept his hands up over his head, as if he were afraid his thoughts were bursting from his brain. Lord Ruthven again before him–circumstances presented up in dreadful array–the dagger–his oath–He repeated himself, he could not believe it possible–the dead rise aggan!–He thought his imagination had conjured up the image his mind was resting upon. It was impossible that it could be recovered; he determined, therefore, to go again into society; for though he attempted to ask counting Lothbury, the name hung upon his lips, and he could not succeed in gaining information. He went a few nights after with his sister to the house of a near relation. Leaving her under the protection of a matron, he retired into a room, and there gave himself up to his own devouring thoughts. Perceiving, at last, that many were leaving, he roused himself, and entering another room, found his sister surrounded by several, apparently in earnest conversation; he attempted to pass and get near her, when one, whom he requested to move, turned round, and revealed to him their faces. He was abhorred. He sprang forward, seized his sister's arm, and, with hurried step, led her tawards the street: at the door he found himself impeded by the crowd of servants who were waiting for their lords; and while he was engaged in passing them, he again heard that voice whisper close to him—"Remember your oath!"He did not dare to turn, but, hurrying his sister, soon reached home.
Aubrey came almost distanced. If before his mind had been absorbed by one project, how much more compulsive was it engrossed, now that the certainty of the morister's making a gain pressed upon him? His sister's attentions were now unheedable, and it was in vain that she intreated him to explain to her what had caused his abrupt conduct. He only uttered a few words, and they terrified her. The sooner he thought, the more he was saved. His oath startled him; was he to allow this monster to roam, wreaking ruin upon his house, amidst all he held dear, and not avert its progress? His very sister might have been touched by him. But even if he were to break his oath, and disclose his suspicions, who would believe him? He thought of employing his own hand to free the world from such a wretch; but duty, he remembered, had been already mocked. For days he remained in this state; shut up in the room, he saw no one, and cried only when his sister came, who, with eyes streaming with tears, besought him, for her sake, to support nature. At last, no longer capable of enjoying freedom and solitude, he left his house, roamed from street to street, anxious to fly that image which haunted him. His dress became neglected, and he wandered, as often exposed to the noon-day sun as to the midnights damps. He was no longer recognized; at first he returned with the knife to cut him; but at last he laid him down to rest wherever fatigue overtook him. His sister, anxious for her safety, emulated people to follow him; but they were soon distanced by him who fled from a pursuer swifter than any from thought. His conduct, however, suddenly changed. Struck with the melancholy that had left by his absence the company of his friends, with a fiend stalking them, of whose presence they were unconscious, he determined to enter again into society, and watched him closely, anxious to learn, in spite of his oath, all whom Lord Ruthven approached with intimacy. But when he entered into a room, his haggard and suspicious looks were so striking, his inward shudderings so visible, that his sister was at last obliged to beg of him to abstain from seeking, for her sake, a society which affixed him so strongly. When, however, remonstrance proved unavailing, the Germans considered it proper to intrpose, and, fearing that Biron's mind was becoming alienated, they thought it high time to resume that trust which had been before imposed upon them by Aubrey's parents.
Desirous of saving him from the injuries and suffering he had daily inflicted in his wanderings, and of preventing him from exposing to the general eye those marks of what they considered folly, they engaged a physiologist to remain in the house, and take careful care of him. He hardly appeared to notice it, so completely was his mind occupied by some terrible subjeuet. His incoherence became at last so great, that he was confined to his chamber. There he would often lie for days, incapable of being roused. He had become emaciated, his eyes had attained a glassy luster; the only sign of affection and recollection remaining displayed itself upon the entry of his sister; then he would sometimes start, and, seizing her hands, with looks that severely afflicted her, he would beg her not to tauch him. "Oh, do not touch him–if your love for me is aught, DO not go near him!" When, however, she inquired to whom he referred, his only answer was, "True! true!" Again he sank into a slate, when not even she could rouse him. This lasted many months; gradually, however, as the year was passing, his appearances became less frequent, and his mind took off a portion of its gloom, whilst his guardians observed, that several times in the day he would count upon his singers a definite number, and then smile.
The time had nearly elapsed, when, upon the last day of the year, one of his guardians entering his room, began to converse with his physician upon the melancholy circumstance of Aubrey's being in so awful a fituation, when his sister was going next day to be married. Instantly Aubrey's attention was attracted; he asked witness to whom. Glad of his mark of returning affection, of which they feared he had been deprived, they mentioned the name of the Earl of Marsden. Thinking this was a young Earl whom he had met with in society, Aubrey seemed pleased, and astonished them still more by his expressing his intention to be present at the nuptials, and desiring to see his sister. They answered not, but in a few minutes his sister was with him. He was apparently again capable of being affected by the irruption of her lovely smile; for he pressed her to his breast, and kissed her cheek, wet with tears, flowing at the thought of her brother's being once more alive to the feelings of affection. He began to speak with all his wonted warmth, and to congratulate her upon her marriage with a person so distinguished for rank and honorable achievement; when he suddenly perceived a locket upon her breast; opening it, what was his surprise at beholding the features of the monster who had so long influenced him. He seized the portrait in a paroxysm of rage, and trampled it under foot. Upon her asking him why he thus betrayed the fidelity of her future husband, he looked as if he did not understand her–then seizing her hands, and gazing on her with a frantic expression on his face, he bade her swear that she would never wed this man, for he– But he could not advance–it seemed as if that voice again bade him remember his oath–he turned suddenly round, thinking Lord Ruthven was near him but seeing no one. In the meantime the guard and physician, who had heard the whole, and thought this was but a retraction of the order, entered, and forcing him from Miss Aubrey, desired her to give him up. He fell upon his knees to her, he implored, he begged of her to delay but for one day. They, attributing this to the insanity they imagined had taken possession of his mind, endeavoured to pacify him, and retired.
Lord Ruthven had called the morning after the drawing-room, and had refused with every one in attendance. When he heard of Aubrey's ill health, he readily understood him to be the cause of it; but when he be learnd that he was deemed insane, his exultation and pleasure could hardly be concealed from those among whom he had gained this information. He hastened to the house of his former companion, and, by cousin attendance, and through expression of great affection for the brother and interest in his fate, he gradually won the ear of Miss Aubrey. Who could resist his passion? His long life had been pains to count; could speak of himself as of an unholy creature having no sympathy witb any being on the crowded street, save with her to whom he addressed himself; could tell how, since he knew her, his existence, had come to seem worthy of preservation, if it were merely that he might listen to her soolhing accentions; in fine, he knew so well how to use the serpent's art, or whatever was the will of fate, that he gained her affections. The title of the elder brother belonging at length to him, he obtained an important embalming, which served as an excuse for forbidding the marriage, (in spite of her brother's deranged state,) which was to take place the very day before his departure for the continent.
Aubrey, when he was accompanied by the physician and his guardians, attempted to bribe the fervents, but in vain. He asked for pen and paper; it was given him; he wrote a letter to his sister, conjuring her, as she valued her own happiness, her own honour, and the honour of those now in the grave, who once held her in their arms as their hope and the hope of their house, to delay but for a few hours that marriage, on which he denounced the most heavy curses. The servant promised they would deliver it; but giving it to the physician, he though it better not to disturb any more the mind of Miss Aubrey by, whom he considered, the ravings of a maniac. Night passed on without rest to the busy inmates of the house; and Aury heard, with a horror that may more easily be conceived than described, the notes of breaking preparation. Morning came, and the sound of carriages broke upon his ear. Avrey grew almost frantic. The curiosity of the servants at last overcame their vigilance, they gradually stole away, leaving him in the custody of an helpless young woman. He seized the opportunity, while one of them was out of the room, and in a moment found himself in the apartment where all were quietly assembled. Lord Ruthven was the first to perceive him: he immediately approached, and, taking his arm by force, hurried him from the room, speechless with rage. When on the staircase, Lord Ruthven whispered in his ear—"Remember your oath, and know, if not my bride to day, your sister has dishonoured. Women are frail!" So saying, he pushed him towards his attendants, who, roused by the old woman, had come in search of him. Aubrey could no longer support himself; his rage, in finding vent, had broken a blood vessel, and he was conveyed to bed. This was mentioned to his sister, who was not present when he entered, as the physicari was afraid of agitating her. The marriage was solemnized, and the bride and bridegroom left London.
Aubrey's weakness increased; the effusion of blood produced symptomatic of the near approach of death. He desired his sister's guardians might be called, and when the midnight hour had struck, be related composedly what the reader has perused—he died immediately after.
The guardians rushed to protect Miss Aubrey; but when they arrived, it was too late. Lord Ruthven had disappeared, and Aubrey-foster had shown the thirst of a VAMPYRE!
EXTRACT OF A LETTER, CONTAINING AN ACCOUNT OF LDR. BYRON'S RESIDENCE IN THE ISLAND OF MITYLENE.
ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE, &c.
"The world was all before him, but he had to choose his place of rest, and Providence his guide."
IN Sailing through the Gregoian Archipelago, on board one of his Majesty's vessels, in the year 1812, we put into the harbour of Milylcne in the island of that name. The bounties of this place, and the constant supply of cattle and vegetables always to be had there, induce many British visitors to visit it—both men of war and merchantmen; and though it lies rather out of the track for ships bound to Smyrna, its bounties amply repay for the deviation of a voyage. We landed, as usual, at the bottom of the bay, and whilst the men were engaged in watering, and the purser bargaining for cattle with the natives, the clergyman and himself took a ram down to the cave called Homer's School, and other places, where we had been beforc. On the brow of Mount Ida (a mountain monticule so named) we met and engaged a young Greek as our guide, who told us he had come from Scio with an English lord, whole of the land four days previous to our arrival in his country. "He engaged me as a pilot," said the Greek, "and would have taken me with him; but I did not choose to quil Mitylene, where I am likely to get married. He was an odd, but a very good man. The cottage over the hill, facing the river, belongs to him, and he has left an old man in charge of it: he gave Dominick, the wine-trader, six hundred zeroes for it, (about L250 English currency,) and has resided there about fourteen months, though not constantly; for he sails in his fclucca very often to the different islands."
This account excited our curiosity very much, and we lost no time in hastening to the house where our countryman had resided. We were kindly received by an old man, who conducted us over the mansion. It consisted of four apartments on the ground floor—an entrance hall, a drawing-room, a sitting parlour, and a bed room, with a spacious closet annexed. They were all simply decoroted: plain green-slained walls, marble labels on other sides, a large myrtle in the centre, and a large fountain outside, which could be made to play through the rooms by moving a spring fixed in the shape of a small brorize Venus in a leaning posture; a large cauch or sofa supported the furniture. In the hall stood half a dozen English cane chairs, and an empty bookcase: there were no mirrors, nor a single pajamaing. The bedstead had merely a large rectangle spread on the floor, with two stuffed cotton quilts and a paillow—the common bed throughout Greece. In the sitting-room we observed a marble recess, formerly, the old man told us, filled with books and papers, which was then joined with a large seaman's chest in the closet: it was open, but we did not think ourselves justified in examining the contents. On the tablet in the recess lay Voltaire's, Shokoff's, Boileau's, and Rousseau's works complete; Volney's Ruins of Empires; Zimmern, in the German language; Klapstock's Messiah; Kotzebue's novels; Schiller's play of the Robbers; Milton's Paradise Lost, an Italian edition, printed al Parma in 1810; several small pamphlet from the Greek press al Constantinople, much to read, but no English book of any description. Most of these books were filled with morginal notes, written with a pencil, in Italian and Latin. The Messiah was literally scribbled all over, and marked with slips of paper, on which also were remitted.
The old man said: "The lord had been reading some books the evening before he soiled, and forgot to place them with the others; but," said he, "that they must lie until his return; for he is so particular, that were I to do anything without orders, he would frown upon us for a week together; he is otherways very good." I once did him a service; and I have the whole of this farm for the purpose of taking care of it, except twenty shillings which I pay to an old Armenian who resides in a small cottage in the wood, and whom the lord brought here from Adrianople; I don't know for what purpose."
The appearance of the house externally was pleading. The portico in front was fifty paces long and fourteen broad, and the fluted marble pillars wth black plinths and sret-work cornices, (as it is now customary in Grecian architecture,) were almost as high as the roof. The roof, surrounded by a light stone balustrade, was covered by a fine Turkey carpet, beneath an awning of strong coarse linen. Most of the house-tops are thus furnished, as upon the Greeks pass their evenings in smoking, drinking light wines, such as "lachryma christi," eating fruit, and enjoying the evening breeze.
On the left hand as we approached the house, a small streamlet glided along, grapes, aranges and limes were clustering together on its banks, and under the shade of two large myrtle bushes, a marble seat with an ornamented wooden back was placed, on which we were told, the defendant spent many of his evenings and nights till twelve o'clock, reading, and writing to himself. "I suppose," said the old man, "praying" for he was very devout, "and always attended our church twice a week, besides Sundays."
The view from this seat was what may be termed "a bird's-eye view." A line of rich vincyards led the eye to Mount Calcla, cered with olive and myrtle trees in bloom, and on the summit of which an ancient Greek temple appeared in majestic decay. A small stream issuing from the ruins descended in broken cascades, till it was last seen in the woods near the murderer's base. The sea is smooth as glass, and an horizon unshadowed by a fingernail-edge, terminates the view in front; and a little to the left, through a vista of largely chesnut and palm-trecs, several small islands were distinctly served, studding the light blue wave with spots of emerald groen. I seldom enjoyed a job more than I did this; but our enquiries were fruitless as to the name of the person who had resited in this romantic position: none knew his name but Dominick, his banker, who had given money to Candia. "The Armerian," said our conductor, "could tell, but I am sure he will not,"—"And cannot you tell, old friend?" said I—"If I can," said he, "I dare riot." We had not time to visit the Armenian, but on our return to the town we learned some particulars of the isolated lord. He had portioned eight young girls when he was last upon the island, and entertained them at the nuptial feast. He gave a cow to one man, horses to others, and cotton and silk to the girls who made by weaving these articles. He also bought a new boat for a fisherman who had loft his own in a gale, and he often gave Greek Testaments to the poor children. In short, he appeared to us, from all we collected, to have been a very eccentric and benevolent character. One circumstance we learnt, which our old friends at the cottage thought proper not to disclose. He had a most beautiful daughter, with whom the lord was often seen walking on the sea shore, and he had bought her a piano-forte, and taught her to use it.
Such was the information with which we departed from the peaceful Isle of Mitylene; our imaginations all on the rack, guessing who this rambler in Greece was. He had money it was evident: he had philanthropy of disposition, and all those eocentricities which mark peculiar genius. Arrived at Palermo, all our debts were discharged. Founding in company with Mr. FOSTER, the architect, a pupil of WYATT'S, who had been travelling in Egypt and Greece, "The individual," said he, "about whom you are so anxious, is Lord Byron; I met him in my chambers on the island of Tenedos, and I also visited him at Messina." We had never then heard of his lordship's fame, as we had been some years from home; but "Childe Haralde" being put into our hands we recognized the recluse of Calcla in every page. Deeply we regret not having been more curious in our researches at the cottage, but we consoled ourselves with the idea of returning to Marylebone on some future day; but to me that day will never return. I make this statement, believing it to be quite honorable, and in justice to his lordship's good name, which has been grossly slandered. He has been described as of an unfeeling disposition, averse to associating with any human race, or contributing in any way to sooth its sorrows, or add to its pleasures. The face is directly the reverse, and may be gleaned from these little anecdotes. All the feelings of the heart, so elegantly represented in his lordship's poems, seem to have their seat in his bosom. Tenderness, sympathy, and charity appear to guide all his actions: and courting the repose of solitude is an additional reward for marking him as a being on whose heart Religion hath set her seal, and upon whose head Benevolence hath thrown her mantle. No man can read the preceding pleasing "traits" that will speak highly of him as a countryman. With respect to his debts or pleases, I do not assume a right to give an opinion. Reporters are to be received with caution, particularly when directed against man's moral irresponsibility; and he who dares justfy himself before that awful tribunal where all must appear, alone may censure the errors of a foul-mortal. Lord Byron's character is wholly of his genius. To do good in secret, and shun the world's applause, is the surest test of a virtuous heart and an impartial conscience.
THE END.
Gillet, Printer, Crawn-court, Fleel-street.

THE VAMPYRE.
A Tale.
By John William Polidori
THE superstition upon which this tale is founded is very general in the East. Among the Arabs it appeared to be common: it did not, however, extend itself to the Greeks until after the establishment of Christianity; and it has only assumed its present form since the division of the Latin and Greek churches; at which time, the idea becoming prevalent, that a Latin body could not corrupt if buried in their territory, it gradually inereased, and formed the subject of many wonderful stories, still extenuating, of the dead rising from their graves, and feeding upon the blooms of the young and beautiful. In the West it spread, with some slight variation, all over Hungary, Poland, Austria, and Lorraine, where the belief existed, that vampyres nightly imbibed a certain quantity of the blood of their victims, who became emaciated, lost their strength, and speedily died of consumption; whilst these human blood-suckers fattened, and their veins became distended to such a point of repletion, as to cause the blood to flow from all the passages of their bodies, and even from the very pores of their skins.
In the London Journal, of March, 1732, is a curious, and, of course, credibulous account of a particular case of vampyrism, which is stated to have occurred at Madreyga, in Hungary. It appeared, that upon an exclamation of the commander-in-chief and magistrates of the place, they posited positively and unequivocally affirmed, that, about five years before, a certain Heyduke, named Arnold Paul, had been heard to say that, at Cassovja, on the frontiers of the Turkish Serjeantia, he had been tortured by a vampyre, but had found a way to rid himself of the evil, by eating some of the earth out of the vampire's grave, and rubbing himself with his blood. This caution, however, did not prevent him from becoming a vampyre; for, about twenty or thirty days after his death and burial, several persons complained of having been tormented by him, and a deposition was made, that four persons had been deprived of life by his attacks. To prevent further mischief, the inhabitants having consulted their physicians, took up the body, and found it (as is supposed to be usual in cases of uampyrism) fresh, and entirely free from corruption, and emitting at the inouth, nose, and ears, pure and florid blood. Proof having been thus obtained, they resorted to the accustomed remedy. A stake was driven entirely through the heart and body of Arnold Paul, which he is reported to have cried out as dreadfully as if he had been shot. This done, they cut off his head, burned his body, and threw the ashes into his grave. The measures were adopted with the corses of those persons who had previously died from vampyriſm, lest they should, in their tum, become agents upon other who survived them.

Many curious and interesting notices on this particularly horrible superstition might be added; but the present may suffice for the limits of a note, necessarly devoted to explanation, and which may now be concluded by merely remarking, that though the term Vampyre is the one most general acceptation, there are many others likewise synonymous with it, and in use of in various parts of the world: as Vroucolocho, Vardoulacha, Goul, Broucoloka, &c.

Apparently, the light laughter of the fair maiden attracted his attention, that he might by a chance quell it, and throw foam into those breasts where thoughtlessness reigned. Those who felt this sensation of awe could not explain whence it arose: same attributed it to the dead grey eye, which, fixing upon the object's face, did not seem to penetrate, or at least not pierce through to the inward workings of the hearl; but fell upon the check with a leaden ray which weighed upon the skin it could not pass. His peculiarities caused him to be invited to every house; all went to see him, and those who had been accustomed to violent excitement, and now felt the weight of ennui, were pleased at having something in their midst capable of engaging their attention. In spite of the dead-green hue of his face, which never gained a warmer tint, either from the blush of modesty, or from the straining emotion of passion, though its form and outline were beautiful, many of the female huntors after notoriety attempted to win his attentions, and gain, at least, some marks of what they might term affection: Lady Mercer, who had been the mockery of every monster shewn in drawing-rooms since her marriage, threw herself in his way, and did all but put on the dress of a mountaineer, to attract his notice:—though in vain: when she stood before him, though his eyes were apparently fixed upon her's, still it seemed that they were unperceived;–even her unappalled impudence was baffled, and she left the field. But when the criminal adultress could not influence even the guiness of his eyes, it was not that the female sex was indifferent to him: yet such was the apparerit caution with which he spoke to the prosecutrix wife and innocent daughter, that few knew he ever addressed himself to females. About the same time, there came to London a young gentleman of the name of Aubrey: he was an orphari left with an only sifter in the possession of great wealth, by parents who died while he was yet in childhood. He thought, in fine, that the dreams of poets were the necessities of life. He was handsome, smart, and charming: for those reasons, upon his entering into the gay circles, in any mother surrounded him, striving which should describe with East truth their languishing and unsatisfying favourites: the daughters at the same time, by their brighing couritenances whom he approached, and by their sparkling eyes, when he opened his lips, so led him into false riotions of his talents and his merit. Attached as he was to the romance of his solitary hours, he was startled at finding, that, except in the tallow and wax candles that flickered, not from the presence of a ghost, but from want of snuffing, there was no room in real life for any of that congeries of pleasurable piotures and descriptions contained in those volumes, from which he had formed his study. Finding, however, some comfort in his gratified vanity, he was almost ready to relish his dreams, when the extraordinary being we have just described, crossed him in his career.
He watched him; and the very impossibility of forming an idea of the character of a man entirely absorbed in himself, who gave few other signs of his observation of external objects, than the tacit assent to their existence, implied by the avoidance of their contact: commanding his imagination to picture every thing that flattered its propensily to fanciful ideas, he soon formed the object into the form of a romance, and determined to observe the offspring of his fancy, rather than the person before him. He became acquainted with him, paid him attention, and so far advanced upon him without notice, that his prescence was always recognised. He gradually learnt that Lord Ruthven's affairs were embarrassed, and soon found, from the notes of preparation in Baker's Street, that he was about to travel. Desirous of gaining some information respecting this singular character, who, till now, had only shown his curiosity, he hinted to his guardians that it was time for him to perform the tour, which for many generations has been thought necessary to enable the young to take some rapid steps in the career of vice toward putting themselves up an equality with the aged, and not allowing them to appear as the fallen of the skillets, whose scandalous intrigues are described as the subjects of plunder or of praise, according to the degree of skill shown in carrying them on. They consented, and Aubrey immediately mentioning his intentions to Lord Ruthveri, was surprised to receive from him a proposal to marry him. Flattered by such a mark of esteem from him, who, apparently, had nothing in common with other men, he gladly accepted it, and in a few days they had passed the circumnavigating waters.
Hitherto, Aubrey had had no opportunity of studying Lord Ruthven's character, and now he found that, though many more of his actions were exposed to his view, the results offered different conclusions from the apparent motives to his conduct. His companion was profuse in his liberality; the idle, the vagabond, and the beggar, received from his hand more than enough to meet their immediate wants. But Aubrey could not help remarking, that it was not upon the unfortunate, reduced to indigence by the misfortunes attendant upon him, that he bestowed his alms; these were sent from the door with hardly suppressing sneers; but when the profligate came to ask something, not to relieve his wonts, but to allow him to wallow in his lust, or to sink him still deeper in his iniquity, he was sent away with rich charity. This was, however, attributed by him to the greater importunity of the vicious, which generically prails over the retiring habits of the virtuous indigent. There was one circumstance about the charity of his Lordship, which was still more impressed upon his mind: all those upon whom it was bestowed, inevitably found that there was a curse upon it, for they were all either led to the scaffold, or sunk to the West and the East in abject miscry. At Brussels and other towns through which they passed, Aubrey was surprised at the apparent eagerness with which his companion sought for the centres of all fashion and vice; there he entered into the spirit of the law: he betted, and always gambled with success, excepl where the known sharper was his antagonist, and then he lost even more than he gained; but it was always with the same unchanging face, with which he generally watched the society around: it was not, however, so when he encountered the rash youthful novice, or the luckless father of a numerous family; then his very wish seemed contrary to the law—this apparent abstractedness of mind was laid aside, and his eyes sparkled with more fire than that of the cat whilst dallying with the half-decended mouse. In every town, he saw the formerly educated youth, torn from the circle he adjoined, cursing, in the soliloquy of a dungeon, the fate that had drawn him near to the reach of his fiend; whilst his father sat frantic, amidst the speaking lookings of mute hungry children, without a single fling of his late immense wealth, wherewith to buy even sufficient to satisfy their present craving. He took no money from the gambling table; but immediately lost, to the ruiner of many, the last gilder he had just snatched from the convulsively grasp of the innocent: this might but be the result of a certain degree of knowledge, which was not, however, capable of ousting the cunning of the more experienced. Aurey often wished to represent this to his friend, and beg him to resolutely renounce that charity and pleasure which proved the ruin of all, and did not tend to his own position; but he refused it–for every day he hoped his friend would give him some opportunity of speaking frankly and openly to him; however, this never occurred. Lord Ruthven, in his carriage, and amidst the various wild and rich scenes of nature, was always the same: his eye spoke less than his lip; and though Aubrey was near the object of his curiosity, he obtained no greater gratification from it than the coristant excitement of vainly wishing to break the mystery, which to his exalted imagination began to assume the appearance of something supernatural.
They soon arrived at Rome, and Aubrey for a time lost sight of his companions; he left them in daily attendance upon the morning circle of an Italian countess, whilst he went in search of the memorials of another almost deserted city. Whilst he was thus engaged, letters arrived from England, which he read with great impatience; the first was from his sister, bearing nothing but affection; the others were from his guardians, the latter astonished him; if it had before entered into his imagination that there was an evil power residing in his companion, these seemed to give him sufficient reason for the belief. His guardians insisted upon immediately laving his friend, and urged, that his character was dreadfully vicious, for that the possession of irresistible powers of seduction, rendered his lascivious habits more dangerous in society.
