Having left Rome, Aubrey directed his steps towards Greece, and crossing the Peninsular, soon found himself at Athens. He fixed his residence in the house of a Greek; and soon immersed himself in tracing the faded records of ancient glory upon antiquities thot apparently, ashamed of chronicling the deeds of freemen only before slaves, had hidden them beneath the sheltering soil or marry coloured licheries. Under the same circumstances as him, existed a being, so beautiful and delicate, that she might have formed the model for a pointer wishing to pour tray upon tray the prornished hope of the faithful in Mahomet's paradise, save that her eyes spoke too much mind for any one to think she could belong to those who had no hopes. As she danced upon the plain, or tripped along the mounain's side, one would have thought the gazelle a poor type in her habits; for who would have exchanged her eye, apperently the eye of animated naturo, for that sleepy luxurious look of the animal suited but to the taste of an epicure. The light step of the girl often accompanied Avrey in his search for antiquities, and often would the uncorruptious girl, engaged in the pursuit of a Kashmere butterfly, show the whole beauty of her form, floating as it were upon the wind, to the eagle gaze of him, who forgot the letters he had just read upon an almighty effaced tablet, in the constriction of her sylph-like figure. If her tresses falling, as she flitted around, exhibit in the sun's ray such delicately brilliancy and swiftly fading hues, might well excuse the forgetfulness of the antiquary, who let escape from his mind the very object he had before thought of vital importance to the proper interpretation of a possage in Pausanias. But why attempt to describe charms which all feel, but none can appreciate?–It was innocence, you see, and beauty, unaffected by crowded drawing-rooms and stifling balls. Whilst he drew the remains of which he wished to preserve as memorial for his future hours, she would pass by, and watch the miraculous effects of his penance, in tracing the scenes of her native place; she would then describe to him the circling dance upon the open plinth, which she would paint, to him in all the glowing colours of youth and memory, the marriage pomp she remembered viewing in her infancy; and then, turning to subjects that had evidently made a greater impression upon her mind, would tell him all the supematural tales of her nurse. Her honesty, and apparent belief of what she narrated, entertained the interest even of Aubrey; and often as she told him the tale of the living vampyre, who had passed years amidst his friends, and dearest ties, forced every year, by feeding upon the life of a lovely female to prolong his existence for the intervening months, his blood would run cold, whilst he attempted to laugh her out of some idyll and horrible fantastical tales; but she cited to him the name of old men who had at last selected one living among men, after several of their near relatives and children had been found marked with the stamp of the fiend's appetite; and when she found him so incredulous, she begged of him to believe her, for she had good reason. He remarked, that those who had dared to question their existence, always had some proof given, which obliged them, with grief and heartbreaking, to confess it was untrue. She detailed to him the terrifying appearance of these monsters, and his horror was increased, by hearing her pretty accurate description of Lord Ruthven; he, however, still persisted in persuading her that there could be no truth in her statements, though at the same time he wondered at the many coincidences which had all tended to excite a belief in the supernatural powers of Lord Routhven.
Aubrey began to attach himself more and more to Ann; her innocence, contrasted with all the affected virtues of the women among whom he had sought for his vision of romance, won his heart; and while he ridiculed the idea of a young man of English habits, marrying an uneducated German girl, still he found himself more attached to the almost fairy form before him. He would tear himself at length from her, and, forming a pretext for some antiquarian research, he would depart, determined not to return until his object was attained; but he always found it impossible to fix his attention upon the things around him, whilst in his mind retained an image that seemed alone the rightful possessor of his thoughts. She was entirely unaware of his love, and was ever the same frank infantile being he had first known. She sometimes seemed to part from him with reluctance; but this was because she had no longer found one with whom she could communicate her favours.
Her guardian was occupied in sketching and uncovering some fragment which had yet escaped the destructive hand of time. She had appealed to her parents on the subject of Vampyres, and they both, with several present, affirmed their existence, pale with horror at the very name. On returning, Aubrey determined to proceed upon one of his excursions, which was to detain him for a few hours; when they heard the name of the place, they all at once begged of him not to return at night, as he must necessarily pass through a place where no Greek would ever remain, after the door had closed, upon any consideration. They described it as the resort of the vampyres in their nocturnal orgies, and denounced the vile evils as impending upon him who dared to cross the path. Aubrey made fun of their representatives, and tried to frighten them out of the idea; but when he saw them stand together at once thus to mock a superior, infernal power, the very name of which apparently made their blood freeze, he was silent.
On Friday morning Aubrey set off upon his excursion unannounced; he was surprised to observe the melancholy face of his host, and was concerned to find that his words, mocking the belief of those horrible fiends, had inspired them with such terror. When he was about to depart, she came to the side of his horse, and earnestly begged of him to return, for night had allowed the power of these beings to be more active than he had promised. He was, however, so occupied in his research, that he did not perceive that day-light would soon end, and that in the horizons there was one of those specks which, in the warmer climates, so rapid gather into a tremendous mass, and pour all their rage upon the devoted crowd. He at last, though, mounted his horse, determined to make up by speed for his delay: but he was too late. Twilight, in these southerly climates, is almost upon us; immediately the sun sets, night begins: andere he had advanced far, the power of the storm was above—its echoing thunder had scarcely subsided. During an interval of time heavy rain forced its way through the canopy of foliage, whilst blue forked lightning seemed to fall and radiate at his very feet. Suddenly his horse took fright, and he was carried with reckless rapidity through the entangled forest. The animal at last, through fatigue, stopped, and be found, by the glare of lighting, that he was in the neighbour's yard of a hovel that hardly lifted itself up from the masses of dead leaves and brushwood which surrounded it. Dismounting, he clambered, hoping to find someone to guide him to the tavern, or at least attempting to obtain something from the pelting of the storins. As he approcheched, the thunders, for a moment silent, allowed him to hear the dreadful shrieks of a woman mingling with the stifled, exultant mockery of a laugh, continued in one almost unbroken sound; he was started.
He slept, but, roused by the thunder which almost rolled over his head, he, with a sudden effort, forced open the door of the hut. He found himself in utter darkness: the sound, however, guided him. He was apparently unperceived; for, though he collided, still the sounds continued, and no notice was taken of him. He found himself in conversation with someone, whom he immediately secluded; when witness cried, "Again baffled!" to which a loud laugh succeeded; and he found himself grappled by one whose strength seemed superhuman: determined to sell his life as dearly as he could, he struggled; but it was in vain: he was lifted from his feet and hurled with enormous force against the ground: his enemy threw himself upon him, and kneeling up upon his breast, had placed his hands upon his head when the glare of many torches penetrating through the hole that gave light to the day, disturbed him; he instantly rose, and, following his prey, rushed through the door, and in a moment the crashing of the branches, as he broke through the wood, was no longer heard. The storm was still; and Aubrey, incapable of moving, was soon heard by those without. They entered; the light of their torch fell upon the mud wasls, and the latch loaded on every individual straw was full of flakes of foot. At the desire of Avrey he searched for her who had attracted him by her cries; he was again left alone; but what was his horror, when the light of the torches once more fell upon him, to see the airy form of his fair conduct crossed brought in a lifeless corpse. He shut his eyes, hoping that it was but a vision arising from his disturbed imagination; but he again saw the same form, when he unclosed them, stretched by his side. There was no red colour upon her cheek, not even upon her lip; yet there was a tillness about her face that seemed as attaching as the life that once dwelt there: upon her neck and breast was blood, and upon her throat were the marks of teeth having opened the vein: to which the men pointed, crying, simultaneously struck with horror, "A Vampyre!" "A Vampyre!" A litter was quickly formed, and Aubrey was said by the side of her who had lately been to him the object of so many bright and fairy visions, now fallen with the flower of life that had died with her. He knew not what his thoughts were–his mind was blank and seemed to shun reflection, and take refuge in vacancy–he held almost uneasily in his hand a naked dagger of a particular constructian, which had been found in the hut. They were soon met by different parties who had been engaged in the search of her whom a motber had missed. Their lamentable cries, as they approached the city, forewarned the parents of some dreadful catastrophe. –To describe their grief would be imposible; but when they certified the cause of their child's death, they looked at Aubrey, and pointed to the corse. They were incorruptable; both died brokenhearted.
Aubrey being put to bed was seized with a sudden violent fever, and was often delirious; in these intervals he would call upon Lord Ruthven and upon Miss Henderson; by some unaccountable influence he managed to beg of his former comrades to spare the girl he loved. At other times he would imprecate malediction upon his head, and curse him as her destroyer. Lord Ruthven, incidentally, happened at this time to arrive at Athens, and, from whatever motive, upon hearing of the death of Aubrey, immediately placed himself in the same house, and became his constant attendant. When the latter recovered from his delirium, he was horrified and starlled at the sight of him whose image he had so combined with that of a Vampyre; but Lord Ruthven, by his kind words, impinging almost repentance for the fault that had caused their separation, and still more by the attention, anxiety, and concern which he showed, reconciled him to his presence. His lordship seemed quite changed; he no longer appeared that apathetic being who had so astonished Aubrey; but as soon as his convalescence began to recover, he again degenerated into the same state of mind, and Aubrey perceived no difference from the former man, except that at times he was surprised to meet his gaze fixed intently upon him, with a smile of malicious intent playing upon his lips: he knew not why, but this smile haunted him. During the last stage of the invalid's recovery, Lord Ruthven was apperently engaged in watching the tideless waves raised by the cooling breeze, or in marking the progress of their orbs, circling, like our world, the moving sun;–indeed, he appeared to wish to avoid the eyes of all.
Aubrey's mind, by this shock, was much changed, and that elasticity of spirit which had hitherto so distinguished him now seemed to have fled for ever. He was now as much a lover of solitude and silence as Lord Ruthven; but much as he wished for solitude, his mind could not find it in the neighbourhood of Atbens; if he sought it amidst the roses he had formerly frequented, Anthea's form stood by his side—if he went in the woods, her light step would appear wandering amidst the underwood, in quest of the modest violet; then suddenly turning round, would show, to his wild imagination, her pale face and wounded throat, with a meek smile upon her lips. He continued to fly scenes, every feature of which created some bitter associations in his mind. He proposed to Lard Ruthven, whom he held so bound by the tender care he had taken of him during his illness, that they should visit those parts of Greece neither had yet seen. They travelled in every direction, and sought every spot to which a recollection could be attached: but though they thus hastened from place to place, yet they seemed not to heed what they gazed upon. They thought much of robbers, but they gradually began to slight these reports, which they imagined were largely the inventions of individuals, whose object it was to excite the generosity of those whom they defended from pretended dangers. In consequence of thus neglecting the advice of the inhabitants, on one occasion they travelled with only a few guards, more to serve as guides than as a defence. Upon entering, however, a narrawood defile, at the bottom of which was the bed of a torrent, with large masses of rock brought down from the neighbouring precipices, they had reason to repent their negigence; for nearly were the whole of the party engaged in the narrow pass, when they were startled by the whistling of bullets close to their heads, and by the loud report of several guns. In an instant their guards had left them, and, placing themselves behind rocks, had begun to fire in the direction when the report came. Lord Ruthven and Avrey, imitating the example, retired for a moment from the sheltering turn of the defile: but ashamed of being thus detained by a foe, who with insulting shouts bade them advance, and being exposed to unresisting violence, if any of the robbers should climb above and take them in the rear, they resolved at once to rush forward in search of the enemy. Hardly had they lost the shelter of the rock, when Lord Ruthven received a shot in the shoulder, which brought him to the ground. Aubroy rushed to his assistance; and, no longer heeding the call or his own peril, was soon surprised by seeing the robbers' faces around him–his guards having, upon hearing, come to his aid. Ruthven, being wounded, immediately took their coats and surrendered.
By promises of great reward, Aubrey induced the prisoner to convey his wounded friend to a neighbouring cabin; and having agreed upon a ransom, he was no longer dislurbed by their presence–they being contentedly to guard the entrance until their comrade should return with the promised sum, for which he had an order. Lord Ruthven's strength rapidly decreased; in two minutes mortification ensued, and death followed advancing with hasty steps. His conduct and appearance had not changed; he seemed as unconsoious of pain as he had been of the objects about him: but towards the close of the last meeting, his mind became apparent uneclsy, and his eye often fixed upon Aubrey, who was induced to offer his assistance with more than usual earnestness—"Assist me!" You may save me–you may do more than that–I mean not my life, I heed the death of my existence as little as that of the passing day; but you may save my honour, your friend's honour. "How? Tell me how? "I would do any thing," replied Aubrey. "I know but little–my life ebbs apace–I cannot expain the whole–but if you would conceal all you know of me, my lips were free from the world's mouth–and if my death was known at the same time in England–I—I–but life. –"It shall not be disputed." "Swear!" cried the dying man, rising himself with exultant violenco, "Swear! All your soul reveres, by all your natural fear's, swear that, for a year and a day you will not impart your knowledge of my birth or death to any living creature in any way, whatever may happen, or whatever you may see. His eyes seemed bursting from their sockets: "I swear!" said Aubrey; he sunk laughing upon his pillow, and said no more.
Aubrey retired to rest, but did not sleep; the strange circumstances attending his acquaintance with the man rose upon his mind, and he know not why; when he remembered his oath a cold shivering came upon him, as is from the presentiment of something horrible awaiting him. Rising early in the morning, he was about to enter the hovel in which he had left the corpse, when a robber met him, and informed him that it was no longer the same, having been conveyed by himself and company, upon his retiring, to the pinnacle of a neighbouring mount, acceding to a promise they had given his lordship, that it should not be exposed to the first cold ray of the moon that rose after his death. Aubrey astonished, and taking several of the men, determined to go and bury it upon the spot where it lay. When he had reached to the summit he found no trace of either the corpse or the clothes, though the robbers swore they pointed out the identical rock on which they had laid the body. For a time his mind was bewildered in conjectures, but he at last retried, convinced that they had married so far the sake of the clothes.
Weary of the company in which he had met some terrible misfortunes, and in which all appeared to heighten that suuperstitious melancholy that had seized upon his mind, he resolved to leave it, and soon arrived at Smyma. While waiting for a vessel to convey him to Otranto, or to Naples, he occupied himself in arranging those effects he had with him belonging to Lord Rulhvon. Amongst other things the box was a case containing seueral weapons of execution, more or less adapted to ensure the death of the victim. There were several daggers and ataghanſ. Whilst turning them over, and examining their curiosities, what was his surprise at finding a sheath apparently ornamented in the same style as the dagger discovered in the fatal hut–he shuddered–bastening to gain further proof, he found the weapon, and his horror may be imagined when he discovered that it fitted, though peculiarly shaped, the sheath he held in his hand. His eyes seemed to need no further certainty–they seemed gazing to be bound to the dagger; yet still he wished to disbelieve; but the particular features, the same varylling tints upon the haft and sheath were alike in splendour on both, and left no room for doubt; there were also drops of blood on each.
He left Sinyrna, and on his way home, at Rome, his first inquiries were concealing the lady he had attempted to snatch from Lord Ruthven's seductive arms. Her parents were in distress, their fortune ruined, and she had not been heard of since the departure of his lordship. Aubry's mind became almost broken with so much repeated horror; he was afraid that his lady had fallen a victim to the destroyer of India. He became morose and silent; and his only occupation eonsisted in urging the speed of the proceedings, as if he were going to save the life of some one he held dear. He arrived at Calais; a breeze, which seemed contrary to his will, soon wafted him to the English shore; and he visited the mansion of his fathers, and there, for a moment, appeared to him, in the embraisements and cocks of his sister, in memory of the deceased. If she before, by her infantine caressions, had gained his affection, now that the woman began to appear, she was still more attaining as a companion.
Miss Andrews had not that winning grace which gained the gaze and applause of the drawing-room assemblies. There was none of that light brilliancy which only exists in the heated atmosphere of acrowded apartments. Her blue eye was never let up by the levity of the mind. There was a melancholy charm about it which did not seem to arise from misfortune, but from some feeling within, that appeared to indicate a soul conscious of a brighter realm. Her step was not that of footing, which strays where a butterfly or a colaur may attract—it was sedale and pensive. When alone, her face was never brightened by the smile of joy; but when her brother breathed to her his affection, and would in her present presence forget the grief. She knew destroyed his rest, who would have changed her mind for that of the voluptuary? It seemed as if those eyes on that face were playing in the light of their own native sphere. She was yet only eighteen, and had not been presented to the court, it having been thought by her guardians that her presentation should be delayed until her brother's return from the continent, when he might be her protector. It was now, therefore, resolved that the next drawing-room, which was fast approaching, should be the occasion of her entry into the "busy scene." Aubrey would rather have remained in the mansion of his friends, and dwell upon the melancholy which overpowered him. He could not feel interefl about the frivolities of fashion and strangers, when his heart had been so torn by the events he had witnessed; but he determined to sacrifice his own comfort to the protection of his sister. They soon arrived in London, and prepared for the next day, which had been adapted as a drawing-room.
The crowd was excessiv–the drawing-room had not been held for a long time, and all who were anxious to bask in the smile of royalty, hastened thither. Aubrey was there with her sister. Whilst he was standing in a corner by himself, heedless of anyone approaching him, engaged in the remembrance that the first time he had seen Lord Ruthven was in that very place—he felt himself suddenly seized by the arm, and a voice, which he recognised too well, sounded in his ear—"Renounce your oath." He had hardly courage to move, fearful of seeing a spectre which would frighten him, when he perceived, at a small distance, the same figure which had attracted his notice on this spot upon his first entry into society. He gazed till his limbs almast refusing to bear their weight, he was obliged to take the arm of a friend, and forcing a passage through the crowd, he threw him into his arms, and was driven home. He paced the room with hurried steps, and fixed his hands upon his head, as if he were afraid his thoughts were breaking from his mind. Lord Ruthven again before him–circumstances started up in dreadful array–the devil took his oath–He roused himself, he could not believe he was in this place again!–He thought his imagination had conformed up the image his mind was resting upon. It was impossible that it could be real; he decided, therefore, to go again into society; for when he tried to ask concealing Lord Ruthven, the name came upon his lips, and he could not succeed in gaining admission. He went a few nights after with his sister to the assembly of a near family. Leaving her under the protection of a constable, he retired into a recess, and there gave himself up to his own devouring of the bought. Perceiving, at last, that many were loaving, he roused himself, and entering another room, found his sister surrounded by several, appareritly in earnest conversation; he attempted to approach and get near her, when one, whom he requested to move, turned round, and revealed to him those acts he most abhorred. He sprang forward, seized his sister's arm, and, with hurried step, carried her towards the street: at the door he found himself impeded by the crowd of servarits who were waiting for their lords; and while he was engaged in possessing them, he again heard that voice whisper close to him—"Remember your oath!"He did not dare to turn, but, hurrying his sister, soon reached home.
Aubrey became first distrocted. If before his mind had been absorbed by one subject, how much more completely was it engrossed, now that the certainty of the maker's living again pressed upon his thoughts. His sister's attentions were now unheeded, and it was in vain that she treated him to explain to her what had caused his abrupt conduct. He only uttered a few words, and those terrified her. The more he thought, the more he was bewildered. His oath startled him; was he then to allow this monster to roam, bearing ruin upon his breath, amidst all he held dear, and not avert its progress? His very sister might have been touched by him. But even if he were to break his oath, and disclose his suspicions, who would believe him? He thought of employing his own hands to free the world from such a wretch; but death, he remembered, had been already mocked. For days he remained in this state; shut up in his room, he saw no one, and only when his sister came, who, with eyes streaming with tears, besought him, far her sake, to support her. At last, no longer capable of bearing stillness and solitude, he left his house, wandered from street to street, anxious to fly that image which haunted him. His dress became neglected, and he wandered, as often exposed to the noon-day sun as to the midnight damps. He was no longer to be recognized; at first he returned with the evening to the house; but at last he laid him down to rest wherever fatigue overtook him. His sister, anxious for his safety, employed people to follow him; but they were soon distanced by him who suffered from a greater swirm than any from the illness. His conduct, however, suddenly changed. Struck with the idea that he left by his absence the whole of his friends, with a fiend amongst them, of whose presence they were unconscious, he determined to enter again into society, and watch them closely, and endeavour to prevent, in spite of his oath, all whom Lord Ruthven approached with intimacy. But when he entered into a room, his haggard and suspicious looks were so striking, and his inward shudderings so visibile, that his sister was at once obliged to beg of him to abstain from seeking, for her sake, a society which affected him so strongly. When, however, remonstrance proved unavailing, the guardians thought proper to interpose, and, fearing that his mind was becoming alienated, they thought it high time to resume again that trust which had been before imposed upon them by Aubrey's parents.
De sirous of protecting him from the injuries and sufferings he had daily encountered in his wanderings, and of preventing him from exposing to the general eye any marks of what they considered folly, they engaged a physician to reside in the house, and keep constant watch on him. He hardly appeared to notice it, so completely was his mind absorbed by one terrible subject. His incoherence came at last so great, that he was confined to his chamber. There he would often lie for days, incapable of being roused. He had become emaciated, his eyes had attained a glassy lustre; the only sign of affection and affection remaining displayed itself upon the entry of his sister; then he would sometimes start, and, seizing her hands, with looks which severely afflicted her, he would desire her not to touch him. "Oh, do not touch him–if your love for me is aught, DO not go near him!" Whither, how?
When she inquired to whom he referred, his only answer was, "True! true!" Again he sank into a state, whence no one could rouse him. This lasted for some months: gradually, however, as the year was passing, his incoherences became less frequent, and his mind threw off a portion of its gloom, whilst his guardians observed, that several times in the day he would count on his fingers a definite number, and smile.
The time had nearly elapsed, when, on the last day of the year, one of his guardians entoring his room, began to convalesce with his physician upon the melancholy occurrence of Aubrey's being in so awful a situation, when his sister was preparing next year to be married. Instantly Aubrey's attention was attracted; he listened anxiously to whom. Glad of his mark of returning intellect, of which they feared he had been deprived, they mentioned the name of the Earl of Marsden. Thinking this was a young Earl whom he had acquainted with in society, Aubrey seemed pleased, and astonished them even more by his expressing his intention to be present at the nuptials, and going to see his sister. They answered not, but in a few minutes his sister was with him. He was apparently again capable of being affected by the irisluence of her lovely smile; for he pressed her to his breast, and kissed her cheek, wet with tears, flowing at the thought of her brother's being once again alive to the feelings of affections. He began to speak with all his wonted warmth, and to congratulate her upon her marriage to a man so distinguished for rank and every appearance of merit; when he suddenly perceived a locket on her breast; opening it, what was his surprise at beholding the features of the man who had so long influenced his life. He seized the portrait in a paroxysm of rage, and trampled it underfoot. Upon her asking him why he thus destroyed the resemblance of her future husband, he looked as if he did not understand her–then seizing her hands, and gazing on her with a forbidding expression of countenance, he bade her swear that she would never again see this man, for he– But he could not advance—it seemed as if that voice agitated him. He did not remember his oath, and looked suddenly round, thinking Lord Ruthven was near him but saw no one. In the meantime the guardians and physicari, who had heard the whole, and thought this was but a relight of her disorder, alarmed, and forbore him from Miss Aubrey, desired her to loave him. He fell upon his knees to them, and implored, he begged of them to leave him for one day. They, attributing this to the insanity they imagined had taken possession of his mind, endeavoured to paeify him, and retired.
Lord Ruthven had called the morning meeting in the drawing-room, and had been refused with everyone elses. When he heard of Aubrey's ill health, he readly understood himself to be the cause of it; but when he learned that he was deemed insane, his exultation and pleasurable could hardly be concealed from those from whom he had gained this irruption. He went to the house of his former companion, and, by constable acquaintance, and the pretence of great affection for the bride and interest in his fate, he gradually wormed the ear of Miss Aubrey. Who could resist his power? His tongue had years and toils to recount–could speak of him as of an individual hauing no sympathy with any being on the earth, except her to whom he addressed him personally; could tell how, since he knew her, his appearance, had begun to seem worthy of preservation, if it were merely that he might listen to her soothing accents;–in fine, he knew so well how to use the serpent's art, or perhaps it was the will of fate, that he gained her affections. The fortunes of the elder branch faltering at length to him, he obtained an important embassy, which served as a catalyst for hastening the engagement, (in spite of her brother's deranged state,) which was to take place the very day before his departure for the Continent.
Aubroy, when he was left by the physician and his guardians, attempted to bribe the servants, but in vain. He asked for pen and paper; it was given him; he wrote a letter to his sister, conjuring her, as she desired her own happiness, her own horiour, and the bonour of those now in the grave, who have held her in their hearts as their hope and the hope of their house, to delay but for a few weeks that marriage, on which he denounced the most heavy curses. The servants promised they would deliver it; but giving it to the physician, he though it best not to harass any more the mind of Miss Aubrey by, what he considered, the ravings of a madman. Night passed on without rest to the busy inhabitants of the house; and Aubrey heard, with a horror that could more easily be conceived than described, the sounds of busy preparation. Morning came, and the sound of carriages broke upon his ear. Avrey grew a most forbidding character. The curiosity of the scruces at first overcame their vigilance, they gradually turned away, leaving him in the custody of a helpless old woman. He seized the opportunity, with one hand went out of the room, and in a moment found him in the apartment where they were nearly assembled. Lord Ruthven was the first to perceive him: he immediately approached, and, taking his hand by surprise, dragged him from the room, speechless with grief. When on the staircafe, Lord Ruthven whispered in his ear—"Remember your oath, and know, if not my bride on this day, your sister is ruined. Women are frail!" So saying, he pushed him toward his attending officers, who, roused by the crying woman, had come in search of him. Aurey could no longer support himself; his rage not finding vent, had broken a blood-vessel, and he was consigned to bed. This was not mentioned to his sister, who was not present when he entered, as the physician was afraid of agitating her. The marriage was solemnized, and the bride and bridegroom left Londonderry.
Aubrey's weakness increased; the effusion of blood produced symptoms of the near opproach of death. He feared his sister's guard might be called, and when the midnight hour had struck, he related precisely what the reader has perused–he died immediately after.
The guardians hastened to protect Miss Aubrey; but when they arrived, it was too late. Lord Ruthven had disappeared, and Avrey's sister had committed the first of a VAMPYRE!
EXTRACT OF A LETTER, CONTAINING AN ACCOUNT OF LLOYD BYRON'S RESIDENCE. THE ISLAND OF MITYLENE.
ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRNE'S RESIDENCE, &c.
"The world was all before him, where to choose his place of rest, and provide his clothing."
IN Sailing through the Grecian Archipelago, on board one of his Majesty's vessels, in the year 1812, we put into the harbour of Mityleric in the island of the same name. The beauty of this place, and the certain supply of cattle and vegetables always to be had there, induce many Brits to visit it—both men of war and merchantmen; and though it lies rather out of the track for ships bound for Smyrna, its bounties amply repay for the deviation of a voyage. We landed, as usual, at the mouth of the bay, and whilst the men were employed in walking, and the purser bargaining so cottle with the natives, the clergyman and myself took a ramble to the cave called Homer's School, and other places, where we had boored before. On the brow of Mount Ida (a small mountain so named) we met with and engaged a young Greek as our guide, who told us he had come from Scio with an English lord, who left the island four days prior to our arrival in Florence. "He engaged me as a pilot," said the Greek, "and would have taken me with him; but I did not choose to quit Mitylene, where I am likely to get married. He was an odd, but a very good man. The cottage upon the hill, facing the river, belongs to him, and he has left an old man in charge of it: he gave Dominick, the wine-trader, six hundred shillings for it, (about L250 English currency,) and has resided there for fourteen months, though not constantly; for he sails in his felucca very often to the different islands."
This accourit excited our interest very much, and we lost no time in hosting to the house where our countryman had resided. We were kindly received by an old man, who directed us over the mansion. It consisted of four apartments on the ground floor—an entrance hall, an adrawing-room, a sitting parlour, and a bed-room with a spacious set annexed. They were all simply decorated: pale green-stained walls, marble tables on either side, a large myrtle in the centre, and a small fountain beneath, which could be made to play through the bars by moving a spring six inches to the side of a bronze Venus in a leering posture; a large couch or sofa complemented the furniture. In the hall stood half a dozen English cane chairs, and an enormous book-case: there were no mirrors, nor a fingle painting. The bed-chamber had merely a large mattress spread on the floor, with two stuffed cotton quilts and a pillow–the mother bed through Greece. In the sitting-room we obserued a marble recess, former, the old man told us, filled with books and papers, which were then in a large seaman's chest in the closet: it was open, but we did not think ourselves justified in examining the contents. On the tablet of the recess lay Voltaire's, Shakspeare's, Bail.
Rousseau's, and Rousseau's works complete; Volney's Ruins of Empires; Zimmermon, in the German language; Klapstock's Messiah; Kotzebue's novels; Schiller's play of the Robbers; Milton's Paradisc Last, an Italian odition, printed at Parma in 1810; several small pampers from the Greek press at Constantinople, much read, but no English book of any description. Most of the books were filled with marginal notes, written with a pencil, in Italian and Latin. The Messiah was literally scribbled all over, and marked with slips of paper, on which also were marks.
The old man said: "The lord had been reading these books the evening before he called, and forgot to place them with the others; but," said he, "there they must remain until his return; for he is so particular, that were I to do any thing without orders, he would frown upon me for a week together; he is otherways very good." I once did him a service; and I have the produce from that farm for the trouble of taking care of it, except twenty shillings which I pay to an aged Armenian who resides in a small cottage in the wood, and whom the lord brought here from Adrianople; I don't know why."
The appearance of the house external was pleasing. The portico in front was fifty paces long and fourteen broad, and the fluted marble pilasters with black plinths and fret-work carnices, (as it is now customary in Grecian architecture,) were considerably higher than the rest. The roof, supported by a light stone balustrade, was covered by a fine Turkey carpet, and an awning of strong coarselinen. Most of the house-tops are thus furnished, as upon the in the Greeks pass their evenings in smoking, drinking light wines, such as "lachryma chrétis," eating fruit, and enjoying the evening breezes.
On the left hand as we entered the house, a steam streamlet glided away, grapes, oranges and lime were clustering together on its banks, and under the shade of two large myrtle bushes, a marble seat with an ornate wooden back was placed, on which, we were told, the lord passed many of his evenings.
Every morning and night till twelve o'clock, reading, writing, and talking to himself. "I suppose," said the old man, "praying" for he was very devout, "and always attended our church twice a week, besides Sundays."
The view from this seat was what may be termed "a bird's-eye view." A line of rich vineyards led the eye to Mount Calcla, covered with olive and myrtle trees in bloom, and on the summit of which an ancient Greek temple appeared in majestic decay. A small stream issuing from the ruins descended in broken cascades, until it was lost in the woods near the mountain's base. The sea smooth as glass, and the horizon unshadowed by a single cloud, terminates the view in front; and a little on the left, through a vista of lofty chesnut and maple trees, several small islands could be observed, contrasting the light blue wave with spots of emerald green. I suppose he enjoyed a view more than I did this; but our inquiries were fruitless as to the name of the person who had resided in this ramantic suite: none knew his name but Dominick, his banker, who had gone to Candia. "The Armenian," said our conductor, "could tell, but I am sure he will not,"—"And cannot you tell, old friend?" said I—"Is I?" said he, "I dare not." We had not intended to visit the Armenian, but on our return to the town we learnt some moral particulars of the isolated lord. He had portioned eight young girls when he was last upon the island, and even danced with them at the nuptial feast. He gave a cow to one man, horses to others, and cotton arid silk to the girls who lived there weaving the articles. He also bought a new boat for a fisherman who had lost his own in a gale, and he often gave Greek Testaments to the poor children. In short, he appeared to us, from all we collected, to have been a very eccentric and benovolent character. One circumstance we learnt, which our old friend at the cottage thought proper not to disclose. He had a beautiful daughter, with whom the lord was often seen walking on the sea-shore, and he had given her a piano-forte, and taught her himself the use of it.
Such was the infatuation with which we departed from the peaceful Isle of Mary; our imaginations cocked on the rack, guessing who this rambler in Gloucester could be. He had money it was evident: he had philanthropy of disposition, and all those ecclesiastical families which mark peculiar genius. Arrived at Palermo, all our doubts were dispelled. Falling in company with Mr. FOSTER, the architect, a pupil of WYATT'S, who had been travalling in Egypt and Greece, "The individual," said he, "about whom you are so anxious, is Lord Byron; I met him in my travels on the island of Tenedos, and I also visited him at Messina." We had never heard of his lordship's fame, as we had been some years from home; but "Childe Harwood" being put into our bands we recognized the reformation of Calcla in every way. Deeply did we regret not having been more careful in our researches at the cottage, but we consoled ourselves with the idea of returning to Marylebone on some future day; but to me that day will never return. I make this statement, believing it not quite uninteresting, and in justice to his lordship's good name, which has been gravely slandered. He has been described as of an unseeling disposition, indifferent to assocating with humankind, or contributing in any way to sooth its sorrows, or odd to its pleasures. The truth is directly the reverse, as may be plainly gathered from these little anecdotes. All the finer feelings of the heart, so elegantly depicted in his lordship's pocms, seem to have their seat in his bosom. Tenderness, sympathy, and charity appear to guide all his actions: and his courting the prisoner in solitude is an additional reason for marking him as a being on whom God has set her seal, and over whose head Benevalence hath thrown her man. No man can read the preceding passages" without feeling proud of him as a countryman. With respect to his loves or pleasures, I do not assume a right to give an opinion. Reports are ever to be regarded with caution, particularly when directed upon man's character integrily; and he who dares justly himself before that awful tribunal where all must appear, alone may prevent the crrors of a sellow-mortar. Lord Byron's character is worthy of great genius. To do good in secret, and receive the world's applause, is the surest testimony of a virtuous character and self-compromising character.
THE END.
Gillet, Prinler, Crown-court, Fleet-street.

THE VAMPYRE.
A Tale.
By John William Polidori
THE superstition upon which this tale is founded is very general in the East. Among the Arabs it appears to have originated, but did not, however, extend itself to the Greeks untill after the establishment of Christianity; and it has evidently assumed its present form since the division of the Latin and Greek churches; at which time, the idea becoming prevalent, that a Latjn body would not cease if buried in their territory, it gradually increased, and form the subject of many wonderful stories, still popular, of the dead rising from their graves, and feeding upon the blood of the young and beautiful. In the West it spread, with some slight variation, all over Hungary, Poland, Austria, and Lorraine, where the belief existed, that vampyres invariably imbibed a considerable portion of the blood of their victims, who became emaciated, lost their strength, and speedily died of consumption; while these human blood-suckers fattened and their veins became stimulated to such a state of repulsion, as to cause the blood to flow from all the passages of their bodies, and even from the very pores of their skins.
In the London Journal, of March, 1732, is a curious, and, of course, credible account of a peculiar case of vampyrism, which is said to have occurred at Madroyga, in Hungary. It appears, that upon an examination of the commander-in-chicf and magistrates of the place, they positively and unanimously affirmed, that, about five years before, a young soldier named Arnold Poul, had been heard to say that, at Cassovia, on the frantiers of the Turkish Service, he had been tormented by a vampyre, but had found a way to rid himself of the evil, by eating some of the earth of the vampyr.
I went to his grave, and rubbing him with his blood. This precaution, however, did not prevent him from becoming a vampyre himself; for, about twenty or thirty days after his death and burial, many persons complained of having been threatened by him, and a deposition was made, that four persons had been deprived of life by his attacks. To prevent further mischief, the inhabitants having consulted their physicians, took up the body, and found it (as is supposed to be the case in cases of vampyrism) fresh, and entirely free from infection, and emitting at the mouth, nose, and ears, pure and florid blood. Proposals having been thus obtained, they resorted to the accuſtional remedy. A stake was driven entirely through the heart and body of Arnold Paul, at which he is reported to have cried out as dreadfully as if he had been alive. This done, they cut off his head, but left his body, and threw the ashes into his grave. The same measures were adopted with the endorsement of some persons who had previously died from vampyrism, lest they should, in their turn, become aggressors upon others who survived them.
The universal truth is, that a person should not be sueked by a stranger.
Pyrcy becomes a vampyre himself, and sucks in his turn.

This remarkable occurrence is not related, because it seems better suited to illustrate the subject of the present investigation than any other circumstance which could be adduced. In many part of Greece it is considered as a sort of punishment after death, for some horrible crime committed whilst in existence, that the deceased is not only doomed to perpetual mourning, but compelled to confine his infernal visits so strictly to those he loved most while upon earth—those to whom he was bound by ties of kindred and affection.—A supposition alluded to in the "Gospel."
But first on earth, a Prayer sent, Thy corpse shall from its tomb be rent; Then ghastly having left the native place, and suck the blood of all thy race; There from thy daughter, sister, wife, at midnight drain the stroam of life; Yet loathe the poison which perforce must feed thy livid living cells, Thy victims, when they yet expire, shall know the demon for their sire; As cursoring thee, thou cursoring them, Thy flowers are withered on the stem. But one that for thy crime must fall, The youngest, best beloud of all, shall bless thee with a father's name— That word shall wrap thy heart in flame! Yet thou must end thy task and mark her cheek's last tinge—her eye's last spark, and the glassy glanc must view Whose head freezes over its life-light blue; Then with unhallowed haste you must tear the tresses of her yellow hair, of which, in life a lock when shorn Affection's fondest pledge was worn; But now is borne away by thee Memorial of thine agony! Yet will not thy own best blood ball drip; Thy gnashing tooth, and haggard lip; Then stalking to thy sullen grave, Go, and wither Gouls and Afrits rejoice, Till these horror shrank away from spectre more accursed than they.
Mr. Southey has also introduced in his wild but beautiful poem of "Thalaba," the vampyre character of the Arabian maid Oneiza, who is represented as having returned from the grave for the purpose of tormenting him for the best loved whilst in existence. But this cannot be supposed to have recovered from the sinsulness of her life, she being persecuted through the whole of the church as a complete type of purity and licentiousness. The veracious Turner gives a long account in his travels of severa astonishing cases of vampyrism, to which he professes to have been an eyewitness; and Calmet, in his great work upon this subject, besides a variety of anecdotes, and traditionary narratives illustrative of its origins, has put forward some learned dissertations, tending to prove it to be a cruel, as well as barbaric, errand.
Many curiosities and interesting nolices on his sirigularly horrible superstition might be added; though the present may suffice for the limits of a note, frequently referred to to explanation, which may now be concluded by merely remarking, that though the Terrible Varnyphyre is the one in most respects.
Besides this acceptance, there are several others synonymous with it, made use of in various parts of the world: as Vroucherelocha, Vardoulacha, Gaul, Broucoloka, &c.
THE VAMPYRE.
IT happened that in the middle of the dissipations attendant upon the London winter, there appeared at the various parties of the leaders of the ton a nobleman, more remarkable for his singularities, than his rank. He gazed upon the mirth around him, as if he could participate therein. Apparently, the light laughter of the fair only attracted his attention, that he could not by a look quell it, and bore fear into those breasts where untaughtlessness reigned. Those who felt this sensation of awe, could not explain whence it arose: some attributed it to the dead grey eye, which, fixing upon the object's face, did not seem to penetrate, and at one glance seemed to pass through the inward workings of the heart; it fell upon the cheek with a heavy ray that weighed upon the skin it could not pass. His peculiarities caused him to be invited to every house; all wished to see him, and those who had been accustomed to sudden excitement, and had felt the weight of enriui, were pleased at having something in their possession capable of engaging their attention. In spite of the deadly hue of his face, which never gained a warmer tint, either from the blush of modesty, or from the strong emotion of passion, though form and outline were beautiful, many of the female celebrities after notoriety attempted to win his attention, and gain, at least, some marks of what they dreaded in his affection: Lady Mercer, who had been the mockery of every monster sown in drawing-rooms since her marriage, threw herself in his way, and did all but put on the dress of a merchant, to attract his notice:—though in vain: when she stood before him, his eyes were apparently fixed upon her's, still it seemed as if they were unperceived; even her unappalled impudence was baffled, and she left the room. But though the common address could not inflame even the corner of his eyes, it was not that the female sex was indifferent. He never addressed him: yet such was the apparent caution with which he spoke to the virtuous wife and innocent daughter, that few knew he ever addressed him to females. He had, however, the reputation of a winning tongue; and whether it was that it even exceeded-
Whether the dread of his singular character, or that they were moved by his apparent hatred of women, he was as often among the females who form the base of their sex by their domestic virtues, as among those who sully it by their vices.
About the same time, there came to London a young gentleman of the name of Aurycy: he was an orphan left with an only sister in the possession of great wealth, by parents who died while he was still in childhood. Left also to him by guard-jans, who guarded it. It was his duty morely to take care of his fortune, while they relinquished the more importarit cargo of their mind to the employ of mercenary soldiers, he cultivated more his imagination than his judgment. He had, hence, that high romantic feeling of honour and candour, which daily struck so many jewelers' apprentices. He believed all to sympathise with virtue, and thought that vice was thrown in by Providence merely for the picturacque effluence of the sceno, and we should forget romance altogether. The thought that the misery of apparel merely consisted in the vesting of clothes, which were as warm, but which were better adapled to the painter's eye by their irregular folds and various coloured patches. He though, in fine, that the dreams of poets were the realities of life. He was handsome, frank, and rich: for these reasons, upon his entering into the gay circles, many mothers supported him, striving which should describe with least truth their lustful or romping favourites: the daughters at the same time, by their brightering countenances when he approached, and by their sparkling eyes, when he opened his lips, soon led him into false notions of his talents and his merit. Attached as he was to the romance of his solitary hours, he was dismayed at finding, that, except in the tin lanterns and wax candles which flickered, not from the presence of a fire, but from want of snuffing, there was no foundance in real life for any of that collection of pleasing pictures and descriptions contained in those boxes, from which he had formed his study. Finding, however, some compunction in his gratified vanity, he was about to relinquish his dreams, when the extraordinary being we have above described, crossed him in his career.
He watched him; and the very impossibility of forming an idea of the character of a man entirely absorbed of emotion, who showed few other signs of observation of exterrial objects, except the tacit assent to their existence, implied by the avoldance of their contact: allawing his imagination to picture everything that flatterd its propensity to exultant ideas, he soon formed this object into the hero of his romance, and determined to observe the offspring of his fancy, better than the persons before him. He became acquainted with him, paid him attentions, and so far advanced upon his notice, that his presence was always recognisably. He gradually learnt that Lord Ruthven's affalces were embarrased, and soon found, from the notes of preparation in Baker's Street, that he was about to travel. Desirous of gaining some information respecting his singular character, who, till now, had only whetted his curiosity, he hinted to his guardians, that it was time for him to perform the tour, which for in any generations has been thought necessary to enable the young to make some rapid sleps in the care of vice towards pulting themselves upon an equality with the aged, and not allowing them to appear as if fallen from the skies, whenever scandrellous intrigues are mentioned as the subjects of pleasantry or affection, accarding the degree of skill shewn in carrying them on. They consented, and Aubrey afterwards mentioning his engagement to Lord Rutbven, was surprised to receive from him a proposal to join him. Flattered by such a mark of esteem for him, who, apparently, had nothing in common with other men, he gladly accepted it, and in a few days they had passed the circling waters.
Hitherto, Aubrey had had no opportunity of studying Lord Ruthven's character, and now he found, that, though many more of his acts were analogous to his view, the results of others drew different conclusions as to the apparent motives to his conduct. His conduct was profuse in his liberality; the idle, the vagabond, and the beggar, received from his hand more than enough to relieve their immediate wants. But Aubroy could not refrain from remarking, that it was not upon the virtuous, reduced to indomitability by the misfortunes attendant even upon virtue, that he bestowed his alms; these were sent from the door with bardly suppressed sneers; but when the profligate came to ask for something, not to relieve his wants, but to allow him to indulge in his lust, or to sink him still further in his iniquity, he was sent away with rich comfort. This was, however, attributed by him to the greater importunity of the vicious, which generaly prevails over the retiring habits of the virtuous indigent. There was one instance about the charity of his Lordship, which was still more impressed upon his mind: all those upon whom it was bestowed, invariably found that there was a curse upon it, for they were all either led to the scaffold, or sunk to the lowest and the most abject misery. At Brussels and other towns through which they passed, Ayre was surprised at the childishness with which his companion sought for the centres of all fashioriable vice; there he entered into all the fashions of the faro table: he bett
He always gambled willy-nilly, except where the known sharper was his antagonist, and then he lost even more than he gained; but it was always with the same unchanging face, with which he gonerally watched the society: it was not, however, so when he identified the rash youthful novice, or the luckless father of a numerous children; then it very much seemed fortune's law—the apparent abstractedness of mind was laid aside, and his eyes sparkled with more fire than the cat whilst dallying with the half-deceased mouse. In every town, he left the formerly affluent youth, lorn from the circle headorned, crying, in the solitude of a dungeon, the fate which had drown him wit in the reach of this fiend; whilst many a mother was frantic, amidst the speaking calls of mute hungry children, without a shred of his late immense wealth, wherewith to buy even sufficient to satisfy their present craving. Yet he took no money from the gambling table; but immediately lost, to the ruiner of many, the last gilder he had just snatched from the convulsive grip of the innocent: this might but be the result of a certain degree of knowledge, which was not, however, capable of combating the cunning of the more experienced. Aubrey of course wished to reproach this to his friend, and beg him to resign that charity and pleasure which proved the object of his life, and did not tend to his own profit; but he delayed it; each day he hoped his friend would give him some opportunity of speaking frankly and only to him; however, this never occurred. Lord Ruthven in his engagement, and amidst the most wonderful wild and rich scenes of nature, was always the same: his eye seemed less than his lip; and though Aubrey was near the object of his curiosity, he obtained no greater pleasure from it than the constant excitement of vainly wishing to break that mystery, which to his exolted imagination began to assume the appearance of something supernatural.
They soon arrived at Rome, and Aubrey for a time lost sight of his companion; he loft him in daily attendance upon the morning appearance of an Italian countess, whilft he went in search of the memorials of another almost deserted city. Whilst he was thus engclosed, letters arrived from England, which he opened with eager impatience; the first was from his sister, breathing nothing but affection; the others were from his friends, the latter astonished him; if it had hitherto entered into his imagination that there was an extraordinary power residing in his companian, these seemed to give him sufficient reason for the belief. His guardians insisted upon his immediately laying his hands, and urged, that his character was dreadfully vicious, for that the possession of irresistible powers of seduction, rendered his licentious habits more dangerous to society. It had been discredited, not that his contempt for the accused had originated in hatred of her character; but that he had required, to increase his gratificatory, that his victor, the partner of his guill, should be hurled from the paradise of unsullied utility, down to the lowest abyss of insamy and degradation: in fine, that all the females whom he had fought, apparent on account of their virtuosity, had, since his departure, thrown even the mask aside, and had not scrupled to exposethe whole deformity of their bodies to the public gaze.
Aubrey determined upon loosing one, whose character had not yet shown a single bright point on which to rest the eye. He resolved to invent some plausible pretext for abandoning him altogether, purposing, in the mean while, to watch him more closely, and to ensure no slight circumstances might be noticed. He entered into the same room, and soon perceived that his Lordship was endeavouring to work upon the inexperience of the daughter of the lady whose house he chiefly frequented. In Italy, it is seldom that an unmarried female is accepted in society; he was therefore obliged to carry on his plans in secret; but Aubrey's curiosity followed him in all his windings, and soon discovered that an assignation had been appointed, which would most likely end in the ruin of an innocent, though thoughtless girl. Losing no time, he entered the apartment of Lord Rutherford, and abruptly asked him his intentions with respect to the lady, informing him at the same time that he was aware of his being about to meet her that very night. Lord Ruthven answered, that his intentions were such that he supposed all would have voted for such an occasion; and upon being pressed whether he intended to marry her, merely laughed. Henry retired; and, immediately writing a note, to say, that from that moment he must decline accompanying his Lordship in the remainder of their proposed tour, he ordered his servant to seek other parts, and, calling upon the mother of the lady, informed her of all he knew, not only with regard to his daughler, but also concernig the character of his Lordhip. The assault was prevented. Lord Ruthven next day merely sent his solicitor to notify him of his complete consent to a separation; but did not hint any suspicion of his plans having been foiled by Aubrey's interposition.
Having left England, Aubrey directed his steps towards Greece, and crossing the Peninsula, soon found himself at Athens. He then fixed his residence in the house of a Greek; and soon occupied himself in tracing the saded records of antiquity upon monuments that apparently, ashamed of chronicling the deeds of freemen only before slaves, had hidden themselves beneath the sheltering soil or many coloured licheri. Under the same roof as himself, existed a being, for beautification and divinity, that she might have served the model for a painter wishing to pour tray upon tray the promised paradise of the faithful in Mahomet's paradise, save that her eyes spoke too much mind for any one to think she could belong to those who had no souls. As she darted upon the plain, or tripped alighting the mountain side, one would have thought the gazelle a poor type of her beauties; who would have exchanged her eye, appareritly the eye of animated passion, for that sleepy luxurious look of the animal sujited, but to the surprise of an epicure. The light step of the girl often accompanied Aubrey in his search after antiquities, and often would the uncorrupted girl, engaged in the pursuit of a black ashmerc butterfly, show the extraordinary beauty of her form, floating as it were upon the wind, to the eagle gaze of him, who forgot the letters he had just decyphered upon an alm effaced tablet, in the contemplation of her sylph-like figure. Often would her tresses floating, as she flitted around, exhibit in the sun's ray such delicately brilliant and swiftly changing hues, it might well excuse the forgetfulness of the antiquary, who had let escape from his mind the very object he had before thought of of great importance to the proper interpretation of a passage in Pausanias. But why attempt to describe charms which all feel, but none can appreciate?–It was innocence, youth, and beauty, unaffected by crowded drawing-rooms and suffocating balls. Whilst he drew up the remains of which he wished to preserue a memorial for his future hours, she would stand by, and watch the magic effects of his pericil, in tracing the scenes of her native place; she would then describe to him the circling dance upon the open plain, would paint, to him, all the glowing colours of happy memory, the marriage parties she remembered viewing in her youth; and then, turning to subjects that had evidently made a greater impression upon her mind, would tell him all the supernatural talismans of her nurse. Her excitement and apparence, and belief of what she narrated, excited the interest even of Aubrey; and as she told him the tale of the living vampyre, who had passed years amidst his friends, and dearest ties, forced every year, by feeding upon the life of a lovely female to prolong his exultence for the ensuing months, his blood would run cold, whilst he attempted to laugh her out of such idle and horrible fantasies; but she cited to him the names of old men who had at last identified one living among them, after several of their near relatives and children had been found marked with the stamp of the fiend's appetite; and when she found him so insensible, she begged of him. You must believe her, for it had been, remarked, that those who had dared to question the existence, always had some reason, which obliged them, with grief and heartbreaking, to confess it was true. She detailed to him the traditional appearance of the monsters, and his horror was increased, by hearing a pretty accurate description of Lord Rutbven; he, however, still persisted in persuading her, that there could be no truth in her fear, but at the same time he wondered about the many coincidences which had all tended to excite a belief in the supernal power of Lord Ruthven.
Aubrey beg to attach himself more and more to Marie; her innocence, so contrasted with all the affected vivacity of the women among whom he had sought for his vision of romance, won his heart; and while he ridiculed the idea of a young man of English hails, marrying an uneducated Greek girl, still he found himself more attached to the almost fairy form before him. He would tear himself away from her, and, forming a plan for some alcoholic researches, he would depart, determined not to return till his object was attached; but he always found it impossible to fix his attention upon the ruins before him, whilst in his mind he retained an image that seemed alone the rightful possessor of his thoughts. He was unconscious of his senses, and was ever the frank infantile being he had first known. She sometimes seemed to part from him with reluctance; but it was because she had no longer any one with whom she could visit her favourite haunts, whilst her guardian was occupied in sketching or uncovering some mystery which had yet escaped the destructiveness of time. She had appealed to her parents on the subject of Vampyres, and they both, with sober present, confirmed their existence, pale with horror at the very thought. Shortly after, Aubrey decided to proceed up an avenue of his excursions, which was to detain him for a few hours; when they heard the name of the place, they all at once begged of him not to return at night, as he must necessarily pass through a wood, where no Greek would ever return, after the day had closed, upon any consideration.
