THE VAMPYRE.
A Tale.
By John William Polidori
THE superstition on which this tale is founded is very general in the East. Among the Arabs it appears to be common: it did not, however, extend itself to the Greeks until after the establishment of Christianity; and it has evidently assumed its present form since the division of the Latin and Greek realms; at which time, the idea being prevalent, that a Latin body could not corrupt if married in their territory, it gradually increased, and became the subject of many wonderful stories, still extant, of the dead rising from their gravestones, and feeding upon the blood of the young and beautiful. In the West it spread, with some slight variation, all over Hungary, Poland, Austria, and Lorraine, where the belief existed, that vampyres invariably imbibed a certain portion of the blood of their victims, who invariably became emaciated, lost their strength, and speedily died from consumptions; whilst these human blood-suckers fattened, and their veins became distended to such a state of repletion, as to cause the blood to flow from all the passages of their bodies, and from the very pores of thoir skins.
In the London Journal, of March, 1732, is a curious, and, of course, credulous account of a peculiar case of vampyrism, which is supposed to have occurred at Madreyga, in Hungary. It appears, that upon an examination of the commander-in-chief and magistrates of the place, they positively and unanimously affirmed, that, about five years before, a certain Heyduke, named Arnold Paul, had borne witness to say that, in Cassovia, on the frontiers of the Russian Service, he had been tormented by a vampyre, but had found a way to rid himself of the evil, by eating some of the earth out of the vampyr's grave, and rubbing himself with his blood. This precaution, however, did not prevent him from becoming a vampyre himself; for, about twenty-one or thirty days after his death and burial, many persons complained of having been tormented by him, and a deposition was made, that several persons had been deprived of their livelihood by his attack. To prevent further mischief, the inhabitants having extinguished their fires, searched up the body, and found it (as is supposed to be usual in cases of vampirism) fresh, and entirely free from corruption, and emitting at the mouth, nose, and cars, pure and florid blood. Proof having been thus obtained, they resorted to the admitted remedy. A stake was driven entirely through the heart and body of Arnold Pclul, at which he is reported to have died out as dreadfully as if he had been alive. This done, they cut off his head, buried his body, and threw the ashes into his grave. The same measures were adopted with the oarses of those persons who had previously died from vampyrism, lest they should, in their turn, become agents upon others who survived them.
The universal belief is, that a person sucked by a vampyre becomes a vampire himself, and sucks in his turn.
Chief bailiff.
The monstrous rodomontade is here related, because it seems better adapted to the subject of the present observations than any other instance which could be adduced. In many parts of Europe it if considered as a sort of punishment after death, for some horrible crime committed whilst in existence, the deceased was not only doomed to vampyrise, but compelled to confine his infernal visitations solely to the beings he loved most while upon earth—the ones to whom ho was bound by ties of duty and affection.—A supposition alluded to in the "Gentleman."
But first on earth, as Vampyre sent, Thy corse must from its roots be rent; Then ghastly haunt the native place, and suck the blood of all thy creatures; There fro thy daughter, sister, wife, At midnight drain the stream of life; Yet wait until the banquet which perforce must feed thy livid living corse, Thy victims. If they yet expire, shall know the doom for their sire; as cursing thee, thou cursing them, thy flowers are withered on the stem. But one that for thy crime must fall, The youngest, best beloved of all, Shall leave thee with a father's name—That word shall wrap thy heart in shame! Yel, thou must end thy task and mark the cheek's last tinge, the eye's last spark, and the mouth's glassy glarice must vanish, Which freezes all living things blue. Then with unhallowed hand she tore the tresses from her yellow hair, of which, in half a lock when shorn Affection's fondest pledge was worn; But now is stripped away by thee Memorial of thine agony! Yet will thy own best blood shall drip; Thy gnashing tooth, and haggard face; Then stalking to thy sullen grave, Go, and with Gouls and Angles rave, Till these in horror shrink away from spectre more acrimonious than they.
Mr. Southey has so introduced in his wild but beautiful poem of "Thrice," the vampyrecords of the Arabian maid Oneiza, who is reputed as having retumed from the grave for the purpose of tormenting him she best loved while in existence. But this cannot be supposed to have resulted from the sinfulness of her life, she being presented throughout the whole of the tale as a complete type of purifying innocence. The veracious Tournesort has had a long acquaintance in his travel of some astonishing cases of vampirism, to which he pretends to have been an eyewitness; and Metcalf, in his great work upon this subject, besides a richness of anecdotes, and traditionary narratives illuminative of its effects, has put forth some malicious dissortations, tending to prove it to be a classical, as well as barbarian error.
Many curious and interesting notices on this singularly horrible occurrence will be added; but the present may suffice for the limits of a note, necessarily subjected to explication, and which may now be concluded by merely remarking, that although the term Vampyrro is the one in most general application, there are several others synonymous with it, made use of in various parts of the world: as Vroucolocha, Vardoula, Goul, Broucoloka, &c.
THE VAMPYRE.
IT happened that in the midft of the dissensions attendant upon a London winter, there appeared at the various meetings of the leaders of the regiment a nobleman, more remarkable for his singularities, than his rank. He gazed upon the mirth surrounding him, as if he could not participate therein. Apparently, the light laughter at the fair only attracted his attention, that he might by a look quell it, and throw fear into those breasts where thoughtless neglect resided. Those who felt this sensation of awe, could not explain whence it arose: some attributed it to the dead grey eye, which, fixing upon the object's face, did not seem to penetrate, and at one glance to pierce through to the inward workings of the cart; but fell upon the cheek with a leaden ray that weighed upon the skin. It could not pass. His pecuniary interests caused him to be summoned to every house; all wished to see him, and those who had been accustomed to a most excited excitement, and now felt the weight of disappointment, were pleased at having something in their presence capable of engaging their attention. In spite of the decently hued hue of his face, which lately gajned a warmer tint, either from the blush of modesty, or from the strong emotion of passion, though its form and outline were still beautiful, many of the female hunters after riotary attempted to win his attentions, and show, at least, some marks of what they might term affection: Lady Mercer, who had been the mockery of every woman shewn in drawing-rooms since her marriage, threw herself in his way, and did all but put on the dress of a merchant, to attract his notice:–though invain: when she stood before him, though his eyes were apparently fixed upon her's, still it seemed as if they were unperceived;–even her unappalled indignation was baffled, and she left the room. But though the common adultress could not influence even the guidance of his eyes, it was not that the female sex was indifferent to him: yet such was the apparent caution with which he spoke to his virtuous wife and innocent daughter, that few knew he ever addressed himself to females. He had, however, the reputation of a winning tongue; and whether it was that it even overcame the dread of his singular character, or whether they were moved by his apparent hatred of vice, he was as often among those females who form the base of the sex by their domestic virtues, as among those who sully it by their vices.
At the same time, there came to London a young gentleman of the name of Aubrey: he was an orphan left with an only sister in the possession of great wealth, by parents who died whil he was yet in childhood. Lured also to himself by guardians, who thought it their duty merely to take care of his fortune, while they relinquished the more important charge of his mind to the care of mercenary subalterns, he cultivated more his imagination than his judgment. He had, however, that high romantic feeling of honour and candour, which daily ruins so many milliners' apprentices. He believed himself to sympathise with the cause, and thought that violence was thrown in by Providence merely for the picturesque effluence of the scene, as we see in romances: he thought that the misery of a cottage merely consisted in the vesting of cloths, which were as warm, but which were better adapted to the painter's tastes by their irregular folds and various coloured patches. He thought, in fine, that the dreams of poets were the realities of life. He was handsome, frank, and rich: for these reasons, upon his entering into the gay circles, many molhers surrounded him, striving which they could describe with least truth their languishing or romping favourites: the daughlers at the same time, by their brightening countenances when he approached, and by their sparkling eyes, when he opened his lips, soon led him into their riotions of his talents and his merit. Attached as he was to the romance of his solitary hours, he was startled at finding that, except in the lace and wax candles which fluttered, not from the prescence of air, but from want of snuffing, there was no faundation in real life for any of that collection of pleasing pictures and descriptions contained in those volumes, from which he had formed his study. Firiding, however, some compensation in his gratified vanity, he was about to relinquish his dreams, when the extraordinary being we have above described, crossed him in his path.
He watched him; and the very possibility of forming a judgment of the character of a man entirely absorbed in himself, who gave few other marks of his observatian of extemal objects, than the tacit assent to their existence, implied by his avoidance of their conduct: allowing his imagination to picture every thing that flatter its propensity to extravagant ideas, he regarded this object as the hero of a romance, and determined to observe the offspring of his passion, rather than the person before him. He became acquainted with him, paid him attentions, and so far advanced upon him that his presence was always recognised. He gradually learnt that Lord Ruthven's affairs were involved, and soon found, from the notes of preposition in Baker's Street, that he was about to travel. Defendant of gaining some iriformation respecting this singular character, who, till now, had only whetted his curiosity, he intimated to his guards that it was time for him to perform the tour, which for many generations has been thought necessary to enable the young to take some preliminary steps in the career of vice towards putting themselves up an equality with the aged, and thus allowing them to appear as if fallen from the skies, when certain scandalous intrigues are mentioned as subjects of pleasantry or of praise, according to the degree of skill shewn in carrying them on. They consented, and Avrey immediately communicating his intentions to Lord Ruthven, was surprised to receive from him a proposal to join him. Flattered by such a mark of esteem for him, who, apparently, had nothing in common with any other man, he gladly accepted it, and in a few days they had passed the circling waters.
Since then, Aubrey had had no opportunity of studying Lord Ruthven's character, and now he found, thither, many more of his own.
Although the circumstances were analogous to his view, the results offered different conclusions from the appartenances to his conduct. His companion was profuse in his liberality; the inmates, the vagabond, and the beggar, received from his hand more than enough to relieve their immediate wants. But Aury could not avoid remarking, that it was not upon the virtuous, reduced to indigence by the misfortunes attendant even upon family, that he bestowed his alms; these were sent from the door with hardly suppressed sneers; but when the profligate came to ask for meeting, not to relieve his wants, but to cudgel him to wallow in his lust, or to sink still deeper in his iniquity, he was sent away with rich charity. This was, however, attributed by him to the greater importunity of the viciours, which generally prevails over the retiring bashfulness of the virtuous indigent. There was one peculiarity about the chority of his Lordship, which was still more impressed upon his mind: all those upon whom it was bestowed, inevitably knew that there was a curse upon it, for they were all either led to the scaffold, or sunk to the lowest and the most abject misery. At Brussels and other towns through which they passed, Aubrey was surprised at the apparent eagerness with which his companion went for the centres of all possible vice; that he entered into all the spirit of the faro table: he betled, and always gambled with success, except where the known sharper was his antagonist, and then he lost even more than he gained. But it was always with the same unseeing face, with which he generally watched the society around: it was not, however, so when he accompanied the rash youthful novice, or the luckless father of a small family; the very wish seemed forune's law—this apparent abstractedness of mind was laid aside, and his eyes sparkled with more fire than the eyes of the cat whilst dallying with the half-dead mouse. In every town, he left the formerly asfluent youth, torn from the circle he adorned, cursing, in the solitude of a dungeon, the folly that had drawn him into the reacb of this fury; whilst mona a sather sat frantic, under the spoaking look of mutinous children, without a single farthing of his late immaculate wealth, wherewith to buy even sufficient to satisfy their present craving. Yet he took no money from the gambling table; but immediately lost, to the surprise of many, the last gilder he had just snatch from the convulsive grasp of the innocents: this could not be the result of a certain degree of knowledge, which was not, however, capable of outlasting the cunning of the more experienced. Aubrey often wished to represent himself to his friend, and beg him to resign that charity and pleasure which had proved the ruin of all, and did not tend to his own interests; but he delayed it–for each day he hoped his friend would give him some opportunity of speaking frankly and affectionately to him; but, wever, this never occurred. Lard Ruthven in his carriage, and under the variably wild and rich conditions of scenery, was always the same: his eye spoke louder than his lip; and though Aubrey was near the object of his curiosity, he obtained no greater gratification from it than the constant excitement of young wishing to break that mystery, which to his excited imagination began to assume the appearance of something supernaturol.
They soon arrived at Rome, and Aubrey for a time lost sight of his companion; he left his daily attondance upon the morning circle of an Italian cantoness, whilst he went in search of the memorials of another almost deserted locality. Whilst he was thus engaged, letters arrived from England, which he opened with eager admiration; the first was from his sister, bearing nothing but affeclion; while others were from his guardians, the Attraction astonished him; if he had before entered into his imagination that there was an evil power resident in his companion, these seemed to give him sufficient reason for the belief. His guardians insisted upon his immediately leaving his position, and urged, that his characler was dreadful and vicious, for that the possession of irresistable powers of seduction, rendered his licentious habits more dangerous to society. It had been discovered that his contempt for the adultress had not originated in hatred of her character; but that he had required, to enhance his gratification, that his victim, the partner of his jealousy, should be hurled from the pinnacle of unsullied virtue, down to the lowest clash of insamy and degradation: in fine, that all the serials whom he had sought, apprentently on account of their virtue, had, since his departure, thrown even the mask aside, and had not scrupled to expose the whole deformity of their vices to the public gaze.
Aubrey determined upon leaving one, who was character had not yet shown a single good point on which to rest the eye. He resolved to invent some plausible pretext for abandoning him altogether, purposing, in the mean while, to watch him more closely, and to let no slight circumcisions pass unnoticed. He entered into the same room, and there perceived that his Lordship was endeavouring to work upon the indiscretion of the daughter of the lady whose house he chiefly frequented. In Italy, it is usual that an unmarried woman is met with in society; he was thus obliged to carry on his plans in secret; but Aubrey's eye followed him in all his windings, and soon discovered that an assignation had been appointed, which would surely end in the ruin of an innocent, though thoughtless girl. Losing his lime, he entored the apartment of Lord Ruthven, and immediately asked him his intents with respect to the lady, informing him at the same time that he was aware of his being about to meet her that night. Lord Ruthven answered, that his interests were such as he supposed they would have upon such an occasion; and upon being pressed whether he intended to marry her, he almost laughed. Aubroy retired; and, immediately writing a note, to say, that from that moment he must decline acccomparishing his Lordship in the remainder of their proposed tour, he ordered his servant to seek other apartments, and colling upon the mother of the lady, inform her of all he knew, not only with regard to her daughter, but also concerning the character of his lordship. The assignation was preverited. Lord Ruthven next day merely wrote to his servant to notify his complete assent to a separation; but did not hint any suspension of his plans having been foiled by Aubrey's interposition.
Having left Rome, Aubrey directed his steps towards Greeco, and crossing the Peripatetic, soon found himself at Athenaeum. He then lodged his belongings in the house of a Greek; and soon occupied himself in trawling the faded records of ancient glory upon monuments that apparently, ashamed of chronicling the deeds of freemen only against their slaves, had hidden themselves beneath the sheltering soil or many coloured leaves. Under the same roof as himself, existed a being, so beautiful and delicate, that she might have formed the model for a painler wisbing to pour tray and carvass the promised hope of the poor in Mahomet's parodise, except that her eyes spoke too much mind for any one to think she could belong to those who had no souls. As she danced upon the plain, or tripped along the mountain's side, one would have thought the girl a poor type of her beaulies; for who would have exchanged her eye, apporently the eye of an insane naturc, for that sleepy luscious look of the animal suited but to the taste of an epiphany. The light step of Miss Beeton accompanied Aubrey in his search after antiquities, and often would the uncoriscious girl, engaged in the pursuit of a Kashmere butterfly, show the whole body of her form, floating as though were upon the wind, to the eagle gaze of him, who forgot the letters he had decyphered up an indeciphered tablet, in the contemplation of her sylph-like form. Often would her curls falling, as she flitted about, and being in the sun's ray such delicately brilliant and swiftly fading hues, it might well excuse the forgetfulness of the antiquary, who let escape from his mind the very object he had before thought of vital importanceto the proper interpretation of a passage in Pausanias. But why attempt to describe charms which all feel, but none can appreciate?–It was innocence, youth, and beauty, unaffected by crowded drawing-rooms and stifling balls. Whilst he drew those remains of which he wished to preserve a mernorial memory for future hours, she would stand by, and watch the magic effects of his paint, in tracing the scenes of her native place; she would then describe to him the circling clouds upon the open plain, would paint, to him in the glwing colours of happy memory, the marlage pomp she remembered viewing in her infancy; and then, turning to matters that had evidently made a greater impression upon her mind, would tell him all the supernatural tales of her nurse. Her earnestness and apparent fear of what she described, aroused the interest even of Aubrey; and often as she told him the tale of the lying murderer, who had spent years amidst his friends, and dearest ties, forced every year, by feeding upon the life of a helpless female to prolong his existence for the ensuing months, his blood would run cold, whilst he attempted to laugh her out of such idle and horrible fantasies; but she cited to him the names of old men who had at last detected him living among themselves, after several of their near relatives and children had been found marked with the stamp of the fiend's appetite; and when she found him so incredulous, she begged of him to believe her, for it had been remarked, that those who had dared to question their existence, always had some proof given, which compelled them, with great and heartbreaking, to confess that it was true. She detailed to him the tradional appearance of these monsters, and his horror was increased, by hearing a pretty accurate description of Lord Ruthven; he, however, still persisted in persuading her, that there could be no truth in her fears, but at the same time he wondered at the many coincidences which had all tended to excite a belief in the supernatural power of Lord Russell.
Aubrey began to attach himself more and more to Marie; her innocence, so contrasted with all the affected virtues of the women among whom he had sought for his vision of romance, won his heart; and while he ridiculed the idea of a young man of English habits, marrying an uneducated Greek girl, he found himself more attached to the almost fairy form before him. He would tear himself away from her, and, making a plan of antiquarian research, he would depart, determined not to return until his object was attained; but he always found it impossible to fix his attention upon the ruins around him, while in his mind he obtained an image that seemed alone the right hand posse of his object. She was unconscious of his love, and was ever the same frank infantile creature he had first known. She always seemed to part from him with reluctance; but this was because she had no longer any one with whom she could visit her favourite haunts, whilst her guard was occupied in sketching or uncovincing some frogmen which had yet escaped the destructive hand of time. She had appeaused to her parents on the subject of Vampyres, and they, with several present, affirmed her accusation, pale with horror at her very name. Soon after, Aubrey determined to proceed upon one of his excursions, which was to detain him for a few hours; when they heard the name of the place, they all at once begged of him not to return at night, as he must necessarily pass through a wood, where no Greek would ever remain, ofter the day had elapsed, upon any consent. They described it as the resort of the vain and nocturnal orgies, and denounced the most heavy evils as impending upon him who dared to cross their path. Aubrey made light of their representations, and tried to laugh them out of the room; but when he saw them shudder at his daring to mock a superior, inferrial power, the very name of which apparently made their hearts freeze, he was silent.
Next morning Aubrey set off upon his excursion unattended; he was surprised to observe the melancholy face of his host, and was concerned to find that his words, mocking the belief of those horrible fiends, had infpired them with such terror. When he was about to depart, she came to the side of his horse, and earnestly begged of him to return, for night allowed the power of these beings to be put in action; but he refused. He was, however, so occupied in his work, that he did not perceive that day-light would soon end, and that in the meantime there was one of those spasms which, in the warmer climates, so rapidly burst into a tremendous riot, and pour all their rage up upon the devoted classes. He at last, however, mounted his horse, determined to make up by speed for his delay: but it was too late. Twilight, in those other climates, is almost unknown; immediately the sun sets, the storm begins: and before he had advanced far, the power of the storm came abve—its echoing thunders had hardly an interval of rest—a thick heavy cloud forced its way through the canopying foliage, whilst the blue socked masses seemed to fall and radiate at his very feet. Suddenly the horse took fright, and ho was carried with dreadful rapidity through the entongled forest. The animal at last, through fury, stopped, and he found, by the glare of lightning, that it was in the neighbourhood of a hovel that hardly lifted itself up from the masses of dead leaves and brushwood which surrounded it. Dismounting, he approached, hoping to find someone to guide him to the town, or at least to obtain shelter from the pushing of the storm. As he approached, the thunders, for a moment silent, allowed him to hear the dreudful shrieks of a woman mingling with the fifled, exultant mockery of a laugh, which continued in one almost unbroken sound; he was startled: but, used by the thunder which again roled over his head, he, with a great effort, forced open the door of the house. He found himself in utter darkness: the sound, however, guided him. He was apparently unperceived; for, though he called, till the services continued, and no notice was taken of him. He came himself in contact with someone, whom he immediatly seized; when a voice cried, "Again baffled!" to which a loud laugh succeeded; and he felt himself grappled by one whose strength seemed superhuman: determined to save his life as dearly as he could, he struggled; but it was in vain: he was lifted from his feet and hurled with enormous force against the ground: his enemy threw himself upon him, and kneeling upon his breast, had placed his hands. Up in his throat–when the glore of many torches penetrating thrugh the wood that gave light in the day, disturbed him–he insensibly rose, and, leaving his prey, rushed through the door, and in that moment the crashing of the branches, as he broke through the wood, was no longer heard. The storm was now still; and Aubrey, incapable of moving, was soon heard by the crowd howling about. They entered; the light of their torches fell upon the mud walls, and the batch loaded on every individual straw with heavy flakes of soot. At the house of Aubrey they searched for her who had attracted him by her cries; he was again left in darkness; but what was his horror, when the light of the torches once more burst upon him, to perceive the airy farm of his fair conduetress bordered in a lifeless corse. He closed his eyes, hoping that it was just a vision arising from his disturbed imagination; but he again saw the same form, when he unclosed them, stretched by his side. There was no blood upon her face, nor upon her lip; yet there was a stillness about her face that seemed almost as attaching as the life that once dwelt there:–upon her head and breast was blood, and upon her throat were the marks of teeth having entered the vein:–to this the men rushed, crying, and simultaneously struck with horror, "A Vampyre!" "A Vampyre!" A riot was quickly formed, and Avrey was laid by the side of her who had lately been to the object of so many bright and happy vislons, now filled with the flow of life that had died with her. He know not what his thoughts were–his mind was benumbed and seemed to lapse into reflection, and take refuge in vacancy–he held almost urically in his hand a naked dagger of a particular construction, which had been found in the but. They were soon met by diffrent parties which had been engaged in the search of her husband whom a miller had missed. Their lainentable cries, as they approached the city, forewarned the parents of some dreadful calastrophe. –To describe their grief would be impossible; but when they ascertained the cause of their child's death, they looked at Aubrey, and pointed to the corse. They were inconsolable; broken-hearted.
Aubrey being put to bed was seized wit a most violent sever, and was for some time delirious; in these intervals he would call upon Lord Rutbven and upon Ianthe; by some unaccountable combination he would beg of his former companian to spare the being he loved. At other times he would imprecate remarks upon his head, and curse him as her thief. Lord Ruthven, chanced at this time to arrive at Athens, and, from whatever recollection, upon hearing of the state of Aubrey, immediately placed himself in the same house, and became his constant attendant. When the latter recovered from his delirium, he was horrified and startled at the sight of him. [SUBJECT OF OBJECTION.] He had now combined with that of a Vampyre; but Lord Ruthven, by his kind words, implying first repentance for the foult that had caused their separation, and still more by the affection, anxiety, and care which he showed, so reconciled him to his presence. His lordship seemed quite changed; he no longer appeared that similar being who had so infuriated Aubrey; but as soon as his convalescence began to be rapid, he again gradually retired into the same state of mind, and Aubrey perceived no difference from the former man, except that at times he was surprised to meet his gaze fixed intently upon him, with a smile of malicious expression playing upon his lips: he knew not why, but this smile haunted him. During the last stag of the invalid's recovery, Lord Ruthven was apparently engaged in watching the tideless waves raised by the cooling breeze, or in marking the progress of those orbs, circling, like our world, the moveless surface;–indeed, he appeared to wish to avoid the eyes of all.
Aubrey's mind, by this shock, was much weakened, and that elasticity of spirit which had once so distinguished him now feemed to have fled for ever. He was now as much a lover of solitude and silence as Lord Ruthven; but much as he wished for solitude, his mind could not find it in the neighbourhood of Athens; if he sought it amidst the ruins he had so memorably frequented, Anthea's form stood by his side—if he found it in tbe woods, her light step would appear wandering amid the underwood, in quest of the modest violet; and, suddenly turning round, would show, to his wild imagination, her pale face, and wounded lips, with a meek smile upon her lips. He determined to fly scenes, every feature of which created such bitter association in his mind. He proposed to Lord Ruthven, to whom he held himself bound by the tender care he had taken of him and his family, that they should visit the parts of Greece neither had yet seen. They travelled in every direction, and sought every spot to which a recollection could be attached: but though they continually moved from place to place, yet they seemed not to heed what they gazed upon. They heard much of robbers, but they gradually began to slight these reports, which they imagined were only the invention of individuals, whose interest it was toexcite the generalosity of those whom they defended from pretended dangers. In consequence of their neglect of the advice of the inhabitants, on several occasions they travelled with only a few guards, more to serve as guides than as a regiment. Upon entering, however, a narrow depression, at the bottom of which was the bed of a torrent, with large masses of rock cascading down from the neighbouring precipices, they had reason to repent their negligence; for scarcely were the whole of the party engaged in the narrow pass, when they were startled by the whistling of bullets close to their heads, and by the echoed report of several shots. In an instant the guard had loft the m, and, placing themselves behind rocks, had begun to fire in the direction from which the report came. Lord Ruthven and Aubrey, imitating their example, retired for a moment behind the sheltering wall of the defile: but on account of being temporarily detained by a foe, who with insulting language bade them advance, and being exposed to continuing slaughter, if any of the robbers should burst in and take them in the rear, they decided at once to rush forward in search of the enemy. Hardly had they lost the shelter of the rail, when Lord Ruthven received a shot in the shoulder, which brought him to the ground. Aubrey hastened to his assistance; and, no longer heeding the call or his own peril, was soon surprised by seeing the robbers' faces approaching him–his guards having, upon Lord Ruthven's being wounded, immediately thrown up their arms and surrendered.
By promises of great reward, Aubrey soon induced them to convey his wounded friend to a neighbouring castle; and having agreed upon a ransom, he was no longer disturbed by their conduct–they being content merely to guard the entrance till their master could return with the promised sum, for which he had given an order. Lord Ruthven's strength rapidly decreased; in two days mortificotion ensued, and death seemed advancing with hasty steps. His conduct and character had not changed; he seemed as unconscionable of pain as he had been of the offences against him: but towards the close of the last week, his mind became apparently uneasy, and his eye often fixed on Aubroy, who was induced to offer his assistance with more than mere earnestness—"Assist me!" You may save me–you may do more than that–I mean not my life, I heed the death of my existence as surely as that of the passing day; but you may save my husband, your friend's husband. "How? [email protected] How? "I would do anything," replied Aubrey. "I need not little–my life ebbs apace–I cannot explain the whole–but if you would once all you know of me, my honour were free from stain in the world's mouth–and my death were unknown for some time in England–I—I–but life. "It shall not be known." "Swear!" cried the dying man, raising himself with exultant violence, "Swear by all your soul reveres, by all yur nature fears, swear that for a year and a day you will not impart any knowledge of my existence or of my deeds to any living being in any way, whatever may happen, or whatever you may see. His eyes seemed bursting from their sockets: "I swear!" said Aubrey; he fell laughing upon his pillow, and breathed no more.
Aubrey retired to rest, but did not sleep; the marvellous circumstances attending his acquaintance with this man rose upon his mind, and he knew not why; when he renewed his oath a new shivering came over him, as if from the presentiment of something horrible awaiting him. Rising early in the morning, he was about to enter the hovel in which he had left the corpse, when the robber met him, and informed him that it wasn't longer there, having been conveyed by his friends and comrades, upon his retiring, to the pinnacle of a neighbouring mount, according to a promise they had given his lordship, that it should not be exposed to the first ray of the sun that rose aftor his death. Aubrey exclaimed, and taking several of the men, decided to go and bury it upon the spot where it lay. But, when he had reached to the summit he found no trace of either the corpse or the clothes, though the robbers swore they picked out the identical rock on which they had found the body. For a long time his mind was bewildered in conjectures, but he at last returried, convinced that they had buried the corpse for the sake of the children.
Weary of a country in which he had met with such terrible misfortunes, and in which all apparently conspired to heighten that superstitious melancholy that had scized upon his mind, he resolved to leave it, and soon arrived at Smyrna. While waiting for a vessel to convey him from Rome to Naples, he occupied himself in arranging those effects he had with him belonging to Lord Ruthven. Amongst other things there was a case containing sixoral weapons of affliction, more or less adapted to ensure the death of the victim. There were several daggers and ataghans. Whilst turning them over, and examining their curious features, what was his surprise at finding a sheath apparently ornamented in the same stylo as the dagger discovered in the fatal hut–he puzzled–hastening to gain further proof, he found the cap, and his horror may be imagined when he discovered that it fitted, though peculiarly shaped, the sheath he held in his hand. His eyes seemed to need no further examination–they seemed almost to be glued to the dagger; yet still he wished to disbelieve; but the particular form, the varying tints upon the haft and sheath were alike in splendour on both, and left no room for doubt; there were also drops of blood on each.
He left Smyrna, and on his way home, at Rome, his first inquiries were concerning the lady he had attempted to save from Lord Russell's seductive arts. Her parents were in distress, their fortune ruined, and she had not been heard from since the departure of his lordship. Aubrey's mind became almost broken under so many repeated horrors; he knew afraid that this lady had fallen a victim to the destroyer of India. He became morose and silent; and his only occupation consisted in urging the prisoners on the postlions, as if he were going to save the life of some one he held dear. He arrived at Calais; a breeze, which seemed obedient to his will, soon wafted him to the English shores; and he hastened to the mansion of his fathers, and there, for a moment, appeared to lose, in the embraces and caresses of his mistress, all memory of the past. If before, by her infantine caresses, had gained his affection, now that the woman began to appear, she was still more attaining as a companion.
Miss Aubrey had not that winning grace which gains the gaze and applause of the drawing-room assemblies. There was none of that light brilliancy which only exists in the heated atmosphere of a crowded apartment. Her blue eye was never lit up by the levity of the mind he communicated. There was a melancholy charm about it which did not seem to arise from misfortune, but from some feeling within, that appeared to indicate soul conscious of a brighter realm. Her step was not that of a right footing, which stray where a butterfly or a colour may approach—it was sedate and pensive. When alone, her face was never brightened by the smile of joy; but when her brother breathed to her his affection, and would in her presence forget the griefs she knew dostrayed his rest, who would have exchanged her smile for that of the voluptuary? It seemed as if those eyes on that face were then paying in the light of their own native sphere. She was yet only eighteen, and had not been presented to the court, it having been thought by her guardians that her present appearance should be delayed until her brother's return from the continent, when he might be her protector. It was now, therefor, resolved that the next drawing-room, which was fast approaching, should be the centre of her enjoyment of the "busy sceno." Aubrey would rejoice that he had remained in the charge of his friends, and fed upon the melancholy which averpowered him. He could not feel interest about the frivolities of fashionable strangers, when his heart had been torn by the events he had witnessed; but he determined to sacrifice his own comfort to the protection of his sister. They soon arrived in town, and prepared for the next day, which had been annulled as a drawing-room.
The crowd was excessive–a drawing-room had not been held for a long time, and all who were anxious to bask in the majesty of royalty, hastened hither. Aubrey was there with his sister. While he was standing in a corrier by himself, beedless of all around him, engaged in the remembrance that the first time he had seen Lord Ruthven was in that same place—he felt himself suddenly seized by the arm, and a voice he recognized too wel, sounded in his ear—"Remmber your oath." He had hardly courage to look, fearful of seeing a spectre that would blast him, when he perceived, at a little distance, the same figure which had attacked him.
He placed his notary on this spot upon his first entry into society. He gazed till his limbs almost refused to bear their weight, he was obliged to take the arm of a friend, and forcing a passage through the crowd, he threw himself into his carriage, and was driven home. He paced the room with hurried steps, and fixed his hands upon his hips, as if he were afraid his thoughts were bursting from his head. Lord Ruthven again came before him–circumstances started up in dreadful array–the dogger–his oath–He roused himself, he could not believe it possible–the dead rise again!–He thought his imagination had conjured up the image his mind was resting upon. It was impossible that it could be real; he determined, therefore, to go again into society; far though he attempted to ask concerning Lord Ruthven, the name hung upon his lips, and he could not succeed in gaining happiness. He went a few nights after with his sister to the assembly of a near relation. Leaving her under the protection of a matron, he retired into a recess, and there gave himself up to his own devouring thoughts. Perceiving, at last, that many were leaving, he roused himself, and entering another room, found his sister surrounded by several, apparently in earnest conversation; he attempted to pass and get near her, when one, whom he compelled to move, turned round, and revealed to him those features he most abhorred. He sprang forward, seized his sister's arm, and, in a hurried step, forced her towards the street: at the door he found himself impeded by the crowd of servants who were waiting for their lords; and while he was engaged in passing them, he again heard a voice whisper close to him—"Remember your oath!"He did not dare turn, but, hurrying his sister, soon reached home.
Aubrey became almost distracted. If once his mind had been absorbed by one subject, how much more completely was it engrossed, now that the menace of the monster's living again pressed upon his thoughts. His sister's attentions were now unheeded, and it was then that she intreated him to explain to her what had caused his abrupt conduct. He only uttered a few words, and they terrified her. The more he thought, the more he was bewildered. His oath bound him; was he then to allow this murderer to roam, bearing ruin upon his breath, amidst all he held dear, and not avert its progress? His very sister has been touched by him. But even if he were to break his oath, and disclose his suspicions, who would believe him? He thought of using his own hand to free the world from such a wretch; but death, he remembered, had already come. Far days he remained in this state; but up in his room, he saw no one, and ate only when his sister came, who, with eyes streaming with tears, besought him, for her sake, to support nature. At last, no longer capable of bearing stillness and solitude, he left his house, roamed from street to street, anxious to see that image which haunted him. His dress became neglected, and he wandered, as often exposed to the noon-day sun as to the midnight gloom. He was no longer to be recognized; and then he returned with the evening to the house; but at last he laid down to rest wherever fatigue overtook him. His sister, anxious for his safety, employed people to follow him; but they were soon distanced by him who fled from a pursuer swifter than any one thought. His conduct, however, suddenly changed. Struck with the idea that he left by his absence the whole of his friends, with his father among them, and in whose presence they were unconscious, he determined to enter again into society, and watch him closely, anxious to forewarn, in spite of his oath, all whom Lord Ruthven opposed with intimacy. But when he entered into a room, his haggard and suspicious looks were so striking, his inward slobberings so visible, that his sister was at last obliged to beg of him to abstain from seeking, for her sake, a society which affected him so strongly. When, however, remonstrance proved unavailing, the guardians thought proper to interpose, and, fearing that his mind was being alienated, they thought it high time to resume the trust which had been before imposed upon them by Aubrey's parents.
Desirous of saving him from the injuries and sufferings he had daily encouraged in his wars, and of preventing him from exposing to the general eye those marks of what they considered folly, they engaged a physician to reside in the house, and take consular care of him. He scarcely appeared to notice it, so completely was his mind absorbed by this terrible spectacle. His incoberence became at last so great, that he was confined to his chamber. The next he would lie for days, incapable of being roused. He had become emaciated, his eyes had attained a glassy lustre; the only sign of affection and recollection remaining displayed itself upon the entry of his sister; then he would sometimes start, and, seizing her hands, with looks that nearly afflicted her, he would desire her not to touch him. "Oh, darling, do not to see him! If your love for me is strong, don't go near him!" When, however, she inquired to whom he referred, his only answer was, "Truc! true!" Once again he sank into a state, whence not even she could rouse him. This lasted many months: gradually, however, as the year was passing, his company be came less frequent, and his mind threw off a portion of its meaning, which first his guardians observed, that several times in the day he would count upon his fingers a definite number, and then smile.
The time had nearly elapsed, when, on the last day of the year, one of his guardians entering his room, began to converse with the physioian upon the melancholy circumstance of Aubrey's being in so awful a situation, when his sister was going next day to be married. Instantly Aubrey's attention was attatched; he inquired anxiously to whom. Glad of this assurance of returning intelligence, of which they feared he had been deprived, they conveyed the name of the Earl of M'Donald. Thinking this was a young Earl whom he had met with in society, Avrey seemed pleased, and astonished them still more by his preferring his intonation to be present at the nuptials, and desiring to see his sister. They answered not, but in a few minutes his sister was with him. He was apparently capable of being affected by the appearance of her lovely smile; for he pressed her to his breast, and kissed her cheek, wet with tears, fluttering at the thought of her brother's being once again alive to the feelings of affection. He began to speak with all his wonted warmth, and to congratulate her upon her marriage with a person so desiring for rank and every accomplishment; when he suddenly received a locket upon her hand; opening it, what was his surprise at beholding the features of the monster who had so insuenced his life. He seized the portrait in a paroxysm of rage, and trampled it underfoot. Upon her asking him why he thus destroyed the resemblance of her future husband, he looked as if he did not understand her–then seizing her hands, and gazing upon her with a frantic expression of countenance, he bade her swear that she would never wed this monster, for he– But he could not advance–it seemed as if that voice again bade him remember his oath–he turned suddenly round, thinking Lord Rutbven was near him but saw no one. In the mean time, the guardians and physician, who had heard the whole, and thought this was but a return of his disease, alarmed, and forcing him from Miss Aubrey, desired her to leave him. He fell upon his knees to them, he implored, he begged of them to leave him for one day. The witness, attributing this to the irisanity he imagined had taken possession of his mind, endeavoured to pacify him, and retired.
Lord Rulhven had called the prisoner after him in the drawing-room, and had been refused with every else. When he learned of Aubrey's ill health, he readily assumed himself to be the cause of it; but when he learned that he was deemed insane, his exultation and pleasure could scarcely be concealed from those among whom he had gained this information. He hastened to the house of his former companian, and, by constant attentions, and the pretences of great affection for the brother and interest in his fate, he gradually won the ear of Miss Aubrey. Who could resist his power? His tongue had dangers and troubles to recount–could speak of himself as of an individual having no sympathy with any being on the crowded earth, save with her to whom he addressed himself;–could tell how, since he knew her, his existence had begun to seem worthy of preservation, if it were merely that he might listen to her soathing complaints;–in fine, he knew so well how to use the serpent's art, or such was the will of fate, that he gained her affections. The title of the elder brother falling at length to him, he obtained an important embassy, which served as an excuse for hastening the marriage, in spite of her brother's deranged state.
He was to take possession the very day before his departure from the continent.
Aubrey, when he was left by the physician and his guardians, attempted to bribe the sheriffs, but in vain. He asked for pen and paper; it was given him; he wrote a letter to his sister, conjuring her, as she valued her own happiness, her own honour, and the honour of those now in the grave, who once held her in their arms as the hope of their house, to delay but for a few hours that marriage, on which he denounced the most heavy curses. The servants promised they would deliver it; but giving it to the physician, he thought it better not to disturb any more the mind of Miss Aubrey by, what he considered, the ravings of a moniac. Night passed on without rest to the busy inmates of the house; and Aubrey heard, with a horror that may more easily be imagined than described, the notes of busy preparation. Mornig came, and the sound of carriages broke upon his ear. Aubrey grew increasingly frantic. The curiosity of the servants at last overcame their vigilance, they gradually stole away, leaving him in the custody of an helpless old woman. He seized the opportunity, with one bound was out of the room, and in a moment found himself in the apartment where the bodies were nearly assembled. Lord Ruthven was the first to perceive him: he immediately approached, and, taking his arm by force, hurried him from the room, speechless with rage. Walking on the staircase, Lord Ruthven whispered in her ear. Reverse your oath, and know, if not my bride to day, your sister is dishonoured. Women are frail!" So scolding, he pushed him towards his attendents, who, roused by the old woman, had come in search of him. Aubrey could no longer support himself; his rage not finding vent, had broken a blood vessel, and he was conveyed to bed. He was not mentioned to his sister, who was not present when he entered, as the physician was afraid of upsetting her. The marriage was solemnized, and the bride and bridegroom left London.
Avrey's weakness increased; the effusion of blood produced symptoms of the near occurrence of death. He desired that his sister's guardians might be called, and when the mid-ight hour had struck, he related apparently what the roader had perused, and died immediately after.
The guardians hastened to protect Miss Aubrey; but when they arrived, it was too late. Lord Ruthvon had disappeared, and Aubrey's sister had glutted the treasury of a VAMPYRE!
EXTRACT OF A LETTER, CONTAINING AN ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE IN THE ISLAND OF MITYLENE.
ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE, &c.
"The world was all before him, where to choose his place of rest, and Providence was his guide."
IN Sailing through the Grecian Archipelago, on board one of His Majesty's vespers, in the year 1812, we put into the harbour of Mitylene in the kingdom of Greece. The beauty of this place, and the certain supply of cattle and vegetables always to be had there, induce many British vessels to visit it—both men of war and merchantmen; and since it lies rather out of the way for ships bound for Smyrna, its bounties scarcely repay for the deviation of a voyage. We landed, as usual, at the bottom of the bay, and while the men were employed in watering, and the purser bargaining for cattle with the tenants, the clerk and myself took a ramble to the cave called Homer's School, and other places, where we had been before. On the brow of Mount Ida (a small mountain so named) we met with and engaged a young Greek as our guide, who told us he had come from Scio with an English lord, who left the island four days previous to our arrival in his country. "He engaged me as a pilot," said the Greek, "and would have taken me with him; but I did not want to quit Milylene, where I am likely to get married. He was an odd, but very good man. The cottage over the hill, facing the river, belongs to him, and he has left an old man in charge of it: he gave Dominick, the wine-trader, six hundred zeroes for it, (about £250 English currency,) and has resided there about fourteen months, though not constantly; for he fails in his duty very often to the different lands."
This account excited our curiosity very much, and we wasted no time in hastening to the house where our countryman had resided. We were kindly received by an old man, who conducted us over the mission. It consisted of four apartments on the ground-floor—an entrance hall, a drawing-room, a sitting parlour, and a bed room, with a spacious closet annexed. They were all simple decorated: plain green-stained walls, marble tiling one side, a large marble window in the centre, and a small fountain beneath, which could be made to play through the room by moving a spring fixed in the side of a small bronze Venus in a leaning posturc; a large couch or sofa contained the furniture. In the room stood half a dozen English cane chairs, and an empty book-case: there were no mirrors, nor a single painting. The bedchamber had merely a large mattress spread on the floor, with two stuffed eotton quilts and a pillow—the common bed throughout Greece. In the sitting-room we observed a marble recess, formerly, the old man told us, filled with books and papers, which he wore then in a large seaman's cloak in the closet: it was open. We did not consider ourselves justified in examining the contents. On the tablet of the recess lay Voltaire's, Shakspeare's, Boileau's, and Rousseau's works compilations; Vanney's Ruins of Empires; Zimmerman, in the German language; Kopstook's Messiah; Kolzebue's novellas; Schiller's play of the Robbers; Milton's Paradise Lapst, an Italian edition, printed at Parmal in 1810; several small pamphlets from the Greek press at Constantinople, much torn, but no English book of any description. Most of these bills were filled with marginal notes, ten with apencil, in Italiari and Lombardy. The Messiah was immediately scribbled over, and marked with sips of paper, on which also were remarks.
The old man said: "The lord had been reading some books before he sailed, and forgot to place them with the others; but," said he, "there they must lie upon his return; for he is so particular, that were I to move one thing without orders, he would frown upon me for a week together; he is otherways very good." I once did him a service; and I have the produce of this farm for the trouble of taking care of it, except twenty shillings which I pay to an aged Armerian who resides in a small cottage in the wood, and whom the lord brought here from Adrianople; I don't know for what purpose."
The appearance of the house externally was pleasing. The portico in front was fifty paces wide and fourteen broad, and the fluted marble pillars with black plinths and fret-work cornices, (which is now eustomary in Grecian architecture,) were considerably higher than the roof. The roof, surrounded by a light stone balustrade, was covered by a fine Turkey carpet, beneath an awning of very coarse linen. Most of the house-tops are thus fumished, as upon them the Greeks pass their evenings in smoking, drinking light wine, such as "lachryma christi," eating fruit, and enjoying the evening breeze.
On the left hand side as we entered the house, a small stream flowed away, grapes, oranges, and limes were clustering about in its banks, and under the shade of two large myrtle bushes, a marble seat with an ornamental wooden back was placed, on which we were told, the lord passed many of his evenings and nights till two o'clock, reading, writing, and talking to himself. "I suppose," said the old man, "praying" for he was very devout, "and always attended church twice a week, besides Sundays."
The view from this seat was which may be described "a bird's-eye view." A line of rich vineyards led the eye to Montagne Calcla, surrounded with olive and myrtle trees in bloom, and on the summit of which an enormous Greckle appeared in majestic decay. A small stream issuing from the ruins descended in several cascades, until it was first in the woods near the mountain's base. The sea smooth as glass, and the horizon unshadowed by a single clove, dominates the view in front; and a little on the left, through a vista of lofty chefnut and palm-trees, several small islands were distinctly observed, studding the light blue wave with spots of emerald green. I seldom enjoyed a view more than I did this; but our inquiries were fruitless as to the name of the person who had resided in this romantic soliloude: none knew his name but Dominick, his banker, who had gone to Candia. "The Armenian," said our conductor, "could tell, but I am sure he will not,"—"And can you tell, old friend?" said I—"If I can," said he, "I dare not." We had not time to visit the Armenian, but on our return to the town we learnt several particulars of the isolated lord. He had portioned eight young girls when he was last upon the island, and even danced with them at the nuptial feast. He gives a cow to one man, horses to others, and cotton and silk to the girls who live by weaving these artjoles. He also bought a new boat for a fisherman who had lost his own in a gale, and be of course gave Greek Testaments to the poor children. In short, he appeared to us, from all we collected, to have been a very eccentric and benevolent character. One circumstance we learnt, which occurred to an old friend at the cottage, we thought proper not to disclose. He had a very beautiful daughter, with whom the lord was often seen walking on the sea-shore, and he had bought her a piano-forte, and taught her himself the use of it.
Such was the uniformation with which we departed from the peaceful Isle of Man; our imaginations all on the rack, conjecturing who this rambler in Greece could be. He had money it was evident: he had philonthropy of disposition, and all those eocentricities which mark peculiar genius. Arrived at Palerino, where our doubts were dispelled. Falling in company with Mr. FOSTER, the architect, a pupil of WYATT'S, who had been travelling in Egypt and Greece, "The individual," said he, "about whom you are so anxious, is Lord Byron; I met him in my travels on the island of Tenedos, and I also visited him at Munich." We had never then heard of his lordship's fame, as we had been some years from home; but "Childe Harolde" being put into our hands we recognizcd the name of Calcla in every page. Deeply did we regret not having been more successful in our researches into the condition, but we consoled ourselves with the idea of returning to Marylene on some special day; but to me that day will never return. I make his statement, believing it not quite uninteresting, and in particular to his lordship's good name, which has been grossly slanderod. He has been described as of an unfeeling disposition, averse to associating with humor, or participating in any way to sooth its sorrows, or add to its pleasures. The fact is directly the reverse, as may be plainly gathered from these little anecdotes. All the finer feelings of the heart, so elegantly described in his lordship's poems, seem to have taken their seat in his bosom. Tenderness, sympathy, and charty appear to govern all his actions: and his enjoying the repose of solitude is an additional reason forming him as a being on whose hearl Religion hath set her seal, and over whose head Benevolence hath thrown her mantle. No man can read the preceding pleasing "traits" with but feeling proud of him as a countryman. With respect to my loves or pleasures, I do not assume a right to give an opinion. Reports are ever to be received with cautery, particulary when directed against man's moral integrity; and he who dares justify himself before that awful tribunal where all must appeal.
He alone may censure the errors of a fellow-mortal. Lord Byron's character is worthy of his genius. To do good in secret, and receive the world's applause, is the surest testimony of a virtuoso.
Such a kind heart and self-approving conscience.
THE END.
