THE VAMPYRE.
A Tale.
By John William Polidori
THE superstition upon which this tale is found is very general in the East. Among the Arabs it appears to be common: it did not, however, among the Jews.
The practice did not extend itself to the Greeks until after the establishment of Christianity; and it has only assumed its present form since the division of the Latin and Greek churches; at which time, the idea becoming prevalent, that a Latin body could not corrupt those buried in their territory, it gradually increased, and formed the subject of many wonderful stories, still extant, of the dead rising from their graves, and feeding upon the bodies of the young and beautiful. In the West it spread, with some slight variation, all over Hungary, Poland, Austria, and Lorraine, where the belief existed, that vampyres nightly imbibed a certain portion of the blood of their victims, who became emaciated, lost their strength, and speedily died of consumptions; whilst the human blood-suckers fattened, and their veins became distended to such a state of completion, as to cause the blood to flow from all the possages of their bodies, and from the very pores of their skins.
In the London Journal, of March, 1732, is a curious, and, of course, credible account of a particular case of vampyrism, which is stated to have occurred at Madreyga, in Hungary. It appears, that upon on examination of the commander-in-chief and magistrates of the place, they positively and unanimously confirmed, that, about five years ago, a certifiable young man, named Arnold Paul, had been heard to say that, at Cassovia, on the frontiers of the Turkish Service, he had been tormented by a vampyre, but had found a way to rid himself of the evil, by eating some of the earth out of the vampyr's grave, and rubbing himself with his blood. This precautiori, however, did not preverit him from becoming a vampyre himself; for, about twenty or thirty days after his death and burial, many persons complained of having been tormented by him, and a deposition was made, that four persons had been deprived of life by his attentions. To prevent further mischievous, the inhabitants having consulted their physicians, took up the body, and found it (as is supposed to be usual in cases of vampyrism) fresh, and entire free from corruption, and including the mouth, nose, and ears, pure white blood. Procedure having been thus obtained, they resorted to the accustomed remedy. A stake was driven entirely through the heart and body of Arnold Paul, at which he is reputed to have cried out as dreadfully as if he had been alive. This done, they cut off his head, burned his body, and threw the ashes into his grave. The some measures were adopted with the assistance of those persons who had proviously died from vampyrism, lest they should, in their deaths, come agents for those who survived them.
The universal belief is, that a person sucked by avampyre comes out of himself, and sucks in his turn.
Chief bailiff.
This monstrous crime is here related, because it seems better adapted to illuminate the subject of the present operations than any other instance which could be adduced. In many parts of Greece it is considered as a sort of punishment aftr death, for some horrible crime committed whilst in office, that the deceased is not only doomed to vampirism, but compelled to confine his infernal visitations solely to those beings he loved most while upon earth—to those to whom he was bound by ties of kinship and affection.—A supposition alluded to in the "Gospel."
But first on earth, as Vampyre sent, the corse shall from its tomb be rent; Then ghastly haunt the native place, and drink the blood of all the race; There from thy daughter, sister, wife, at midnight drink the milk of life; Yet loathe the banquet which perforce must feed thy living enemies; Thy victims, though they yet expire, must know the mercy for their sire; As cursing thee, thou cursing them. The flowers are withered on the stem. But one that for thy crime must fall, The youngest, best belated of all, may God bless thee with a sister's name— That word shall wrap thy heart in flame! Yet must you end thy life and mark her cheek's last tinge–her eye's last spark, and the last glacial glance must view which freezes on her lifeless blue; Then with unhallowed hand shall tear the trosses of her yellow bair, of which, as life a lock when shorn Affection's fondest pledge was worn– But now is born upon the Memorial of her agony! Yet with thine own best blood ball drip; Thy gnashing tooth, and haggard lip; Then stalking to thy wretched grave, Go-arid with Gouls and Afrits rave, Till these in horror shrink away from a spectre more accursed than they.
Mr. Sullivan.
They were also introduced in his wild but beautiful persona of "Thalaba," the vampyre corse of the Arabian Majd Oncizcl, who is reputed as having returried from the grave for the purpose of tormenting him she best loved while in existence. But this cannot be supposed to have resulted from the sinfulness of her life, she being presented forthright about the whale of the tale as a complete type of purity and goodness. The veracious Tournefort gives a long account in his travels of severing cases of vampyrism, to which he pretends to have been an eyewitness; and Calmet, in his considerable work upon this subject, besides a variety of anecdotes, and traditionary narrations illustrative of its effects, has put forth some learned dissertations, tending to prove it to be a classical, as well as barbarian error.
Many curious and interesting notices on this singularly horribleness superstition might be added; though the present may suffice for the limits of a note, nocossarily devoted to explanation, and which may now be corolluded by merely remarking, that though the term Vampyre is the one in most general use, there are many other synonyms with it, made use of in different contexts.
Some parts of the world: as Vrouoolocha, Vardoula, Goul, Broucoloka, &c.
THE VAMPYRE.
IT happened that in the midst of the disjuncture attendant upon a London winter, there appeared at the various parties of the leader of the ton a nobleman, more remarkable for his singularities, than his rank. He gazed upon the mirth around him, as if he could not participate in it. Apparently, the laugher of the fair only attracted his attention, that he might by a look quell it, and throw fear into those breasts where thoughtlessness reigned. Those who felt this sensation of awe, could not explain whence it arose: some attributed it to the dead grey eye, which, fixing upon the subject's face, did not seem to penetrate, and at one glance to pierce through to the inward workings of the heart; but fell upon the cheek with a leaden ray that weighed upon the skin it could not pass. His peculiarities caused him to be invited to every house; all went to see him, and those who had been accustomed to violent excitement, and now felt the weight of ennui, were pleased at having something in their presence capable of engaging their attention. In view of the deadly hue of his face, which never gained a warmer tint, either from the blush of modesty, or from the strong emotion of passion, though its form and outline were beautiful, many of the female hunters after notoriety attempted to win his attentions, and gain, at least, some marks of which they might signify affection: Lady Mercer, who had been the mockery of every woman shewn in drawing-rooms since her marriage, threw herself in his way, and did all but put on the dress of a merchant, to attract his notice:—though in vain: when she stood before him, though his eyes were apparently fixed upon her's, still it seemed as if they were unperceived; even her unclenched impudence was baffled, and she left the field. But though the common odour could not influence even the guidance of his eyes, it was not that the female sex was inferior to him: yet such was the apparerit caution with which he spoke to the virtuous wife and innocent daughter, that few knew he ever addressed himself to females. He had, however, the reputation of a wicked tongue; and whether it was that it even came the dread of his singular companion, or that many were moved by his apparent hatred of vice, he was as often among those females who for the boast of their sex from their domestic practices, as among those who sully it by their vicissitudes.
About the same time, there came to London a young gentleman of the name of Aubrey: he was an orphan left with an only sister in the possession of great parents, who died while he was yet in childhood. Left also to him.
By guardians, who thought it their duty merely to take care of his fortune, while they relinquished the more important charge of his mind to the care of mercenary subalterns, he exercised more his imagination than his judgment. He had, hence, that high Romanlic feeling of honour and candour, which daily ruins so many manufacturers' apprentices. He believed all to sympathise with vice, and thought that vice was thrown in by Providence merely for the picturesque effect of the scene, as we see in romances: he thought that the misery of a confinement merely consisted in the vestiges of clothes, which were as warm, but which were better identified to the painter's eye by their irregular folds and various coloured patches. He thought, in fine, that the dreams of poets were the necessities of life. He was handsome, frank, and rich: for these reasons, upon his entering into the gay circles, many mothers surrounded him, and which they would describe with least truth as having possessing or romping favourites: the daughters at the same time, by their brightening countenances when he approached, and by their sparkling eyes, when he opened his lips, soon led him into false notions of his talents and merit. Attached as he was to the romance of those solitary hours, he was startled at riding, that, except in the tallow and wax oandles that flickered, not in the presence of a ghost, but for want of snuffing, there was no foundation in real life for any of that congeries of pleasing pictures and desires contained in those volumes, from which he had formed his study. Finding, however, no compensation in his gratified vanity, he was about to relive his dreams, when the extraordinary being we have above described, crossed him in his career.
He watched him; and the very impudence of forming an idea of the character of a man almost entirely absorbed in himself, who gave few other signs of his observation of external objects, than the passive assent to their existence, implied by the avoidance of their contact: allowing his imagination to capture every thing that flattered its propensity to extravagant ideas, he soon molded this object into the hero of a romance, and endeavoured to observe the offspring of his fancy, rather than the subjects before him. He became acquainted with him, paid him attentions, and so far advanced upon his notice, that his presence was always recognised. He gradually learnt that Lord Ruthven's affairs were embarrassed, and then found, from the notes of preparation in Stretton, that he was aboul to travel. Desirous of gaining some infarmation respecting this singular character, who, till now, had only whetted his curiosity, he hinted to his guardians, that it was time for him to perform the tour, which for many generations has been thought necessary to enablage the young to take some rapid step in the direction of vice towards putting them upon an equality with the aged, and not allowing them to appear as having fallen from the skips, when scandalous intrigues are mentioned as subjects of pleasoration or of praise, according to the degree of skill shewn in carrying them on. He confented, and Aubrey immediately declaring his intentions to Lord Ruthven, was surprised to receive from him a proposal to join him. Flattered by such a mark of respect from him, who, apparently, had been in company with other men, ho gladly accepted it, and in a few days they had passed the circling waters.
Hitherto, Ayre had had no opportunity of studying Lord Ruthven's character, and now he found, that, though any more of his acts were exposed to his view, the results offered different corollaries from the appearance motives to his conduct. His conduct was prosuse in his liberality; the idle, the vagabond, and the beggar, received from his hand more than enough to relieve their immediate want. But Aury could not avoid remarking, that it was not upon the virtuosity, reduced to indigence by the misfortunes attendant even upon virtue, that he deposited his alms; these were received from the door with hardly suppressed sneers; but when the profligate came to ask something, not to relieve his wants, but to allow him to wallow in his lust, or to sink him still deeper in his iniquity, he was sent away with rich chority. This was, however, attributed by him to the greater importunity of the vicious, which generally prevails over the retiring bashfulness of the virtuous indigent. There was one circumstance about the charity of his Lordship, which was still more pressing upon his mind: all those upon whom it was bestowed, inevitably found that there was a caprice upon it, and they were all either led to the scaffold, or sunk to the lowest and most abject misery. At Brussels and other towns through which they passed, Aubry was surprized at the apparent eagerness with which his companions sought for the centros of all fashionable vice; there he entered into all the spirit of the faro table: he betted, and always gambled with success, except when the known sharper was his antagonist, and then he lost even more than he gained; but it was always the same unchanging face, with which he generally watched the society around: it was not, however, so when he encountered a rash youthful novice, or the luckless father of a small family; then his very wish seemed fortune's will—this apparent abstracted state of mind was laid aside, and his eyes sparkled with more fire than that of the cat which was dallying with the half-dead mouse. In every town, he saw the formerly affluenl youth, torn from the company he adorned, contemplating, in the solitude of a dungeon, the fate that had drawn him within the reach of this fiend; whilst another a father sat frantic, amid the speaking looks of mute hungry children, without a single farthing of his late immensurable wealth, wherewith to buy food sufficient to satisfy his present craving. Yet he took no notice of the garnishing tablo; he immediately turned, to the ruiner of many, the last gilder he had just snalched from the convulsive grasp of the innocent: this might but be the result of a certain degree of knowledgings, which were not, however, capable of combating the fury of the more experienced. Avrey often wished to reprove this lo his friend, and beg him to resign that company and pleasure which proved the ruin of all, and did not tend to his own profit; but he delayed it–for each day he hoped his friend would give him some opportunity of speaking frankly and openly to him; but this never occurred. Lord Rutledge in his carriage, and amidst the various wild and rich scenes of nature, was always the same: his eye spoke less than his lip; and though Aubrey was constantly the object of his curiosity, he obtained no greater gratification from it than the constant excitement of vainly wishing to break that mystery, which to his exalted imagination began to assume the appearance of something supernatural.
They soon arrived at Rome, and Aubrey for a time lost sight of his companion; he left him in daily attendance upon the morriing grounds of an Italian court, whilst he went in search of the memoraries of another almost deserted city. Whilst he was thus engaged, letters arrived from England, which he opened with eager impatience; the first was from his sister, hreathing nothing but affection; the others were from his guardians, the latter admonished him; if it had before entered into his imagination that there was an evil power residing in his companion, these seemed to give him sufficient reason for the belief. His guardians insisted upon his immediately leaving his friend, and urged, that his character was deliberately vicious, for that the possession of irresistible powers of seduction, rendered his licentious habits more dangerous to society. It had been discovered, that his contempt for the adultress had not originated from hatred of her character; but that he had required, to enhance his gratificatiion, that the victim, thepartner of his guilt, should be hurled from the pinnacle of urbane virtue, dawn to the lowest abysm of infamy and degradation: in fine, that all those females whom he had sought, apparently on account of their virtuosity, had, since his departure, thrown even the mask aside, and had not scrupled to exposit the whole deformity of their vice to the public gaze.
Aubrey determined upon leaving one, whose character had not yet shawn a single bright point on which to rest the eye. He resolved to invent some plausible pretext for abandoning him altogether, purposing, in the mean while, to watch him more closely, and to ensure no slight circumstonces pass by unnoticed. He entered into the same circle, and soon perceived that his Lordship was endeavouring to work upon the inexperience of the daughter of the lady whose house he frequently frequented. In Italy, it is seldom that an unmarried female is met with in society; he was thus obliged to carry on his plans in secret; but Aubrey's eye followed him in all his windings, and soon discovered that an assignation had been appointed, which would most likely end in the ruin of his innuent, though he had bought the girl. Losing patience, he entored the attention of Lord Ruthven, and earnestly asked him his feelings with respect to the lady, infarming him at the same time that he was aware of his being about to meet her that very night. Lord Rutbven answered, that his intentions were such as he supposed all would have upon such an occasion; and upon being pressed whether he intended to marry her, merely laughed. Avrey retired; and, immediately writing a letter, to say, that from that position he must decline accompanying his Lordship in the remainder of their proposed tour, he ordered his servant to seek other apartments, and colling upon the mother of the lady, informed her of all he knew, not only with regard to her daughter, but also concealing her.
Having the character of his Lord'ship. The assignation was prevented. Lord Ruthven next day morely sent his serjeant to riotify his consent to separation; but did not hint any suspicion of his plans having been foiled by Aubrey's interposition.
Having left Rome, Aubrey directed his steps towards Naples, and crossing the Peninsula, soon found himself al Athenaeum. He then fixed his residence in the house of a Greek; and immersed himself in tracing the faded records of ancient glory upon monuments which apparently, ashamed of marking the deeds of freemen only before slavery, had hidden themselves beneath the sheltoring soil or many coloured flowers. Under the same roof as himself, existed a girl, so beautiful and delicate, that she might have furnished the mode for a painter wishing to paint on canvass the promised hope of the faithful in Mahoinet's paradise, save that her eyes spoke too much mind for any one to think she could belong to those who had no souls. As she danced upon the plain, or tripped along the mountaineer's side, one would have thought the gazelle a poor type of her beauties; for who would have exchanged her eye, apprentrently the eye of animated nature, for that sleepy luxurious look of the animal suited to the taste of an epicure. The light of day often accompanied Aubrey in his search after antiquities, and often would the unconscious girl, engaged in the pursuit of a Kashmere butterfly, show the whole body of her form, floaling as it were upon the wind, to the eager gaze of him, who forgot the letters he had just dictated up an almost effaced page, in the contemplation of her sylph-like figure. Often would her tresses falling, as she flitted around, exhibit in the sun's rays a delicate sheen. If brilliant and swiftly fading ideas, it might well be to blame the forgetfulness of the author, who let escape from his mind the very object he had before thought of vital importance to the proper interpretation of a passage in Pausanias. But why attempt to describe charms which all feel, but none can appreciate?–It was innocence, youth, and beauty, unaffected by crowded drawing-rooms and stifling ballets. Whilst he drew those remains of which he wished to preserve a memorial for his future hours, she would stand by, and watch the magical effects of his pencil, in tracing the lines of her narrative path; she would then describe to him the graceful dance up and down the open plain, would paint, to him in the glowing colours of youth memory, the marriage procession she remembered viewing in her youth; and then, turning to subjects that had evidenlly made a greater impression upon her mind, would tell him all the supernatural tales of her nurse. Her earnestness and apparent sincerity of what she narrated, exciled the interest even of Aubrey; and often she told him the tale of the living vampyre, who had passed many years amidst his friends, and dearest ties, and forced every year, by feeding on the life of a lovely female to prolong his existence for the ensuing months, his blood would run coarse, whilst he attempted to make her out of such idle and horrible fantasies; but she cited to him the examples of old men, who at last detected one living among themselves, after several of their near relatives and children had been found marked with the stamp of the fiend's appetite; and when she found him so incredulous, she begged of him to believe her, for it had been remarked, that those who had dared to question its existence, invariably had some proof given, which obliged them, with grief and heartbreaking, to confess it was true. She detailed to him the peculiar appearance of these monstrosities, and his horror was increased, by hearing a remarkably accurate description of Lord Ruthven; he, however, still persisted in convincing her, that there could be no truth in her fears, though at the same time he wondered at the many coincidences which had all tended to excite a belief in the supernatural power of Lord Ruthven.
Aubrey beguited himself more and more to love her; her innocence, so contrasted with all the asfected virtues of the women among whom he had sought for his vision of romance, won his heart; and while he ridiculed the idea of a young man of English habits, marrying an uneducated Greck girl, still he found himself more attached to the first fairy tale before him. He would tear himself away at times from her, and, forming a plan for some antiquarian research, he would depart, determined not to return until his object was attained; but he always found it impossible to fix his attention upon the ruins around him, while in his mind he retained an image that seemed alone the sole possessor of his thoughts. She was unconseious of his love, and was ever the most frank infantile boing he had first known. She always wished to part from him with regret; but it was because she had no longer any one with whom she could visit her favourite haunts, whiles her guardian was occupied in sketching or uncovering some fragment which had yet escaped the destructive hand of time. She had appealed to her parents on the subject of Vampyres, and they both, with several present, confirmed their existence, pale with horror at the very name. Soon after, Hurrey decided to proceed upon one of his excursions, which would detain him for a few hours; when they heard the name of the place, they all at once begged of him not to return at night, as he must necesarily pass through a wood, where no Greek would ever remain, after the day had closed, upon any consideration. They described it as the resort of the vampyres in their nocturnal orgies, and denounced the most heavy evils as impending upon him who dared to cross their path. Aubrey made some of their representations, and tried to laugh them out of the idea; but when he saw them shudder at his daring to mock a superior, infernal power, the very power of which apparently made their blood freeze, he was silent.
Next morning Aubrey set off upon his excursion unattended; he was surprised when he arrived.
He saw the melancholy face of his host, and was comforted. He found that his words, mocking the belief of those horrid fiends, had inspired them with such terror. When he was about to depart, she came to the side of his horse, and earnestly begged of him to return, for night allowed the power of the living beings to be put in action; he promised. He was, however, so occupied in his research, that he did not perceive that day-light would soon end, and that on the horizon there was an increase of those specks which, in the warmer climates, so rapidly gather into a tremendous mass, and pour all their rage upon the devoted country. He at once lunted his horse, determined to make up some speed for his delay: but it was too late. Twilight, in these southern friends, is almost unknown; immediately the sun sets, night begins: and before he had advanced far, the power of the storm was above—its echoing thuriders had scarcely passed. During an interval of time, its thick heavy rain forced its way through the canopying foliage, whilst the blue forked lightning seemed to fall and radiate from his very feet. Suddenly his horse took fright, and he was carried with dreadful rapidity through the entangled sorest. The animal at last, through fatigue, stopped, and he found, by the glare of lightning, that he was in the neighbourhood of a hovel that hardly lifted itself up from the masses of dead leaves and brushwood which surrounded it. Dismounting, he approached, hoping to find someone to guide him to the town, or at least to the horses.
It was difficult to obtain shelter from the pelling of the storm. As he approached, the thunder, for a moment insistent, allowed him to hear the dreadful shrieks of a woman mingling with the stifled, exultant mockery of a laugh, continued in one almost unbroken sound; he was startled: but, roused by the thunder which almost rolled over his head, he, with a sudden effort, forced open the door of the hut. He found himself in utter darkness: the sound, however, guided him. He was apparently unperceived; for, though he called, still the sounds continued, and no notice was taken of him. He found himself in contact with one, whom he immediately seized; when a voice cried, "Agitated!" to which a loud laugh succeeded; and he felt himself grappled by someone whose strength seemed superhuman: determined to sell his life as dearly as he could, he struggled.
He struggled; but it was in vain: he was lifted from his feet and hurled with enormous force against the ground: his enemy threw himself upon him, and kneeling upon his breast, had placed his bands upon his throat when the glare of many torches blinded him.
The rays penetrating through the window, which gave light in the day, disturbed him; he instantly rose, and, leaving his prey, rushed through the door, and in a moment the crashing of the branches, as they broke through the wood, was no longer heard. The stock was now still; and Aubrey, incapable of moving, was still heard by those without. They entered; the light of their torches fell upon the mud walls, and the smoke lingered on every individual straw with heavy flakes of soot. At the house of Aubrey they searched for her who had attacked him by his cries; he was again in darkness; but was his bed, when the light of the torches once more burst upon him, to perceive the airy form of his fair conductress brought in a lifeless condition. He shut his eyes, hoping that it was but a vision arising from his disturbed mind; but he immediately saw the same form, when he unclosed them, stretched by his hands. There was no colour upon her face, not even upon her lip; yet there was a stillness about her face that seemed almost as attaining as the darkness that dwelt there: upon her neck and chest was blood, and upon her throat were the marks of someone having opened the vein: to which the men pointed, crying, simultaneously struck with horror, "A Vampyre!" "A Vampyre!" A litter was quickly formed, and Aubrey was lying by the side of her who had longly been to him the object of so many right and foiry visions, now fallen with the flower of life that had died with her. He knew not what his thoughts were–his mind was blanked and seemed to shun reflection, and take refuge in vocaney–he held almost unconsciously in his hand a naked dagger of a particular construction, which had been sound in the hut. They were soon met by disinterested parties.
Some who had been engaged in the search of her said a mother had misfed her. Their lamentable cries, as they approached the city, forewarned the parents of some dreadful catastrophe. –To describe their grief would be impossible; but when they established the cause of their child's death, they looked at Aubrey, and pointed to the corse. They were incorruptable; both died broken-hearted.
Aubrey being put to bed was seized with a most violent fever, and was often delirious; in these intervals he would call up upon Lord Ruthven and upon Ianthe—by some unaccountable combination he seemed to beg of his former companion to spare the being he loved. At other times he would imprecate maledictions upon his head, and Crow regarded him as her destroyer. Lord Rutbaven, chanced at this time to arrive in Athens, and, from whatever reason, upon hearing of the state of Aubrey, immediately placed himself in the house, and became his constant companion. When the prisoner recovered from his delirium, he was horrified and startled at the sight of him with the image he had formerly communicated with of a Vampyre; but Lord Ruthven, by his kind words, implying some repentance for the fault he had caused their displeasure, and even more by the attentions, anxiety, and concern which he showed, soon reconciled him to his presence. His lordship feemed quite changed; he no longer appeared the apatetic being who had so astonished Aubrey; but as soon as his canvassing began to be rapid, he gradually reverted into the same state of mind, and Aubrey perceived no difference from the former man, except that at times he was surprised to meet his gaze fixed intently upon him, with a smile of indignant exultation playing upon his lips: he knew not why, but this smile haunted him. DURING the last stage of the invalid's recovery, Lord Routh was apparently engaged in watching the tideless waves raised by the cooling breeze, or in marking the progress of those orbs, circling, like our world, the moueless sun;—indeed, he appeared to wish to avoid the eyes of all.
Aubrey's mind, by this shock, was much wakeried, and that elasticity of spirit which had once so distinguished him now seemed to have fled for ever. He was now as much a lover of seclusion and silence as Lord Ruthven; but much as he wished for serenity, his mind could not find it in the neighbourhood of Athens; if he sought it amidst the streets he had formerly frequented, Ianthe's form stood by his side—if he sought in the woods, her light step would appear wandering amidst the underbrush, in quest of the modest violet; then suddenly turning round, would show, to his wild imagination, her pale face and wounded throat, with a meek smile upon her lips. He directed to fly scenes, every feature of which created such excitement in his mind. He proposed to Lord Ruthven, to whom he held himself bound by the tender care he had taken of him during his illness, that they should visit the parts of Greece no one had yet seen. They loured in every direction, and sought every spot to which a recollection could be attached: but though they thus hastened from place to place, yet they seemed not to heed what they gazed upon. They heard much of robbers, but they gradually began to slight these reports, which they believed exaggerated.
These were only the invention of individuals, whose interest it was to excite the generosity of those whom they defended from pretended dangers. In consequence of their neglecting the advice of the inhabitants, on one occasion they travelled with only a few guards, more to serve as a guard than as a defence. Upon entailing, however, a narrow defile, at the bottom of which was the bed of a river, with great masses of rock brought down from the neighbouring precipices, they had to repent their negligence; for scarcely was the whole of the party engaged in the narrow pass, when they were startled by the whistling of bullels close to their heads, and by the echoed report of several guns. In an instant their guards had leaped up, and, placing themselves behind rocks, had begun to fire in the direction whence the reply came. Lord Ruthven and Aubrey, imitating their example, retired for a moment behind the shell firing turn of the defile: but ashamed of being detained by a man, who with insulting shouts had them ad vance, and being exposed to unresisting slaughter, if any of the robbers should escape and take them in the rear, they desisted at once to rush forward in search of the enemy. Hardly had they lost the shelter of the rock, when Lord Ruthven received a shot in the shoulder, which brought him to the ground. Aubrey hastened to his assistance; and, no longer hoeding the contest at his own peril, was soon surprised by seeing the robbers' faces around him–his guards having, upon Lord Ruthven's being wounded, immediately thrown up their arms and surrendered.
By promises of great reward, Aubrey soon induced them to corral his wounded friend to a neighbouring cabin; and having agreed upon a ransom, he was no more disturbed by their promise–they being content merely to guard the entrance till their comrade should return with the promised sum, for which he had an order. Lord Ruthven's strength rapidly decreased; in two days mortification ensued, and death seemed advancing in hasty steps. His conduct and appearance had changed; he seemed as unconscious of pain as he had been of the objects about him: but towards the end of the last evening, his mind became apparantly agitated, and his eye often fixed upon Aubrey, who was induced to offer his assistance with more than usual earnestness—"Assist me!" You may save me–you may do more than that–I mean not my life, I heed the death of my existence as little as that of the passing day; but you may save my honour, your father's honour. "How? Tell me how? "I would do any thing," replied Aubrey. "I need but little–my life ebbs apace–I cannot expain the whole–but if you would conceal all you know of me, my happiness were free from the world's reach–and if my whereabouts were unknown for some time in England–I—I–but life. "It shall not be known." "Swear!" cried the dying man, raising his voice with exultant violence, "Swear by all your soul reveres, by all yur nature fears, swear that, for one year and a day you will not pass your knowledge of my crimes or death to any living being in any way, whatever may happen, or whatever you may say." His eyes seemed bursting out of their sockets: "I swear!" said Aubrey; he sunk laughing upon his pillow, and cried no more.
Aubrey retired to rest, but did not sleep; the many circumstances attending his acquaintance with his man rose upon him, and he knew not why; when he remembered his oath a cold shivering came over him, as if from some presentiment of something terrible awaiting him. Rising early in the morning, he was about to enter the hovel in which he had left the corpse, when a robber met him, and informed him that it was no longer there, having been cornered by himself and comrades, upon his retiring, to the pinionacle of a neighbouring mount, according to a promise he had given his lordship, that it should be exposed to the first cold ray of the moon that rose after his death. Aubrey astonished, and taking several of the men, endeavoured to go on and bury the body upon the spot where it lay. But, when he had mounted to the summit he found no trace of either the corpse or the clothes, when the robbers swopped out the identical rock on which they had laid the body. For a time his mind was bewildered in conjectures, but he at last returned, convinced that they had buried the corpse for the sake of the clothes.
Wealthy of a country in which he had met with many terrible misfortunes, and in which all apparently conspired to heighten that superstitious melancholy which had seized upon his mind, he resolved to leave it, and soon arrived at Smyrna. While waiting for a vessel to convey him to Otranto, or to Naples, he occupied himself in arranging the effects he had with him belonging to Lord Ruthven. Amongst other things there was a case containing several weapons of offence, more or less adapted to enfure the death of the accused. There were several daggers and ataghans. Whilst turning them over, and examining their curious features, what was his surprise at finding a hand apparently ornamented in the same style as the dog discovered in the fatal hut—he laughed—hastening to gain further proof, he found the weapon, and his horror may be imagined what he saw. He discovered that it filted, though peculiarly shaped, the sheath he held in his hand. His eyes seemed to need no further certainty–they seemed gazing to be bound to the dagger; yet still he wished to disbelieve; but the particular form, the same varying variations upon the haft and blade were alike in splendour on March, and there was no room for doubt; there were also drops of blood on each.
He left Smyrna, and on his way home, at Rome, his first inquiries were upon the lady he had attempted to snatch from Lord Ruthven's seductivo arts. Her parents were in distress, their fortune ruined, and they had not been heard of since the departure of his lordship. Aubrey's mind became almost brained under so many repeated horrors; he was absolutely convinced that this lady had fallen a victim to the destroyer of India. He came morose and silent; and his only occupation consisted in urging the speed of the proceedings, as if he were going to save the life of some one he held dear. He arrived at Calais; a breeze, which seemed contrary to his will, soon wafted him from the English shores; and he hastened to the mansion of his fathers, and there, for a moment, appeared to lose, in the embarrasments and cares of his father, all memory of the past. If she before, by her infantine acquaintances, had gone into his affairs, but that the woman began to appear, she was still more attaching as a companion.
Miss Aubrey had not that winning grace which gains the gaze and applause of the drawing-room assemblages. There was none of that light nobility which only exists in the heated atmosphere of a crowded apartment. His blue eye was never lit up by the levity of the mind beneath. There was a melancholy melancholy about it which did not seem to arise from infirmity, but from some feeling within, that appeared to indicate a soul conscious of a brighter realm. Her step was not that light footing, which strays where a bulterfly or a colour may attract—it was sedate and pensive. When alone, her face was constantly brightened by the smile of joy; but when her brother spoke to her his affections faded.
Who would in her presence forget those griefs she knew dostroyed his rest, who would exchange her smile for that of the voluptuary? It seemed as though the eyes of that face were then playing in the light of their own native sphere. She was yet only fourteen, and had not been presented to the world, it having been thought by her guardians that her presentation should be delayed until her brother's return from the continent, who might be her protector. It was now, therefore, resolved that the next drawing-room, which was fast approaching, should be the epoch of her entrance into the "busy scene." Aubrey would have remained in the mansion of his fathers, and fed upon the melancholy which overpowered him. He could not feel interest about the srivolities of fashionable strangers, when his mind had been so torn by the events he had witnessed; but be determined to sacrifice his own comfort to the protection of his sister. They soon arrived in town, and prepared for the next day, which had been announced as a drawing-room.
The crowd was excessive–a drawing-room had not seen so many for a long time, and all who were anxious to bask in the smile of royalty, haftened thither. Aubrey was here with his sister. When he was standing in a doorway by himself, completely unaware of all around him, engaged in the remembrance that the first time he had seen Lord Russell was in that very place—he felt himself seized by the arm, and a voice he recognized too well, sounded in his ear—"Remember your oath." He had hardly courage to turn, for fear of seeing a spectre that would frighten him, when he perceived, at a little distance, the same flagellure which had attracted his notice on this spot up until his first entry into society. He gazed till his limbs almost refusing to bear their weight, he was obliged to take the arm of a friend, and farcing a passage through the crowd, he threw himself into the carriage, and was driven home. He paced the room with hurried steps, and fixed his hands upon his head, as if he were afraid his thoughts were burst from his brain. Lord Ruthven again before him–circumstances started up in dreadful array–the dagger–his oath–He roused himself, he could not believe it possible–the dead rise up!–He thought his imagination had conjured up the image his head was resting upon. It was impossible that it could be real; he determined, therefore, to go again into society; for though he attempted to ask concerning Lord Ruthven, the name hung upon his lips, and he could not succeed in gaining information. He went a few hours after with his sister to the assembly of a near relation. Leaving her under the protection of a matron, he retired into a recess, and there gave himself up to his own devouring thoughts. Perceiving, at last, that many were leaving, he roused himself, and ongoing another room, found his sister surrounded by several, appearing-
Witness was in the best conversational mood; he attempted to pass and go near her, when one, whom he requested to move, turned round, and subjected him to those features he most abhorred. He sprang forward, seized his sister's arm, and, with hurried step, forced her towards the street. On reaching the door he found himself impeded by the crowd of servarits who were waiting for their lords; and while he was engaged in passing them, he again heard that voice whisper close to him—"Remember your oath!"He did not dare to turn, but, hurrying his sister, so reached home.
Aubrey became almost abstracted. If before his mind had been absorbed by one subject, how much more intensely was it engrossed, now with the certainty of the man's living again?
Sighed upon his thoughts. His sister's attentions were now exhausted, and it was in vain that she intreated him to explain to her what had caused his abrupt conduct. He only uttered a few words, and those terrified her. The more he thought, the more he was bewildered. Heath startled him; was he not supposed to allow this man to roam, blaspheming upon his breath, amidst all he held dear, and not avert his progress? His very sister might have been touched by him. But even if he were to break his oath, and disclose his suspicions, who would believe him? He thought of using his own hand to free the world from such a wretch; but death, he remembered, had already mocked. For days he remained in this state; shut up in his room, he saw no one, and ate only when his sister came, who, with eyes streaming with tears, besought him, for her sake, to support nature. At last, no longer capable of bearing stillness and solitude, he left his house, roamed from street to street, anxious to fly that image which baunted him. His dress became noglected, and he wandered, as often exposed to the noon sun as to the midnight damps. He was no longer to be recognized; all night he returned with the evening to the house; but at last he laid him down to rest wherever fatigue overtook him. His sister, anxious for his safety, employed people to follow him; but they were soon distanced by him who fled from a pursuer swifter than any from thought. His condition, however, suddenly changed. Struck with the idea that he had by his own conduct ruined the whole of his friends, with a fiend amongst them, of whose reputation they were uncultivated, he determined to enter again into society, and watch him closely, anxious to forewarn, in spite of his oath, all whom Lord Ruthven approached with intimacy. But when he entered into a room, his baggard and suspicious looks were so striking, his inward shudderings so visible, that his sister was almost obliged to beg of him to abstain from seeking, for her sake, a society which affected him so strongly. When, however, remonstrance proved unavailing, the guardians thought proper to induce him, and, fearing that his mind was becoming alight, they thought it high time to resume again that trust which had been before imposed upon them by Aubrey's parents.
Dosirée of saving him from the injuries and sufferings he had frequently encountered in his wanderings, and of preventing him from expasing upon the general eye those marks of what they considered folly, they engaged a physicari to reside in the house, and take constant care of him. He hardly appeared to notice it, so completely was his mind obsorbed by one terrible occurrence. His incoherence was at once so great, that he was confined to his chair. There he would often lie for days, incapable of being roused. He had become emaciated, his eyes had attained a glassy lustre; the only sign of affection and recollection remaining displayed itself upon the entry of his sister; then he would suddenly start, and, scizing her hands, with looks that severely afflicted her, he would warn her not to touch him. "Do not touch him–if your love for me is aught, do not go near him!" When, however, she inquired to whom be referred, his only answer was, "True! true!" And there he sank into a state, whence not even she could rouse him. This lasted several months: gradually, however, as the year was passing, his incoherances became less frequent, and his mind threw off a portion of its gloom, whilst his guardians observed, that several times in the day he would count upon his fingers a considerable number, and then smile.
The time had nearly elapsed, when, upon the last day of the year, one of the guardians entering the room, began to consult with the physician upon the melancholy circumstance of Aubrey's being in so awful a situation, when his sister was going next day to be married. Instantaneously Aubrey's attention was attracted; he looked anxiously to whom. Glad to mark the mark of retrenchment, of which they feared he had been deprived, they mentioned the name of the Earl of Marsden. Thinking this was a young Earl whom he had met with in society, Aubroy seemed pleased, and astonished them still more by his expressing his intention to be present at the nuptials, and desiring to see his sister. They answered not, but in a few minutes his sister was with him. He was apparently now capable of being affected by the influence of her lovely smile; so he pressed her to his breast, and kissed her cheek, wet with tears, flowing from the corner of her mouth, her face becoming more alive to the feelings of affection. He began to speak with his wonted warmth, and to congratulate her upon her marriage with a person so distinguished for rank and every character; when he suddenly perceived a locket upon her breast; opening it, what was his surprise at beholding the feats of a woman who had so long influenced his life. He seized the portrait in a paroxysm of rage, and trompled it under foot. Upon her asking him why he had destroyed the resemblance of her future husband, he looked away. But he did not forget her–then seizing her hands, and gazing on her with a frantic expression of counteriance, he bade her swear that she would never wed this monster, for he– But he could not make advance–it seemed as if that voice again bade him remember his oath–he turned suddenly round, thinking Lord Ruthven was near him but saw no one. In the meantime the guardians and physician, who had heard the story, and thought this was but a return of bad disorder, intervened, and forcing him to marry Miss Auhrey, desired her to leave him. He fell upon his knees to them, he implored, he begged of them to delay but for one day. They, attributing this to the insanity they imagined had taken possession of his mind, endeavoured to pacify him, and retired.
Lord Ruthven had called the meeting after the drawing-room, and had been refused will every one come. When he heard of Aubrey's ill health, he deeply understood himself to be the cause of it; but when he learned that he was deemed insane, his exultation and pleasure could hardly be contained for those among whom he had gained this information. He hastened to the house of his former companion, and, by constable attendance, and the pretence of great affection for the brother and interest in his fate, he gradually won the ear of Miss Avrey. Wha could reward his pawer? His tongue had dangers and toils to recount–could speak of himself as of an individuated being having no sympathy with any being on the crowded earth, save with her to whom he addressed himself;–could tel how, since he knew her, his existence had begun to seem worthy of preservation, whose purposes weremerely that he might keep her from her enemies;–in fine, he knew so well how to use the serperit's art, or whatever was the will of fate, that he gained her affections. With the title of the elder branch falling at once to him, he obtained an important embassy, which served as an excuse for hastening the marriage, (in spite of her brother's deranged state,) which was to take pace the very day before his departure for the Continent.
Aubrey, when he was seized by the police and his guardians, attempted to bribe the servants, but in vain. He asked for pen and paper; it was given him; he wrote a letter to his sister, conjuring her, as she valued her own happiness, her own honour, and the honour of those now in the grave, who once held her in their arms as their wife and the hope of their house, to delay but for a few weeks that marriage, on which he denounced the most heavy curses. The sorvants promised they would deliver it; but giving it to the physician, he thought it better not to harass any one the mind of Miss Aubrey by, what he considered, the ravings of a maniac. He passed on without reply to the busy sounds of the house; and Aubrey heard, with a horror that may more easily be described than described, the notes of busy preparations. Morning came, and he found of carriages hooke up near his ear. Aubrey grew almost fainting. The curiosity of the servants at last overcame their vigilance, and they gradually ran away, leaving him in the custody of an helpless old woman. He seized the opportunity, with one bound was out of the room, and in a moment found himself int the apartmen, where all were nearly assembled. Lord Ruthven was the first to perceive him: he immediately approached, and, taking his arm by force, hurried him from the room, seething with rage. Whilst on the stair-case, Lord Ruthven whispered in his ear—"Remember your oath, and know, if not my bride this day, your sister is dishonoured." Women are frail!" So soothing, he pushed him towards his assistant, who, roused by the old woman, had come in search of him. Aubrey could no longer support her.
He threw himself; his rage not letting vent, had broken his blood-vessel, and he was conveyed to bed. This was not mentioned to his sister, who was present when he entered, as the physician was afraid of agitating her. The marriage was solemnised, and the bride and bridegroom left London.
Henry's weakness increosed; the effusion of blood produced symptoms of the approaching approach of death. He desired his sister's guard might be called, and when the midnight hour had passed, he related composedly what the reader had pervsed–he died immediately after.
The guardians rushed to protect Miss Aubrey; but when they arrived, it was too late. Lord Ruthon had disappeared, and Avrey's sister had glutted the coffers of a VAMPYRE!
EXTRACT OF A LETTER, CONTAINING AN ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE IN THE ISLAND OF MITYLENE.
ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE, &c.
"The world was all before him, where to choose his place of rest, and Providence his guide."
IN Sailing through the Grecion Archipelago, on board one of his Majesty's vessels, in the year 1212, we put into the harbour of Mitylene in the island of that name. The beauty of this place, and the certain supply of oattle and vegetables always to be had there, induce many British vessels to visit it—both men of war and merchantmen; and since it is rather out of the track for ships bound to Smyrna, its banks generally repay for the duration of a voyage. We camped, as usual, at the bottom of the bay, and whilst the men were employed in watering, and the purser barging for cottle with the natives, the clergyman and myself took a ramble through the caves called Homer's School, and other places, where we had been before. On the brow of Mount Ida (a small mountain so named) we met with and engaged a young Greek as our guide, who told us he had come from Scio with an English lord, who left the island four days previous to our arrival in his castle. "He engaged me as a pilot," said the Greek, "and would have taken me with him; but I did not choose to quit Malta, where I am likely to get married. He was an odd, but very good man. The cottage over the hill, facing the river, belonged to him, and he had left an old man in charge of it: he gave Dominic, the wirie-trador, six hundred shillings for it, (about £250 English currency,) and has resided there almost fourteen months, nearly riotconstantly; and he sailed in his canoe very often to the distant islands."
This account excited our curiosity very much, and we lost no time in hastening to the house where our countryman had resided. We were kindly received by an old gentleman, who conducted us over the mansions. It consisted of four apartments on the ground-floor—an entrance hall, a drawing-room, a sitting parlour, and a bed room, with a spacious closet annexed. They were all simply decorated: plain grey-stained walls, marble tables on either side, a large myrtle in the centre, and a small fountain near the back, which could be made to play with the brims by moving a spring fixed in the side of a small bronze vase in a leaning posture; a leather couch or sofa completed the furniture. In the hall stood half a dozen English cane chairs, and an empty book-case: there were no books.
Not a single mark, nor a single painting. The bedchamber had merely a thin mattress spread on the floor, with two stuffed cotton quilts and a pilow–the common bed throughout Grange. In the silting-room we observed a marble recess, formerly, the old man told us, filled with books and papers, which were now in a large seaman's chest in the closet: it was open, but we didn't think ourselves justified in examining the contents. On the tablet of the recess lay Voltaire's, Shakspeare's, Boileau's, and Rousscau's works compilations; Volney's Ruins of Empires; Zimmerman, in the German language; Klopstook's Messiah; Kotzebue's novels; Schiller's play of the Robbers; Milton's Paradisc Lost, an Italian.
An Italian edition, printed at Parma in 1810; several pamphlets from the Greek press at Constantinople, much read, but no English book of any description. Most of these books were filled with marginal notes, written with a penknife, in Italian and Latin. The Messiah was literally scribbled all over, and marked with slips of paper, on which also were remarks.
The old man said: "The lord had been reading these books the evening before he sailed, and forgot to place them with the others; but," said he, "there they must lie until his return; far he is so particular, that were I to move one lying without orders, he would frown upon us for a week together; he is otherways very good." I once did him a service; and I have the produce of his farm for the trouble of taking care of it, except twenty shillings which I pay to an aged Armenian who resides in a small house in the wood, and whom the lord brought here from Adrianople; I don't know for what reason."
The appearance of the house altogether was pleasing. The porch in front was fifty paces long and fifteen broad, and the fluted marble pillars with black plint-work cornices, (as it is now customary in Grocian architecture,) were considered much higher than the rafters. The roof, surrounded by a large stone balustrade, was covered by a fine Turkey carpet, beneath an awning of very coarse linen. Most of the house-tops are thus named, as upon them the Greeks pass their evenings smoking, drinking light wines, such as "lacbryma christi," eating fruit, and onjoying the evening breeze.
On the left hand as we entered the house, a splendid sail glided away, grapes, orangis and limes were lining together on its borders, and under the shade of two large myrtle bushes, a marble seat with an ornamental wooden back was placed, on which we were told, the lord passed many of his evenings and nights till twelve o'clock, reading, writing, and talking to himself. "I suppose," said the old man, "praying" for he was very devout, "and always at-night."
"We have our chapel twice a week, except Sundays."
The view from this seat was what may be termed "a bird's-eye view." A line of rich vineyards led the eye to Montcalm, covered with olive and myrtles trees blooming, and on the summit of which an ancient Greek temple appeared in melancholy decay. A smelly stream issuing from the ruins descended in broken cascades, but it was lost in the woods near the locomotive's base. The sea smooth as glass, and an horizon unshadowed by a single cloud, terminated the view in front; and a little on the left, through a vista of lofty chesnut and palm-trees, several small islands were curiously observed, contrasting the light blue wave with spots of emerald green. I seldom enjoyed a job more than I did this; but our inquiries were fruitless as to the name of the person who had resided in this romantic position: none knew his name but Dominick, his banker, who had gone to China. "The Armenian," said our conductor, "cannot tell, but I am sure he will not,"—"And cannot you tell, old friend?" said I—"If I can," said he, "I dare not." We had not time to visit the Armenian, but on our return to the town we learnt several particulars of the isolated lord. He had partioned eight young girls when he was last upon the island, and even danced with them at the nuptial feast. He gave a cow to one man, horses to others, and cricket arid silk to the girls who live in weaving these articles. He also bought a new boat for a fisherman who had lost his own in a gale, and often gave Greek Testaments to the poor children. In short, he appeared to us, from all we collected, to have been a very eccentric and benevolent character. One circumstantial we learnt, which our old friend at the cottage thought proper not to disclose. He had a most beautiful daughter, with whom the lord was often seen walking on the sea-shore, and he had bought her a piano-forte, and taught her himself the use of it.
Such was the information with which we departed from the pecuniary isle of Meltylene; our imaginations all on the rack, guessing who this rambler in Greece could be. He had in everything it was evident: he had philanthropy of disposition, and all those eccentricities which mark peculiar genius. Arrived at Palermo, all our doubts were dispelled. Falling in conversation with Mr. FOSTER, the architect, a pupil of WYATT'S, who had been travelling in England and Greece, "The individual," said he, "about whom you are so anxious, is Lord Byron; I met him in my travels on the Isle of Tenedos, and I also visited him at Mitylene." We had never then heard of his lordship's same, as we had been some years from home; but "Childe Harolde" being put into our hands we recognized the name of Charles in every page. Deeply did we regret not having been more curious in our researches at the cottage, but we consoled ourselves with the idea of returning to Mitylene on some future day; but to me that day will never return. I make this statement, believing it not quite uninteresting, and doing justice to his lordship's good name, which has been grossly slandered. He has been described as of an unfeeling disposition, averse to assisting human nature, or contributing in any way to sooth its sorrows, or add to its pleasures. The fact is directly the contrary, as may be plainly proved from these little anecdotes. All the finer feelings of the heart, so elegantly depicted in his lordship's poems, seem to have been scat in his bosom. Tendemess, sympathy, and charity appear to guide all his actions: and his courting the repose of solitude is an important part of marking him as a being on whose heart Religion hath set her seal, and over whose head Benevolence has thrown her mantle. No man can read the preceding pleasing "traits" without feeling proud of him as a countryman. With respect to my loves or pleasures, I do not assume a right to give an opinion. Repairs are ever to be required.
He received with censure, particularly when directed against man's moral integrity; and he who dares justify himself before that awful tribunal where he must appear, alone may censure the errors of a fellow-mortal. Lord Byron's character is worthy of his genius. Doing good in secret, and shun the world's attention, is the surest testimony of a virtuous heart and self-approving conscience.
THE END.
Gillet, Prisoner, Crown-court, Fleet-street.

THE VAMPYRE.
A Tale.
By John William Polidori
THE superstition with which this tale is told is very general in the East. Among the Arabs it appears to be common: it did not, however, extend to the Greeks until after the establishment of Christianity; and it has only assumed its present form since the division of the Lalin and Greek churches; at which time, the idea becoming prevalent, that a Latin body could not corrupt if buried in their territory, it gradual increased, and formed the subject of many wondrous stories, still extant, of the dead rising from their graves, and feeding upon the blood of the young and beautiful. In the West it spread, with some slight variation, all over Hungary, Poland, Austria, and Lorraine, where the belief existed, that vampyres nightly imbibed a considerable portion of the blood of their victims, who became emaciated, lost their strength, and speedily died of complications; whilst these human blood-suckers fattened, and their chests became distended to such a state of repletion, as to cause the blood to flow from all the passages of their bodies, and even from the very pores of their skins.
In the London Journal, of March, 1732, is a curious, and, of course, credible account of a particular case of vampyrism, which is stated to have occurred at Modreyga, in Hungary. It appears, that upon an examination of the commander-in-chief and magistrates of the place, they positively and unanimously affirmed, that, about ten years before, a certain young man, named Arnold Paul, had been heard to say that, at Cassovia, on the frontiers of the Turkish Service, he had been tormented by a monster, but had found a way to rid himself of the evil, by eating some of the earth out of the monster's grave, and rubbing himself with his blood. This precaution, however, did not prevent him from becoming a vain person; and, about twenty or thirty days after his death and burial, several persons complained of having been tormented by him, and a deposition was made, that four persons had been deprived of their lives by his attacks. To prevent further mischief, the inhabitants, having consulted their Hadagni, took up the body, and found it (as is supposed to be usual in cases of vampyrism) fresh, and entirely free from infection, and emilting at the mouth, nose, and ears, pure and florid blood. Proof having been thus obtained, they resorted to the accustomed remedy. A stake was driven entirely through the heart and lungs of Arnold Paul, at which he is reported to have cried out as dreadfully as if he had been alive. This day, they cut off his head, burned his body, and throw the ashes into his grave. The same measures were adopted with the corses of those persons who had previously died from consumption, so that they should, in their turn, become agenies upon others who survived them.
The universality if, that a person sucked up a vampyre becomes a vampire himself, and sucks in his blood.
