THE VAMPYRE.
A Tale.
By John William Polidori
THE superstition upon which this tale is based is very general in the East. Among the Arabs it appears to be common: it did not, however, extend to the Greeks until after the establishment of Christianity; and it has only assumed its present form since the division of the Latin and Greek churches; at which time, the idea becoming prevalent, that a Latin body could not corrupt if burjed in their territory, it gradually increased, and formed the subject of many well-known stories, still extant, of the dead rising from their graves, and feeding upon the blood of the young and beautiful. In the West it spread, with some light variation, over Hungary, Poland, Austria, and Lorraine, where the belief existed, that prisoners nightly imbibed a portion of the blood of their victims, who became emaciated, lost their strength, and speciously died of consumptions; whilst the human blood-suckers fattened, and their veins became distended to such a state of repletion, as to cause the blood to flow from all the passageways of their bodies, and even from the pores of their skins.
The London Journal, of March, 1732, is a curious, and, of course, credible account of a partcular case of ampyrism, which is slated to have occurred at Madreyga, in Hungary. It appears, that upon an examination of the commander-in-chief and magistrates of the place, they unanimously and unanimously affirmed, that, about five years before, a certain Heyduke, named Arnold Paul, had borne witness to say that, at Cossovja, on the territory of the Turkish Servia, he had been tormented by a vampyre, but had found a way to rid himself of the evil, by eating some of the earth out of the vampyr's grave, and rubbing himself with his blood. This precaution, however, did not prevent him from becoming a vampyre himself; for, out twenty or thirty days after his death and burial, many persons complained of being tormented by him, and a deposition was made, that four persons had been deprived of life by his attacks. To prevent further mischievous, the inhabitants having consulted their physicians, took up the hair, and found it (as is supposed to be required in cases of vampyrism) fresh, and entirely free from corruption, and emitting from the mouth, nose, and ears, pure and florid blood. Proof having been thus obtained, they resorted to the accustomed remedy. A stake was driven entirely through the chest and body of Arnold Paul, at which he is reported to have cried as dreadfully as if he had been stabbed. This done, they cut off his head, burned it, and threw the ashes into his grave. The same measures were adopted with the horses of those persons who had previously died from vampyrism, so that they should, in their tum, become agents upon others who survived them.
The jury returned a verdict.
The general belief is, that a person sucked by a vampyre becomes a vampire himself, and sucks in his turn.
Chief bailiff.
The monstrous occurrence is here related, because it seems better adapted to illustrate the subject of the present observances than any other instance which could be adduced. In many ports of Greece it is considered as a sort of punishment after death, for such a heinous crime committed whilst in existence, that the deceased is not only doomed to vampyriſe, but compelled to confine his infernal visitations solely to those beings he loved most while upon earth—those to whom he was bound by ties of kindred and affection.A supposition alluded to in the "Glamour."
But first on earth, Clerkenwell sent. Thy corse shall from its tomb be rent; Then ghastly haunt the native place, and suck the blood of all thy creatures; There be your daughter, sister, wife, at midnight drain the stream of life; Yet loathe the banquet which perforce must fated thy livid enemies, The victims, when they yet expire, shall know the demon for their sire; As cursing thee, thou cursing them, Thy flowers are withered on the stem. But one that for thy crime must fall, The youngest, best beloud of all, shall be born with a father's name. That word shall wrap thy heart in flame! Yet you must end thy task and mark her death's last glimpse–her eye's last spark, and the last glassy glance must view which freezes on its lifeless head; Then with unhinged hand shall tear the tresses of her long black hair, of which, in life, was a lock when her former Affection's fondest pledge was worn– But now is borne away as the Memorial of thine agony! Yel with the best blood shall drip; Thy gnawing tooth, and haggard lip; Then stalking to thy sullen grave, Go, and with Gouls and Angles rave, Till these in horror shririk away from spectre more accursed than this.
Mr. Southoy has also introduced in his wild and beauliful poem of "Thaaba," the vampyrecourse of the Arabian maid Oneiza, who is represented as having returned from the grave for the purpose of tormenting him she had loved whilst in existence. But this cannot be supposed to have result from the insincerity of her wife, she being represented throughout the course of the tale as a complete type of purity and innocence. The veracious Tovarnefort gives a long account in his travels of several astounding cases of vampyrism, to which he pretends to have been an eyewitness; and Calmet, in his great work up on the subject, besides a variety of anecdotal, and traditionary narratives illuftrative of its effects, has put forth some learned dissertations, tending to prove it to be a classical, as well as a barbararian error.
Many documentaries and intemperate notices on this singularly horrible superstition might be compiled; though the present may suffice for the limits of a note, necessarily devoted to explanation, and which may now be concluded by merely remarking, that although the term Vampyre is the one in most general acceptation, there are several others synonymous with it, made us of in various parts of the world: such as Vroucolocha, Vardoulacha, Goul, Broucoloka, &c.
THE VAMPYRE.
It happened that in the midst of the dissensions attendant on a London winler, the deceased appeared at the various parties of the leaders of the ton a nobleman, more remarkable for his singularities, than his rank. He gazed upon the mirth around him, as though he could not participate therein. Apparently, the light laughter of the fair only attracted his attention, that he might by a look quell it, and throw fear into those breasts where thoughtlessness reigned. Those who regarded the sight with a sense of awe, could not explain whence it appeared: some attributed it to the dead grey eye, which, flinging upon the object's face, did not seem to penetrate, and at one glance to point downwards to the inward workings of the heart; but fell upon the check with a leaden ray that weighed upon the skin so much it could not pass. His peculiarities caused him to be invited to every house; many wished to fee him, and those who had been accustomed to violence, and now felt the weight of melancholy, were pleased at having something in their presence capable of aging their attentions. In spite of the deadly hue of his face, which scarcely gairied a warmer tint, either from a blush of modesty, or from the strong emolion of passlon, though his form and outline were beautiful, many of the female hunters after notoriety attempted to win his attentions, and gain, at least, some marks of what they might term affection: Lady Mercer, who had been the mockery of every lady shewn in drawing-rooms since her arrival, threw herself in his way, and did all but put on the dress of a milliner, to attract his notice:—though in fact, when she stood before him, and though his eyes were apparently fixed upon her's, still it seemed as if they were unperceived;–even her unappalled impudence was baffled, and she left the field. But since the common adultress could not induce even the guidance of his eyes, it was not that the female sex was indifferent to him: yet such was the apparent caution with which he addressed to the virtuous wife and innocent daughter, that few knew he ever addressed letters to females. He had, however, the reputation of a winning torigue; and what was that it even overeame the dread of his singular character, that they were moved by his apparent hatred of vice, he was as infamous among those femoles who form the boast of their sex from their domestic habits, as among those who sully it by their vices.
About the same time, there came to London a young gentleman of the name of Aubrey: he was an orphan left with an only sister in the possession of great wealth, by parents who died while he was yet in childhood. Left also to himself by guardians, who thought it their duty merely to take care of his fortune, while they relinquished the more important cargo of his mind to the care of mercenary subalterns, he cultivated more his imagination than his judgment. He had, hence, the highest romantic feeling of honour and candour, which daily ruins so many milliners' apprenticeship. He believed all to sympathise with virtue, and thought that vice was thrown in by necessity merely for the pictorial effect of the scene, as we see in romances: he thought that the misery of a cottage merely consisted in the vesting of clothes, which were as warm, but which were better adapted to the prisoner's eye by their irregular folds and vorious coloured patches. He thought, however, that the dreams of poets were the reallties of life. He was handsome, frank, and rich: for these reasons, upon his entering into the gay circles, many mothers surrounded him, striving which should describe with least regret their languishing or romping favouritcs: but all at the same time, by their brightening countenances when he approached, and by their sparkling eyes, when he opened his lips, soon led him into false notions of his talent and his merit. Attached as he was to the romance of his solitary hours, he was startled at finding that, except in the torch and wax candles that flickered, not from the presence of a ghost, but from want of snuffing, there was no support in real life for any of that congeries of pleasing pictures and descriptions contained in those volumes, from which he had formed his study. Finding, however, some compensation in his gratified career, he was about to relish his dreams, when the extraordinary being we have above described, crossed him in his career.
He watched him; and the very impossibility of forming an idea of the character of a man completely absorbed in himself, who gave few other signs of his observation of external objects, than the tacit indifference to their existence, implied by the avoidance of their contact: allowing his imagination to picture every thing that flattered its propensity to extravagant ideas, he soon formed this object into the hero of a romance, and determined to observe the offspring of his passion, rather than the person before him. He became acquainted with him, paid him attentions, and so far advanced up his notice, that his presence was always recognised. He gradually learnt that Lord Ruthven's friends were embarrassed, and soon found, from the noise of preparation in High Street, that he was about to travel. Desirous of gaining some information respecting this singular character, who, until now, had only whetted his curiosity, he hinted to his guard, that it was time for him to perform the tour, which for many generations has been thought necessary to enable the young to take some rapid steps in the career of vice, by putting them themselves up to an equality with their elders, and not allowing them to appear as if fallen from the sky, wherher scandalous intrigues are mentioned as the subjecs of pleasantry or of praise, according to the degree of skill shewn in carrying them on. They consented, and Avrey immediately mentioning his intentions to Lord Ruthven, was surprised to receive from him a proposal to join him. Flattered by such a mark of respect from him, who, appareritly, had not much in common with other men, he gladly accepted it, and in a few days they had passed the circling waters.
Hitherto, Aubrey had had no opportunity of ascertaining Lord Ruthven's character, and now he found, that, although many more of his actions were exposed in his view, the results offered different conclusions from the applicatory motives of his conduct. His companion was profuse in his liberality; the idle, the vagabond, and the beggar, received from his hand more than enough to relieve their immediate wants. But Aubrey could not avoid remarking, that it was not upon the virtuous, reduced to indigence by the difficulties attendant even upon virtue, that he beslowed his alms; these were sent from the door with hardly suppressed fancies; but when the profligate came to ask something, not to relieve his wants, but to allow him to wallow in his lust, or to sink him still deeper in his iniquity, he was sent away with charity. This was, however, attributed by him to the greater inportunity of the vicious, which generally prevails over the retiring strength of the virtuous indigent. There was one circumstance about the charity of his Lordship, which was much more impressed upon his mind: all those upon whom it was bestwed, inevitably believed that there was a curse upon it, and they were all either condemned to the scaffold, or sunk to the lowest and the most abject misery. At Brussels and other towns through which they passed, Aubrey was surprised at the apparent eagerness with which his companion sought for the centres of all fashable vice; there he entered into all the spirit of the faro table: he betted, and always gambled with success, except where the known sharper was his antagonism, and then he lost more than he led; but it was always with the same unchanging face, with which he generally watched the crowd. It was not, however, so when he confronted the rash youthful novice, or the luckless fellow of a numerous family; the latter his very wish sceamed fortune's law; this apparent obstinateness of mind was said aside, and his eyes sparkled with more fire than that of the cat whilst lying with the half-decensed mouse. In every town, he left the formerly affluent youth, from the company he adorned, cursing, in the silence of a dungeon, the fate that had drawn him within the reach of this end; whilst many a father sat frantic, amidst the speaking looks of mute hungry children, without a single farthing of his immense wealth, wherewith to buy even sufficient to satisfy their present craving. Yet he took no money from the gambling table; he immediately lost, to the ruiner of rnany, the last gilder he had snatched from the convulsive grasp of the innocent: this might well be the result of a certain degree of knowedge, which was not, however, capable of combating the cunning of the more experienced. Aubrey often wished to represent this to his brother, and beg him to renounce that charity and pleasure which proved the ruin of all, and did not tend to his own interests; but he delayed it; for each day he hoped his friend would give him some opportunity of speaking frankly and openly to him; however, this never occurred. Lord Ruthven in his carriage, and amidst the various wild and rich scenes of nature, was always the same: his eye spoke louder than his lip; and though Aubrey was near the object of his curiosity, he obtained no greater gratification from it. He felt the consternation of finally knowing to break that mystery, which to his excited imagination began to assume the appearance of something supernatural.
He soon arrived at Rame, and there for a time last sight of his companion; he left him in daily attendance upon the morning circle of an Italian countess, whilst he went in search of the memorials of another almost deserted city. While he was thus engaged, letters arrived from England, which he opened with eager impatience; the first was from his sister, bearing nothing but affection; the others were from his guardians, the latter astonished him; if it had before entered into his conviction that there was an evil power resident in his companion, these seemed to give him sufficient reason for the belief. Heif guards insisted upon his immediately leaving his friend, and urged him to do so. His character was particularly vicious, for that the possession of irresistable powers of seduction, rendered his licentious habits more dangerous than others.
-ety. It had been covered, that his contempt for the adultress had not originated in hatred of her character; but that he had required, to enhance his gratification, that her lover, the partner of his life, should be burled from the pinnacle of unsullied virtue, down to the lowest depths of infamy and degradation: in consequence, that all those females whom he had sought, apperently on account of their beauty, had, since his departure, thrown even the mask aside, and had not scrupled to expose the whole deformity of their vices to the public gaze.
Aubrey determined upon finding one, whose pupil had not yet showered a single bright spot on which to rest the eye. He resolved to invent some plausible pretext for abandoning him altogether, purposing, in the mean time, to watch him more closely, and to let no suspicious circumstances pass unnoticed. He entered into the same circle, and soon perceived that his Lordship was endeavouring to work upon the inexperience of the daughter of the lady whose house he chiefly frequented. In Italy, it is seldom that an unmarried female is met with in society; he was therefore obliged to carry on his plans in secret; but Avrey's eye followed him in all his windings, and soon discovered that an assignation had been appointed, which would most likely end in the murder of an innocent, but thoughtless girl. Losing no time, he entered the office of Lord Ruthven, and abruptly asked him his intentions with respect to the lady, informing him at the same time that he was aware of his being about to meet her that very night. Lord Ruthven answered, that his intentions were such as he supposed all would have upon such an occasion; and on being asked whom he intend to marry her, merely laughed. Aubrey retired; and, immediately writing to not to say, that from that point he must refrain from accompanying his Lordship in the remainder of their proposed to visit, he ordered his servant to search at her apartments, and, calling upon the mother of the lady, informed her of all he knew, not only with regard to her daughter, but also concerning the character of his lordship. The assignation was prevented. Lord Ruthven next day sent his servant to notify his consent to a separation; but did not hint any suspicion of his plans having been foiled by Aubrey's interposition.
Having left Rome, Aubrey directed his steps towards Greece, and crossing the Peninsula, landed himself at Athens. He then fixed his residence in the house of a Greck, and immersed himself in tracing the faded relict of ancient glory upon monuments that apparently, ashamed of chronicling the deeds of freemen only before saves, had hidden themselves beneath the shellering soil or many coloured lies. Under the same roof as himself, existed a being, so beautiful and deceased, that she might have formed the model for a painter wishing to place on canvass the promised hope of the faithful in Mahomet's paradise, save that her eyes spoke too much mind for any one to think she could belong to those who had no souls. As she danced upon the plain, or tripped along the mountain's fringe, one would have thought the gazelle a poor type of her beauties; for who would have excused her eye, apparently the eye of animatronic nature, for that sleepy luxurious look of the animal suited her to the taste of an epicure. The lively step of the osten accompanied Aubrey in his search for antiquities, and often would the unconscious girl, engaged in the pursuit of a Kashmere butterfly, show the whole beauty of her form, floating as if were upon the wind, to the eager gaze of him, who forgot the letters he had just decamped upon an almost effaced trunk, in the contemplation of her sylph-like figure. Often would her tresses falling, as she flitted around, exhibit in the sun's ray such delicately brilliant and swiftly fading hues, it might well illustrate the forgetfulness of the antiquary, who let escape from his mind the very object he had before thought of vital importance to the proper interpretation of a passage in Pausanias. But why attempt to describe charms which all feel, but no one can appreciate?–It was innocence, youth, and beauty, unasfected by crowded drawing-rooms and stifling balls. Whilst he drew those remains of which he wished to preserve a memorial for his future hours, she would stand by, and watch the magic effects of his penance, in tracing the scenes of her native place; she would then describe to him the carnival dance upon the open plain, would paint, to him in all the glowing colours of youthful memory, the marriage pomp she remembered viewing in her infancy; and then, turning to subjects which had evidently made a greater impression upon her mind, would tell him all the supernatural tales of her nurse. Her earnestness and affection for what she narrated, excited the interest even of Aubrey; and often as she told him the tale of the lying vampyre, who had passed years amidst his friends, and deceased every year, by seeding upon the life of a lovely girl a lovely secret to prolong his existence for the indefinite months, his blood would run cold, whilst he attempted to laugh her out of such idle and horrible fantasies; but she cited to him the names of old men who had at last detected one living among themselves, after several of their near relatives and children had been found marked with the stamp of the fiend's appetite; and when she found him so incredulous, she begged of him to believe her, for it had been, remarked, that those who had dared to question their existence, always had some proof giving them, which compelled them, with grief and heartbreaking, to confess it was true. She detailed to him the traditional appearance of these monsters, and his horror was increased, by hearing a pretty accurate description of Lord Ruthven; he, however, still persisted in persuading her, that there could be no truth in her fears, though at the same time he wondered at the many coincidences which had all tended to excite a belief in the supernatural power of Lord Ruthven.
Aubrey seemed to attach him more and more to her; her irinocence, contrasted with all the abstracted virtues of the women whom he had sought for his vision of romance, won his heart; and while he disparaged the idea of a young man of Englisb habits, marrying an uneducated Greek girl, still he found himself more attached to the almost fairy form before him. He would tear himself at times from her, and, forming a plan for some anti-vulgar research, he would depart, determined not to return until his object was attained; but he always found it impossible to fix his attentions upon the ruins around him, whilst in his mind he retained an image that seemed alone the centre of his thoughts. She was unconscious of his love, and was ever the same fearful infantile being he had first known. She always seemed to withdraw from him with reluctance; but it was because she had no longer quarrel with who she could visit her favourite haunts, whilst her guard was occupied in sketching or uncovering some mystery which had yet escaped the destructive hand of time. She had appealed to her parents on the subject of Vampyreſ, and they had, with severance present, affirmed their existence, pale with horror at the very name. Soon after, Aubrey determined to proceed upon one of his excursions, which was to detain him for a few hours; when they heard the name of the place, they all at once begged of him not to proceed at night, as he must necessarily pass through a wood, where no Greek would ever remain, after the day had closed, upon any consideration. They described it as the resort of the vampyres in their nocturnal orgies, and denounced the most heavy ovils as intending upon him who dared to cross the path. Avrey made light of their reproach, and tried to laugh them out of the idea; but when he saw them shudder at his daring to mock a superior, infernal power, the very name of which apparently made their blood freeze, he was silent.
Next morning Aubry set off upon his excursion unattended; he was surprised to observe the raucous face of his host, and was concerned to find that his words, mocking the belief of those horrible spirits, had inspired such error. When he was about to depart, the woman came to the side of his horse, and earnestly begged of him to roturn, since night allowed the power of these beings to be put in action; he promised. He was, however, so occupied in his work, that he did not perceive that day-light would soon end, and that in the horizon there was one of those spocks which, in the warmer climates, rapidly gather into a tremendous mass, and pour all their rage upon the devoted country. He at last, though, mounted his horse, determined to make up by speed for his delay: but he was too late. Twilight, in the southern climates, is almost instantaneous; immediately the sun sets, night begins: andere he had advanced far, the power of the storm was aboue–its echoing thunders had scarcely an interval of rest–its thick heavy rain forced its way through the canopying foliage, whilst the blue forked lightning seemed to fall and radiate from his very feet. Suddenly his horse look fright, and he was carried with dreadfulness through the entangled forest. The engine at once, through fatigue, stopped, and he found, by the glare of the setting sun, that he was in the neighbourhood of a hovel that hardly lifted itself up from the masses of dead leaves and brushwood which surrounded it. Dismounting, he approached, hoping to find some one to guide him to the towri, or at least to obtain shelter from the pelting of the storm. As he approached, the thriders, for a moment silent, allowed him to hear the dreadful shrieks of a woman mingling with the stifled, exuberant mockery of a lough, continuod in one almost unbroken sound; he was startled: but, roused by the thunder which again rolled over his head, he, with a determined effort, forced open the door of the hut. He found himself in utter darkness: the sound, however, guided him. He was apparently unperceived; for, though he called, still the sounds continued, and no notice was taken of him. He found himself in confrontation with some one, who in he immediately seized; when a voice cried, "Again baffled!" to which a loud laugh succeeded; and he felt himself grappled by one whose strength seemed superhuman: determined to sell his life as deceased as he could, he slugled; but it was in vain: he was lifted from his feet and hurled with enormous force upon the ground: his enemy threw himself upon him, and kneeling upon his back, had placed his hands up to his throat when the glare of many lorches penetrating through the hole that gave way in the day, disturbed him; he instantly rose, and, leaving his prey, rushed through the door, and in a moment the crashing of the branches, as he broke through the wood, was no longer heard. The storm was now still; and Aubrey, unable to keep moving, was soon followed by those without. They exploded; the light of the flaming tarches fell upon the mud walls, and the thatch loaded on every individual bed with heavy flakes of soot. At the desire of Aubroy they searched for her who had attracted him by her manners; he was again left in darkness; but what was his horror, when the light from the windows once more burst upon him, to perceive the airy form of his fair conductress brought in a lifeless state. He closed his eyes, hoping that it was but a vision arising from his disturbed imagination; but he again saw the same form, when he opened them, stretched by his side. There was no colour on her cheek, not even on her lip; yet there was a stench aboul her face that seemed almost as attaching as the life that had once been there: upon her neck and breast was blood, and upon her throat were the marks of teeth having opened the vein: to this the men pointed, crying, simultaneously struck with horror, "A Vampyre!" "A Vampyre!" A quarrel was quarrelled, and Aubrey was laid by the side of her who had lately been to him the object of so much jealousy and saisonions, now fallen with the flower of life that had died within her. He knew not what his thoughts were–his mind was benumbed and seemed to shun reflection, and take refuge in vacancy–he held almost unconsciously in his hand a raked dagger of a particular construction, which had been found in the hut. They were soon met by different parties who had been engaged in the search for her whom a mother had missed. Their lamentable cries, as they approached the city, warned the parents of some dreadful catastrophe. –To describe their grief would be impossible; but when they ascertained the cause of their child's death, they looked at Aubrey, and pointed to the carse. They were inconsolable; both died broken-hearted.
Aubrey being put to bed was seized with a sudden violent fever, and was often delirious; in these disturbances he would call upon Lord Ruthven and upon Miss Cantwell–by some unclandestine combination he seemed to beg of his former companions to spare the being he loved. At other times he would imprecate maledictions upon her head, and curse him as her destroyer. Lord Ruthven, chanced at this time to arrive at Athenf, and, from whatever motive, upon hearing of the state of Aubrey, immediately placed himself in the same house, and became his constable. When the latter recovered from his delirium, he was horrified and startled at the sight of him whoso image he had now combined with that of a Vampyre; but Lord Ruthven, by his kind words, implying almost repentance for the fault that had caused their separation, and still more by the attention, anxiety, and care which he showed, soon reconciled him to his presence. His lordship seemed somewhat changed; he no longer appeared the apathelic being who had soastonished Aubrey; but as soon as his recovery seemed to be rapid, he again gradually retired into the same state of mind, and Aubrey perceived no difference from the former man, except that at times he was surprised to see his gaze fixed intently upon him, with a smile of malicious satisfaction playing upon his lips: he knew not why, but this smile haunted him. During the last stage of the invalid's recovery, Lord Rulbven was apparently engaged in watching the tides and waves raised by the cooling breeze, or following the progress of the large orbs, circling, like our world, the maveless sun;—indeed, he appeared to wish to avoid the eyes of all.
Aubrey's mind, by the shock, was much weakened, and that elasticity of spirit which had once so distressed him now seemed to have fled far away. He was now as much a lover of solitude and silence as Lord Routhven; but much as he wished for solitude, his mind could not find it in the neighbourhood of Athens; if he searched it among the ruins he had formerly frequented, Anthe's form would be by his side—if he found it in, the woods, her light would appear wandering amidst the underwood, in quest of the modest violet; then suddenly turning round. Would how, to his wild imagination, her pale face arid wounded throat, with a meek smile upon her lips. He determined to remember all scenes, every one of which created such strong associations in his mind. He proposed to Lord Ruthven, to whom he held himself bound by the careful care he had taken of him during his illness, that they should visit those parts of Greece neither had yet seen. They trawled in every direction, and sought every spot to which a recollocation could be attached: but though they thus moved from place to place, yet they seemed not to heed what they gazed upon. They heard much of robbers, but they gradually began to slight these reports, which they imagined were only the invention of individuals, whose interest it was to excite the generosity of those whom they defended from pretended dangers. In consequence of thus neglecting the advice of the authorities, on occasion they travellcd with only a few guards, more to serve as guides than as a defence. Upon entering, however, a narrow defile, at the bottom of which was the bed of a river, with large masses of rock brought down from the neighbouring provinces, they had reason to repent their negligence; for scarcely were the members of the party engaged in the narrow pass, when they were startled by the whistling of gunpowder close to their heads, and by the echoed report of cannon guns. In an instant their guards had left them, and, placing themselves behind rocks, had begun to fire in the direction whence the report came. Lord Ruthven and Avrey, having exhausted their ammunition, retired for a moment behind the sheltering turn of the ditch; but ashamed of being thus detained by a foe, who with insulting shouts bade them advance, and being exposed to unresisting slaughter, if any of the robbers should climb above and take them in the rear, they decided at once to rush forward in search of the enemy. Hardly had they left the shelter of the rock, when Lord Ruthven received a shot in the shoulder, which brought him to the ground. Aubrey hastened to his assistance; and, no longer heeding the cantest or his own peril, was soon surprised by seeing the robbers' faces around him–his guards having, upon Lord Russell's being wounded, immediately thrown up their arms and surrendered.
By promises of great reward, Aubrey soon induced them to convey his wounded friend to a neighbouring cabin; and having agreed upon a ransom, he was no more disturbed by their presence–they being committed merely to guard the entrance till his comrade returned with the promised sum, which he had obtained. Lord Ruthven's strength rapidly decosed; in two days martyrdom ensued, and death seemed advancing with hasty slaps. His conduct and appearance had not changed; he seemed as unconscious of pain as he had been of the objects about him: but towards the close of the last evening, his mind became apparently uneasy, and his eye often fixed upon Aubrey, who was inclined to offer his assistance with more than mere earnestness—"Assist me! You may save me–you may do more than that–I moan not my life, I heed the death of my existence as little as that of the passing day; but you may save my honour, your friend's honour. "How? Tell me how? "I would do anything," replied Aubrey. "I need but little–my life ebbs apace–I cannot explain the whole–but if you would conceal all you know of me, my honour were free from stain in the world's mouth–and if my death were unknown for some time in England–I—I—but life. "It shall not be known." "Swear!" cried the young man, raising him up with exultant violence, "Swear by all that your soul reveres, by everything that your nature fears, swear that, for a year and a day you will not impart your knowledge of my crimes or death to any living being in any way, whatever may happen, or whatever you may see. His eyes seemed bursting from their sockets: "I swear!" Sald Aubrey; he sunk laughing up into his pillow, and breathed no more.
Aubrey retired to rest, but did not sleep; the many circumstances atending his acquaintance with this man rose upon his mind, and he knew not why; when he remembered his oath a cold shivering came over him, as if from the presentiment of something horribleness awaiting him. Rising early in the morning, he was about to enter the hovel in which he had found the corpse, when a robber met him, and informed him that it was no longer there, having been conveyed by himself and comrades, upon his retiring, to the pinnacle of a neighbouring mount, according to a promise they had given his lordship, that he should not be exposed to the first cold ray of the moon that came aftr his doath. Aubrey astonished, and taking several of his men, determined to go and bury it upon the spot where it lay. But, when he had mounted to the summil he found no trace of either the corpse or the clothes, though the robbers swore they pointed out the identical rock on which they had laid the body. For a time his mind was lost in conjectures, but he at last relurned, convinced that they had buried the corpse for the sake of the clothes.
Weary of a country in which he had met with such terrible misfortunes, and in which all apparently confpired to highten the superstitious melancholy that had seized upon his mind, he resolved to leave, and soon arrived at Smyrna. Whilst waiting for a vessel to convey him to Otranto, or to Naples, he occupied himself in arranging those effects he had upon him belonging to Lord Ruthven. Amongst other things there was a case containing several weapons of violence, more or less adapted to occasion the death of the victim. There were several daggers and cudgels. Whilst turning them over, and examining their peculiar forms, what was his surprise at finding a sheath apparently ornamented in the same style as the dagger discovered in the fatal hut–he shuddered–hastening to gain further proof, he found the woapon, and it may be imagined what he discovered that it filted, though peculiarly shaped, the sheath he held in his hand. His eyes seemed to need no further certification–they seemed gazing to be bound to the dagger; yet still he wished to disbelieve; but the particular form, the various tints upon the haft and sheath were alike in splendour on both, and left no room for doubt; there were also drops of blood on both.
He left Smyrna, and on his way home, at Rorne, his first inquiries were upon the lady he had attempted to snatch from Lord Ruthven's seductress. Her parents were in distress, their fortune ruined, and she had not been heard of since the departure of his lordship. Henry's heart became almost broken under so many repeated horrors; he was afraid that this lady had fallen a victim to the destroyer of India. He became morose and silent; and his entire occupation consisted in urging the speed of the proceedings, as if he were going to save the life of some one he held dear. He arrived at Calais; a breeze, which seemed abedjent to his will, soon wafted him to the English shores; and he hastened to the house of his fathers, and there, for a moment, appeared to lose, in the embraces and caresses of his sister, all memory of the past. If she, through her husband's care, had strengthened his affections, now that the woman began to appear, he was still more attaching as a companion.
Miss Aubrey had not that winning grace which gains the gaze and admiration of the drawing-room company. There was none of that great brilliancy which only exists in the heated atmosphere of a crowded apartment. Her blue eye was red and lit up with the levity of the mind. There was a melancholy charm about it which did not seem to arise from misfortunes, but from some feeling within, that appeared to inspire a hope of a brighter future. Her step was not that light footing, which strays where a butterfly or a calour may attract—it was sedate and perisive. When she was alone, her face was never brightened by the smile of joy; but when her brother breathed to her his affection, and she could in her mind forget those griefs she knew destroyed his life, who would have exchanged her smile for that of the victor? It seemed as if the eyes were then playing in the light of their own native sphere. She was yet only seventeen, and had not been presented to the world, it having been decided by her guard-jans that her presentation should be delayed until her brother's return from the continent, when he might be her protector. It was now resolved that the royal drawing-room, which was fast approaching, should be the epoch of her entry in the "busy sceno." Aubrey would not have remained in the mansion of his father, and fed on the insanity which overpowered him. He could not feel interest about the habits of fashionable strangers, when his mind had been so torn by the events he had witnessed; but he determined to sacrifice his own comfort to the protection of his sister. They soon arrived in town, and proposed for the next day, which had been described as a drawing-room.
The crowd was excessive–a drawing-room riot been held for a long time, and all who were anxious to bask in the smile of royalty, hastened thither. Aubrey was there with his sifter. While he was standing in a carner by himself, heedless of all around him, engaged in the remembrance that the first time he had seen Lord Rulhven was in that very place—he fell himself sudderily seized by the arm, and a voice he recognized well, sounded in his ear—"Remember your oath." He had hardy courage to look, fearful of seeing a spectre that would frighten him, when he perceived, at a little distance, the same figure which had attracted his notice on his spot upon his first entry into society. He gazed till his limbs almost refusing to bear their weight, he was obliged to seize the arm of a friend, and forcing a passage through the crowd, he threw himself into his carriage, and was driven home. He paced the room with hurried steps, and fixed his hands upon his head, as if he were afraid his brains were hursting from his brain. Lord Ruthven again before him–circumstances started up in dreadful array–the devil–his oath–He repeated himself, he could not believe it possible–the dead rise again!–He thought his imagination had conjured up the image his mind was resting upon. It was impossible that it could be real–he determined, therefore, to go again into society; for when he attempted to ask concerning Lord Ruthven, the name hung upon his lips, and he could not succeed in gaining information. He went a few nights after with his sister to the assembly of a near relation. Loaving her under the prolection of a matron, he retired into a recoss, and there gave himself up to his own devouring habits. Perceiving, at once, that many were coming, he roused himself, and entering another room, found his sister surrounded by several, apparently in excitement; he attempted to pass and get near her, when one, whom he requested to move, turned round, and revealed to him the foatures he most abhorred. He sprang forward, seized his sister's arm, and, with hurried step, forced her towards the street: at the door he found himself blocked by the crowd of servants who were waiting for their lord; and while he was engaged in passing them, he heard that voice whisper close to him—"Remain!"
He did not dare to turn, but, hurrying his sister, soon reached home.
Aubrey became almost distracted. If before his mind had been absorbed by one thing, how much more completely was it crossed, now that the constriction of the machine's engine had pressed upon his thoughts. His sister's attentions were now unhindered, and it was in vain that she intreated him to explain himself to her. What had caused his abrupt conduct. He only uttered a few words, and those terrified her. The more he thought, the more he was bewildered. His oath bound him; how could he be then to allaw this morister to rage, swearing upon his breath, amidst all he held dear, and not avert its progress? He very sifter might have been touched by him. But even if he were to break his oath, and disclose his suspicions, who would believe him? He thought of employing his own hand to save the world from suicide; but death, heremembered, had been already mocked. For days he remained in his state; shut up in his room, he saw no one, and ate only when his sister came, who, with eyes streaming with tears, besought him, for her sake, to support nature. At midnight, no longer capable of remaining stillness and soliloude, he left the house, roamed from place to place, anxious to fly that image which haunted him. His dress became neglected, and he wandered, as exposed to the noon-day sun as to the midnight gloom. He was no stranger to be recognized; at first he returned with the deceased to the house; but at last he laid him to rest wherever fatigue overtook him. His sister, anxious for her safety, employed people to follow him; but they were soon distanced by him who fled from a pursuer swifter than any from thought. His conduct, however, suddenly changed. Stricken with the idea that he had lost by his absence the whole of his friends, with a fiend amongst them, of whose protection they were unconscious, he determined to enter again into society, and watch him closely, anxious to forewarn, in spite of his oath, all whom Lord Ruthven approached with intimacy. But when he entered into town, his haggard and suspicious looks were striking, his inward shuddering so viscerally, that his sister was at last obliged to beg of him to abstain from seeking, for her sake, that particular society which had affected him so bitterly. When, however, remonstrance proved unsatisfactory, the guards considered it proper to interpose, and, finding that his mind was becoming alienated, they thought it might be time to resume again that trust which had been before imposed upon them by Aubrey's parents.
Desirous of saving him from the injuries and sufferings he had daily encountered in these assaults, and of preventing him from exposing to the general eye any marks of what they considered folly, they induced a physician to reside in the house, and take care of him. He hardly appeared to notice it, as though he was completely absorbed by one terrible subject. His incoherence became at last so great, that he was confined to his chamber. For he would often lie for days, incapable of being roused. He had become emaciated, his eyes had attained a gassy lustre; the only sign of affection and recollection remaining displayed itself upon the entry of his sister; then he would sometimes start, and, seizing her hands, with looks that severely afflicted her, he would instruct her not to touch him. "Dh, do not touch him–if your love for me is aught, DO not go near him!" When, however, she inquired to whom she referred, his only answer was, "True! true!" Once again he sank into a stupor, when not even she could rouse him. This lasted many months, but gradually, as the year was passing, his incoherences became less frequent, and his memory threw off a portion of its meaning, whilst his friends observed, that several times in the day he would count on his fingers a defence.

The time had nearly elapsed, when, upon the last day of the year, one of his guardians entering his room, beg him to communicate with his physician upon the most alarming occurrence of Aubrey being in so awful a state, when his sister was going next day to be married. Instantly Aubrey's attention was attracted; he asked anxiously to whom. Glad of this mark of returning intellect, of which they feared he had been deprived, they mentioned the name of the Earl of Marrsden. Thinking this was a young Earl whom he had met with in society, Aubrey seemed pleased, and excited them still more by his expressing his readiness to be presont at the nuptials, and desiring to see his sister. They answered not, but in a few minutes his sister was with him. He was apparently again capable of being affected by the influence of her lovely smile; for he pressed her to his breast, and kissed her cheek, wet with tears, flowing at the thought of Robert's being once more alive and the feelings of affection. He began to speak with all his well-wited warmth, and to congratulate her upon her marriage with a person so distinguished for rank and extraordinary achievement; when he suddenly perceived a locket upon her breast; opening it, what was his surprise at seeing the features of the morister who had so long occupied his life. He seized the portrait in a paroxysm of rage, and trampled it upon his foot. Upon her asking him why he thus destroyed the resemblance of her future husband, he looked as though he did not understand her–then seizing her hands, and gazing on her with a frantic expression of countenance, he bade her swear that she would never wed this monster, or he would– But he could not make advance–it seemed as if that voice agajn bad. He turned suddenly round, thinking Lord Ruthven was near him but saw no one. In the meantime the guardians and physicion, who had heard the whole, and thought this was but a return of his disorder, entered, and forcing him from Miss Auhrey, desired her to leave him. He fell upon his knees to them, he implored, he begged of them to delay but for one day. The friends, attributing this to the insanity they imagined had taken possession of his mind, endeavoured to paeify him, and retired.
Lord Ruthven had called the morning after the drawing-room, and had been refused by no one else. When he heard of Aubrey's ill health, he readily understood himself to be the cause of it; but when he learned that he was deemed insane, his exultation and pleasure could hardly be concealed from those among whom he had gained this information. He hastened to the house of his former employer, and, by constant attendance, and the pretence of great affection for the brother and interest in his fate, he gradually won the ear of Miss Aubrey. Who could resist his power? If tongue had dangers and toils to recount, could speak of himself as of an individual having no sympathy with any being on the rodded earth, save with her to whom he addressed himself; could tell how, since he knew her, his existence, had begun to seem worthy of preservation, if it were morely that he might listen to her soothing appeals; in fine, he knew so well how to use the serpents's art, or such was the will of fate, that he gained her afflicions. The title of the elder branch falling at once to him, he obtained an important embassy, which served as an excuse far haftening the marriage, (in spite of her brother's deranged conduct,) which was to take place the very day before his departure from the Continent.
Aubrey, when he was left by the physician and his guardians, attempted to bribe the servants, but in vain. He asked for pen and paper; it was given him; he wrote a letter to his sister, conjuring her, as she valued her own happiness, her own honour, and the lives of those now in the grave, who once held her in their arms as their hope and the cornerstone of their house, to delay but for a few months that marriage, on which he denounced the most heavy curse. The servants promised they would deliver it; but giving it to the physician, he thought it better not to harass any more the mind of Miss Aubrey by, what he considered, the rauings of a maniac. Night passed on without rest to the friends of the house; and Aubrey heard, with a horror that may more easily be conceived than described, the noise of busy preparation. Morning came, and the sound of carriages hooke upon his ear. Aubrey grew almost frantic. The curiosity of the servants at last overcame their vigilance, they gradually stole away, leaving him in the custody of an helpless old woman. He seized the opportunity, with one bound was out of the room, and in a moment found himself in the apartment where all was unlawfully assembled. Lord Ruthven was the first to perceive him: he immediately app-
He reached, and, taking his arm by force, hurried him from the room, speculatively with rage. When on the staircase, Lord Ruthven whispered in his ear—"Remember your oath, and know, if not my bride to day, your sister is dishonoured." Women are frail!" So saying, he pushed him towards his fellows, who, roused by the old woman, had come in search of him. Aubrey could no longer support him; his rage not subsiding, had broken a blood-uncle, and he was conveyed to bed. This was not mentioned to her sister, who was not present when she entered, as the physician was afraid of upsetting her. The marriage was solemnized, and the bride and bridegroom left London.
Aubrey's weakness grew; the esfusion of blood produced symptoms of the near approaching of death. He desired his sister's guardians to be called, and when the midnight hour had struck, he related compilatively what the reader has perused–he died instantly after.
The guardians hastened to protect Miss Aubry; but when they arrived, it was too late. Lord Ruthven had disappeared, and Aubrey's sister had glutted the thirst of a VAMPYRE!
EXTRACT OF A LETTER, CONTAINING AN ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE IN THE ISLAND OF MITYLENE.
A CONSTANT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE, &c.
"The world was all before him, where to find his place of rest, and whom to be his guide."
IN Sailing through the Grecian Archipelago, on board one of his Majesty's vessels, in the year 1812, we put into the harbour of Malinocleo in the island of the same name. The buoyly of this place, and the certain supply of cattle and vegetables to be had there, induce many British vessels to visit it—both men of war and merchantmen; and though it lies far out of the track for ships bound to Smyrna, its bourities amply compensate for the deviation of their voyage. We landed, as usual, at the bottom of the bay, and whilst the men were employed in watering, and the purser bargaining for cattle with the natives, the clergyman and myself took a ramble round the cave called Homer's School, and other places, where we had been before. On the brow of Mount Ida (a small mountain so named) we met with and engaged a young German guide, who told us he had come from Scio with an English lord, who had left the island four days prior to our arrival in his country. "He engaged me as a pilot," said the Greek, "and would have taken me with him; but I did not want to quit Mitylerie, where I am likely to get married. He was an odd, but a very good man. The cottage over the hill, facing the river, belongs to him, and he has left an old man in charge of it: he gave Dominick, the wine-trader, six hundred zeroes for it, (about L250 English currency,) and had resided there about fourteen months, though not consulsantly; for he sails his felucca very often to the different rent islands."
This account excited our curiosity very much, and we lost no time in hastening to the house where our countryman had resided. We were kindly received by an old man, who conducted us over the mansion. It consisted of four apartments on the ground floor—an entrance hall, a drawing-room, a sitting parlour, and a bed room, with a spacious closet annexed. They were all uniformly decorated: plain green-stained walls, marble tiles on either side, a large window in the centre, and a small fountain outside.
A spring which could be made to play through the branches by moving a spring fixed in the side of a small bronze Venus in a leaning posture; a large couch or sofa constituted the furnitvre. In the hall stood half a dozen English cane chalrs, and an emply book-café: there were no mirrors, and a single window.
MONDAY. The bedchamber had merely a large mattress spread on the floor, with two stuffed cotton quilts and a pillow—the common bed throughout Greece. In the sitting-room we observed a marble desk, formerly, the old man told us, filled with books and papers, which were then in a large seaman's chest in the closet: it was open, but we did not think ourselves justified in examining the contents. On the tablet of the recess lay Voltaire's, Shakspeare's, Boileau's, and Roufseau's works compilations; Vanney's Ruin of Empires; Zimmermari, in the German language; Klopstock's Messiah; Kotzebue's novellas; Schiller's play of the Robbers; Milton's Paradise Lost, an Italian edition, printed at Parma in 1810; several small pamphlets from the Greek press at Constantinople, now torn, but no English book of any description. Most of these books were filled with handwritten notes, written with a pencil, in Ancient and Latin. The Moses was literally scribbled all over, and marked with slips of paper, on which also were remarks.
The old man said: "The lord had been reading these hooks the evening before he sailed, and forgot to place them with the others; but," said he, "there they must lie until his return; for he is so particular, that were I to move one without orders, he would frown upon me for a week together; he is otherways very good." I once did him a service; and I have the produce of this farm for the trouble of taking care of it, except twenty shillings which I pay to an aged Armenian who resides in a small cottage in the wood, and whom the lord brought here from Adriaticople; I don't know for what reason."
The appearance of the house externally was pleasing. The portico infront was fifty paces long and fourteen broad, and the fluted marble pillars willhack pinnacles and fret-work cornices, (as it is now customary in Grecian architecture,) were considerably higher than the roof. The roof, surrounded by a light stone balustrade, was covered by a flannel Turkey carpet, beneath an awning of fine coarse linen. Most of the house-tops are now fumished, as upon them the Greeks pass their evenings in smoking, drinking light wines, such as "lachryma christi," eating fruit, and enjoying the evening breeze.
On the left hand as we entered the house, a small streamlet glided away, grapes, oranges and limes were cluttering up logs on its banks, and under the shade of two large myrtle bushes, a marble seal with an ornamental wooden back was placed, on which we were told, the lord passed many of his evenings and nights till twelve o'clock, reading, writing, and talking to himself. "I suppose," said the old man, "praying" for he was very dejected, "and always attended church twice a week, besides Sundays."
The view from this seat was what may be termed "a bird's-eye view." A line of rich vineyards led the eye to Mount Calela, covered with olive and myrtle trees in bloom, and on the summit of which an important Greek temple appeared in majestic decay. A small stream flowing from the ruins descended in small cascades, until it was first in the woods near the mountain's base. The sea smooth as glass, and an horizon unshadowed by a single cloud, terminates the view in front; and a little on the left, through a vista of lofty chesnut and palm-trees, several small islands were distinctly observed, studding the blue wave with spots of emerald green. I seldom enjoyed a view more than I did this; but our enquiries were fruitless as to the name of the person who had resided in this romantic solitude: none knew his name but Dominick, a banker, who had gone to China. "The Armenian," said our conductor, "could tell, but I am sure he will not,"—"And can you tell, old friend?" said I—"If I can," said he, "I dare not." We had not time to visit the Armenian, but on our return to the towri we learnt some particulars of the isolated lord. He had portioned eight young girls when he was last upon the island, and had danced with them at the nuptial feast. He gave a cow to one man, horses to others, and cut silk to the girls who live by weaving articles. He also bought a new boat for a fisherman who had lost his in a gale, and he often gave Greek Testaments to the poor children. In short, he appeared to us, from what we learned, to have been a very eccentric and benevolent character. One circumstantial we learnt, which our old friend at the cottage thought proper not to disclose. He had a most beautiful daughter, with whom the lord was often seen walking on the sea-shore, and he had bought her a piano-forte, and taught her himself the use of it.
Such was the informatlon with which we departed from the peaceful Isle of Milylene; our imaginations all on the rack, guessing who his rambler in Greece could be. He had money it was evident: he had philanthropy of disposition, and all those eccentricities which mark peculiar genius. Arriued al Palermo, all our debts were discharged. Falling in company with Mr. FOSTER, the architect, a pupil of WYATT'S, who had been travelling in Egypt and Greece, "The individual," said he, "about whom you are so anxious, is Lord Byron; I met him in my travels on the island of Tenedos, and I also visited him at Constantinople." We had not then heard of his lordship's fain, as we had been some years from home; but "Childe Harold" being put into our hands we recognized the recluse of Calcla on every page. Deeply did we regret not having been more curious in our researches at the cottage, but we consoled ourselves with the idea of returning to Mityleno on some future date; but to me that day will never come. I make this statement, believing it not to be uninteresting, and in justie to his lordship's good name, which has been grossly slanderod. He has been described as having an unpleasant disposition, indifferent to associating with human nature, or conlributing in any way to sooth its sorrows, or add to its pleasures. The fact is direlly therever, as may be readily gathered from these little anecdotes. All the finer seelings of the heart, so elegant and deplored in his lordship's poems, seem to have taken their seat in his bosom. Tenderness, sympatico, and charity appear to guide all his acts: and his enjoying the repose of solitude is an additional reason for marking him as a being on whose heart Religion hath set her sea, and on whose head Benevolence hath thrown her mantles.
LONDON. No man can read the preceding pleasing "trails" without feeling proud of himself as a gentleman. With respect to his loves or pleasures, I do not assume a right to give an opinion. Reports are to be received with caution, particularly when directed against man's moral integrity; and he who dares justify himself before that awful tribunal where all men are apportioned, alone may censure the errors of a fellow-mortal. Lard Byron's character is worthy of his genius. To do good in secret, and receive the world's applause, is the testimony of a virtuous and self-approving conscience.
THE END.
Gillet, Printer, Crown-court, Fleet-street.

THE VAMPYRE.
ATALES.
By John William Polidori
THE superstition upon which his tale was founded is very general in the East. Amsterdam. For the Arabs it appears to be common: it did not, however, extend itself to the Greeks until after the establishment of Christianity; and it has evidently assumed its present position since the division of the Latin and Greek churches; at which time, the idea becoming prevalent, that a Latin body could not corrupt if buried in their territory, it gradually irreased, and formed the subject of many wonderful stories, still extant, of the dead rising from their graves, and feeding upon the blood of the young and weak. In the West it spread, with some slight variation, all over Hungary, Poland, Austria, and Lorraine, where the belief existed, that vampyrcs generally imbibed a certain portion of the blood of their victims, who became emaciated, lost their strength, and speedily died of consumptions; whilst the vampyrs themselves drank human blood.
-Suckers fattened, and their velves became distended to such a state of repletion, as to cause the blood to flow from all the passages of their bodies, and even from the very pores of their skins.
In the London Journal, on March, 1732, is a curious, and, of course, credible count of a peculiar case of vampyrism, which is stated to have occurred at Madreyga, in Hertfordshire. It appears, that upon an examination of the commander-in-chief and magistrates of the regiment, they positively and unanimously affirmed, that, about five years before, a certain Heyduke, named Arnold Paul, had been heard to say, at Cassovia, on the frontiers of the Turkish Service, ho had been threatened by a vampyre, but had found a way to rid himself of the evil, by eating some of the earth out of the vampire's grave, and rubbing himself with his blood. This precaution, however, did not prevent him from becoming a vampyre himself; for, about twenty or thirty years after his death and burial, many persons complained of having been tormented by him, and a deposition was made, that four persons had been deprived of life by his attacks. To prevent further mischief, the inhabitants having consulted their physicians, took up the body, and found it (as is supposed to be the case in cases of vampyrism) fresh, and entirely free from corruption, and emitting from the mouth, nose, and ears, fresh and florid blood. Proof having been thus obtained, they resorted to the accustomed remedy. A stake was driven entire through the heart and body of Arnold Paul, who is reported to have cried out as dreadfully as if he had been alive. This done, they cut off his head, burned his body, and threw the ashes into his grave. The same habits were adopted with the corses of those persons who had previously died from vampirism, lest they should, in their turn, become agents upon others who survived them.
The universal belief is, that a person sucked into a vampyre becomes a vampire himself, and suks in his turn.
Chief bailiffs.
This most unfortunate occurrence is here related, because it seems more adapted to illuminate the subject of the present observations than any other instance which could be added. In many parts of Greece it is considered as a form of punishment after death, for some heinous crime committed whilst in absence, that the deceased is not only doomed to vampyrise, but compelled to make fine infernal visitations solely to those beings he loved most while upon earth—those to whom he was bound by ties of kindred affection.
But first on earth, as Vampyre sent, Thy corse shall from its tomb he rent; Then ghostly haunt this place, and suck the blood of all thy race; There from thy daughter, sister, wife, at midnight drain the stream of life; Yet now the banquet-room must feed thy living corse, Thy victims, ere they yet expire, shall know the demon for their sire; As cursing thee, thou curfing them, Thy flowers are withered on the stem. But one word for thy culpable fall, The youngest, best beloved of all, shall leave thee with a father's name—That word shall wrap your heart in flame! Yet thou must end this task and mark her cheek's last tinge–hereye's last spark, and the last glassy glance must view which freezes over its lifeless blue; Then with unblowed hand shall tear the trims of her yellow hair, of which, in life a lock when shorn Affection's fondest possession was warned; But now is borne away by thee Memorial of thine agony! Yet with thine own best blood shall drip; Thy gnashing tooth, and haggard lip; Then stalking to thy own grave, Go, and with Gouls and Asrits rave, Till these in horror shrink away from spectre more accursed than they.
Mr. Southey has also introduced in his wild but beautiful poem of "Thalaha," the vampyre character of the Arabian maid Oneiza, who is represented as having returned from the grove for the purpose of tormenting him she best loved whilst in exile. Although she could not be permitted to be justified from the sinfulness of her life, she was represented through the whole of the tale as a complete type of purity and innocence. The crowd was excessive–a drawing-room had not been held for a long time, and all who were anxious to bask in the smile of royalty, hastened to see her. Aubrey was there with his sister. While he was standing in a corrier by himself, heedless of all around him, engaged in the recollection of the first time he had seen Lord Rutbven was in that very place—he felt himself suddenly seized by the arm, and a voice, which he recognised too well, sounded in his ear—"Remember your oath." He had hardly courage to turn, fearful of seeing a spectre that would blast him, when he saw, at a little distance, the same figure which had attracted his attention on this spot upon his first entry into society. He gazed till his limbs almost failing to bear their weight, he was obliged to take the arm of a friend, and forcing a passage through the crowd, he threw himself into his carriage, and was driven home. He paced the room with burried steps, and fixed his hands upon his head, as if he were afraid his thoughts were bursting from his brain. Lord Ruthven again came before him–circumstances started up in dreadful array–the dagger–his oath–He roused himself, he could not believe it–the dead rise again!–He thought his imagination had conjured up the image his mind was resting on. It was impossible that it could be real; he determined, therefore, to go again into society; for then he attempted to ask concerning Lord Rulhven, the name having passed on his lips, and he could not secure in positive information. He went a few nights after with his sister to the establishment of a near relation. Leaving her under the prolection of a matron, he retired into a room, and there gave himself up to his own devouring thoughts. Perceiving, at last, that many were leaving, he followed them, and entering another room, found his sister surrounded by mourners, apparently in earnest conversation; he attempted to pass and get near her, when one, whom he requested to move, turned round, and revealed to him those features he most abhorred. He sprang forward, seized his sister's arm, and, with a hurried step, carried her towards the passage: at the door he found himself blocked by the crowd of servants who were waiting for their lords; and while he was engaged in passing them, he again heard that voice whisper close to him—"Remember your oath." He did not dare to turn, but, hurrying his sister, soon came back.
Aubrey was almost distracted. If before his mind had been absorbed by this subject, how much more completely was it engrossed, now that the certainty of the monster's living evil pressed upon him? His sister's admonitions were now unheeded, and it was in vain that she urged him to cease to do what had caused his abrupt conduct. He only uttered a few words, and those terrified her. The more he thought, the more he was bewildered. His oath startedled him; was he then to allow this monster to roam, bearing ruin upon his breath, amidst all he held dear, and not avert its progress? His younger sister might have been touched by him. But there is no way to break his arm, and disfigure him.
If he made these statements, who would believe him? He thought of employing his own hand to free the world from such a wretch; but death, he remembered, had been already mocked. For days she remained in this state; shut in his room, he saw no one, and opened only when his sister came, who, with eyes streoming with tears, pleaded with him, far her sake, to support nature. At last, no longer capable of bearing stillness and salitude, he left his house, roamed from street to street, anxious to fly away from that which had hounded him. His dress became neglected, and he wandered, as often exposed to the noon-day sun as to the midnight gloom. He was no longer able to be recovered; at first he returned with the deceased to the house; but at last he laid him down to rest whereuer fatigue overtook him. His sister, anxiously for his safety, employed people to follow him; but they were soon distanced by him who fled from a pursuor swifter than any one thought. His conduct, however, suddenly changed. Struck with the idea that he left by his absence the whole of his friends, with a fiend amongst them, of whose presence they were unconsciences, he determined to enter again into society, and watch him closely, anxious to forewarn, in spite of his oath, all whom Lord Ruthven approached with inquiries.
