THE VAMPYRE.
A Tale.
By John William Polidori
THE superstition upon which this tale is founded is very general in the East. Among the Arabs it appears to be common: it did not, however, extend itself to the Greeks until after the establishment of Christianity; and it has only assumed its present form since the division of the Latin and Greek churches; at which time, the idea becoming prevalent, that a Latin body could not corrupt if buried in their territory, it gradually increased, and farmed the subject of any wonderful stories, still existing, of the dead rising from their graves, and descending upon the blood of the living beautified. In the West it spread, with some slight variation, all over Hungary, Poland, Austria, and Lorraine, where the belief existed, that bandits generally imbibed a certain portion of the blood of their victims, who became emaciated, lost their strength, and speedily died on consumptions; whilst the unfortunate blood-suckers fattened, and their veins became distended to such a point of repletion, as to cause blood to flow from all the passages of their bodies, and even from the very pores of their skin.
In the London Journal, of March, 1732, is a curious, and, of course, credible account of a particular case of vice-marriage, which is said to have occurred at Madreygcl, in Hungary. It appears, that upon an examination of the commander-in-chief and magistrates of the place, they positively and unanimously affirmed, that, about five years before, a certain Heyduke, named Arnold Paule, had been heard to say that, at Cassovia, on the frontiers of the Turkish Service, he had been tormented by a vampyre, but had found a way to rid himself of the evil, by cutting some of the earth out of the vampyr's grave, and rubbing himself with his blood. This precaution, however, did not prevent him from becoming a vampyre himself; for, about twenty or thirty days aftor his death and burial, many persons complained of having been harassed by him, and a deposition was made, that four persons had been deprived of food by his ottacks. To prevent further mischief, the inhabitants having consulted their physicians, took up the body, and found it (as is supposed to be the case in cases of vampyrism) fresh, and entirely free from corruption, and emitting at the mouth, nose, and eyes, pure amber fluid. Proof having been thus obtained, they resorted to the accustomed remedy. A stake was driven entirely through the heart and body of Arnold Paul, on which he is reported to have cried out as dreadfully as if he had been alive. When they were done, they cut off his head, burned his body, and threw the ashes into his grave. The same measures were adopted against the interests of those persons who had previously suffered from vampyrism, so that they should, in their turn, become agents upon others who threatened them.
The universal belief is that a person sucked by poison becomes a vampyre himself, and sucks in others turn.
Chilwell bailiff.
This monstrous crime is here related, he cause it seems better adapted to illustrate the subject of the present observations than any other evidence which could be adduced. In many parts of Greece it is considered as a sort of punishment after death, for some heinous crime committed whilst in existence, that the deceased is not only doomed to vampirism, but compelled to regulate his infernal visitations religiously to the beings he loved most while upon earth—those to whom he was bound by ties of kindred and affection.—A supposition alluded to in the "Gospel."
But first on earth, as Vampyre sent, thy corse shall from his tomb be rent; Then ghastly haunt the native place, and sully the blooms of all thy ranks; There from thy daughter, sister, wife, at once drain the stream of life; Yet from the banquet which perforce must feed thy enemies, Thy victims, though they yet expiro, shall know the demon for their sire; As cursing thee, thou cursing them, Thy flocks are withered on the stem. But one that knows thy crime must first fall, The youngest, beloved of all, shall bless thee with a father's name. That word shall wrap thy heart round life! Yet thou must end thy task and mark her cheek's last tinge—her eye's last spark, and the last glassy glance must view Whose head freezes over its lifeless blue; The with unhallowed hand shall tear the tresses from her yellow hair, of which, in life a lock when shorn Affection's solemn pledge was worn; But now is borne away by the Memorial of the agony! Yet with the own blood shall drip; Thy gnashing teeth, and haggard lip; Then stalking to thy sullen grave, Go, and will Gouls and Afrits rave, Till these in horror shrink away from spectre more accursed than they.
Mr. Southey has also introduced in his wild and beautiful poem of "Thaaba," the vampyre character of the Arabian maid Oneizcl, who is represented as having returned from the grave for the purpose of tormenting him she best loved whilst in exile. But this cannot be supposed to have recovered from the sinfulness of her life, she being presented to the readers of the tale as a complete type of purity and jinnocence. The veracious Tremort gives a long account in his travel of several astonishing cases of vampyrism, to which he pretends to have been an eyewitness. Calmet, in his great work upon this subject, besides a variely of anecdotes, and historical narratives illustrative of its effects, has put forth some learned dissertations, tending to prove it to be a classical, as well as a barbarian error.
Many curious and intemperate occurrences of this singularly horrible superstition might be added; though the present may suffice for the limits of a note, necessarily devoted to explanation, and which may now be conoluded by merely remonstrating, that though the term Vampyre is the one in most general acceptation, there are several other synonyms with it, made use of in various ports of the world: as Vroucalocha, Vardoulacha, Goul, Buccoloko, &c.
THE VAMPYRE.
It happened that in the middle of the dissipations occurred upon a London win.
In consequence, there appeared at the frequent parties of the leadors of the regiment a man, more remarked for his manners, than his rank. He gazed upon the mirth coursing through him, as though he could not participate therein. Apparently, the light laughter of the fair woman excited his attentions, that he might by chance look upon it, and throw himself into the breasts where thoughtless habits reigned. Those who felt this sensation of awe, could not explain whence it came: some attributed it to the dead grey eye, which, falling upon the prisoner's face, did not seem to penetrate, and at one glance to pierce through to the inward workings of the heart; but fell upon the cheek with a leader ray that weighed upon the skin it could not pass. His peculiarities caused him to be invited to every house; all wished to see him, and those who had been accustomed to violent excitement, and now felt the weight of ennui, were pleased at having someone in their presence capable of engagling their attention. In spite of the deadly hue of his face, which gradually gained a warmer tint, either from the blush of modesty, or from the vigorous movement of passion, though its form and outline were beautiful, many of the female hangers after notoriety attempted to win his attentions.
Ladies, and gentlemen, at least, same marks of what they might term affliction: Lady Mercer, who had been the mockery of every monster shewn in drawing-rooms since her marriage, threw herself in his way, and did nothing but put on the head of a mantle, to attract his notice:–though in vain:–when she stood before him, though his eyes were apparently fixed upon her's, still it seemed as though they were unperceived;–even her unappalled impudence was baffled, and she left the field. But though the common men could not influence him without the guidance of his eyes, it was not that the female sex was indifferent to him: yet such was the apparent caution with which ho spoke to the virtuous wife and innocent daughter, that few knew he ever addressed himself to females. He had, however, the reputation of a winning tongue; and whether it was that it evoked the dread of his sombre character, or that they were moved by his apparent hotred of vice, he was as often among those females who form the boast of their sex from their domestic virtues, as among those who sully it by their vices.
About the same time, there came to Lyon a young gentleman of the name of Aubrey: he was an orphan left with an unmarried sister in the possession of great wealth, by parents who died while he was yet in childhood. Left also to himself by guardians, who thought it their duty mere to take care of his fortune, when they relinquished the more imporant charge of his mind to the care of mercenary subalterns, he cullivated more his imagination than his judgment. He had, hence, that high reputation for honour and candour, which daily ruins so many milliners' apprenticeships. He believed all to sympathise with virtue, and thought that vice was thrown in by Provider merely for the picturesque effect of the scene, as we see in romances: he thought that the misery of a cottage merely eonsisted in the vesting of clothing, which were as warm, but which were better adapted to the painter's eye by their irregular folds and various coloured patches. He thought, in fine, that the dreams of poets were the realities of life. He was handsome, frank, and rich: all these things.
Upon his entering in the gay circles, many mothers supported him, striving which should describe with least truth their languishing or romping favourites: the daughters at some time, by their brightening countenances when he approached, and by their sparkling eyes, when he opened his lips, soon drew him into their notions of his talents and his merit. Attached as he was to the romances of his youth, he was startled at finding that, except in the lallow and wax candles that flickered, not from the presence of a ghost, but from want of snuffing, there was no foundance in real life for any of that congeries of pleasing pictures and descriptions contained in those volumcs, from which he had formed his study. Finding, however, some compunction in his gratified vanity, he was about to give up his dreams, when the extraordinary being we have above described, crossed him in his career.
He watched him; and the very impossibility of forming an idea of the character of a man enviously abused in himself, who gave few other signs of his observance of extemal objects, than the tacit assent to their existence, implied by the avoidance of human contact: allowing his imagination to picture every thing that flattered his propensity to extravagant ideas, he soon formed the object into the object of a romance, and determined to observe the offspring of such union, rather than the person before him. He became acquainted with him, paid him attentions, and so far advertised upon his notice, that his presence was always recognisably. He gradually learnt that Lord Rutbven's finances were embarrossed, and so was found, from the notes of preparation in Baker's Street, the place he was about to trovel. Desirous of obtaining some information respecting his singular character, who, till now, had only whet his curiosity, he hinted to his guardian that it was time for him to perform the tour, which since many generations has been thought necessary to induce the young to take some ropid steps in the career of man, towards putting themselves upon an equality with the aged, and not allowing them to oppear as prey from the skies, whenever scandalous intrigues are mentioned as the subjects of platoons of praise, according to the degree of skill required in corrying them off. They consented, and Aubrey immediately mentioning his intentions to Lord Ruthven, was surprised to receive from him a proposal to join him. Flattered by such a mark of affection from him, who, apparently, had nothing in common with other men, he gladly accepted it, and in a few days they had passed the circling waters.
Hitherto, Aubrey had had the opportunity of studying Lord Ruthven's character, and now found, that, though many more of his actions were exposed to his view, the results offered different conclusions from the apparent motives to his conduct. His companion was profuse in his liberality; the idle, the vagaband, and the beggar, received from his hand more than enough to relieve their immediate wants. But Aubrey could not avoid remarking, that it was not upon the virtuosos, reduced to indignity by the misfortunes attendant even upon virtue, that he gave his alms; these were sent from the door with hardly suppressed sneers; but when the profligate came to ask something, not to relieve his wants, but to allow him to walow in his lust, or to sink him still deeper in his iniquity, he was sent away with rich charity. This was, however, attributed by him to the greater importance of the vicar, which generically contrasts with the reticent bashfulness of the venerable indigenes. There was one circular about the character of his Lordship, which was still more impressible upon his mind: all those upon whom it was bestowed, inevitably found that there was a curse upon them, for they were either led to the scaffold, or sunk to the lowest and the most abject misery. At Brussels and other towns through which they passed, Aubrey was surprised at the apparent eagerness with which his compariion sought for the centres of all sashionable vice; there he entered into all the spirit of the faro table: he betted, and always gambled with success, except where the known sharper was his antagonist, and then he lost even more than he gained; but it was always with the same unchanging face, with which he generically watched the society around: it was not, however, so when he encountered the rash youth of a novice, or the luckless father of a numerous family; then his very wish seemed contrary to fortune's law—this apparent abstractedness of mind was laid aside, and his eyes sparkled with more fire than that of the cat whilst dallying with the half-dead mouse. In every town, he found the formerly affluenly youth, torn from the circle he adorned, cursing, in the solitude of a dungeon, the fate that had drawn him within the reach of this folly; whilst many a father became frantic, amidst the speaking cries of mute hungry children, without a single farthing of his late immeasurably wealth, with to buy anything sufficient to satisfy their present craving. The took no money from the gambling table; but immediately lost, to the ruiner of many, the last gilder he had just snatched from the convulsive grasp of the innocents: this might but be the result of a certain degree of knowledge, which was not, however, capable of matching the cunning of the more experienced. Aubrey often wished to represent this to his friend, and beg him to resign that charity and pleasurable which proved the ruin of his life, and did not tend to his own profit; but he dreaded it, for each day he hoped his friend would give him an opportunity of speaking honestly and openly to him; but, thankfully, this never occurred. Lord Ruthven in his carriage, and during the various wild and rich scenes of nature, was always the same: his eye spoke less than his lip; and although Avrey was always in the object of his curiosity, he obtained no greater satisfaction from it than the constant excilement of vainly wishing to break the mystery, which to his exalted imagination begait to assume the appearance of some extraordinary supernatura.
They soon arrived at Rome, and Aubrey for a time lost sight of his companion; he left him in daily attendance upon the morning call of an Italian countess, whilst he went in search of the memoranda of another almost deserted city. Whilst he was thus engaged, letters arrived from England, which he opened with eager impatience; the first was from his sister, containing nothing but affection; the others were from his guardians, the latter astoriished him; if it had before entered into his imagination that there was an evil power resident in his companion, these seemed to give him sufficient reason for the belief. His guardians insisted upon his immediately leaving his friend, and charged, that his character was dreadfully vicious, for the possession of irresistable powers of seductian, rendered his licentious habits more dangerous to society. It had been discovered that his enetempt for the adultress had not originated in hatred of her character; but that he had required, to enhance his gratisication, that his victim, the partner of his guilt, should be hurled from the pinnacle of unsullied virtue, down to the lowest abyss of infamy and degradation: in fine, that all those females whom he had sought, apparently on account of their virtue, had, since his departure, thrown even the mask aside, and had not scrupled to exposit the whole desolation of their vices into the public gaze.
Aubrey discharged upon arrival.
This one, whose character had not yet shown a single bright point on which to rest the eye. He resolved to invent some plausible pretext for abaridding him of her, purposing, in the mean time, to watch him exceedingly, and to let no suspicious circumstances pass by unnoticed. He entered into the room, and soon perceived that his Lordship was endeavouring to work upon the inoxperience of the daughter of the lady whose house he chiefly frequented. In Italy, it is seldom that an unmarried female is met with indifference; he was therofore obliged to carry on his plan in secret; but Aubrey's eye followed him in all his windings, and soon discovered that an assignation had been oppointed, which would most likely end in the ruin of an innately, though thoughtless girl. Losing no time, he entered the apartment of Lord Ruthven, and abruptly asked him his intentions with respect to the lady, informing him at the same time that he was aware of him being about to meet her that very night. Lord Ruthven answered that his interitions were such as he supposed all would have upon such an occasion; and upon being pressed whether he intended to marry her, merely laughed. Aubrey retired; and, immediately writing a note, to say, that from that moment he must refrain from accompanying his Lordship in the remand of their proposed tour, he ordered his servants to seek other employment, and calling upon the mother of the lady, informed her of all he knew, not only with regard to her daughter, but also concerning the character of his Lordhip. The assignation was preverited. Lord Ruthven next day merely sent his servant to notify his complete assent to a separation; he did not raise any suspicion of his plans having been foiled by Aubrey's interposition.
Having left Rome, Aubrey directed his ship towards Greece, and crossing the Peninsula, soon found himself at Athens. He then fixed his residence in the house of a Greek; and soon occupied himself in tracing the faded records of ancient glory upon inscriptions that apparently, ashamed of chronicling the deeds of freemen only before slaves, had hidden themselves beneath the sheltering soil or many coloured lichen. Under the same roof as himself, existed a being, so beautiful and delicate, that she might have formed the model for a palnter to pour tray on canvass that promised hope to the faithful in Mahomet's paradise, save that her eyes spoke too much mind for any one to think she could lead to those who had no souls. As she danced on the plain, or tripped along the mountain's side, one would have thought the gazelle a poor type of her beauties; for who would have exchanged her eye, apparently the eye of animated naturc, for that sleazy, sullen look of the animal suited but to the taste of an epicure. The light step of the girl often accompanied Avrey in his search after antiquities, and often would the unconscious girl, engaged in the pursuit of some mysterious buttery, show the whole beauty of her form, fluttering as it were upon the wind, and the eager gaze of him, who forgot the letters he had just decyphered upon an almofl effaced desk, in the contemplation of her sylph-like figurines. Often would her tresses falling, as she flitted around, exhibit in the sun's ray such dolicently briliant and swistly fading spots, it might reveal the forgetfulness of the annullary, who let escape from his mind the very object he had before thought of of great importanee to the proper interpretation of a passage in Pausanias. But why attempt to prescribe choruses which all agree, but none can appreciate? –It was innocence, youth, and beauty, unaffected by crowded drawing-rooms and stifling ballrooms. Whilst he drew those pictures of which he wished to preserve a memorial far his future hours, she would stand by, and watch the magic effects of his pencil, in tracing the scenes of her former place; she would then describe to him the ceaseless dance upon the open plain, would paint, to him in all the glowing colours of her happy memory, the marriage procession she remembered viewing in infancy; and then, referring to matters that had evidently made a greater impression upon her mind, would tell him the supernatural tales of her nurse. Her extraordinary description and appclrent belief of what she described, excited the interest even of Avrey; and often as she told him the tale of the living vampyre, who had passed years amidst his friends, and dearest ties, forced himself upon them each year, by feeding upon the flesh of a lovely female to prolong his existence for the ensuing months, his blood would run cold, whilst he attempted to laugh her out of such idiotic and horrible fantasies; but she cited to him the names of old men who had at last detected one living among themselves, after several of their near relations and children had been found marked with the stamp of the fiend's appetite; and when she found him so incredulous, she begged of him to believe her, for it had been, remarking, that those who had dared to question his existence, always had some proof given, which obliged them, with grief and heartbreaking, to confess it was true. She detailed to him the traditional appearance of these monsters, and his horror was increased, by hearing a pretty accurate description of Lord Ruthven; he, however, still persisted in persuading her, that there could be no truth in her fears, although at the same time he wondered at the many coincidences which had all tended to excite a belief in the supernatural power of Lord Rulven.
Aubrey began to attach himself more and more to Marie; her innocence, so contrasted with all the affected virtues of the women among whom he had sought for his vision of romance, touched his heart; and while he ridiculed the idea of a young man of English blood, marrying an uneducated Greek girl, still he found himself more attached to the almost fairy form before him. He would tear himself away at times from her, and, forming a plan for some antiquarian reseclaration, he would depart, determined not to return until his object was attained; but he often found it impossible to fix his attentions upon the objects before him, whilst in his mind he retained an image that seemed alone the rightful possessor of his possessions. She was unconscious of his love, and was ever the same frank and fantastic being he had first known. She always seemed to part from him with reluctance; but it was because she had no longer any one with whom she could visit her favourite haunts, whilst her guardian was occupied in sketching or uncovering some fragment which had yet escaped the destructive hands of time. She had appealed to her porents on the subject of Vampyres, and they whole, with many present, affirmed their existence, pale with horror at the very name. Soon after, Aubrey decided to proceed upon one of his excursions, which was to detain him for a few hours; when they heard the name of the place, they all at once begged of him not to return at once, as he must necessarily pass through a wood, where no Greek would ever remain, after the day had closed, upon any consideration. They described it as the resort of the vampyres in their nocturnal orgies, and described the most heavy evils as impending upon him who dared to cross their path. Aubrey made light of their representations, and tried to laugh them out of the idea; but when he saw them shudder at his daring thus to mock a superior, inferrial power, the very name of which immediately made their blood freeze, he was silent.
Next morning Aubrey set off upon his excursion unattended; he was surprised to observe the meloncholy state of his host, and was concerned to find that his words, mocking the belief of those horrible creatures, had inspired him with such terror. When he was about to depart, she came to the side of his horse, and earnestly begged of him to return, for night all seemed the power of these beings to be put in action; he promised. He was, however, so occupied in his research, that he did not perceive that day-light would soon end, and that in the morning there was one of those specks which, in the warmer climates, so rapidly gather into a tremendous mass, and pour all their rage upon the devoted country. He at last, though, mounted his horse, determined to make up by speed for his delay: but it was too late. Twilight, in these southern climates, is almost unknown; immediately the sun sets, night begins: and before he had advanced far, the power of the storm was above—its echoing thunders had scarcely an interval of rest—it thick heavy rain forced its way through the canopying foliage, whilst the blue forked lightning seemed to fall and radiate at his very feel. Suddenly his horse took fright, and he was carried with dreadful rapidity through the entangled forest. The collision at last, through fury, stopped, and he found, by the glare of lightning, that he was in the neighbourhood of a hovel which hardly lifted itself up from the masses of dead leaves and brushwood which surrounded it. Dismounting, he approached, hoping to find someone to guide him to the other side, or at least trusting to obtain shelter from the pelting of the storm. As he approached, the thunders, for a moment, allowed him to hear the dreadful fainting cries of a woman mingling with the stifled, exultant mockery of a laugh, continued in one almost unbroken sound; he was startled: and, roused by the thunder which again rolled over his head, he, with a sudden effort, flung open the door of the house. He found himself in utter darkness: the snake, however, guided him. He was apparently unperceived; and, though he called, still the sounds continued, and no notice was taken of him. He found himself in contact with someone, whom he immediately seized; when a voice exclaimed, "Again baffled!" to which a loud laugh succeeded; and he felt himself grappled by one whose strength seemed superhuman: determined to sell his wife as dearly as he could, he struggled; but it was in vain: he was lifted from his spot and hurled with enormous force against the grove: his enemy threw himself upon him, and kneeling upon his breast, had placed his hands upon his head when the glare of many torches penetrating through the hole that gave way in the day, disturbed him; he immediately rose, and, leaving his prey, rushed through the door, and in a moment the crash of the branches, as he broke through the wood, was no longer heard. The storm was raging still; and Aubrey, incapable of moving, was soon heard by those without. They entered; the light of their torches fell upon the mud wolls, and the thatch loaded every individual straw with heavy fakes of soot. At the desire of Aubrey they separated from her who had attracted him by her cries; he was again in darkness; but what was his horror, when the light of the torches one more bore upon him, to perceive the airy form of his fair conductress brought in a lifelike condition. He shut his eyes, hoping that it was but a vision arising from his disturbed imagination; but he again saw the same form, when he opened them, streaked by his tears. There was no colour upon her cheek, not even on her lip; yet there was a stillness about her face that seemed almost as attached to the life that once dwelt there:–upon her neck and breast was blood, and upon her throat were the marks of teeth having opened the wound:–to this the men pointed, crying, simultaneously slunk with horror, "A Vampyre!" "A Vampyre!" A litter was quickly formed, and Avrey was laid by the side of her who had lately been the object of so many bright and fairy visions, now fallen with the flower of life that had died within her. He knew not what his thoughts were–his mind was benumbed and seemed to shun refloction, and take refuge in vacancy–he held almost unconscionably in his hand a naked dagger of a particular construction, which had been found in the hut. They were soon met by different parties who had been engoged in the sight of her whom a whole had missed. Their lamentable cries, as they approached the city, forewamed the parents of this dreadful catastrophe. To describe their grief would be impossible; but when they ascertained the cause of their child's death, they looked at Aubrey, and pointed to the corse. They were inconsolable; both died brokenhearted.
Aubrey going to bed was seized with a violent fever, and was often delirious; in those intervals he would call on Lord Ruthven and upon himself; upon some unfortunate combination he seemed to beg of his former companion to spare the being he loved. At other times he would imprecise molested children upon his head, and curse him as her destroyer. Lord Ruthven, chanced at that time to arrive at Athens, and, from what seemed verifiable, upon hearing of the state of Aubrey, immediately placed himself in the same house, and became his constable attendant. When the lad recovered from his delirium, he was horrified and startled at the sight of him whose image he had now combined with that of a Vampyre; but Lord Routhven, by his kind words, implying almost repentance for the fault that had caused their separation, and still more by the attention, anxiety, and care which he showed, so reconciled him to his presence. His lordship seemed scarcely changed; he no longer appeared that apathetic being who had so astonished Aubrey; but after some time his convalescence began to become rapid, be again degenerated into the same state as before, and Aubrey perceived no difference from the former man, except that at times he was surprised to meet his gaze fixed intently upon him, with a smile of malicious exultation playing on his lips: he knew not why, but this smile haunted him. During the early stage of the invalid's recovery, Lord Ruthven was apparently engaged either in watching the tideloss wave's raised by the cooling breeze, or in marking the progress of those orbits, circling, like our world, the moveless sun;—indeed, he appeared to wish to avoid the eyes of all.
Aurey's mind, by this shock, was greatly weakened, and that elasticity of spirit which had once so distressed him now seemed to have fled for ever. He was now as much a lover of solitude and seclusion as Lord Ruthven; but much as he wished for solitude, his mind could not find it in the neighbourhood of Athens; if he sought it amidst the ruins he had formerly frequented, Anthea's form stood by his side; if be sought in the woods, her lightslep would appear wandering amidst the underwood, in quest of the modest violet; then suddenly turning round, would show, to his wild imagination, her pale face and wounded throat, with a meek smile upon her lips. He determined to fly scenes, every feature of which created such bitter associations in his mind. He proposed to Lord Ruthven, to whom he held himself bound by the tender care he had taken of him during his illness, that they should visit those parts of Greece neither had yet seen. They travelled in every direction, and sought every spot to which a recollection could be attached: but though they thus passed from place to place, they seemed not to heed what they gazed upon. They heard many reports of robbers, but they gradually began to slight the reports, which they imagined were ony the invention of indolent spirits, whose object it was to excile the generosity of those whom they defended from pretended dangers. In consequence of their neglecting the advice of the inhabitants, on one occasion they travelled with only a few guards, more to serve as guides than as a defence. Upon entering, through, a narrow defile, at the bottom of which was the bed of a torrent, with large masses of rock brought down from the neighbouring precipices, they had reason to repent their negligence; for scarcely were the whole of the party engaged in the narrow passage, when they were startled by the whistling of bullets close to their heads, and by the excited report of several guns. In an instant their guards had left them, and, placing themselves behind rocks, had begun to follow the direction whence the report came. Lord Ruthven and Aubrey, imitating their example, retired for a moment behind the shearers.
Atering turn of the file: but ashamed of being detained by a foe, who with insulting shoutings bade them advance, and being exposed to unresisting slaughter, if any of the robbers should come above and take them in the rear, they desisted at once to rush forward in search of the enemy. Hardly had they lost the shelter of the rock, when Lord Ruthven received a shot in the shoulder, which brought him to the ground. Aubrey hastened to his assistance; and, no longer heeding the canlest or his own peril, was soon surprised by seeing the robbers' faces close around him–his guards having, upon Lord Rutbaven's being wounded, immediately thrown up their arms and surrendered.
By promisos of great reward, Aubrey soon induced them to convey the wounded prisoner to a neighbouring cabin; and having agreed upon a ransom, he was no more disturbed by their presence–they being there merely to guard the establishment until their comrade should return with the promised sum, for which he had an order. Lord Ruthven's strength rapidly decreased; in two days mortality ensued, and death seemed advancing with slow steps. His conduct and appearance had not changed; he seemed as unconscious of pain as before. He had been of the objects about him: but towards the close of the last evening, his mind became apparently uneasy, and his eye often fixed upon Aubrey, who was induced to offer him assistance with more than his usual earnestness—"Afsift me! You may save me–you may do more than that–I care not my life, I heed the dictates of my existence as little as that of the passing day; but you may save my honour, your friend's honour. "How? Tell me how? "I would do anything," replied Aubrey. "I need but little–my life ebbs apace–I cannot exploit the whole–but if you would conceal all you know of me, my honour were safe from the world's mouth–and if my death were unknown for some time in England–I—I–but life. "It shall not be known." "Swear!" cried the dying man, raising himself with exultant violence, "Swear! by all your soul reveres, by all you nature fears, that, for a year and a day you will not impinge your knowledge of my crimes or death to any living being in any way, whatever may happen, or whatever you may see. His eyes seemed bursting from their sockets: "I swear!" said Aubrey; he sunk laughing on his pillow, and breathed no more.
Aubrey retired to rest, but did not sleep; the many circumstances altending his acquaintance with this man remained upon his mind, and he knew not why; when he remembered his oath a cold shivering came over him, as if from the presentiment of something horrible awaking him. Rising early in the morning, he was about to enter the hovel in which he had left the corpse, when a robber met him, and informed him that it was no longer there, having been conveyed by him and his comrades, upon his retiring, to the pinnacle of a neighbouring mount, according to a promise they had given his lordship, that it should be exposed to the first cold ray of the moon that rose after his death. Aubrey astonished, and taking some of the men, determined to go and bury the body upon the spot where it lay. He, when he had mounted to the summit, found no trace of the corpse or the clothes, though the robbers swore they pointed out the identical rock on which they had laid the body. Far a lime his mind was filled in conjectures, but he at last returned, convinced that they had buried the corpse for the sake of the clothes.
Weary of a country in which he had met with such terrible misfortunes, and in which all apparently conspired to heighten that superstilious melancholy which had seized upon his mind, he resolved to leave it, and soon arrived at Smyrna. While waiting for a vessel to convey him to Ortranto, or Naples, he occupied himself in arranging those effects he had with him belonging to Lord Ruthven. Amongst other things there was a box containing several weapons of offence, more or less adapted to ensure the death of the victim. There were feveral daggers and ataghans. Whilst turning some things over, and examining their curious forms, what was his surprise at finding a sheath apparenlly ornamented in the same style as the dagger discovered in the fatal hut—he shuddered—hastening to gain further proof, he found the woapon, and his horror may be imagined when he discovered that it fitted, though peculiarly shaped, the sheath he held in his hand. His eyes seemed to need no further certainty–they seemed gazing to be bound to the dagger; yet still he wished to disbelieve; but the porticula farm, the same varylling tints upon the haft and shaft, were in splendour on both, and left no room for doubt; there were also draps of hood on both.
He left Smyrna, and on his way homo, at Rome, his first inquiries were concerning the lady he had attempted to snatch from Lord Ruthven's seductive arts. Her parents were in distress, their fortune ruined, and she had not been heard of since the departure of his lordship. Aubrey's mind became almost broken under so many repulsive horrors; he was afraid that this lady had fallen a victim to the destroyer of India. He became ruffian and silent; and his only occupation remained in urging the speed of the proceedings, as if he were going to save the life of some one he considered dear. He arrived at Calais; a breeze, which seemed obedient to his will, soon wafted him to the English shores; and he hastened to the mansion of his fathers, and there, for a moment, appeared to bask, in the embraces and embraces of his sister, in a memory of the past. If she before, by her infantine caresses, had gained some affection, upon that the woman began to appear, she was still more attaching as a companion.
Miss Aubrey had not the winning grace which gains the gaze and applause of the dressing-room assemblies. There was much of that light brilliancy which only exists in the heated atmosphere of a crowded establishment. Her blue eye was never lit up by the levity of the moment. There was a melancholy charm about it which did not seem to arise from misfortune, but from some feeling, that appeared to indicate a soul conscious of a brighter future. His step was not that lightfooting, which strays where a butterfly or a colour may attract—it was sedate and penitent. When alone, her face was never brightened by the sensation of joy; but when her brother breathed to her his affection, and would in her presence forget those griefs she knew destroyed her rest, who would have exchanged her smile for the sorrows of the world? It seemed as if those eyes…
That face were then playing in the light of their own native sphere. She was yet only eight years, and had not been presented to the world, having been though by her guardions more fit that her presentation should be delayed until her brother's return from the continent, when he might be her protector. It was now, therefore, resolved that the next drawing-room, which was fast approaching, should be the epoch of her entry into the "busy scene." Aubrey would rather have remained in the company of his friends, and fed upon the melancholy which overpowered him. He could not feel in the least about the frivolities of fashion and strangers, when his heart had been so torn by the events he had witnessed; but he determined to sacrifice his own comfort to the protection of his sister. They soon arrived in town, and prepared for the next day, which they had advertised as a drawing-room.
The crowd was excessive–a drawing-room had not been held for a long time, and all who were anxious to bask in the smile of royalty, hastened thither. Aubrey was there with his sister. While he was standing in a crowd by himself, completely unaware of all around him, engaged in the remembrance that the first time he had seen Lord Ruthven was in that very place—he felt himself suddenly seized by the arm, and a voice he recognized too wel, sounded in his ear—"Remember your oath." He had hardly courage to turn, fearful of seeing a spectre which would frighten him, when he perceived, at a little distance, the same figure which had attracted his notice on this spot upon his first entry into society. He gazed till his limbs almost refused to bear his weight, he was compelled to take the arm of a friend, and forcing a passage through the crowd, he threw himself into his cloak, and was driven home. He paced the room with hurried steps, and fixed his hands upon his head, as if he were afraid his thoughts were slipping from his brain. Lord Ruthven stood before him–circumstances started up in dreadful array–the dagger–his oath–He revved himself, he could not believe it possible–the dead rife again!–He thought his imagination had conjured up the image his mind was resting upon. It was impossible that it could be real–he decided, therefore, to go again into society; for though he attempted to obtain information concerning Lord Ruthven, the name hung upon his lips, and he could not succeed in gaining information. He went a few nights after with his sister to the assembly of a near relation. Leaving her under the prolection of a matron, he retired into a recess, and there gave himself up to his own devouring thoughts. Perceiving, at last, that many were leaving, he roused himself, and entering another room, found his sister surrounded by several, apparently in earnest conversation; he struggled to pass and get near her, when one, whom he requested to move, turned round, and revealed to him those features he most abhorred. He sprang forward, seized his sister's arm, and, with hurried step, forced her towards the street: at the door he found himself impeded by the crowd of servants who were waiting for their lords; and while he was engaged in passing them, he again heard that voice whisper close to him—"Reverse your oath!"He did not dare to turn, but, hurrying his sister, soon reached home.
Aubrey became almost distanced. If before his mind had been absorbed by this subject, how much more completely was it engrossed, now that the certainty of the morister's verdict again pressed upon his thoughts. His sister's attentions were now unheeded, and it was in vain that she intreated him to explain to her what had caused his abrupt departure. He only uttered a few words, and those terrified her. The more he thought, the more he was bewildered. His oath slurred him; how could he then allow this murderer to roam, bearing plunder under his breath, as he held deor, and not avert its progress? His very sister might have been touched by him. But even if he were to break his oath, and disclose his suspicions, who would believe him? He thought of employing his own hand to free the world from such a wretch; but duty, he remembered, had been all but mocked. For days he remained in this state; shut up in his room, he saw no one, and ate only when his sister came, who, with eyes streaming with tears, besought him, for her sake, to support nature. At last, no longer capable of bearing stillness and solitude, he lest leave his house, roamed from street to street, anxious to fly that image which haunted him. His dress became loose, and he wandered, as often exposed to the noon day sun as to the midnight damps. He wasn't able to be recognized; at first he returned with the children to the house; but at last he laid himself down to rest wherever fatigue overlook him. His sister, anxious for his safely, employed people to follow him; but they were soon distanced by him who fled through a window swifter than any could be bought. His conduct, however, sudderily changed. Struck with the idea that he left by his absence the whole of his friends, with a fiend among them, of whose presence they wore unconscious, he determined to enter again into society, and watch him close, anxious to forewarn, in spite of his oath, all whom Lord Routhven approached with interest. But when he entered into a roam, his haggard and suspicious eyes were so striking, his inward shudderings so visible, that his father was at last obliged to beg of him to abstain from seeking, for her sake, a society which affected him so strongly. When, however, remonstrance proved unnecessary, the guineas thought proper to introbe, and, fearing that his mind was becoming agitated, they thought it high time to resume again that trust which had been before imposed upon him by Aubrey's porents.
Desirous of rescuing him from the injuries and sufferings he had daily encountered in his wanderings, and of preventing him from exposing to the general eye those marks of what they considered folly, they induced a physician to reside in the house, and take constant care of him. He hardly appeared to notice him, so completely was his mind absorbed by one torrible occurrence. His incoherence became at once so great, that he was consined to his chamber. There he would often lie for days, incapable of being roused. He had become emaciated, his eyes had attained a glassy lustre; the only sign of affection of recollection having displayed itself upon the appearance of his sister; then he would sometimes start, and, seizing her hands, with looks that severely afflicted him, he would desire her not to touch him. "Oh, do not touch him–if your love for me is aught, DO not go near him!" When, however, she inquired to whom he referred, his only answer was, "True!" Again he sank into a state, whence not even she could rouse him. This lasted many months: gradually, however, as the year was passing, his incoherences came less frequent, and his mind threw off a portend of its gloom, whilst his guard observed, that several times in the day he would count upon himself a definite nutter, and smile.
The time had nearly elapsed, when, on the last day of the year, one of his guardians entering his room, began to converse with his physician upon the melancholy circumstance of Aubrey being in so awful a fit, when his sister was going next day to be married. Instantly Aubrey's attention was attracted; he listened anxiously to whom. In consequence of this mark of returning intellect, of which they feared he had been degraded, they mentioned the name of the Earl of Marsden. Thinking this was a young Earl whom he had met in company, Aubrey seemed pleased, and astonished them still more by expressing his readiness to be present at the nuptials, and desiring to see his sister. They answered not, but in a few minutes his sister was with him. He was apparently again capable of being affected by the irruption of her lovely smile; for he pressed her to his breast, and kissed her cheek, wet tears, flowing at the thought of her brother's being once again alive to the feelings of affection. He began to speak with all his wonted warmth, and to congratulate her upon her marriage with a person so distinguished for rank and every accomplishment; when he suddenly perceived a locket upon her breast; opening it, what was his surprise at beholding the fancies of the monster which had so long occupied his life. He seized the purse in a paroxysm of rage, and trampled it underfoot. Upon her asking him why he thus destroyed the resemblance of her future husband, he looked as if he did not understand her–then seizing her hands, and gazing on her with a frantic expression on his countenance, he bade her swear that she would never wed this murderer, for he– But he could not advance–it seemed as if the woman again bade him reinstate his oath–he turned suddenly round, thinking Lord Ruthvon was near him but saw no one. In the meantime the guardians and physician, who had heard the whole, and thought this was the return of his disorder, cautioned, and sorcing him from Miss Avrey, desired her to leave him. He fell upon his knees to them, he implored, he begged of them to delay but for one day. They, attributing this to the infanity they imagined had taken possession of his mind, endeavoured to pacify him, and retired.
Lord Ruthven had called the morning after into the drawing-room, and had been refused with every one else. When he heard of Aubrey's ill health, he readlly understood himself to be the cause of it; but when he learned that he was deemed insane, his exultation and pleasure could hardly be concealed from those from whom he had gained this information. He hastened to the house of his former companiori, and, by constant appearance, and the pretence of great affection for the brother and interest in his fate, he gradually won the car of Miss Aubrey. Who could resist his power? His tongue had dangers and troubles to recount–could speak of himself as of an individual having no sympathy with any being on the crowded carth, save with her to whom he addressed himself;–could tell how, since he knew her, his affection, had come to seem worthy of preservation, if it were merely that he might listen to her distinct accents;–in fine, he knew so well how to use the serpent's art, or such was the will of fate, that he gained her affections. The title of the elder brother falling at length to him, he obtained an important embassy, which served as an excuse for hastening the marriage, (in spite of her brother's deranged state,) which was to take place the very day before his deporture for the continent.
Aubrey, when he was left by the physician and his guardian, attempted to bribe the servants, but in vain. He asked for pen and paper; it was given him; he wrote a letter to his sister, conjuring her, as she valued her own happiness, her own honour, and the honour of those now in the grave, who once held her in their arms and their hope and the hope of their house, to delay but for a few hours that marriage, on which be denounced the most heavy curses. The servants promised they would deliver it; but giving it to the physician, he thought it better not to harass any more the inind of Miss Aubrey by, what he considered, the rovings of a man. He passed on without rest to the busy inner part of the house; and Aubrey heard, with a horror that may more easily be imagined than described, the sounds of some terrible preparation. Morning came, and the sound of carriages broke upon his ear. Aubrey grew almost frantic. The curiosity of the servants at last overtook their vigilance, they gradually stole away, leaving him in the custody of an helpless old woman. He seized the opportunity, with one bound was out of the room, and in a moment found himself in the apartment where all were nearly assailed. LATEST. Ruthven was the first to perceive him: he immediately approached, and, taking his arm by force, hurried him from the room, speechless with rage. Wheron on the stair-case, Lord Ruthven whispered in his ear—"Remember your oath, and know, if not my bride to day, your sister has dishonoured. Women are frail!" He saying, he pushed him towards his attendances, who, roused by the old man, had come in search of him. Avrey could no longer support himself; his rage not finding vent, had broken a blow-vase, and he was conveyed to bed. This was not communicated to the prisoner, who was not present when he entered, as the physician was afraid of agitating her. The marriage was solemnized, and the bride and bridegroom left London.
Aubrey's weakness improved; the effusion of blood produced symptoms of the near approach of death. He desired his sister's guardians might be called, and when the midnight hour had passed, he related composedly what the roader has perused–he died immediately afterwards.
The guards hastened to protect Miss Aubrey; but when they arrived, it was too late. Larder had appeared, and Aubrey's sister had glutted the thirst of a VAMPYRE!
EXTRACT OF A LETTER, CONTAINING AN ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE IN THE ISLAND OF MITYLENE.
ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRNE'S RESIDENCE, &c.
"The world was all before him, where to choose his place of rest, and Providence his guide."
IN passing through the Grecjan Arohlopago, on board one of his Majesty's vessels, in the year 1812, we put into the harbour of Mitylene in the island of that name. The beauty of this place, and the certain supply of cattle and vegetables alwoys to be had there, induce many British seamen to visit it—both men of war and merchantmen; and though it lies rather out of the track for ships bound to Smyrria, its bounties almost repay for the cost of a voyage. We landed, as usual, at the bottom of the hay, and whilst the men were employed in watching, and the purser barging.
In looking for cattle with the natives, the clergymen and myself took a ramble to the cave called Homer's School, and other places, whoro we had been before. On the brow of Mount Ida (a mountain monticule so named) we met with and engaged a young Greek as our guide, who told us he had come from Scio with an English lord, who left the island four days previous to our arrival in his country. "He engaged me as a pilot," said the Greek, "and would have taken me with him; but I did not choose to quit Mitylene, where I am likely to get married. He was an odd, but very good man. The cottage on the hill, facing the river, belonged to him, and he had left an old man in charge of it: he gave Dominick, the wine-trader, six hundred zeroes for it, (about £250 English currency,) and has resided there about fourteen months, but it was not constant; for he sails in his felucca very often to the different islands."
This account excited our curiosity very much, and we lost no time in hastening to the house where our countryman had resided. We were kindly received by an old man, who conducted us over the mansion. It consisted of four apartments on the ground-floor—an entrance hall, a drawing-room, a sitting parlour, and a bed room, with a spacious closet enclosed. They were all simply decorated: plain green-staincd walls, marble tohings on either side, a large myrtle in the centre, and a small fountain beneath, which could be made to play through the branches by moving a spring fixed in the side of a small bronze Venus in a leaning position; a large couch or sofa completed the furniture. In the hall stood half a dozen brown cane chairs, and an empty book-case: there were no mirrors, nor a single painting. The bedchamber had merely a mattress spread on the floor, with two stuffed cotton quilts and a pillow—the cornmon bed through which Greeley came. In the sitting-room we obserued a marble chest, formerly, the old man told us, filled with books and papers, which were then in a large seaman's chest in the dock: it was open, but we did not think ourselves justified in examining the contents. On the table of the recess lay Voltaire's, Shakspeare's, Bolleau's, and Rousseau's works complete; Volney's Rules of Empires; Zimmman, in the German language; Klapock's Messiah; Kotzebue's novels; Schiller's play on the Robbers; Milton's Parodise Lost, an Italian edition, printed at Parma in 1846; several small pamphlets from the Greek press at Constantinople, much torn, but no English book of any description. Most of these books were filled with marginal notes, written with a pencil, in Italian and Latin. The Messiah was literally scribbled all over, and marked with slips of paper, on which also were remarks.
The old man said: "The lord had been reading these books the evening before he sailed, and forgot to lace them with the others; but," said he, "there they must remain until his return; for he is so particular, that were I to move one thing without orders, he would frown upon me for a week together; he is not altogether very good." I once did him a service; and I have the produce of this farm and the burden of taking care of it, except two pence cheques which I pay to an aged Armenian who resides in a small cottage in the wood, and whom the lord brought here from Adrianople; I don't know for what purpose."
The appearance of the house externally was pleasing. The portico in front was fifty paces long and fourteen broad, and the fluted pilasters with black plinths and freestone cornice, (as it is now customary in Grecian architecture,) were considerably higher than the roof. The roof, surrounded by a light stone balustrade, was covered by a fine Turkey carpet, beneath an awning of strong caarse linen. Most of the house-tops are well furnished, as upon them the Greeks pass their evenings in smoking, drinking light wines, such as "lachryma christi," eating fruit, and enjoying the evening breeze.
On the left hand side, as we approached the house, a small streamlet glided away, grapevines, orangos and limes were clustering together on its borders, and under the shade of two large myrtle bushes, a marble seal with an ornamental wooden back was placed, on which we were told, the lord passed many of his evenings and mornings till twelve o'clock, reading, writing, and talking to himsels. "I suppose," said the old man, "praying" for he was very devout, "and always attended our church twice a week, except Sundays."
The view from this window was what may be termed "a bird's-eye view." A line of rich vegetable gardens led him up to Mount Calcla, covered with olive and myrtle trees in bloom, and on the summit on which an ancient Greek temple clapped in majestic decay. A small stream issuing from the ruins descended in broken easements, until it was lost in the woods near the mountain's base. The sea smooth as glass, and an horizon unfhadowed by a single cloud, terminated the view in front; and a little on the left, through a vista of lofty chesnut and palm-trees, several small islands were distinctly observed, studding the light blue wave with spots of emerald green. I seldom enjoyed a view more than I did of him; but our enquiries were fruitless as to the name of the person who had resided in this romantic solitude: none knew his name but Dominick, his banker, who had gone to China. "The Armenian," said our conductor, "could come, but I am sure he will not,"—"And can you come, old friend?" said I—"If I can," said he, "I dare not." We had not time to visit the Armerian, but on our return to the town we learnt some particulars of the isolated lord. He had portioned eight young girls when he was last upon the island, and even danced with them at the nuptial feast. He gave ox to one man, horses to others, and cotton and silk to the girls who live by weaving these articles. He also bought a new boot for a gentleman who had lost his own in a gale, and he often gave Greek teats to the poor children. In short, he appeared to us, from what we collected, to have been a very eccentric and nevolent character. One circumstance we learnt, which our old friend at the cottage thought proper not to disclose. He had a most beautiful daughter, with whom the lord was often seen walking on the sea-shore, and he had bought her a piano-forte, and taught her himself the use of it.
Such was the information with which we departed from the peaceful Isle of Milylene; our imaginations all on the rack, guessing what this ramblor in Greece might be. He had money it was evident: he had philanthropy of disposition, and all those eccentricities which inark peculiarity. Arrived at Palermo, all our doubts were dispelled. Founding in company with Mr. FOSTER, the architect, a pupil of WYATT'S, who had been lravelling in Egypt and Greece, "The individual," said he, "about whom you are so anxious, is Lord Byron; I met him in my travels on the island of Tenedos, and I also visited him at Constantinople." We had never then heard of his lordship's fame, as we had been some years from home; but "Childe Harolde" being put into our hands we recognized the recluse of Calclo in every page. Deeply did we regret not having been more curious in our research at the cottage, but we consoled ourselves with the idea of returning to Mitylene on some future day; but to me that day will never return. I make this statement, believing it not quite uninteresting, and in justice to his lordship's good name, which has been gravely slandered. He has been described as of an unfeeling disposition, utterly opposed to associating with human nature, or contributing in any way to its woes, or add to its pleasures. The fault is directly the revoir, as may be plainly gathered from these little anecdotes. All the finer feasts of the heart, so elegantly depicted in his lord's poems, should have their seat in his bosom. Tenderness, sympathy, and charity appear to guide all his acts: and his courting the repose of solitude is an additional reason far reaching him from a man on whose head Religion hath set her seal, and upon whose head Benevolence hath thrown her mantle. No man can read his preceding pleasing "traits" without feeling fond of him as a countryman. With respect to his loves or pleasures, I do not assume a right to give an opinion. Reports are ever to be received with great caution, particularly when concerned with a man's moral integrity; and he who must justify himself before that awful tribunal where all men appear, alone may censure the errors of a fellow-mortal. Lord Byron's character is worthy of his genius. To do good in secret, and shun the world's applause, is the surest testimony of a voracious heart and serene conscience.
THE END.

IT happened that in the midst of the dissipations attendant upon a London winter, there appeared at the various parties of the ton a nobleman, more remarkable for his sirigularities, than his rank. He gazed upon the mirth surrounding him, as if he could not participate there. Those who felt this sensation of awe, could not explain whence it arose: some attached it to the dead grey eye, which, fixing upon the object's face, did not seem to penetrate, and at one point to pierce through to the inward workings of the heart; but fell upon the cheek with a leaden weight that weighed upon the skin it could not pass. His peculiarities caused him to be invited to every house; all wished to see him, and those who had been accustomed to violent excitement, and now felt the weight of ennui, were pleased at having something in their presence capable of engaging their attentions.
