They were inconstable.
They both died broken-hearted.
Aubrey being put to bed was seized with a most violent fury, and was often delirious; in these intervals he would call upon Lord Ruthven and upon Miss Henderson; by some unaccounlable combination he seemed to beg of his former companion to spare the being he loved. At other times he would imprecate malodictions upon his head, and curse him as his destroyer. Lord Ruthven, chanced at this time to arrive at Athens, and, from personal motive, upon bearing of the name of Aubrey, immediately placed him in the same house, and became his constant attendant. When the latter recovered from his delirium, he was horrified and saddened at the sight of him, whose image he had now combined with that of a Vampyre; but Lord Ruthven, by his kind words, implying almost repentance for the fault that had caused their separation, and still more by the attention, anxiety, and care which he showed, soon reconciled him to his present condition. His lordship seemed suddenly changed; he no longer appeared that apathetic being that had so astonished Aubrey; but as during his convalescence he seemed to be recovering, he eventually retired into the same state of mind, and Aubroy perceived no difference from the former man, except that at times he was surprised to meet his gaze fixed intently upon him, with a smile of malicious intent playing upon his lips: he knew not why, but this smile haunted him. During the last stage of the invalid's recovery, Lord Ruthven was apparently engaged in watching the tideless waves raised by the cooling breeze, or in morking the progress of those orbs, circling, like round the world, the moving sun;—indeed, he appeared to wish to avoid the eyes of all.
Aubrey's mind, by this shock, was greatly weakened, and that elasticity of spirit which had once so distinguished him now seemed to have fled for ever. He was now as much a lover of solitude and silence as Lord Ruthven; but much as he wished for solace.
If his mind could not find it in the neighbourhood of Athens; if he sought it amidst the ruins he had formerly occupied, Anthea's form would appear at his side—if he fought in the wood, her light step would appear wandering amidst the underwood, in quest of the modest violet; then suddenly turning round, would come, to his wild imagination, her pale face and wounded throat, and a meek smile upon her lips. He determined to fly scenos, one feature of which created such bitter associations in his mind. He proposed to Lord Ruthven, to whom he was bound by the tender care he had taken of him during his illness, that they should visit those parts of Greece neither had yet visited. They travelled in every direction, and sought every spot to which a recollection could be attached: but though they hastened from place to place, they seemed not to heed what they gazed upon. They heard much of robberies, but gradually began to slight these reports, which they imagined were only the invention of individuals, whose interest it was to excite the generosity of those whom they defended from pretended dangers. In consequence of thus neglecting the advice of the inhabitants, on one occasion they travelled with only a few guards, more to serve as guides than as a defence. Upon entering, however, a narrow valley, at the bottom of which was the head of a torrent, with large masses of rock brought down from the neighbouring precipiccs, they had reason to repent their negligence; for scarcely were the whole of the party engaged in the narrow pass, when they were startled by the whistling of bullets close to their heads, and by the echoed report of several guns. In an instant their guards had left them, and, placing their muskets and rocks, had begun to fire in the direction whence the report came. Lord Ruthven and Aubroy, imitating their example, retired for a moment behind the swelling turn of the defile: but ashamed of being thus detained by their foe, who with insulting shouts made them advance, and being exposed to an unresisting charge, if any of the robbers should climb above and cut them in the rear, they determined at once to rush forward in fear of the destruction. Hardly had they lost the shelter of the rock, when Lord Ruthven received a shot in the shoulder, which brought him to the ground. Aubrey hastened to his assistance; and, no longer keeping the contest at his own peril, was soon surprised by seeing the robbers' faces around him–his guards having, upon Lord Ruthven's being wounded, immediately thrown up their arms and dispersed.
By promises of great reward, Aubrey soon induced them to convey his wounded friend to a neighbouring cabin; and having agreed upon a ransom, he was no more disturbed by their presence–they being provided merely to guard the entrance till the complainant should return with the promised sum, for which he had an order. Lord Rulhven's strength rapidly declined; and two days mortification ensued, and death seemed advancing with hasty steps. His conduct and appearance had not changed; he seemed as uncouplicable of pain as he had been of the injuries inflicted upon him: but towards the end of the last evening, his mind came apparently uneasy, and his eye often fixed upon Auhrey, who was led to offer his assistance with more than his usual gentleness—"Help me! You may save me–you may do more than that–I mean not my life, I heed the death of my children as little as that of the passing day; but you may save my house, your family, your friends. "HARD?" Tell me how? "I would do any thing," replied Aubrey. "I meant but little–my life ebbs and flows–I cannot explain the whole–but if you would conceal all you know of me, my honour were free from stain in the world's mouth–and is my death was unknown for some time in England–I—I—bless you." "It shall not be known." "Swear!" cried the dying man, raising himself with exullant violence, "Swear by all your soul reveres, by all you nature fears, swear that, for a year and a day you will not impart your knowledge of my crimes and death to any living being in any way, what you see, or whatever you may see." His eyes seemed bulging from their sockets: "I swear!" said Aubrey; he sunk laugting upon his pillow, and breathed no more.
Aubrey retired to bed, but did not sleep; the many circumstances attending his acquaintance with this man rose upon his mind, and he knew not what to do; when he remembered his oath a cold shivering come over him, as if from the presonculent of something horrible awalting him. Rising early in the morning, he was about to enter the hovel in which he had left the corpse, when a robber met him, and informed him that it was no longer there, having been conveyed by himself and his companions, upon his retiring, to the pinnacles of a nearby mount, according to a promise they had given his lordship, that it should be exposed to the first old ray of the moon that rose after his death. Aurey astonished, and taking several of the men, decided to go and bury it up on the spot where it lay. But, when he had mounted to the top, he found no trace of either the corpse or the clogs, although the robbers swore they had picked out the identical rock on which they had laid the body. For a time his mind was bewildered in conjectures, but he at last returned, convincingly that they had buried the corpse for the sake of the children.
Weary of a county in which he had met with such terrible misfortunes, and in which all apparently conspired to heighten that superstitious melancholy that had seized upon his mind, he resolved to leave it, and soon arrived at Smyrna. While waiting for a servant to convey him to Ortranto, or to Naples, he occupied himself in arranging those effeels he had with him belonging to Lord Ruthven. Amongst other things there was a case containing several weapons of offence, more or less adapted to ensure the death of the victim. There were several daggers and atags. Whilst turning them over, and examining their curious forms, what was his surprise at finding a dagger apparently ornamented in the same style as the dagger discavered in the fatal hut–he exclaimed–hastening to gain some composure, he sight the weapon, and his horror may be imagined when he discovered that it fitted, although peculiarly shaped, the sheath he held in his hand. His eyes seemed to need no further certainty–they seemed gazing to be bound to the dagger; yet still he wished to disbelieve; but the circular form, the same varying tints upon the blade and sheath were all in sploridour on both, and left no room for doubt; there were also drops of blood on the floor.
He left Smyrna, and on his way home, at Rome, his first inquiries were concerning the lady he had employed to snatch from Lord Ruthven's seduction chambers. Her parents were in distress, their fortune ruined, and she had not been heard of since the departure of his lordship. Aubrey's mind became almost broken under so many repeated horrors; he was afraid that this lady had been a victor to the destroyer of Ianthe. He became morose and melancholy; and his only occupation consisted in urging the prosecution of the prisoners, as if he were going to save the life of someone he held dear. He arrived at Calais; a breeze, which seemed obedient to his will, soon wafted him to the Eriglish shores; and he clung to the arms of his fathers, and there, for a moment, appeared to lose, in the ironbraces and cuffs of his suit, all memory of the past. If she before, by her insatiable egotism, had gained his affection, now that the woman began to appear, she was still more attaching as a companion.
Miss Aubrey had not that winning grace which gains the gaze and applause of the drawing-room assemblies. There was none of that brashness which sometimes exists in the heated atmosphere of a crowded apartment. Her blue eye was constantly lit up by the levity of the mind beneath. There was a melancholy charm about it which did not seem to arise from misfortune, but from some feeling of melancholy, that appeared to indicate a soul conscious of a brighter realm. Her step was not that light footing, which trays where a fly or a colour might attract—it was sedate and pensive. When alone, her face was never brightened by the smile of joy; but when her brother breathed to her his affection, and would in her presence forget those griefs she knew destroyed his rest, who would have exchanged her smile for that of the voluptuary? It seemed as if those eyes were then ploying in the light of their own native sphere. She was yet only fourteen, and had not yet presented to the world, having been thought by her guardians more fit that her presentation should be delayed until her brother's return from the continent, when he might be her representative. It was now, therefore, resolved that the next drawing-room, which was now approaching, should be the occasion of her entry into the "busy feene." He would have remained in the mansion of his fathers, and fed upon the melancholy which overpowered him. He could not feel interest about the politics of fashionable strangers, when he had been so shocked by the events he had witnessed; he would be determined to sacrifice his own comfort to the protection of his sister. They soon arrived in town, and prepared for the next day, which had been announced as a drawing-room.
The crowd was excess.
Such a drawing-room had not been held for a long time, and all who were anxious to bask in the smile of royalty, hastened to enter. Aubrey was there with his sister. Whistleblower. As he was standing in a corner by himself, heedless of all around him, engaged in the remembrance that the first time he had seen Lord Ruthven was in that very place—he felt himself suddenly seized by the arm, and a voice he recognized too well, saunded in his ear—"Remember your oath." He had hardly courage to turn, fearful of seeing a spectre that would frighten him, when he perceived, at a considerable distance, the same figure which had attracted his attention on the spot upon his first entry into society. He groaned till his limbs almost refusing to bear their weight, he was obliged to take the arm of a friend, and forcing a passage through the crowd, he threw himself into his carriage, and was driven home. He paced the room with hurried steps, and fixed his hands upon his head, as if he were afraid. All his thoughts were bursting from his brain. Lord Ruthven again before him–circumstances slarted up in dreadful array–the dagger–his oath–He roused himself, but could not believe it possible–the dead rise again!–He thought his imagination had conjured up the image his mind was resting upon. It was impossible that he could be real; he determined, therefore, to go again into society; for though he intended to ask concealing Lord Ruthven, the name hung upon his lips, and he could not succeed in gaining information. He went a few hours afterwards with his sister to the house of a near relation. Leaving her under the protection of a matron, he retired into a recess, and there went himself up to his own devouring habits. Perceiving, at last, that many were leaving, he followed them, and entering another room, found his sister surrounded by several men, apparently in earnest conversation; he attempted to pass and get near her, when one, whom he requested to move, turned round, and revealed to him the features he most abhorred. He sprang forward, seized his sister's hand, and, with hurried step, forced her towards the street: at the door he found himself impeded by the crowd of servitors who were waiting for the lords; and while he was engaged in passing them, he again heard the voice whisper close to him—"Remember your oath!"–He did not dare to turn, but, hurrying his sister, still reached home.
Aubrey became ill and was discharged. Before his mind had been absorbed by one subject, but much more completely was it engrossed, now that the certainty of the monster's living again pressed upon his thoughts. His sister's attentions were now unheeded, and it was in vain that she intreated him to explain to her what had caused his bankrupt conduct. He only said a few words, and those terrified her. The more he bought, the more he was bewildered. His oath startled him; was he then to allow this monster to roar, bearing raving upon his breath, amidst all he held dear, and not avert its consequences? His very sister might have been touched by him. But even if he were to break his oath, and disclose his suspicions, who would believe him? He thought of employing his own hand to free the world from this wretched creature; but death, he remembered, had been already inocked. For days he remained in this state; locked up in his room, he saw no one, and ate only when his sister came, and, with eyes swelling with tears, begged him, for her sake, to support nature. At last, no longer capable of bearing stillness and solitude, he lofted himself from window to window, endeavouring to fly that mantle which haunted him. His dress became ragged, and he wandered, as often exposed to the noon-day sun as to the mid-night gloom. He was no longer to be recognized; at first he returned with the evening to the house; but at last he put him down to rest where fatigue overtook him. His sister, anxious for his safety, employed people to follow him; but they were soon distanced by him who fled from a pursuer swifter than any from thought. His conduct, however, suddenly changed. Struck with the idea that he left by his abasement the whole of his friends, with a fiend amongst them, of whose presence they were unconscious, he determined to enter back into society, and watch him closely, anxious to warn, in spite of his oath, all whom Lord Ruthven approached with intimacy. But when he be entered into a marriage, his haggard and suspicious looks were so striking, his inward shudderings so visible, that his sister was at last induced to beg of him to abstain from seeing, for her sake, a sociability which affected him so strongly. When, however, correspondence proved unclenching, the guardians thought proper to effect, and, searing that his mind was becoming alienated, they thought it high time to resume again that trust which had been before imposed upon them by Aubrey.
[SUBJECT.]
Desirous of saving him from the injuries and sufferings he had daily encountored in his wanderings, and of preventing him from exposing to the general eye those marks of what they considered folly, they engaged a physician to reside in the house, and take constant care of him. He hardly appeared to notice it, so completely was his mind absorbed by one terrible tragedy. His incoherence became al laft so great, that he was confined to his chamber. There he would often lie for days, incapablo of being roused. He had become emaciated, his eyes had become a glassy luscence; the only sign of affection and recollection remaining displayed itself upon the entry of his sister; then he would somersault, and, seizing her hands, with looks that nearly assaulted her, he would desire her not to touch him. "Oh, do not touch him–if your love for me is aught, DO not go near him!" When, however, she inquired to whom he referred, his only answer was, "True! true!" Again he fell into a state, whence not even she could rouse him. This lasted several months: gradually, however, as the year was passing, his incoherence became less frequent, and his mind threw off a portent of its gloom, whilst his guardians observed, that several times in the day he would call upon his finger a definite number, and then smile.
The time had nearly eloped, when, upon the last day of the year, one of his friends entering his room, began to communicate with his physician on the melancholy circumstantial of Aubrey being in so awful a situation, when his sister was going next day to be married. Instantly Aubrey's attention was attracted; he asked anxiously to whom. Glad of his mark of returning into consideration, of which they believed he had been deprived, they mentioned the name of the Earl of Marrsden. Thinking this was a young Earl whom he had met with in society, Aubrey seemed pleased, and astonished them still more by his expressing his intention to be present at the nuptials, and desiring to see his sister. They answered not, but in a few minutes his sister was with him. He was apparently again capable of being affected by the influence of her lovely smile; for he pressed her to his breast, and kissed her cheek, wet with tears, flowing at the thought of her brother's being once more alive to the feelings of affection. He began to speak with all his wonted wisdom, and to commend her upon her marriage to a man so distinguished for rank and every accomplishment; when he suddenly perceived a lock upon her breast; peeling it, what was his surprise at beholding the features of the monster who had so long influenced his life. He seized the portrait in a paroxysm of rage, and trampled it under foot. Upon her asking him why he thus destroyed the reputation of her former husband, he looked as though he did not understand her–then seizing her hands, and gazing on her with a sullen expression of countenance, he bade her swear that she would never wed this monster, for he was– But he could not advance–it seemed as if that witness again bade him remember his oath–he looked suddenly round, thinking Lord Ruthven was near him but saw no one. In the meantime the physicians and physicion, who had heard the whole, and thought this was but a return of his disease, entered, and foreing him from Miss Aubrey, desired her to leave him. He fell upon his knees to them, he implored, he begged of them not to delay but for one day. They, attributing the insanity to the insanity they indicted had taken possession of his mind, endeavoured to pacify him, but failed.
Lord Ruthven had called the morning after the drawing-room, and had been acquainted with every one else. When he heard of Aubrey's ill health, he readily understood himself to be the cause of it; but when he learned that he was diagnosed insane, his exultation and pleasure could hardly be concealed from those among whom he had gained this loyalty. He hastened to the house of his former companion, and, by cousin attendance, and the pretence of great affection, kissed her.
With respect for his brother and interest in music, he gradually won the ear of Miss Aubrey. Who could resist his power? His tongue had dangers and toils to recover.
He could speak of himself as of an individual having no sympathy with any being on the crowded earth, except with her to whom he addressed himself; could tell him that since he knew her, his existence, had ceased to seem worthy of preservation, if it were merely that he might listen to her soothing accents; in fine, he knew so well how to use the serpent's art, or such was the will of fate, that he coveted her affections. The title of the elder brother falling at length to him, he obtained an important embassy, which served as an excuse for hastening the inarriage, (in spite of her brother's deranged conduct,) which was to take place the day before his departure for the Continent.
Aubrey, when he was separated from the physiclan and his guardians, attempted to bribe the servant, but in vain. He asked for pen and paper; it was given him; he wrote a letter to his sister, consoling her, as she valued her own happiness, her own honour, and the honour of those now in the grave, who once held her in their arms as their hope and the basis of their house, to delay for a few hours that morrow, on which he denounced the most heavy penalties. The servants promised they would deliver it; but giving it to the prisoner, he thought it would be riot to harass any man in the neighbourhood of Miss Aubrey by, what he considered, the raving of a maniac. Night passed on without rest to the busy inmates of the house; and Aubrey heard, with a horror that may not easily be described, the notes of busy preparation. Morning came, and the noise of corriages broke upon his ear. Aubrey grew almost frantic. The curiosity of the servants at last overcame their vigilance, they gradually stole away, leaving him in the custody of an exhausted old woman. He seized the opportunity, when one bourd was out of the room, and in a moment found himself in the apartment where all were now assembled. Lord Ruthven was the first to perceive him: he immediately approached, and, taking him by force, hurried him from the room, speechless with rage. When on the staircase, Lord Ruthven whispered in his ear—"Remember your oath, and know, if not my bride to day, your sister has dishonoured. Women are frail!" So saying, he pushed him to his attendant, who, roused by the old woman, had come in search of him. Aubrey could no longer support himself; his rage not finding vent, had broken a blood-vessel, and he was conveyed to bed. This was not mentioned to his sister, who was present when he entered, as the physicari was afraid of agitating her. The marriage was solemnized, and the ride and bridegroom left London.
Aubrey's weakness increased; the effusion of blood produced symptoms of the near approach of death. He desired his sister's governesses might be called, and when the midnight hour had struck, he repeated exactly what the reader has perused–he died immediately after.
The guardian hastened to protect Miss Aubrey; but when he arrived, it was too late. Lord Ruthven had disclosed, and Aubrey's sister had had the thirst of a VAMPYRE!
EXTRACT OF A LETTER, CONTAINING AN ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S SUICIDE IN THE ISLAND OF MITYLENE.
ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE, &c.
"The world was all before him, he had to choose his place of rest, and Providence his guide."
IN Sailing through the Greciari Archipelago, on board one of his Majesty's vessels, in the year 1812, we passed into the harbour of Mitylene, on the island of that name. The beauty of this place, and the constant supply of cattle and vegetables always to be had there, induce many British vessels to visit it—both men of war and merchantmen; and though it lies rather out of the track for ships bound to Smyrna, its bounties amply repay for the deviation of a voyage. Welcomed, as usual, at the bottom of the bay, and whilst the men wore themselves out in watering, and the purser bargaining for cattle with other officials, the clergyman and myself took a ramble to the cave called Homer's School, and other places, where we had been before. On the brow of Mount Ida (a small mountain so named) we met with and engaged a young Greek as our guide, who told us he had come from Scio with an English lord, who left the two days prior to our arrival in his custody. "He described me as a pilat," said the Greek, "and would have taken me with him; but I did not choose to quit Malinoe, where I am likely to get married. He was an odd, but a very good man. The cottage over the hill, facing the river, belongs to him, and he has left an old man in charge of it: he gave Dominick, the wine-trader, six bundred zechines for it, (about £250 English currency,) and has resided there about fourteen months, though not constantly; for he sails in his feluccia very often to the different islands."
This account excited our curiosity very much, and we lost no time in hastening to the house where our countryman had resided. We were immediately received by an old man, who conducted us over the mansion. It consisted of three apartments on the ground-floor—an entrance hall, a dressing-room, a sitting parlour, and a bed-room with a spacious closet annexed. They were all simply decoraled: pale green-stained walls, marble labels on each side, a large laurel in the centre, and small fountains throughout, which could be made to play through the branches by moving a spring fixed in the side of a small bronze Venus in a leaning posture; a large couch or sofa complemented the furniture. In the hall stood half a dozen brown cane chairs, and an empty book-case: there were no mirrors, nor a single painting. The bedchamber had merely a large mattress spread on the floor, with two stuffed cotton quilts and a pillow—the common bed throughout Greece. In the sitting-room we observed a marble recess, somewhat, the old man told us, silled with books and paper, which were kept in a large seaman's chest in the closet: it was open, but we did not think ourselves justified in examining the contents. On the tablet of the row lay Voltaire's, Shakspeare's, Boileau's, and Ruscau's works complete; Volney's Ruins of Empires; Zimmerman, in the German language; Klopstock's Messiah; Katzehue's novellas; Schiller's play of the Robors; Milton's Paradise Lost, an Italian novel, printed at Parma in 1810; several small pamphlets from the Greek press at Constantinople, much torn, but no English book of any description. Most of these books were filled with marginal notos, written with a poncil, in Italian and Lalin. The Messiah was literally scribbled all over, and marked with slips of paper, which also were remarks.
The old man said: "The lord had been reading these books the evening before he sailed, and wanted to place them with the others; but," said he, "there they must lie until his return; for he is so particular, that were I to move one thing without orders, he would frown upon me for a week together; he is otherways very good." I once did him a service; and I have the privilege of the farm and the trouble of taking care of it, except twenty shillings which I pay to an aged Armenian who resides in a small cottage in the wood, and whom the lord brought here from Adrianople; I don't know for what purpose."
The appearance of the house externally was displeasing. The portico in front was fifty paces long and thirteen broad, and the fluted marble pillars with black plinths and frel-work cornices, (as it is now customary in Greek architecture,) were considered a little higher than the roof. The roof, surrounded by a light stone balustrade, was supported by a fine Turkoy carpot, and an awning of strong coarse linen. Most of the house-tops are thus furnished, as upon them the Greeks pass their evenings in smoking, drinking light wines, such as "lachryma christi," eating fruit, and enjoying the evening brecques.
On the left hand side we entered the house, a small streamlet glided awcly, grapes, oranges and limes were clustered together on its borders, and under the shade of two large myrtles, a marble seat with an ornamental wooden back was placed, on which we were told, the lord passed many of his evenings and nights till twelve o'clock, reading, writing, and talking to himself. "I suppose," said the old man, "praying" for he was very devout, "and always attended our church twice a week, except Sundays."
The view from this seat was what may be termed "a bird's-eye view." A line of rich vineyards lodges the eycto Mount Calcla, covered with olive and myrtle trees in bloom, and on the summit of which a large arch exists. Greek temple appeared in majestic decay. A small stream arising from the river descended in broken cascades, until it was last in the woods near the mountain's base. The sea smooth as glass, and an horizon unshadowed by a single cloud, terminates the view in front; and a little on the left, through a vista of lofty chesnut and palm-trees, several small islands were distinctly observed, studding the light blue wave with spots of emerald green. I seldom enjoyed a view more than I did this; but our inquiries were fruitless as to the name of the prisoner who had resided in this remote solitude: none knew his name but Doininick, his banker, who had gone to Calais. "The Armenian," said our conductor, "could tell, but I am sure he will not,"—"And cannot you tell, old friend?" said I—"If I can," said he, "I will not." We had no time to visit the Armenian, but on our return to the town we learnt feveral particular of the isolated lard. He had portioned eight young girls when he was last upon the island, and danced with them at the nuptial feast. He gave a cow to one man, horses to others, and cotton and silk to the girls who made by weaving these articles. He also bought a new boat for a fisherman who had lost his own in a gale, and he often gave Reek Testaments to the poor children. In short, he appeared to us, from all we collected, to have been a very eccentric and benevolent character. One circumstance we cannot forget, which our old friend at the coltage thought best not to disclose. He had a most beautiful daughter, with whom the lord was often seen walking on the sea-shore, and he had bought her a piano-forc, and taught her himself the use of it.
Such was the information with which we departed from the peaceful Isle of Man; our imagination was on the rack, guessing who this rambler in Greece could be. He had much, it was evident: he had philanthropy of disposition, and all those eccenologicalities which mark peculiar character. Arrived at Palermo, all our things were delivered. Falling in comportment was Mr. FOSTER, the architect, a pupil of WYATT'S, who had been travelling in Egypt and Greece, "The individual," said he, "about whom you are so anxious, is Lord Byron; I met him in my travels on the island of Tenedos, and I also visited him at Messina." We had never then heard of his lordship's family, as we had been some years from him; but "Childe Harold" being put into our hands we recognized the recluse of Calcla in this page. Deeply did we regret not having been more curious in our researches at the cottage, but we consoled ourselves with the idea of returning to M'Mahlerie on some future day; but to me that day will neuer retum. I make this statement, believing it not to be uninteresling, and in service to his lordship's good name, which has been grossly insulted. He has been described as of an unfeeling disposition, averse to associating with human nature, or attempting in any way to sooth its sorrows, or add to its pleasures. The case was largely the result, as may be plainly gathered from these little anecdotes. All the finer feelings of the heart, so elegantly depicted in his lordship's poems, seem to have taken their seat in his bosom. Tenderness, sympathy, and charity appear to guide all his emotions: and his courting the repose of solitude is an additional reason for marking him as a being on whom heart Religion hath set her seal, and over whose head Benevolence hath thrown her mantle. No man can read the preceding pleasing "traits" without feeling proud of him as a countryman. With respect to his loves or pleasures, I do not assume a right to give an opinion. Rports are to be received with caution, particularly when directed against man's moral integrity; and he who dares justify himself before that awful tribunal where all must appear, alone may censure the errors of a fellow-mortal. Lord Byron's character if wholly of his genius. To do good in secret, and shun the world's applause, is the surest testimony of a virtuous heart and self-appreciating conscience.
THE END.
Gillel, Printer, Crown-court, Fleet-street.
