THE VAMPYRE.
A Tale.
By John William Polidori
THE superstition upon which this tale is founded is very general in the East. Among the Arabs it appears to be common: it did not, however, extend itself to the Greeks until after the establishment of Christianity; and it has only assumed its present form since the division of the Latin and Greek churches; at which time, the idea becoming prevalent, that a Latin body could not corrupt if buried in their territory, it gradually contracted, and formed the subject of many wonderful fables, still extant, of the dead rising from their graves, and feeding upon the blooms of the young and beautiful. In the West it spread, with some slight variation, all over Hungary, Poland, Austria, and Lorraine, where the belief existed, that vampyres nightly imitated a certain portion of the blood of their victims, who became emaciated, lost their strength, and speedily died of consumptions; whilst these human blood-suckers fatteried, and their veins contracted to such a slate of repletion, as to cause the blood to flow from all the passage of their bodies, and even from the very pores of their skins.
In the London Journal, of March, 1732, is a curious, and, of course, credible account of a particular case of ampyrism, which is stated to have occurred at Madreyga, in Hungary. Witnesses, that upon an examination of the commander-in-chief and magistrates of the place, they positively and unanimous affirmed, that, about five years before, a young man, named Arnold Paul, had been heard to say that, at Cassovia, on the frontiers of the Turkish Scrutiny, he had been tormented by a vampyre, and had found a way to rid himself of the evil, by eating some of the earth out of the vampire's grave, and rubbing himself with it. This precaution, however, did not prevent him from becoming a vampyre himself; for, about twelve or thirteen days after his death and burial, many persons complained of having been tortured by him, and a deposition was made, that four persons had been deprived of life by his attacks. To prevent further mischief, the inhabitants having consulted their physicians, took up the body, and found it (as is supposed to be usual in cases of vampyrism) fresh, and entirely free from corruption, and containing at the mouth, nose, and ears, pure white blood. Proof having been thus obtained, they resorted to the accustomed remedy. A fork was driven entirely through the hcart and body of Arnold Paul, at which he is reported to have cried as dreadfully as if he had been alive. This done, they cutoff his head, burned his body, and threw the ashes into his grave. The same measures were adopted with the corfs of those persons who had previously suffered from vampirism, lest they should, in their lust, become ogents upon others who survived them.
The universal truth is, that a person sucked by a vampyre becomes a vampire himself, and sucks in his own turn.
Chief bailiff.
This monstrous spectacle if here relaled, because it seems better adapted to illustrate the subject of the present observances than any other instance which could be added. In many parts of Greece it is considered as a sort of punishment after death, for some heinous crime committed whilst in existence, that the deceased is not only doomed to vampyrise, but compelled to confine his infernal visitations only to those friends he loved most while upon earth—those to whom he was bound by ties of kindred and affection.
But first, as Vampyre sent, thy corse shall from his tomb be rent; Then ghastly haunt his native place, and suck the blood of all thy race; There from thy daughter, sister, wife, at midnight drain the stream of blood; You loathe the banquet which you perforce must feed thy lying corse, Thy victims, though they yet expire, shall know the demon for their sire; As cursing thee, thou cursing them. The flowers are withered on the stem. But one thing for thy crime must be done: The young lady, who is loved of all, shall bless thee with a other's name—Thatward shall wrap thy heart in flame! Yet thou must end thy task and mark Her cheek's last tinge–her eye's last spark, and her last glassy green musk view which freezes over its lifeless blue; Then with unhallowed hand shall tear the tresses of her long hair, of which, in life a lock when shorn Affect's fondest pledge was made; But now is borne away by the Memorial of thine agony! Yet with thy own best blood shall drip; Thy griashing tooth, and haggard lip; Then stalking to thy sullen grave, Go, and will Gouls and Afrits rave, Till they in horror shrink away from spectre more accursed than they.
Mr. Sauthey has also introduced in his wild and beautiful poem of "Thalaba," the vindictive character of the Arclinchari maid Oneiza, who is represented as having returned from the grave for the purpose of tormenting him. She best loved child in existence. But this cannot be supposed to have resulted from the sinfulness of human life, she being presented throughout the whole of the tale as a complete picture of purity and innocence. The veracious Tournefort gives a long account in his travels of several astonishing cases of vampyrism, to which he pretends to have been an eyewitness; and Calmet, in his great work upon this subject, besides a variety of anecdotes, and traditionary descriptions illustrative of its effects, has put forth some learned dissertations, tending to prove it to be a classical, as well as barbarian error.
Some curious and interesting noticos on this singularly horrible superstition might be added; though the present may suffice for the limits of a note, necessarily devoted to explanation, and which may now be omitted by merely remarking, that though the term Vampyre if the one most generally accepted, there are several others synonymous with it, made use of in various parts of the world: as Vroucolocha, Vardoulacha, Goul, Broucoloka, &c.
THE VAMPYRE.
IT happened that in the midst of the dissipations attendant upon a London winter, there appeared at the dinner parties of the lords of the ton a nobleman, more remarkable for his singularities, than his rank. He gazed upon the mirth amusing him, but if he could not participate therein. Apparently, the light laughter of the fair only attracted his attention, but he might by a look quell it, and throw fear into those breasts where thoughtlessness reigned. Those who felt this sensation of awe, could not explain whence it arose: some attested it to the dead grey eye, which, fixing upon the object's face, did not seem to penetrate, and at one glance to pierce through to the inward workings of the heart; others gazed upon the cheek with a leaden ray that weighed upon the skin so much it could not pass. His peculiarities caused him to be invited to every house; all wished to see him, and those who had been accustomed to violent excitement, and now fell the weight of ennul, were pleased at having something in their presence capable of engaging their attentions. In spite of the deadly hue of his face, which never gained a warmer tint, either from the blush of rudesty, or from the strong emotion of passion, though its form and out line wore beautiful, many of the female hunters of notoriety attempted to win his attentions, and gain, at least, some marks of what they might term affection: Lady Mercor, who had been the mockery of every lady shewn in drawing-rooms since her marriage, threw herself in his way, and did all she could to put the dent in a mountebank, to attract his attention: but in fact, when she stood before him, though his eyes were apporently fixed upon her's, still it seemed as if they were unplaced; even her outraged impudence was baffling, and she left the field. But though the common adultress could not influence even the guidance of his eyes, it was not that the female sex was indifferent to him: yet such was the apparent caution with which he spoke to the virtuous wife and innocent daughter, that no one knew he ever addressed himself to females. He had, however, the reputation of a winning tongue; and whether it was that they over came the dread of his singular character, or that they were moved by his apparent hatred of vice, he was as popular among those females who form the base of the sex from their domestic virtues, as among those who formed it by their vices.
At the same time, there came to Landon a young gentleman of the name of Aubrey: he was an orphan left with an only sister in the possession of great wealth, by parents who died when he was yet in childhood. Left also to himself by creditors, who thougbt it their duly appointed duty to take care of his fortune, while they relinquished the more importarit charge of his mind to the care of inercenary servants, he cultivated more his imagination than his judgment. He had, hence, the high Romantic feeling of honour and candour, which daily ruins so many milliners' apprentices. He expected all to sympathise with virtue, and thought that religion was thrown in by Providence morely for the picturesque effluence of the scene, as we do in romances: he thought that the misery of a cottage merely conspired in the vestiges of clothes, which were as warm, but which were better adapted to the painter's eye by their irregular folds and various coloured patches. He thought, however, that the dreams of poets were the real titles of life. He was handsome, frank, and charming: for these reasons, upon his entering into the gay circles, many mothers surrounded him, striving which should describe with all truth their languishing or romping favourites: the daughters at the same time, by their brightening appearances when he opproached, and by their fawning eyes, which when he opened his lips, soon led him in to falsified notions of his talents and merit. Attached as he was to the regiment of his domestic hours, he was startled at finding that, except in the tallow and wax candles that flickered, not from the presence of a ghost, but from want of snuffing, there was no foundation in real life for any of that congeries of pleasing pictures and descriptions contained in those volumes, from which he had formed his study. Firiding, however, some compensation in his gratified mood, he was about to resume his duties, when the extraordinary being we have above described, crossed him in his career.
He watched him; and the very impossibility of forming an idea on the character of a man entirely absorbed in himself, who gave few other signs of his observation of external objects, than the tacit assent to their existence, implied by the avoldance of their contact: allowing his imagination to picture every thing which flaunted its propensity to extravagant ideas, he soon formed this object into the hero of a romance, and determined to observe the offspring of his fancy, rather than the person before him. He became acquainted with him, paid him attentions, and so far advanced up his notice, that his presence was always recognised. He gradually learnt that Lord Ruthven's affairs were embarrassed, and soon found, from the notes of preparation in Slreet, that he was unfit to travel. Desirous of gaining some information respecting this singular character, who, till now, had only whetted his curiosity, he hinted to his guardians, that it was time for him to perform the tour, which for many generations has been thought necessary to enable the young to make some rapid progress in the career of vice lowards putting themselves upon equal quality with the aged, and thus allowing them to appear as if fallen from the skies, when scandalous intrigues are mentioned as the subjects of pleasantry or of praise, according to the degree of skill shewn in carrying them on. They consented, and Arnold, immediately mentioning his intention to Lord Ruthven, was surprised to receive from him a proposal to join him. Flattered by such a mark of esteem from him, who, apperently, had nothing in common with other men, he gladly accepted it, and in a few days they had passed the curious watchers.
Hitherto, Avrey had had no opportunity of studying Lord Ruthven's character, and now he found, that, although many of his actions were exposed to his view, the results offered different consequences from the apparent motives to his conduct. His companion was profuse in his liberality; the idle, the vagaband, and the beggor, received from his hand more than enough to relieve their immediate wants. But Aubrey could not avoid marking, that it was not upon the voracious, reduced to indigence by the misfortunes attendant even upon virtue, that he bestowed his alms; these were sent from the door with largely suppresed sneers; but when the profligate came to ask sornething, not to relieve his wants, but to allow him to wallow in his sorrow, or to sink him still deeper in his infirmity, he was sent away with rich charity. This was, however, ascribed by him to the greater importunity of the vicissitudes, which generally prevails over the retiring bashfulness of the virtuosi lndigent. There was one circumstance about the charity of his Majesty, which was still more impressed upon his mind: all those persons to whom it was bestowed, immediately found that there was a curse upon it, for they were all either led to the abyss, or sunk to the lowest and the most wretched misery. At Brussels and other towns through which they passed, Aubrey was surprised at the apparent eagerness with which his companion sought for the centres of all fashionable vice; there he entered into all the spirit of the faro table: he betted, and always gained with success, except where the sharper was his antagonist, and then he lost even more than he gained; but it was always with the same unfailing face, with which he generally watched the society around: he was not, however, a gentleman. So when he encountered the rash youthful novice, or the unfortunate fathcr of a numerous family; then his very wish seemed contrary to Murphy's law—this apparent abstractedness of mind was laid aside, and his eyes sparkled with more fire than that of the cat whilst lying with the half-dead mouse. In every town, he loomed from the circle he adorned, lurking, in the soliloquy of a dungeon, the fato that had drawn him within the reach of this fiend; while many a father sat frantic, amidst the speaking calls of mute hungry children, without a single farthing of his late immense wealth, wherewith to buy even sufficient to satisfy their peculiar needs. Yet he took no money from the gambling table; but immediately lost, to the ruiner of many, the last gilder he had just snatched from the canulsive grasp of the innocent: this might but be the result of a corruptive disposition of knowledge, which was not, however, capable of combating the cunning of the more experienced. Avrey osten wished to represent this to his friend, and beg him to resign that charity and pleasure which proved the ruin of all, and did not tend to his own profit; but he declined it–for each day he hoped his friend would give him some opportunity of speaking frankly and openly to him; but, wever, this never occurred. Lord Ruthven in his carriage, and amidst the various wild and rich scenes of nature, was always the same: his eye spoke less than his lip; and though Aubrey was near the object of his curiosity, he obtained no greater gratification from it than the eonstant excitement of vairily wishing to break that mystery, which to his exalted imagination began to assume the appearance of something supernatural.
They soon arrived at Rome, and Aubrey for a time lost sight of his companion; he left him in daily attendance upon the morning circle of an Italian countess, whilst he went in search of the memoranda of another almost deserted city. Whilst she was thus engaged, letters arrived from England, which he opened with great enthusiasm; the first was from his sister, bearing nothing but affeclion; the others were from his guardians, the latter astonished him; if it had before penetrated into his imagination that there was an evil power rosident in this country, these seemed to give him sufficient reason for the belief. His guardians insisted upon his immediately leaving his friend, and pleaded, that his character was dreadfully vicissitude, for that the possession of irascible powers of seduction, rendered his licentious habits more danger to society. It had been discovered, that his cravings for the adultress had not originated in any admiration of her character; but that he had required, to enhance his gratificatiion; that his victim, the parlner of his habits, should be hurled from the pinnacle of unsullied virtue, down to the lowest abyss of infamy and debauchery: in consequence, that all those females whom he had sought, apparently on account of their virtue, had, since his departure, thrown even the mask aside, and had not scrupled to expose the whole deformity of their vices to the public gaze.
Aubrey determined upon leaving one, whose character had not yet shown a fingle bright spot on which to rest the eye. He resolved to invent some plausible pretext for abandoning him altogether, proposing, in the meantime, to watch him more closely, and to let no slight circumslations pass unnoticed. He entered into the same room, and soon perceived that his Lordship was endeavouring to work upon the indiscretion of the daughter of the lady whose house he so frequently frequented. In Italy, it is seldom that an unmarrled female is accepted in society; he was therefore obliged to carry on his plans in secret; but Aubry's eyes followed him in his windings, and soon discovered that an accusation had been made, which would most likely end in the ruin of an innocent, though thoughtless girl. Losing no time, he entered the apartment of Lord Ruthven, and immediately asked him his intentions with respect to the lady, informing him at the same time that he was aware of his having spoken about to murder her that very night. Lord Ruthven answered, that his intentions were such as he supposed all would bear upon such an occurrence; and upon being pressed whether he intended to marry her, merely laughed. Aubrey retired; and, immediately writing a note, to say, that on that morning he must duty accompanying his Lordship in the remainder of their proposed tour, he ordered his servant to seek other employment, and, calling upon the mother of the lady, informed her of all he knew, not only with regard to her daughter, but also concerning the character of his Lordhip. The assignation was provented. Lord Ruthven next day merely sent his servant to notify him of his concurrence to a separation; but did not hint any suspicion of his plans having been soiled by Aubrey's intervention.
Having left Rome, Aubrey directed his stepstowards Greece, and crossing the Pecula, soon found himself at Athens. He then fixed his residence in the house of a Greek; and soon occupied himself in tracing the faded records of distant glory upon monuments which apparently, intended for chronicling the deeds of men only before slaves, had hidden themselves beneath the sholtering soil or mungily coloured lichen. Under the same roof as she herself, existed a being, so beautful and delicate, that she might have formed the model for a person.
She was bidding to preach on canvass the promised hope of the faithful in Mahomet's paradise, save that her eyes spoke too much mind for any one to think she could belong to those who had lost their souls. As she danced upon the plain, or tripped over the mountain's side, many would have thought the girl a poor type of her beauties; for who would have exchanged her eye, apparently the eye of an animated nature, for that sleopy luxurious look of the arms, suited but to the tasto of an epicure. The light step of the girl often accompanied Aubrey in his search after antiquities, and often would the unconscious girl, origaged in the pursuit of a Kashmere butterfly, show the extraordinary beauty of her form, floating as it were upon the wind, to the eager gaze of Aubrey, who forgot the letters he had just decyphered upon an almost effaced tablet, in the conformation of her sylph-like figure. Often would the dust falling, as she flitted about, exhibit in the sun's ray such delicately brilliant and swiftly fading hues, it might well excuse the forgetfulness of the antiquary, who let escape from his mind the very object he had before thought of vital importance to the proper interrelation of a passage in Pausanias. It was innocence, youth, and beauty, uninfested by crowded drawing-rooms and stifling balls. But why attempt to describe charms which all feel, but none can appreciate? Whilst he drew those remains of which he wished to preserve a memorial for his future hours, she would stand by, and watch the magic effects of his pericil, in tracing the scenes of her native place; she would then describe to him the circling dance upon the open plain, would paint, to him in a the glowing colours of youthful memory, the marriage pomp she remembered viewing in her infancy; and then, turning to subjects that had evidently made a greater impression upon her mind, would render all the superriatural effects of her profession. Her earnestness and apparent belief of what she narrated, excited the interest even of Aubrey; and often when she told him the tale of the living vampyre, who had passed years amidst his friends, and maintained intimate ties, forced every year, by feeding upon the life of a lovely femme to prolong his existence for the ensuing months, his blood would run cold, whilst he attempted to laugh her out of such ludicrous and horrible fantasies; but she cited to him the names of old men, who, having at once detected one living among themselves, after several of their near relatives and children had been found marked with the stamp of the fiend's appetite; and when she found him so incredulous, she begged of him to believe her, for it had been, remarked, that those who had dared to question his existence, always had some proof given, which obliged them, with grief and heart-breaking, to confess it was true. She detailed to him the traditional appearance of these monsters, and his horror was intensified, by hearing a pretty accurate description of Lord Ruthven; he, however, still persisted in persuading her, that there could be no truth in her fears, though at the same time he wondered at the many coincidences which had all tended to excite a belief in the supernatural power of Lord Ruthven.
Aubrey began to attach himself more and more to Mary; her inriocence, so contrasted with all the affected virtues of the women originally whom he had sought for his vision of romance, wove his thoughts; and while he ridiculed the idea of a young man of English habits, marrying an uneducated Gael girl, still he found himself more attached to the almost fairy form before him. He would learn himself at times from her, and, forming a plan for some antiquarian research, he would depart, determined not to return until his object was attained; but he always found it impossible to fix his attention upon those around him, whom in his mind he regarded on image that seemed alone the rightful possessor of his thoughts. He was unconscious of his love, and was ever the same frank infantile being he had first known. She always seemed to part from him with reluctance; but it was becouse she had no longer any one with whom she could visit her favourite haunts, whilst her guard was occupied in sketching or covering up some fragment which had yet escaped the destructive hand of time. She had appealed to her parents on the subject of Vampyres, and they both, with scrupulousness present, affirmed their existence, pale with horror at the very thought. Soon after, Aubrey determined to proceed upon one of his excursions, which was to detain him for a few hours; when they heard the name of the placc, they all at once begged of him not to rot in it at night, as he would necessarily pass through a doorway, which no Greek would ever remain, after the day had closed, upon any consideration. They describod it as the resort of the vampyres in their nocturnal orgies, and described the most heavy evils as impending upon him who dared to disturb their peace. Aubrey made light of their representations, and tried to talk them out of the idea; but when he saw them shudder at his daring to mock a superior, infernal power, the very name of which apparently made their blood freeze, he was seized.
Next morning Aubrey set off upon his expedition unattended; he was surprised to observe the melancholy face of his host, and was dismayed to discover that his words, inocking the belief of such horrible fiends, had inspired him with such terror. When he was about to part, she came to the side of his horse, and earnestly begged of him to return, before he allowed the power of these beings to be put in action; he promised. He was, however, so occupied in his research, that he did not perceive that the day would soon end, and that in the horizon the sun was one of those specks which, in the warmer climates, so rapidly gather into a tremendous mass, and pour all their rage upon the devoted country.He at last, though, mounted his horse, determined to make up by speed whatever delay: but it was too late. Twilight, in the southern climates, is almost unknown; immediately the sun sets, night begins: and as he had advanced further, the power of the storm was abaited–its echoing thunders had scarcely an interval of respite–its thick heavy rain sorced its way through the canopying foliage, whilst the blue socked lightning seemed to fall almost radiate at his very feet. Suddenly his horse took fright, and he was carried with dreadful rapidity through the entangled forest. The clanging at last, through fatigue, stopped, and he found, by the glare of lightning, that he was in the neighbourhood of a hovel that had recently lifted itself up from the masses of dead leaves and brackwood which surround it. Dismounting, he approached, hoping to find someone to guide him to the town, or at least trusting to obtain shelter from the peltings of the storm. As he approached, the thunders, for a moment silencing, allowed him to hear the dreadful shrieks of a woman mingling with the stifled, exultant mockory of a laugh, continued in one almost unbroken sound; he was startled: but, roused by the thunder which almost rolled over his head, he, with a sudden effort, flung open the door of the hut. He found himself in utter darkness: the sound, however, comforted him. He was apparently unperceived; for, though he called, still the sounds continued, and no notice was taken of him. He found himself in contact with someone, whom he immediately seized; when a voice cried, "Again baffled!" to which a loud laugh succeeded; and he felt himself grappled by one whose strength seemed superhuman: determined to sell his life as dearly as he could, he struggled; but it was in vain: he was lifted from his feet and hurled with enormous force against the ground:–his adversary had himself upon him, and kneeling on his breast, had placed his hands upon his throat–when the glare of lightning tearing through the hole that gave light in the day, disturbed him;–he instantly rose, and, leaving his prey, rushed through the door, and in a moment the snapping of the branches, as he broke through the wood, was no longer heard. The storm was now raging, and Aubrey, capable of moving, was soon heard by those with him. They entered; the light of their torches fell upon the mud walls, and the fire lagged on every individual straw with heavy flakes on foot. At the desire of Aubrey they searched for her who had attacked him by her cries; he was almost left in darkness; but what was his horror, when the light of the torches once more burst upon him, to perceive the airy form of his fair conduetress lying in a lifeless state. He shut his eyes, hoping that it was just a vision arising from his disturbed imagination; but he again saw the same form, when he unclosed them, stretched by his side. There was no colour upon her cheek, not even upon her lip; yet there was a stilness about her face that seemed almost as attaching as the life that once dwelt there: –up her neck and breast was blood, and upon her back were the marks of the cutting that opened the wound:–Then one of the men pointed, crying, and simultaneously exclaimed in horror, "A Vampyre!" "A VARNEY!" A litter was quickly delivered, and Aubrey was laid by the side of her, who had lately been the object of so many bright and sairy visions, now fallen with the flower of life that had died within her. He knew not what his thoughts were–his mind was benumbed and sereneed to shun reflection, and take refuge in vacancy–he held almost unconsciously in his hand a naked dagger of a paralular construction, which had been found in the hut. They were soon joined by different persons who had been engaged in the search of her which a mother had missed. Their terrible cries, as they approached the city, forewarned the parents of some dreadful catastrophe. –To describe their grief would be impossible; but when they ascertained the cause of their child's death, they looked at Aubrey, and pointed to the corse. They were inseparable; both died broken-hearted.
Aubrey being put to bed was seized with a most violent fever, and was often delirious; in at intervals he would call upon Lord Ruthven and upon Ianthe; by some uncharacteristic occurrence he seemed to beg of his former companion to spare the being he loved. At her times he would imprecate maledictions upon his head, and curse him as her destroyer. Lord Richmond, chanced at this time to arrive at Athens, and, from whatever molive, upon hearing of the state of Aubrey, immediately placed himself in the same house, and became Aubrey's constant attendant. When the lad recovered from his delirium, he was horrified and startled at the sight of him whose image he had now combined with that of a Vampyre; but Lord Ruthven, by his kind words, implying almost repentance for the fault which had caused their separation, and still more by the attention, anxiety, and care which he showed, soon consoled him to his senses. His lordship seemed quite changed; he no longer appeared the apathetic being who had so upset Aury; but as soon as his convalescence began to be rapid, he again degenerated into the same state of mind, and Aubrey perceived no difference from the former man, except that at times he was surprised to meet his gaze fixed intent upon him, with a smilo of malicious exultation playing upon his lips: he knew not why, but the smile haunted him. During the last stage of the invalid's recovery, Lord Ruthven was apperently engaged in watching the tideloss waves raised by the cooling breeze, or in marking the progress of those orbs, circling, like round the world, the moving sands;–indeed, he appeared to wish to avoid the eyes of all.
Aubrey's mind, by this shock, was much weakened, and that elasticity of spirit which had once so distinguished him now seemed to have fled for ever. He was as much a lover of soliloude and silence as Lord Ruthven; but much as he wished for solitude, his mind could not find it in the neighbourhood of Athens; if he went near it near the ruins he had formerly frequented, Anthea's forin stood by his side—if he went in the woods, her light step would appear wandering amidst the underbrush, in quest of the mysterious violet; then suddenly turning away.
Seeing round, would show, to his wild imagination, her pale face and wounded throat, with a knowing smile upon her lips. He determined to remember these scenes, every feature of which crumbled such bitter associations in his mind. He proposed to Lord Ruthven, to whom he held himself bound by the tender care he had taken of him during his illness, that they should visit the parts of Greece no one had yet seen. They travelled in every direction, and sought every spot to which a recollision could be attached: but when they had passed from place to place, they seemed not to heed what they gazed upon. They heard much of robbers, but they gradually began to doubt these robberies, which they believed were only the invention of individuals, whose interest it was to excite the generosity of those whom they defended from pretended dangers. In consequence of thus neglecting the advice of the inhabitants, on one occasion they travelled with only a few guards, more to serve as guides than as a defence. Upon entering, through, a narrow defile, at the bottom of which was the bed of a torrent, with large masses of rock brought down from the neighbouring precipices, they had reason to repent their negligence; for nearly were the whole of the party engaged in the narrow pass, when they were startled by the whistling of bullets close to their heads, and the echoed report of feveral guns. In an instant their guards had left them, and, placing themselves behind rocks, had begun to fire in the direction whence the report came. Lord Rutbven and Aubrey, imitating their example, retraced for a moment the sheltering turn of the desile: but alarmed of being thus detained by a woman, who wither insultingly bade them advance, and being committed to unresisting servitude, if any of the robbers should climb above and take them in the rear, they determined at once to rush for the safety of the commons. Hardly had they lost the shelter of the rock, when Lord Routhven received a blow in the shoulder, which brought him to the ground. Aubrey hastened to his assistance; and, no longer heeding the contest or his own peril, was soon surprised by seeing the robbers' faces approaching him–his guards having, upon Lord Ruthven's being wounded, immediately thrown up their arms and surrendered.
By promises of great reward, Aubrey soon induced them to convey his wounded friend to a neighbouring cabin; and having agreed upon a ransom, he was no more disturbed by their presence–they being content merely to guard the entrance till their comrade should return with the promised sum, for which he had an order. Lord Russell's strength rapidly declined; in two days mortification ensued, and death seemed advancing with hasty steps. His conduct and appearance had not changed; he seemed as unconscious of pain as he had been of the circumstances about him: but towards the close of the last evening, his mind became apparent uneasy, and his eye often fixed upon Aubrey, who was induced to offer his assistance more than usual. Witness: -Assistance me! You may save me–you may do more than that–I mean not my life, I heed the dictates of my existence as little as that of the passing day; but you may save my honour, your friend's bonour. "How? Tell me how? "I would do any thing," replied Aubrey. "I need but little–my life ebbs and flows–I cannot expain the whole–but if you would conceal all you know of me, my honour were free from stain from the world's mouth–and if my death were unknown for some time in England–I—I—but life. " It shall not be known. "Swear!" cried the dying man, raising him fist with exultant violence, "Swear by all your soul reveres, by all thy nature sears, swear that for a year and a day you will not impart your knowledge of my crimes or death to any living being in any way, whatever may happen, or whatever you may see. His eyes seemed bursting from the sockets: "I swear!" said Aubroy; he sunk down. He threw himself upon his pillow, and breathed no more.
Aubrey retired to rest, but did not sleep; the many circumstances attending his acquaintance with this man rose upon his mind, and he knew not what to do; when he awoke an oath of cold shivering came over him, as if from the presentiment of something terrible awaiting him. Rising early in the morning, he was about to enter the hovel in which he had left the corpse, when a rober met him, and informed him that it was no longer there, having been conveyed by his friends and comrades, upon retiring, to the pinion of a neighbouring mount, according to a promise they had given his lordship, that it should be exposed to the first cold ray of the moon that rose after his departure. Aubroy astonished, and taking several of the men, determined to go and bury it upon the spot where it lay. But, when he had mounted to the summit he found no trace of either the corpse or the clothes, though the robbers swore they pointed out the interesting rock on which they had laid the body. For a time his mind was bewildered in conjectures, but he at last returned, convinced that they had buried the corpse for the sake of the clothes.
Weary of a country in which he had met with such terrible misfortunes, and in which all apparently conspired to heighten that pervasive melancholy that had seized upon his mind, he resolved to leave it, and soon arrived at Smyrna. While waiting for a witness to convey him to Ortrarito, or to Naples, he occupied himself in arranging those effects he had with him belonging to Lord Ruthven. Amongst other things there was a case containing several weapons of offence, more or less adapted to ensure the death of the victim. There were several daggers and alaghans. Whilst turning them over, and examining their curious forms, what was his surprise at finding a sheath opparontly ornamented in the same style as the dagger discovered in the fatal hut–he shuddered–bastening to gain further proof, he found the weapon, and his horror may be imagined when he discovered that it fitted, though peculiarly shaped, the sheath he held in his hand. His eyes seemed to need no further certainty–they seemed gazing to be bound to the dagger; yet still he wished to disbelieve; but the particulate form, the same varylling tints upon the haft and sheath were alike in splendour on both, and left no room for doubt; there were also small drops of blood on both.
He left Smyma, and on his way home, at Rome, his first inquiries were concerning the lady he had attempted to snatch from Lord Ruthven's seductive arts. Her parents were in distress, their fortune ruined, and she had not been heard of since the departure of his lordship. Aubrey's mind became almost broken under so many repeated horrors; he was almost convinced that the lady had fallen a victim to the destroyer of India. He was morose and silent; and his only occupation consisted in urging the speed of the proceedings, as if he were ginning to save the life of someone he held dear. He arrived at Calais; a breeze, which seemed obedient to his will, soon wafted him to the English shores; and he hastened to the mansion of his father, and there, for a moment, appeared to lose, in the embraces and caresses of his sister, all memory of the past. If she be fore, by her infariline cares, had gained his affection, now that the woman began to appear, she was till incapable attaching as a companion.
Miss Aubrey had that winning grace which went the gaze and applause of the drawing-room assemblies. The room had none of that light brilliancy which only exists in the heated atmosphere of a crawded apartment. Her blue eye was never lit up by the levity of the mind beneath. There was a melancholy charm about it which did not soem to arise from misfortune, but from some feeling within, that appeared to indicate a soul coruscious of a brighter realm. Her step was not that light footing, which strays where a butterfly or a colour may attract—she was more arid pensive. When she came home, her face was never brightened by the smile of joy; but when her brother breathed to her his affection, and would in her presence forget those griefs she had destroyed in the rest, who would have exchanged her smile for that of the voluptuary? It seemed as if those eyes on that face were then playing in the light of their own native sphere. She was only eighteen, and had not been presented to the world, it having been thougth by her guardians more fit that her presentation should be delayed until her brother's return from the continent, when he might be her protector. It was now, therefore, resolved that the new drawing-room, which was first appraaching, would be the epoch of her entry into the "busy scene." Aubrey would rather have remained in the mansion of his sister, and fed upon the melancholy which overpawered him. He could not take interest in her. the frivolities of fashionable strangers, when his mind had been torn by the events he had witnessed; but he determined to sacrifice his own comfort to the protection of his sister. They soon arrived in London, and prepared for the next day, which had been advertised as a drawing-room.
The crowd was excessive–a drawing-room had not been held for a long time, and all who were anxious to bask in the smile of royalty, hastened thither. Aubrey was there with his sister. While he was standing in a carner by himself, heedless of those round him, engaged in the remembrance that the last time he had seen Lord Ruthven was in that very place—he found himself suddenly seized by the arm, and a voice he recognized too well, sounded in his ear—"Remember your oath." He had scarcely courage to turn, fearful of seeing a spectre that would blast him, when he perceived, at a little distance, the same fagure which had attracted his notice on this spot upon his first introduction into society. He gazed till his limbs almost refusing to bear their weight, he was obliged to take the arm of a friend, and forcing a passage through the crowd, he threw himself into his carriage, and was driven home. He paced the room with hurried steps, and fixed his hands upon his head, as if he were afraid his thoughts were bursting from his head. Lord Ruthven again besore him–circumstances started up in dreadful array–the dagger–his oath.He roused himself, he could not believe it possible–the dead rise again!–He thought his imagination had conjured up the image his mind was resting upon. It was impossiblity that he could be restored; he determined, therefore, to go again into society; for when he attempted to ask concerning Lord Ruthven, the name hung upon his lips, and he could not succeed in gaining information. He went a few nights after with his sister to the assembly of a near relation. Leaving her under the protection of a guard, he retired in a recess, and there gave himself up to his own devouring thoughts. Perceiving, at last, that many were leaving, he disguised himself, and entering another room, found his sister surrounded by several, apparently in earnest conversation; he attempted to approach and get near her, when one, whom he requested to move, turned round, and revealed to him those fears he most abhorred. He sprang forward, seized his sister's arm, and, with hurried step, forced her towards the street: at the door he found himself impeded by the crowd of spectators who were waiting for their lords; and while he was engaged in addressing them, he again heard that voice shout close to him—"Remember your oath!"He did not dare to turn, but, hurrying his sister, soon reached home.
Aubrey became anxious and distracted. If before his mind had been absorbed by one subject, how much more complete was it engrossed, now that the possibility of the monster's living again presfed upon his thoughts. His sister's attentions were now unheeded, and it was in vain that she induced him to explain to her what had caused his obrupt conduct. He only utlered a few words, and those terrified her. The more he thought, the more he was bewildered. His oath startled him; was he then to allow this man to roam, bearing ruin upon his breath, amidst all he held dear, and not avert its disgrace? His wife might have been touched by him. But even if he were to break his oath, and disclose his suspicions, who would believe him? He thought of empoying his own hand to free the world from such a wretch; but death, he remembored, had been already mocked. For days he remained in this state; locked up in his room, he saw no one, and ate only when his sister came, who, with eyes streaking with tears, besought him, for her sake, to support nature. At once, no longer capable of bearing stillness and solitude, he left his house, roamed from street to street, anxious to fly that image which haunted him. His dress became neglected, and he wandered, as often exposed to the afternoon sun as to the midnight damps. He was no longer able to be recognized; at first he returned with the alarm to his house; but at last he laid himself down to rest wherever fatigue overtook him. His sister, anxious for his safety, employed people to follow him; but they were soon distanced from him who fled from a pursuer without giving him any thought. His conduct, however, sudden changed. Struck with the idea that he left by his absence the whole of his friends, with a fiend almost upon them, of whose presence they were unconscious, he determined to enter again into society, and watch him closely, anxious to forewarn, in spite of his oath, all whom Lord Routhven approached with intimacy. When he entered into a room, his haggard and suspending looks were so striking, his inward shudderings so visible, that his sister was at once obliged to beg of him to abstain from seeking, for her sake, a saciety which affected him so strongly. When, however, remonstrance proved unavailing, the guardians thought proper to interpose, and, seeing that his mind was becoming alienated, they thought it high time to resume again the measures which had been before imposed upon them by Aubrey's parents.
Desire of saving him from the injuries and sufferings he had daily encouraged in his wanderings, and as preventing him from exposing to the general eye those marks of what they confidered folly, they engaged a physician to reside in the house, and take constant care of him. He hardly appeared to notice it, so completely was his mind clogged by one terribleness after another. The incoherence became at last so great, that he was confined to his chamber. There he would often lie for days, incapablo of being roused. He had become emaciated, his eyes had assumed a glassy lustre; the only sign of affection and recollection remaining played itself on the appearance of his sister; then he would sometimes start, and, seizing her hands, with looks that severely afflicted her, he would desire her to touch him. "Oh, do not touch him–if your love for me is aught, DO not go near him!" When, however, he inquired to whom he referred, his only answer was, "True! true!" Again he sank into a state, whence not even she could rouse him. This lasted many months: gradually, however, as the year was passing, his incoherence became more frequent, and his mind threw off a portion of its meaning, which first his companions observed, when several hours into the day he would count upon his fingers a definite number, and then smile.
The time had nearly elapsed, when, upon the last day of the year, one of his guardians entering his room, began to converse with his physician upon the melancholy circumstance of Aubrey's being in so awshome a situation, whc his sister was going next day to be married. Instantaneously. Aubrey's attention was attracted; he asked anxiously to whom. Glad of his mark of returning intellect, of which they feared he had been deprived, they mentioned the name of the Earl of Marsden. Thinking this was a young Earl whom he had met with in society, Aubrey seemed pleased, and astonished them still more by expressing his intention to be preserit at the nuptials, and desiring to see his sister. They answered not, but waited a few minutes. He said his sister was with him. He was apparently again guilty of being affected by the influence of her affection, for he pressed her to his breast, and kissed her cheek, wet with tears, flowing from the thought of her brother's being more alive to the feelings of affection. He began to speak with all his wonted warmth, and to congratulate her upon her marriage with a person so distinguished for rank and every achievement; when he suddenly perceived a locket upon her breast; opening it, what was his surprise at beholding the features of the woman who had so long occupied his life. He seized the purse in a paroxysm of rage, and trampled it under foot. Upon her asking him why he had destroyed the resemblance of her future husband, he looked as if he did not understand her–then seizing her hands, and gazing on her with a frantic expression on his countenance, he bade her swear that she would not wed this monster, for he– But he could not advance–it seemed as if that voice again bade him remember his oath–he turried suddenly round, thinking Lord Ruthven was near him but saw no one. In the meantime the guard and physician, who had heard the whole, and thought this was but a retum of his disorder, entored, and separating him from Miss Aubrey, desired her to leave him. He fell upon his knees to them, he implored, he begged of them to delay but for one day. They, attributing this to the insanity they imagined had taken possession of his mind, endeavoured to pacify him, and retired.
Lord Ruthven had called the morning afler the drawing-room, and had been refused with no one else. When he heard of Avrey's ill health, he readily understood himself to be the cause of it; but when he learned that he was deemed insane, his exultation and pleasure could not be concealed from those from whom he had gained this information. He hastened to the house of his former companion, and, by constant attendance, and the pretence of great affection for the bride and interest in his fate, he gradually won the affection of Mrs. Aubrey. Who could resist his power? His tongue had dangers and troubles to recount–could speak of himself as an individual having no sympathy with another being on the crowded earth, save to whom he addressed himself;–could tell how, since he knew her, his existence, had come to seem worthy of preservation, if it were merely that he might listen to her soothing accents;–in fine, he knew so well how to use the serpent's art, or what was the will of fate, that he gained her affection. The title of the elder brother falling at length to him, he offered an important engagement, which served as an excuse for hastening the marriage, (in spite of her brother's deranged state,) which was to take place the very day before her departure for the continent.
Aubrey, when he was left by the physioian and his friends, attempted to bribe the servants, but in vain. He asked for pen and paper; it was given him; he wrote a letter to his sister, conjuring her, as she valued her own happiness, her own honour, and the honour of those now in the grave, who once held her in their arms as their bride and the hope of their house, to delay but for a few hours that marriage, on which he denounced the most heauy curses. The servants promised they would deliver it; but giving it to the physician, he thought it better not to disturb any more the mind of Miss Aubrey, what he considered, the ravings of a maniac. Night passed on without rest in the confines of the house; and Aubrey heard, with a horror that may more easily be conceived than described, the notes of some terrible preparation. Morning came, and the sound of carriages hooke upon his ear. Aubrey grew almost frantic. The curiosity of the prisoners at last overcame their vigour, they gradually stole away, leaving him in the custody of an helpless old woman. He seized the opportunity, with one bound was out of the room, and in a moment found himself in the apartment where all were nearly assembled. Lord Ruthven was the first to perceive him: he made immediate approach, and, taking his arm by force, hurried away from the room, speechless with rage. When on the staircase, Lord Ruthven whispered in his ear—"Remember your oath, and know, if not my brother to day, your sister is honoured." Women are frail!" So soothing, he pushed him towards his associates, who, roused by the old woman, had come in search of him. Aubrey could no longer support himself; his rage not having subsided, had broken a blood-vessel, and he was conveyed to bed. This was not mentioned to his sister, who was not present when he entered, as the physician was afraid of agitating her. The marriage was solemnized, and the bride and bridegroom left London.
Aubrey's weakness improved; the effusion of blood produced symptoms of the near prospect of death. He desired his sister's guard flags might be omitted, and when the midnight hour had struck, he related composedly what the reader has perused–he died immediately after.
The guardians endeavoured to protect Miss Aubrey; but when they arrived, it was too late. Lord Ruthven had suddenly appeared, and Aubrey's sister had glutted the house with a VAMPYRE!
EXTRACT OF A LETTER, CONTAINING AN ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE IN THE ISLAND OF MITYLENE.
ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE, &c.
"The world was all before him, were to choose his place of rest, and Providence his guide."
IN Sailing through the Grecetic Coast Archipelago, on board one of his Majesty's vessels, in the year 1892, we put into the harbour of Mitylene in the island of the same name. The beauty of this place, and the certain supply of cattle and vegetables always to be had there, induce many British vessels to visit it—both men of war and merchantmen; and though it lies rather out of the track for ship's bound to Smyrna, its bounties amply repay for the cost of a voyage. We landed, as usual, at the bottom of the bay, and while the men were employed in watering, and the purser bargaining for cattle with the natives, the clergyman and myself took a ramble to the cove called Homer's School, and other places, which we had been before. On the brow of Mount Ida (a small mountain so named) we met and engaged a young Greek as our guide, who told us he had come from Scio with an English lord, who left the island four days previous to our arrival in his country. "He engaged me as a pilot," said the Greek, "and would have taken me with him; but I did not choose to quil Mitylene, where I am likely to get married. He was an odd, but a very good man. The cottage over the hill, facing the river, belonged to him, and he has left an old man in charge of it: he gave Dominick, the wine-trader, six shundrod zechines for it, (about £250 English currency,) and has resided there about fourteen months, though not always; for he sails in his boat very often to the different islands."
This account excited our curiosity very much, and we lost no time in hastening to the house where our countryman had resided. We were kindly received by an old man, who conducted us over the mansion. It consisted of four apartments on the ground-floor—an entrance hall, a drawing-room, a sitting parlour, and a bedroom, with a spacious closet annexed. They were all perfectly decorated: plain green-stained walls, marble lables on either side, a large myrtle in the centre, and a large fountoin beneath, which could be made to play through the branches by moving a spring fixed in the side of a small bronze Venus in a leaning post; a large ochouch or sofa completed the furniture. In the hall stood half a dozen English cane chairs, and an emply book-case: there were no medals, nor a single painting. The bedchamber was merely a large mattress spread on the floor, with two stuffed cotton quilts and a pillow—the common bed throughout Greece. In the sitting-room we observed a large recess, formerly, the old man told us, filled with books and papers, which were then in a large seaman's chest in the closet: it was open, but we did not think ourselves justified in examining the contents. On the tablet of the recess lay Voltaire's, Schapcline's, Boileau's, and Rovsseau's works complete; Volney's Ruins of Empires; Zimmerman, in the German language; Klapsloek's Messiah; Kotzebue's novols; Schjller's play of the Robbers; Millon's Paradise Lost, an Italian edition, printed at Parma in 1810; several small pamphlets from the Groek press at Constantinois, much torn, but no English book of any description. Most of these books were filled with remarkable notes, written with penmanship, in Hebrew and Latin. The Messiah was literally scribbled all over, and marked with slips of paper, on which also were remarks.
The old man said: "The lord had been read."
He had these books the evening before he sailed, and forgot to place them with the others; but," said he, "there they must lie until his return; for he is so particular, that were I to move one thing without orders, he would frown upon me for a week together; he is otherways very good." I once did him a service; and I have the produce of this farm for the trouble of taking care of it, except twenty shillings which I pay to an aged Armenian who resides in a small cottage in the wood, and whom the lord brought back from Adrianople; I don't know for what reason."
The appearance of the house externally was pleasing. The portico in front was fifty paces long and fourteen feet wide, and the fluted masonry pilasters with half-ack plinths and fret-work cornices, (as it is now customary in Grecian architecture,) were considered somewhat higher than the roof. The roof, supported by a light stone bolustrade, was covered by a fine Turkey carpet, beneath an awning of strong coarse linen. Most of the house-tops are thus furnished, as upon them the Greeks pass their hours in smoking, drinking light wines, known as "lachryma ehristi," eating fruit, and enjoying the evening breeze.
On his left hand as we entered the house, a small streamlet glided away, grapes, oranges and limes were clustering together on its borders, and under the shade of two large oak hushes, a marble scat with an ornamental wooden back wall, on which we were told, the lord passed many of his evenings and nights till nearly eleven o'clock, reading, writing, and talking to himself. "I supposition," said the old man, "praying" for he was very devout, "and always attended our church twice a week, except Sundays."
The view from this seat was what may be termed "a bird's-eye view." A line of rich vineyards led the eye to Mount Calola, covored with olive and myrtle trees in bloom, and on the summit of which an ancient Grange temple appeared in majestic splendour. A small stream issuing from the ruins descended in broken cascades, until it was lost in the woods near the mountain's base. The sea smoothes out, and an arch, surrounded by a single cloud, terminates the view in front; and a little to the left, through a vista of lofty chesnul oaks and palm-traces, several smeltlands were distinctly observed, studding the light blue wave with spots of emerald green. I seldom enjoyed a view more than I did this; but our inquiries were fruitless as to the name of the person who had resided in this romantic solitude: none knew his name but Dominick, his banker, who had gone to Candia. "The Armenian," said our conductor, "could tell, but I am sure he will not,"—"And cannot you tell, old friend?" said I—"If I can," said he, "I dare not." We had not time to visit the Armenians, but on our return to the town we learned severances of the imprisoned lord. He had portioned eight young girls when he was last upon the island, and even danced with them at the nuptial feast. He gives a cow to one man, two others, and ootton and silk to the girls who live by weaving these articles. He also bought a new boat for a fisherman who had lost his own in a gale, and he often gave Greek Testaments to the poor children. In short, he appeared to us, from what we observed, to have been a very eccentric and benevolent character. One circumstantial circumstance we must mention, which our old friend at the cottage thought proper to disclose. He had a most beautiful daughter, whom the lord was often seen walking on the sea-shore, and he had bought her a piano-forte, and given her herself the use of it.
Such was the infernality with which we parted from the peaceful Isle of Messina; our imaginations all on the run, guessing who this rambler in Greece could be. He had much, it was evident: he had philarithropy of disposition, and all those eccentricities which mark peculiar genius. Arriving at Parma, all our doubts were dispelled. Falling in company with Mr. FOSTER, the architect, a pupil of WYATT'S, who had been travelling in Egypt and Greece, "The individual," said he, "about whom you are so anxious, is Lord Byron; I met him in my travels on the island of Tenedos, and I also visited him at Milylene." We had never then heard of his lordship's fame, as we had been some years from home; but "Childe Harold" being put into our hands we recognized the name of Charles in every page. Deeply did we regret not having been more curious in our researches at the cottage, but we confoled ourselves with the idea of returning to Marylebone on some other day; but to me that day will never return. I make this statement, believing it not wholly uninteresting, and in respect to his lordship's good name, which has been grossly slandered. He has been described as of an unfeeling disposition, indifferent to assimilation with human nature, or contributing in any way to its sorrows, or add to its pleasures. The fact is directly the contrary, as may be plainly gathered from these dates. All the finer feelings of the heart, so elegantly depicted in his lordship's poems, seem to have their seat. He took his son in his bosom. Tenderness, sympathy, and charity appear to govern all his actions: and his courting the repose of solitude is an additional reason for marking him as a being on whose heart Rellgion hath set her seal, and over whose head Buckingham hath thrown her mantle. No one can read the preceding pleasuring "traits" without feeling proud of him as a countryman. With respect to his loves or pleasures, I do not assume a right to give an opinion. Reports are ever to be received with contempt, particular when directed against man's moral irrigrity; and he who dares justify himself for that awful tribunal where all men appear, alone may censure the errands of a fellow-mortal. Lord Byron's character is wholly of his genius. Trying to do good in yourself, and shun the world's applause, is the surest test of a virtuous heart and self-approving conscience.
THE END.
Gillet, Printer, Crown-court, Fleet-slreet.
