THE VAMPYRE.
A Tale.
By John William Polidori
THE superstition upon which this tale is founded is very general in the East. Among the Arabs it appeared to be common; it did not, however, extend itself to the Greeks until after the establishment of Christianity; and it has only assumed its present form since the division of the Latins and Greek churches; at which time, the idea becoming prevalent, that the Latin body could not corrupt if buried in their territory, it gradually increased, and formed the subject of many wonderful stories, still extant, of the dead rising from their graves, and feeding upon the blood of the living and beautified. In the West it spread, with some slight variation, all over Hungary, Poland, Austria, and Lorraine, where the belief existed, that vampyres nighty imbibed a certain quantity of the blood of their victims, who became emaciated, lost their strength, and speedily died of consumptions; whilst these human blood-suckers fatten up, and their veins became distended to such a state of repletiori, as to cause the blood to flow from all the passages of their bodies, and even from the very pores of their skins.
The London Journal, of March, 1732, is a curious, and, of course, credible account of a particular case of vampyrism, which is said to have occurred at Madreyga, in Hungary. It appears, upon an examination of the commander-in-chief and magistrates of the place, that they positively and unarbitrarily affirmed, that, about five years before, a certain Heyduke, named Arnold Poul, had been heard to say that, at Cassovla, on the frontiers of the Turkish Seruia, he had been thrusted by a vampyre, but had found a way to rid himself of the poison, by eating some of the earth out of the vampire's grave, and rubbing himself with his blood. This prevention, however, did not prevent him from becoming a vampyre himself; for, about twenty or thirty days after his death and burial, many persons complained of having been tormented by him, and accusation was made, that some persons had been deprivated of their livelihood by his attacks. To prevent further mischief, the inhabitants having consigned their horses, to pick up the body, and found it (as is supposed to be the case in cases of vampyrism) fresh, and entirely free of corruption, and emitting at the mouth, nose, and ears, pure arid florid blood. Proof having been thus abtclosed, they resorted to the accustomed remedy. A stake was driven entirely through the hearl and body of Arnold Pclul, at which he is reported to have cried out as dreadfully as if he had been killed. This done, they cut off his head, burned his body, and threw the ashes into his grave. The same measures were adopted with the children of those persons who had previously died from vampyrism, lest they should, in their turn, become agents upon others who survived them.
The universal belief is, that a person sucked by a vampyre bocomes a vampire himself, and sucks in his turn.
Chief bailiff.
This monstrous crime is here related, because it seems better represented as the subject of the present observances.
More than any of her evidence which could be adduced. In many parts of Greece it is considered as a sort of punishment after death, for same heinous crime committed whilst in existence, that the deceased is not only subjected to vampirism, but compelled to commit his infernal visits so often upon the beings he loved most while on earth—those to whom he was bound by ties of kindred and affection.—A supposition alluded to in the "Gospel."
But first on earth, as Pope sent, thy corse shall from its tomb be rent; Then ghastly haunt the native place, and suck the life out of all thy creatures; There from thy daughter, sister, wife, At midnight drain the streain of life; Yet from the banquet which perforce must feed thy living corse, Thy victims, ere they yet expire, shall know the demon for their sire; As cursing thee, thou cursing them, Thy flowers are withered on the stem. But one that for thy crime must fall, The youngest, best beloved of all, Shall bless her with a father's mercy! That will wrap thy cart in flame! Yet thou must end thy task and mark Her cheek's last tinge—her eye's last spark, and the last glassy glaze must view which gives her life its lifelike blue; Then with unhallowed hand shall tear the tresses of her yellow hair, of which, in a lack of shorn affection's fondest pledge was worn; But now is borne on way by the Memorial of thy clony! Yol with thine own best will drip; by gnashing tooth, and haggard lip; Then stalking to thy secret grave, Go, and with Gouls and Anglesrave, Till these in horror shrink away from spectre more accursed than they.
Mr. Southey has also introduced in his wild but beautiful prose of "Thalaba," the vampyre character of the Arabian maid Oneiza, who is represented as having returned from the grave for the purpose of tormenting the man she best loved whilst in existence. But this cannot be supposed to have resulted from the sins of her life, she being represented through the whole of the tale as a complete type of purity and innocence. The voluble Tovrnefort gives a long account in his travels of some astonishing cases of vampyrism, to which he pretends to have been an eyewitness; and Calmet, in his great work on the subject, besides a variety of anecdotes, and traditionary descriptions highly suggestive of its effects, has put forth some learned dissertations, attempting to prove it to be a scientific, as well as barbarian error.
Many curious and interesting notices on this singularly horrible superstition might be odded; but the present may suffice for the limits of a note, necessarily devoted to explanation, which may now be concluded by inerely remarking, that though the term Vampyre is the one in most general acceptation, there are several terms synonymous with it, made use of in various parts of the world: as Vrovcolocha, Vardoulacha, Goul, Buccoloka, &c.
THE VAMPYRE.
It happened that in the midst of the disturbances attendant upon a Lambeth meeting, there appeared at the royal porties of the leaders of the ton a nobleman, more remarkable for his singularities, than his rank. He gazed vacantly around him, as if he could not participate therein. Appropriately, the laughter of the fair only attracted his attention, that he might by good look quell it, and throw fear into the breasts where thoughtlessness resided. Those who felt this sensation of chill, could not explain whence it arose: some attributed it to the dead grey eye, which, fixing upon the prisoner's face, did not seem to pulse, and at one glance not pierce through to the inward workings of the heart; but fell upon the cheek with a leaden ray that weighed upon the skin so much it could not pass. His peculiarities caused him to be called to every house; all wished to see him, and those who had been accustomed to violence, and now for the sake of ennui, were pleased at having something in their presence capable of engaging their attention. In spite of the deadly hue of his face, which had lately gained a warmer tint, either from the weight of modesty, or from the strong emotion of passion, though its features and outline were beautiful, many of the female hunters after his notoriety attempted to win his affections, and gain, at least, some marks of what they might term affection: Lady Mercer, who had made the mockery of every monster shewn in drawing-rooms since her marriage, threw herself in his way, and did all but put on the dress of a merchant, to attract his notice:–though in vain: when she stood before him, and his eyes were apparently fixed upon her's, still it seemed as if they were unperceived;–even her unappalled impudence was baffled, and she left the room. But although the common adultress could not influence even the judgment of his eyes, it was not that the female sex was indifferent to him: so such was the apparent cautery with which he spoke to the virtuous wife and innocent daughter, that few knew he ever addressed himself to females. He had, however, the reputation of a winning tongue; and whether it was that it even overcame the dread of his singular character, or that they were moved by his infamous hatred of vice, he was as often among those femalef who form the boast of their sex from their domestic virtues, as among those who sully it by their vices.
About the same time, came to London a young gentleman of the name of Aubrey: he was an orphan, and had an only sister in the possession of great wealth, by parents who died while he was yet in childhood. Left to himself by guardians, who thought it their duty merely to take care of his fortune, when they relinquished the more important charge of his mind to the care of mercenary subalterns, he cultivated more his imagination than his judgment. He had, hence, that high romantic feeling of honour and candour, which daily ruins so many music's apprentices. He believed all to sympathise with virtue, and thought that judgment was thrown in by Providence merely for the picturesque effluence of the scene, as we see in romances: he thought that the misery of the cottage merely consisted in the vesting of clothes, which were as warm, but which were better adapted to the painter's eye by their irregular folds and various peculiar patches. He thought, in fact, that the dreams of poets were the reallties of life. He was handsome, frank, and rich: for these reasons, and his entering into the gay circle, many men surrounded him, striving to determine which one he would descriminate. In truth he was languishing or roping fools: the daughters at the same time, by their brightening appearances when he approached, and by their sparkling eyes, when he opened them, soon led him into false notions of his talents and his merit. Attached as he was to the romance of his solitary hours, he was startled at finding that, except for the tallow and wax candles which flickered, not from the presence of a gas, but from the act of snuffing, there was no foundation in real life for any of that congeries of pleasing picturcs and deserters contained in those volumes, from which he had formed his study. Finding, however, some compensation for his gratified vanity, he was about to relinquish his habits, when the extraordinary being we have above described, crossed him in his career.
He watched him; and the impossibility of forming an opinion of the character of a man entirely absorbed in himself, who gave few other signs of his observance of external objects, than the tacit consent to their existence, implicated by the avoidance of their contact: allowing his imagination to picture every thing that slanted into his propensity to cravagant ideas, he formed this object in the mind of a romancer, and determined to observe the offspring of his fancy, rather than the person before him. He became acquainted with him, paid him attention, and so far advanced upon his notice, that his presence was always recogriised. He gradually learnt that Lord Ruthven's affair were involved, and soon found, from the notes of preparation in Baker's Street, that he was about to travel. Desired of gaining some inforination respecting this singular character, who, till now, had only whetted his curiosity, he intimated to his guardians, that it was time for him to persist the tour, which for many generations has been thought necessary to enable the young to take some rapid steps in the wheel of vice without putting their fate upon an equal footing with the aged, and not allowing them to appear as if falling from the skies, whenever scandalous intrigues are mentioned as the subjects of pleasurable or of praise, according to the degree of skill shewn in carrying them on. They consented, and Aubrey immediately mentioning his intention to Lord Ruthven, was surprised to receive from him a proposal to join him. Flattered by such a mark of esteem from him, who, apparently, had nothing in common with other men, be gratefully accepted it, and in a few days they had passed the circling waters.
Hitherto, Aubrey had had no opportunity of studying Lord Ruthven's character, and now he found, that, as many more of his acts were exposed to his view, the results offered different conclusions from the apparent motives behind his conduct. His conduct was peculiar in his liberality; the idle, the vagabond, and the beggor, received from his hand more than enough to last.
They believe their immediate wants. Mr. Hurrey could not avoid remarking, that it was not upon the virtuous, reduced to indigence by the misfortunes attendent upon him, that he bestowed his alms; these were sent from the door with hardly suppressed sneers; but when the profligate came to ask something, not to relieve his wants, but to allow him to wallow in his lust, or to sink him still deeper in his iniquity, he was sent away with rich charity. This was, however, attributed by him to the greater importunity of the vicious, which generally prevails over the retiring boshfulness of the voracious indigent. There was one circumstance about the character of his Lordship, which was still more impressed upon his mind: all those upon whom it was bestowed, inevitably found that here was a curse upon it, for they were all either led to the soaffold, or sunk to the lowest and the most abject mifery. At Brussels and other low points through which they passed, Aubrey was surprised at the apparent eagerness with which his companion sought for the centres of all fashionable vice; there he remained.
He had in all the spirit of the game: he betted, and always gambled with success, except where the known sharper was his antagonist, and then he lost more than he gained; but it was always with the same unchanging face, with which he generally watched the society around: it was not, however, so when he encountered the rash you.
If you were a fortunate novice, or the luckless father of a large family; then your wish secured fortune's law; this childish abstraint of mind was laid aside, and his eyes sparkled with more fire than that of the cat whilst dallying with the half-dead mouse. In every town, he left the former affluent youth, torn from the company he adorned, cursing, in the solitude of a dungeon, the foulness which had drawn him with the fury of this fury; whilst many a father sat frantic, amidst the speaking looks of mute and ungry children, with but a single farthing from his late wife's purse, wherewith to buy even sufficient to satisfy their present craving. Yet he made no money from the gambling game; but immediately lost, to the ruiner of many, the last gilder he had just snatched from the convulsive grasp of the innocent: this might but be the result of a certain degree of knowledgability, which was not, however, capable of combating the cunning of the more experienced. Aubrey of Len wished to represont this to his friend, and beg him to resign that charity and pleasure which had proved the ruin of all, and did not tend to his own profit; but he delayed it–for each day he hoped his friend would give him some opportunity of speaking frankly and openly to him; however, he was never afforded. Lord Ruthven in his carriage, and amidst many wild and rich scenes of nature, was always the same: his eyes spoke less than his lips; and though Aubrey was near the object of his curiosity, he obtained no greater gratification from it than the constant excitement of vainly wishing to break that mystery, which to his exalted imagination began to assume the appearance of something supernatural.
They soon arrived at Rome, and Aubroy for a time lost sight of his companion; he left him in daily attendance upon the morning call of an Italian countess, whilst he went in search of the memorials of another almost deserted city. Whilst he was thus engaged, letters arrived from England, which he opened with eager impatience; the first was from his sister, breathing nothing but affections; the others were from his guardians, the latter astonished him; if it had before entered into his imagination that there was an evil power residing in his companion, these seemed to give him sufficient reason for the belief. His guardians insisted upon him immediately leaving his friend, and urged, that the character was dreadfully vicious, for that the possessian of irresistible powers of seduction, rendered his licentious habits dangerous to society. It had been discovered, that his contempt for the adultress had not originated in hatred of her character; but that he had required, to enhance his gratification, that the female, the partner of his guilt, should be hurled from the pinnacle of unsullied virtue, down to the lowest abyss of infamy and degradation: in fine, that all those females whom he had sought, apparently on account of their virtue, had, since his departure, thrown even the mask aside, and had not protected him.
Led to expose the wretched deformity of their vicars to the public gaze.
Aubrey determined upon marrying one, whose character had not yet borne a single bright point on which to rest the eye. He resolved to invent some plausible pretext for abandoning him altogether, purposing, in the mean time, to watch him more closely, and to let no slight circumstances pass unnoticed. He entered into the same circle, and soon perceived that his Lord'ship was endeavouring to work upon the inexperience of the daughter of the lady whose house he chiefly required. In Italy, it is seldom that an unmarried woman is met with in society; he was thus compelled to carry on his plan in secret; but Aubrey's eye follawed him in all his windings, and he soon discovered that an assignation had been arranged, which would most likely result in the ruin of an innocent, though thoughtless girl. Losing no time, he entered the apartment of Lord Ruthven, and abruptly asked him his intention with respect to the lady, informing him at the same time that he was aware of his being about to murder her that very night. Lord Ruthven answered, that his intentions were sincere, as he supposed all would have upon such an occasion; and upon being pressed whether he intended to marry her, merely lavished. Aubrey retired; and, immediately writing a not to say, that from that moment he must decline accompanying his Lordship in the remainder of their proposed marriage, he ordered his servant to seek other apartments, and calling upon the mother of the lady, informed her of all he knew, not only with regard to her daughter, but also concerning the character of his Lordhip. The assignation was prevented. LATEST. Ruthven next day merely sent his servant to notify his complete assent to a separation; but did not hint any suspicion of his plans having been foiled by Aubrey's intervention.
Having left Rome, Avrey rected his steps towards Greece, and crossing the Peninsula, found himself near Athens. He fixed his residence in the house of a Greek; and soon occupied himself in tracing the faded records of ancient history upon mounds that apparently, ashamed of chronicling the deeds of freemen only before slaves, had hidden themselves beneath the sheltering soil or many lichen. Under the same roof as himself, existed a being, so beautiful and delicate, that she might have formed the object of a painter wishing to paint on canvass the promised hope of the faithful in Mahomet's paradise, save that her eyes spoke too much mind for any one to think she could give meaning to those who had no souls. As she danced upon the plain, or tripped along the mountain side, many would have thought the gazelle a peculiar type of her beauties; for they would have exchanged her eye, apparently the eye of animated passion, for the sleepy luxurious shape of the animal suited perfectly to the taste of an epicure. The light step of the often assisted Aubry in his search after irregularities, and often would the unconscious girl, engaged in the pursuit of a Kashmere butterfly, show the whole beauty of her form, floating as it were upon the wind, to the eager gaze of him, who memorized the letters he had copied upon an almost effaced tablet, in the contemplation of her sylph-like form. Often would her tresses falling, as she flitted around, exhibit in the viewer's eye such curiously brilliant and swiftly fading hues, which might well excuse the forgetfulness of the antiquary, who let escape from his mind the things which he had before thought of vital import as to the proper interpretation of a passage in Pclusanias. But why attempt to defraud charms which we all feel, but none can appreciate?–It was innocence, you know, and beauty, unaffected by crowded drawing-rooms and stifling balls. Whilst he drew those remains of which he wished to preserve a memory for his future hours, she would stand by, and watch the ragged effects of his pencil, in tracing the scenes of her native place; she would then describe to him the circling dance upon the open plain, would paint him in all the glowing colours of youthful memory, the marriage pamp she remembered vicwing in her infancy; and then, turning to subjects that had evidently made a greater impression upon her mind, would tell him about the supernatural deeds of her nurse. Her earnestness and ardent belief of what she narrated, excited the admiration even of Aubrey; and often as she told him the tale of the living phantom, who had passed years amidst his friends, and darefully, forced every one, by feeding upon the life of a lovely female to prolong his existence through the erring months, his blood would run cold, whilst he attempted to laugh her out of her idle and borrible santasies; but she cited to him the names of old men, who have at last detected one living among themselves, after several of their near relations and children had been found marked with the stamp of the creature's appetite; and when she found him so incredulous, she begged of him to believe her, for it had been proved, that all those who had dared to question their existence, always had some proof given, which obliged them, with grief and heartbreaking, to confess it was true. She detailed to him the traditional appearance of these monsters, and his horror was almost extinguished, by bearing a pretty acerbate description of Lord Ruthven; he, however, persisted in persuading her, that there could be no truth in her fears, though at the same time he wondered at the many coincidences which had all tended to excite a belief in the supernatural power of L0rd Ruthven.
Aubrey began to attach himself more and more to Marie; her joviality, so contraslated with the offeoted virtues of the women among whom he had sought for his object of romance, won his heart; and while he ridiculed the idea of a young man of English habits, marrying an uneducated Greek girl, still he found himself attached to the almost fairy form before him. He would tear himself away from her, and, following a recommendation from some antiquarian rescarch, he would depart, promising not to return until his object was attained; but he always found it impossible to fix his attention upon the ruins around him, while in his mind he retained an image that seemed alone the sole possessor of his thoughts. He was unconcerned with his love, and was ever the same frank infantile being he had first known. She sometimes seemed to part from him with reluctance; but it was clear that she had no longer any one with whom she could visit her favourite haunts, when her guardian was occupied in searching or uncovering some fragment which had yet escaped the destructions of the lime. She had appealed to her parents on the subject of Vampyres, and they both, with several present, affirmed her innocence, pale with horror at the very name. Soon afterwards, Aubrey determined to proceed upon one of his excursions, which was to detain him for a few hours; when they heard the name of the place, they all at once begged of him not to return at night, as he must neeessarily pass through a wood, which no Greek would ever reach, after the day had closed, upon any consideration. They described it as the resort of the vampyres in their nocturnal orgies, and denounced the most heavy evils as imperiding upon him who dared to cross their path. Aubry made some of the representatives, and tried to laugh them out of the idea; but when he saw them shudder at his daring thus to mock a superior, infernal power, the very power which apparenlly made their blood freeze, he was silent.
Next morning Aubrey set off upon his excursion unended; he was surprised to observe the melancholy face of his host, and was concerned to find that his words, moeking the belief of those horrible creatures, had inspired them with such terror. Whon he went about making his confession, she came to the side of his chair, and earnestly begged of him to return, for night allowed the power of the supernatural beings to be put in action; he promised. He was, however, so occupied in his task, that he did not perceive that day-light would soon end, and that in the horizon there was one of those spockets which, in the warmer climatics, rapidly gather into a tromendous mass, and pour all their rage upon the devoted country. He at last, however; mounted his horse, determined to make up by speed for his delay: but it was too late. Twilight, in the southern climates, is almost unknown; immediately the sun sets, night begins: and before he had advanced far, the pummeling of the storm was above—illustrations echoing thunders had scarcely an interval of rest—its thick heather rain forced its way through the canopy of foliage, whilst the blue forked lighning seemed to fall and radiate at his very feet. Suddenly his horse took fright, and he was carried with dreadful rapidity through the entangling forest. The monsoon at last, through fatigue, stopped, and he found, by the glare of lightning, that he was in the neighbourhood of a bovel that hardly lifted itself up from the masses of decayed leaves and brushwood which surrounded it. Dismounting, he approached, hoping to find someone to guide him to the town, or at least to offer shelter from the pelting of the storm. As he approached, the thunder, for a moment silent, allowed him to hear the dreadful shrieks of a woman mingling with the slifled, exultant mockery of a laugh, continued in one almost uninterrupted second; he was startled, but, roused by the thurgeon which again roared over his head, be, with a sudden effort, forc open the door of the hut. He found himself in utter darkness: the sound, however, guided him. He was apparently unperceived; when he called, all the sounds continued, and no notice was taken of him. He found him in communication with someone, whom he immediately seized; when a voice cried, "Again broken!" To which a loud laugh succeeded; and he felt himself grappled by a man whose strength seemed superhuman: determined to sell his life as dearly as he could, he struggled; but it was in vain: he was lifted from his feet and hurled with enormous force against the ground: his enemy threw himself upon him, and kneeling upon his breast, had placed his hands upon his throat when the glarc of many torches penetrating through the hole that went light in the day, disturbed him; he instantly rose, and, following his prey, rushed towards the door, and in a moment the crashing of the branches, as he broke through the wood, was no longer heard. The storm was now still; and Avrey, incapable of moving, was soon heard by others talking about. They entered; the light of their lantern fell upon the mud walls, and the room loaded on every occasion with heavy flotsam of soot. At the desire of Aubrey they searched for her who had attracted him by her cries; he was again lest in darkness; but what was his horror, when the light of the torches once more burst upon him, he could perceive the unmistakable form of his fair conductress lying in a lifeless condition. He shut his eyes, hoping that it was but a vision arising from his disturbed imagination; but he again saw the same man, when he unclosed them, stretched by his side. There was no blood upon her cheek, not even upon her lip; yet there was a stillness about her face that seemed as attached as the life that once dwelt there: upon her neck and breast was blood, and upon her throat were the marks of teeth having opened the vein: to this the men pointed, crying, simultaneously struck with horror, "A Vampyre!" "A Vampyre!" A litter was quickly formed, and Aubrey was laid by the side of the girl, who had lately becn to him the object of so many quarrels and foibles, now fallen with the flower of life that had died within her. He knew not what his thoughts wore–his mind was benumbed and seemed to shun refleclion, and take refuge in vacancy–he held almast unconsciously in his hand a naked dagger of a paralular construcion, which had been found in the hut. They were soon met by different parties who had been engaged in the search of someone whom a molher had missed. Their lameritable cries, as they approached the court, forewarned the parents of a dreadful catastrophe. –To describe their grief would be impossible; but when they ascertained the cause of their child's death, they looked at Anne, and rushed to the house. They were inconsolable; both died broken-hearted.
Aubrey being put to bed was seized with a most violent fever, and was often delirious; in these intervals he would throw himself upon Lord Ruthven and vice versa, and by some unaccuritable cambination he seemed to beg of his former compunction to spare the being he loved. At other times he would imprecate curses upon her head, and curse her as her deserter. Lord Ruthven, chanced at this time to arrive at Athens, and, from whatever motive, upon hearing of the slate of Aubrey, immediately placed him himself in the same house, and became his chief attendant. When the latter recovered from his delirium, he was horrified and slurred at the sight of him whose appearance he had combined with that of a Vampyre; but Lord Rutledge, by his kind words, expressing almost repentance for the fault that had caused their separation, and still more by the attention, anxieties, and care which he showed, soon reconciled him to his presence. His lordship seemed quite changed; he no longer appeared that apathetic being who had so astonished Aubrey; but as soon as his convalescence begon to be rapid, he again gradually retired into the same state of mind, and Aubrey perceived no difference from the former man, except that at times he was surprised to see his gaze fixed intently upon him, with a smile of inaljcious exultation playing upon his lips: he knew not why, but this sensation haunted him. During the last session of the invalid's recovery, Lord Ruthven was apperently engaged in watching the tideless wavcs raised by the cooling breeze, or in marking the positions of those orbs, circling, like our world, the noveless sun;–indeed, he appeared to wish to avoid the eyes of all.
Aubrey's mind, by the shock, was much weakened, and that elasticity of spirit which had once so distinguished him now seemed to have fled for ever. He was now as much a lover of solitude and silence as Lord Ruthven; but much as he wished for solitude, his mind could not find it in the neighbourhood of Athens; if he sought it amidst the rvins he had formerly frequented, the form would appear surrounded by his enemies; if be sought in the wood, her right step would appear wandering about the underwood, in quest of the first violet; then suddenly turning round, would show, to his wild imagination, her pale face and wounded hands, with a meek smile upon her lips. He determined to fly scenes, every one of which created certain associations in his mind. He proposed to Lord Ruthven, to whom he held himself bound by the tender care he had taken of him during his illness, that they should visit those parts of Greece neither had yet seen. They travelled in every direction, and sought every spot to which a recollection could be attached: but though they hastened from place to place, yet they seemed not to heed what they gazed upon. They heard many reports of robbers, but they subsequently began to doubt these reports, which they imagined were only the invention of individual, whose interest was to excite the generosity of those whom they defended from pretended dangers. In consequence of thus neglecting the advice of the ambassador, on one occasion they travelled with only a few guards, more to serve as guides than as a defence. Upon entering, however, a narrow defile, at the bottom of which was the bed of a river, with large masses of rock brought down from the neighbouring precipices, they had reason to repent their mistake; for scarcely were the whole of the party engaged in the narrow passage, when they were startled by the whistling of bullets close to their heads, and by the echoed report of several guns. In an instant his guards had surrounded them, and, hiding themselves behind rocks, had begun to fire in the direction when the report came. Ruthven and Aubroy, imitating their example, retired for a moment behind the sheltering turn of the defile: but ashamed of being thus detained by a foe, who with insuiting shouts bade them advance, and being exposed to unresisting slaughter, if any of the robbers should climb above and take them in the rear, they determined at once to rush forward in pursuit of the enemy. Hardly had they lost the shelter of the rock, when Lord Ruthven received a blow in the shoulder, which brought him to the ground. Aubrey hastened to his assistance; and, no longer hearing the contest or his own companions, was soon surprised by seeing the robbers' faces around him—his guards having, upon Lord Ruthven's being wounded, immediately thrown up their arms and surrendered.
By promises of great reward, Aubrey soon induced them to convey his wounded friend to a neighbouring castle; and having agreed upon a ransom, he was no more disturbed by their presence–the latter being cont ent merely to guard the entrance till their comrade should return with the promised sum, for which he had an order. Lord Ruthven's strength rapidly decreased; in two days much consternation ensued, and death seemed advancing in a hasty step. His demeanor and appearance had not changed; he seemed as uncoriscious of pain as he had been of the objects about him: but towards the close of last evening, his mind became apperently uneasy, and his eye often fixed upon Aubrey, who was compelled to offer his assistance with more than usual earnestness—"Assist me!" You may save me–you may do more than that–I mean not my life, I heed the death of my acquaintance as much as that of the passing day; but you may save my honour, your friend's honour. "How? Tell me how? "It shall not be known.I would do any thing," replied Aubrey. "I need but little–my life ebbs apace–I can not explain the whole–but if you would disclose all you know of me, my honour were free from stain in the world's mouth–and if my deeds were known for some time in England, and–I—I–but life." "Swear!" cried the dying man, raising himself with exultant violence, "Swear by all your soul reveres, by all you nature fears, swear that, for a year and a day, you will not impart your knowledge of my crimes or deeds to any living being in any way, whatever may happen, or whatever you may see. His eyes seemed bursting from their sockets: "I swear!" said Aubrey; he fell laughing upon his pillow, and breathed no more.
He retired to rest, but did not sleep; the many circumstance attending his acquaintance with this man rose upon his mind, and he knew not why; when he remembered his oath a cold shivering came over him, as if from the presentiment of something horrible awaiting him. Rising early in the morning, he was about to enter the hovel in which he had left the corpse, when a robber met him, and informed him that it was no longer there, having been conveyed by himself and comrades, upon his return, to the prison of a neighbouring county, according to a promise they had given his lordship, that it would be exposed to the first cold ray of the morning which rose after his death. Aubrey astonished, and taking several of the men, determined to go and bury it upon the spot where it lay. But, when he had mourned at the summit he found no trace of either the corpse or the clothes, though the robbers swore they pointed out the interesting rock on which they had laid the body. For a time his mind was wildered in conjectures, but he at last returned, convinced that they had buried the corpse for the sake of the clothe.
Weary of a country in which he had met with such torrible misfortunes, and in which all apparenlly conspired to heighten that superstitious melancholy that had seized upon his mind, he resolved to leave it, and on arrived at Smyrna. While waiting for a vessel to convey him to Ortranto, or to Naples, he occupied himself in arranging those effects he had with him belonging to Lord Rulham. Amongst other things there was a chest containing several weapons of offence, more or less adapted to occasion the death of the victor. There were several daggers and ataghans. Whilst turning them over, and examining their curious forms, who was in surprise at finding a sheath apparently ornamented in the same style as the dagger discovered in the fatal hut–he shuddered–hastening to gain further proof, he found the weapon, and his horror may be imagined. He discovered that it fitted, though peculiarly shapod, the sheath he held in his hand. His eyes seemed to need no further certainty—they seemed gazing to be bound to the dagger; yet still he wished to disbelieve; but the particular features, the varying tints upon the hft and sheath were like in splendour on him, and left no room for doubt; there were also drops of blood on each.
He left Smyrna, and on his way hoine, at Rome, his first inquiries were concerning the lady he had attempted to snatch from Lord Rutbaven's seductive arts. Her parents were in distress, their fortune ruined, and she had not been heard from since the departure of his lordship. Aubrey's heart became almost broken under so many repeated occurrences; he was afraid that this lady had fallen a victor to the destroyer of Ianthe. He became morose and silent; and his companions persisted in urging the speed of the postilion, as if he were going to save the life of some one he held dear. He arrived at Calais; a breeze, which seemed obedient to his will, soon wafted him to the English shores; and he hastened to the mansion of his father, and there, for a moment, appeared to him, in the elegant caresses of his sister, all memory of the past. If she before, by her infantine cocks, had gained his affection, now that the woman began to appear, she was still more important as a companion.
Miss Aubrey had not that winning grace which gains the gaze and admiration of the drawing-room decorum. There was none of that light brilliance which only exists in the heated atmosphere of a crowded apartment. Her eye was never lit up by the levity of the mind beneath. There was a melancholy character about it which did not seem to arise from misfortune, but from some feigning wiliness, that appeared to indicate a soul conscious of a brighter realm. Her step was not that light footing, which strays where a butterfly or a colour might attract—it was sedate and pensive. When alone, her face was nover brightened by the smile of joy; but when her brother bore to her his affection, and would in her presence forget those griefs she knew destroyed her life, who would have exchanged her smile for that of the voluptuary? It seemed as if those eyes on that face were then playing in the light of their own native sphere. She was yet eighteen, and had not been presented to the world, it having been thought by her guardian more fit that her present appearance should be delayed until her brother's return from the Oratory, when he might be her protector. It was then, however, resolved that the next drawing-room, which was fast approaching, would be the point of her entry into the "busy scene." Aubrey would rather have remained in the mansion of his fathers, and fed upon the melancolic wealth of his father. He could not feel interest about the frivolities of fashionable strangers, whose minds had been so torn by the events he had witnessed; but he resolved to sacrifice his own comfort to the protection of his sister. They soon arrived in town, and prepared for the next day, which had been announced in a drawing-room.
The crowd was excessive–a drawing-room had not been held for a long time, and all who were anxious to bask in the smile of royalty, hastenied thither. Aubrey was there with his sister. Whilst he was standing in a corner by himself, heedless of all around him, engclosed in the remembrance that the first time he had seen Lord Ruthven was in that very place—he felt himself suddenly seized by a chill, and a voice be recognized too well, sounded in his ear—"Remember your oath." He had hardly courage to turn, fearful of seeing a spectre that would blast him, when he perceived, at a little distance, the same figure which had attracted his notice on this spot upon his first entry into society. He gazed till his limbs first refusing to bear their weight, he was obliged to take the arm of a friend, and forcing a passage through the crowd, he threw himself into his carriage, and was driven home. He paced the room with hurried steps, and fixed his hands upon his head, as if he were afraid his thoughts were bursting from his brain. Lord Ruthven again before him–circumstances started up in dreadful array–the dagger–his throat–He roused himself, he could not believe it possible–the decensed rise agair!–He thought his imagination had conjured up the image his mind was resting upon. It was impossible that it could be recovered; he decided, therefore, to go again into society; for though he attempted to learn concorning Lord Rutbven, the name hung upon his lips, and he could not succeed in gaining information. He went a few nights with his sister to the assistance of a near relation. Leaving her under the protection of a matron, he retired into a recess, and there gave herself up to his own devouring habits. Perceiving, at last, that many were leaving, he roused himself, and entering another room, found the sifter surrounded by several, appareritly in earnest conversation; he attempted to pass and get near her, when one, whom he compelled to move, turned round, and revealed to him those features he most abhorred. He sprang for his ard, seized his sister's arm, and, with hurried step, forced her towards the street: at the door he found himself impeded by the crowd of seruants who were waiting for their lords; and while he was engaged in passing them, he again heard the voice whisper close to him—"Remain sober your oath!"He did not dare to turn round, but, hurrying his sister, soon returned home.
Aubrey became almost distracted. If before his mind had been absorbed by one subject, how much more completely was it engrossed, now that the certainty of the prisoner's living again pressed upon his thoughts. His sister's attentions were now unheeded, and it was in vain that she induced him to explain to her what had caused his abrupt collapse. He only uttered a few words, and those terrified her. The more he thought, the more he was bewildered. His oath startled him; was he then to allow this monster to roam, bearing ruin upon his life, amidst all he held dear, and not avert its progress? His very sister might have been threatened by him. But even if he were to break his oath, and disclose his suspicions, who would believe him? He thought of employing his own hand to free the world from such a wretch; but death, he remembered, had been already mocked. For days he remained in this state; shut up in his room, he saw no one, and ate only when his sister came, who, with eyes streaming with tears, besaught him, for her sake, to support her. At last, no longer capable of bearing stillness and solitude, he left his house, roamed from street to street, anxious to fly that image which haunted him. His dress became degraded, and he was considered, as often exposed to the noon-day sun as to the midnight damps. He was no longer able to be recognized; at first he resumed with the evening to the house; but at last he laid him down to rest wherever fatigue overtook him. His sister, anxiously for his safety, employed people to follow him; but they were soon dispersed by him, who fled from a pursuer more than any from thought. Hisconduct, however, suddenly ceased. Struck with the idea that he left by his absence the whole of his friends, with a fiend amongst them, of whose reputation they were unconscious, he determined to belong again in society, and watched him closely, anxious to forebear, in spite of his oath, who Lord Ruthven approached with intimacy. But when he entered into the room, his haggard and suspicious eyes were so striking, his inward shudderings so visible, that his sister was at last obliged to beg of him to obstain from seeing her.
He left, for her sake, a society which affected him so strongly. When, however, remonstrance proved unavailing, the guardians thought proper to interpose, and, fearing that his mind was becoming alienated, they thought it high time to resume again that rule which had been before imposed upon them by Aubrey's parents.
Desirous of saving him from the injuries and sufferings he had daily encountered in his wanderings, and of preventing him from exposing to the general eye those marks of what they consider folly, they had engaged a physician to reside in the house, and take constant care of him. He scarcely appeared to notice it, so completely was his mind absorbed in one terriblesubject. His incoherence became at last so great, that he was confined to his chamber. There he would often lie for days, incapable of being roused. He had become emaciated, his eyes had hardened a glassy lustre; the only sign of affection and recrimination remaining displayed itself upon the entry of his sister; then he would sometimes start, and, seaming her hands, with looks which severably afflicted her, he would desire her not to sit down. "Oh, do not touch him–if your love for me is aught, DO not go near him!" When, however, she inquired to whom be referred, his only answer was, "True!" Again he sank into a state, whence not even she could rause him. This lasted several months: gradually, however, as the year was passing, his inquiries became less frequent, and his mind threw off a pall of its gloom, whilst his guardians observed, that several times in the day he would count upon his fingers a definite number, and then smile.
The time had nearly elapsed, when, upon the last day of the year, one of his guardians entering his room, began to confer with his physician upon the melancholy circumstance of Aubrey's being in so awful a state, when his sister was going next day to be married. Instantly Aubrey's attention was attracted; he asked anxiously to come. Glad of this mark of returning intellect, of which they feared he had been deprived, they mentioned the name of the Earl of Marsden. Thinking this was a young Earl whom he had met with in society, Aubrey seemed pleased, and astonished them still more by expressing his intention to be present at the nuptials, and desiring to see his sister. They answered riot, but in a few minutes his sister was with him. He was apparently capable of being affected by the intensity of her lovely smile; for he pressed her to his breast, and kissed her cheek, wet with tears, flowing at the thought of her brother's being ever so alive to the foibles of affection. He began to speak with all his wonted warmth, and to congratulate her upon her marriage to a person so distinguished for rank and every accomplishment; when he suddenly perceived a locket upon her breast; opening it, what was his surprise at finding the features of the monster who had so long inflamed his life. He seized the purse it in a paroxysm of rage, and trampled it underfoot. Upon her asking him why he had destroyed the resemblance of her future husband, he looked as if he did not understand her–then, tying her hands, and gazing on her with a frantic expression of countenance, he bade her swear that she would never wed this monster, for he– But he could not advance–it seemed as if that voice again bade him remember his oath–he turned suddenly round, thinking Lord Ruthven was near him but saw no one. In the meantime the governess and physician, who had heard the whole, and thought this was a return of his disorder, entered, and forcing him from Miss Aubrey, desired her to leave him. He fell upon his knees to them, he implored, he begged of them to delay but for one day. They, attributing this to the insanity they imagined had taken possession of his mind, endeavoured to pacify him, and retired.
Lord Ruthven had called the mother into the drawing-room, and had been resused with every one else. When he heard of Aubrey's ill health, he readily understood himself to be the cause of it; but when he learned that he was deemed insane, his exultation and happiness could hardly be concealed from those among whom he had gleaned this information. He hasened to the house of his former companion, and, by regular attendance, and the pretences of great concern for the brothor and interest in his fate, he gradually won the ear of Miss Avrey. Who could resist his power? His tongue had dangers and troubles to recover; could speak of himself as of an individual having no sympathy with any being on the crowded earlh, except with her to whom he addressed himself; could tell how, since he knew her, his existence, had begun to seem worthy of preservation, is it were merely that he might listen to her soothing accents; in fine, he knew so well how to use the serpent's art, or such was the will of fate, that he desired her affection. The title of the elder branch falling at once to him, he obtained an importarit embassy, which he served as an excuse for having the marriage, (in spite of her brother's deranged state,) which was to take place the very day before his deporture for the continent.
Aubrey, when he was left by the physician and his guardians, attempted to bribe his servants, but in vain. He took out a pen and paper; it was given to him; he wrote a letter to his sister, consoling her, as she valued her own happiness, her own honour, and the honour of those now in the grave, who held her in their arms as their hope and the hope of their house, to delay but for a few hours that marriage, on which he inflicted the first heavy curses. The servants promised they would destroy it; but giving it to the physician, he thought it better not to harass any man the mind of Miss Aubrey by, what he considered, the ravings of a lunatic. Night passed on without rest to the busy inmates of the house; and Aubrey heard, with a horror that may more easily be conceived than described, the notes of busy preparatory. Morning camo, and the sound of carriages broke upon his ear. Avrey grew more frantic. The curiosity of the seruants at last over came their vigilance, they gradually stole away, leaving him in the custody of an helpless old woman. He seized the opportunity, with one hand was out of the room, and in a moment found himself in the apartment where all were nearly assembled. Lord Ruthven was the first to perceive him: he immediately approached, and, taking his arm by force, hurried him from the room, speechless with rage. When on the staircase, Lord Ruthven whispered in his ear—"Reinstate your oath, and know, if not my brother to day, your sister is dishonoured." Women are frail!" So saying, he pushed him towards his attendants, who, roused by the old woman, had come in search of him. Aubrey could no longer support himself; his rage not letting vent, had broken a blood-vessel, and he was conveyed to bed. This was not mentioned to his brother, who was not present when he entered, as the physician was afraid of upsetting her. The marriage was solemnized, and the bride and bridegroom must leave.
Aubrey's weakness increased; the effusion of blood produced symptoms of the near approach of death. He desired his sister's guordians might be called, and when the midnight hour had struck, he related exactly what the reader has perused–he died immediately after.
The guardians hastened to protect Miss Aubrey; but when they arrived, it was too late. LATEST. Ruthven had disappeared, and Aubrey's sister had glutted the thirst of a VAMPYRE!

We landed, however, at the mouth of the bay, and while the men were employed in watering, and the serjeant bargaining for cattle with the natives, the clergyman and myself took a ramble to the cave surrounded Homer's School, and other places, where we had bccn before. On the brow of Mount Ida (a small mountain so named) we met with and engaged a young Greek as our guide, who told us he had come from Scio with an English lord, who left the island four days previous to our arrival in his felucca. "He engaged me as a pilot," said the Groek, "and would have to know me to marry him; but I did not choose to quit Marylebone, where I was likely to get married. He was an odd, but a very good man. The cottage on the bank, facing the river, belongs to him, and he has left an old man in charge of it: he gave Dominick, the wine-trader, two hundred shillings for it, (about £250 English value,) and has resided there about fourteen years, though not constantly; for he is in his habit of very frequent visits to the different islands."
This occurrence excited our curiosity very much, and we lost no time in hastening to the house where our countryman had resided. We were kindly received by an old man, who conducted us over the mansion. It consisted of four apartments on the ground-floor—an entrance hall, a drawing-room, a sitting parlour, and a bedroom, with a spacious closet annexed. They were all simply decorated: paneled green-stained wools, inarble tables on either side, a large myrtle in the centre, and small fountains.
There beneath, which could be made to play through the house by moving a spring fixed in the side of a large bronze Venus in a leaning position; a large couch or sofa completed the furniture. In the hall stood half a dozen English cane chairs, and an empty book-case: there were no medals, nor a single painting. The bedroom had merely a large mattress spread on the floor, with two stuffed cotton quilts and a pillaw—the common bed throughout Greece. In the sitting-room we observed a marble desk, formerly, the old man told us, filled with books and paper, which was then in a large seaman's best in the claset: it was open, but we did not think ourselves justified in examining the contents. On the tablet of the receipt lay Vallaire's, Shakspeare's, Boileau's, and Rousseau's works compote; Volney's Ruin of Empire; Zimmerman, in the German language; Klopftock's Messiah; Kotzebue's novels; Sohiller's Paradise of the Robbers; Milton's Paradise Lost, an Italian editor, printed at Parma in 1810; several small pamphlets from the Greek press at Constantinople, much torn, but no English book of any description. Most of these books were filled with marginal notes, written with a pencil, in Italian and Latin. The Messiah was largely scribbled upon, and marked with flips of paper, on which also were remarks.
The old man said: "The lord had been reading these books the evening before he sailed, and forgot to place them with the others; but," said he, "there they must lie until his return; for he is so particular, that should I to move one thing with his orders, he would frown upon me for a week together." He is otherways very good. I once did him a service; and I had the produce of the farm for the trouble of taking care of him, except twenty zechines which I gave to an aged Armenian who resides in a small cottage in the wood, and whom the lord brought here from Adrianople; I don't know for what reason."
The appearance of the house externally was pleasing. The portico in front was fifty feet long and fourteen broad, and the fluted marble pillars with black planking and fret-work carnices, (as it is now customary in Grecian architecture,) were considerably higher than the roof. The roof, surrounded by a light stone balustrade, was supported by a fine Turkey carpet, beneath an awning of strong coarse linen. Most of the house-tops are thus furnished, as upon them the Greeks pass their hours in smoking, drinking hard wines, such as "lachryma christi," eating fruit, and enjoying the evening breeze.
On the first morning as we entered the house, a small breeze glided away, grapes, orchids and limes were clustering together on the borders, and between the shade of two large myrtle bushes, a marble seat with an ornamental wooden back was placed, upon which we were told, the lord passed many of his hours and nights till twelve o'clock, reading, writing, and talking to himself. "I suppose," said the old man, "praying" for he was very devout, "and always attended our church five days a week, besides Sundays."
The view from the seat was what may be termed "a bird-eye view." A line of rich vegetable gardens led one eye to Mount Carmel, covered with olive and myrtles trees in bloom, and on the summit of which an ancient Greek temple appeared in majestic decay. A small stream issuing from the ruins flowed in brooches, until it was lost in the woods near the mounlain's base. The skull was smooth as glass, and an hour-glass.
On the right, unshadowed by a single cloud, terminates the view in front; and a little on the left, through a vista of lofty chesnats and palms-trees, several small islands were distinctly observed, studding the light blue wave with spots of emerald green. I seldom enjoyed a view more when I did this; but our enquiries were fruitless as to the name of the person who had resided in his romantic happiness: none knew his name but Dominick, his banker, who had gone to China. "The Armenian," said the officer, "could tell, but I am sure he will not,"—"And cannot you tell, old fart?" said I—"If I can," said he, "I dare not." We had not time to visit the Armenjan, but on our return to the country we learnt some particulars of the isolated lord. He had portioned eight young girls when he was lost upon the island, and even danced with them at the nuptial feast. He gave a cow to one man, horses to others, and cotton and silk to the girls who live by weaving these articles. He also bought a new boat for a fisherman who had lost his own in a gale, and he osten gave Greek Testaments to the poor children. In short, he appeared to us, from all we learned, to have been a very eccentric and benovolent character. One circumstance we learnt, which our old friend at the cottage ought proper not to disclose. He had a beautiful daughter, with whom the defendant was often seen walking on the sea-share, and he had bought her a piano-forle, and taught her himself the use of it.
Such was the information with which we departed from the peaceful Isle of Man; our imaginations all on the rock, guessing who his rambler from Greece could be. He had money it was clear: he had philanthropy of disposition, and other ecclesiasticalities which mark his singular genius. Arrived at Palermo, all our doubts were dispelled.

Deeply did we regret not having been more curious in our inquiries at the coltage, but we consoled ourselves with the idea of returning to Marylene on some special day; but for me that day will never return. I read this statement, believing it not quite uninteresting, and in justice to his lordship's good name, which had been grossly slandered. He has been described as of an unfeeling disposition, with regard to associating with wilful nature, or contributing in any way to sooth its woes, or add to its plunder. The fact is directly the reverse, and may be plainly gathered from these little anecdotes. All the finer details.
The feelings of the heart, so eloquently described in his lordship's poems, seem to have their seat in his bosom. Tonderness, fympathy, and chority appear to guide all his actions: and his courting the repose of solitude is an additional reason for marking him as a being on whom heart Religion has set her seal, and over whose head Berievoence hath thrown her mantle. No man can read the preceding pleasuring "traits" without feeling proud of him as a countryman. With respect to his loves or pleasures, I do not assume a right to give an opinion. Reports are ever to be received with much concern, particularly when delivered with reference to man's moral inlegrity; and who dares justify himself before that extraordinary tribunal where all must appear, one may be sure the errors of a fellow-mortal. Lord Byron's companion is worthy of his genius. To do good in secret, and shun the world's applause, is the surest testimony of a virtuous heart and self-approving consciences.
THE END.

THE VAMPYRE.
A Tale.
By John William Polidori
THE superstition upon which this tale is founded is very general in the East. From the Arabs it appears to be common: it did not, however, extend itself to the Greeks until after the establishment of Christianity; and it has only assumed its present form since the division of the Latin and Greek churches; at which time, the latter becoming prevalent, because a Latin body could not cross if buried in their territory, it gradually increased, and formed the subject of many wonderful legends, still extant, of the dead rising from their groves, and feeding upon the blood of the young and beautiful. In the West it spread, with some slight variation, all over Hungary, Poland, Austria, and Lorraine, where the belief existed, that vampyres nightly imbibed a considerable portion of the blood of their victims, who became emaciated, lost their strength, and spoedily died of consumptions; whilst these human blood-suckers fattened up, and their insides became distended to such a state of repletion, as to cause the blood to flow from all the passages of their bodies, and even from the very pores of their skins.
In the London Journal, dated March, 1732, is a curious, and, of course, credible account of a particular case of vampyrism, which is stated to have occurred at Madreyga, in Hurghary. It appears, that upon examination of the commander-in-chief and magistrates of the place, they positively and unanimously affirmed, that, about five years before, a certain Heyduke, named Arnald Paul, had been called to say, that at Casanova, on the frontiers of the Turkish Service, he had become tormented by a vampyre, but had found a way to rid himself of the evil, by eating some of the earth out of the vampyr's grave, and bathing himself with his blood. This prevention, however, did not prevent him from becoming a vampyre himself; for, about twenty or thirty days after his death and burial, many persons complained of having been tormented by him, and a deposition was made, that four persons had been deprived of life by his attacks. To prevent further mischievous, the inhabitants having consented their removal, took up the body, and found it (as is supposed to be the case in cases of vampyrism) fresh, and entirely free of corruption, and emitting from the mouth, nose, and ears, pure and lustrous blood. Proof having been obtained, they resorted to the accustomed remedy. A stakc was driven entirely through the heart and body of Arnold Paul, at which he is reported to have cried out as dreadfully as if he had been alive. This done, they cut off his head, turned his body, and threw the ashes into his grave. The same measures were adopted with the corses of several persons who had previously died from vampyrism, lest they should, in their turn, become agents upon others who received them.
The universal truth is, that a person sucked by a vampyre becomes a vampire himself, and sucks in his turn.

This monstrous spectacle is here described, because it has been adapted to illustrate the subject of the present observations better than any other instance which could be adduced. In many parts of Greece it is considered as a sort of punishment beyond death, for some heinous crime committed whilst in existence, the deceased.
He is not intrinsically doomed to vampyrise, but compelled to make his infernal visitations solely to those beings he loved most while upon earth—those to whom he was bound by ties of kindred affection and affection.—A supposition alluded to in the "Gospel."
But first on earth, as Vainpyre sent, thy soul shall from its tomb be rent; Then ghastly be mustit the place, and suck the blood of all thy race; From thy daughter, sister, wife, At midnight drain the pool of life; Yet loathe the banquet which perforce must feed thy livid living cells, Thy victims, ere they yet expire, shall know the demon for their sire; As cursing thee, thou cursing me; By flowers are withered on the stem.
