This monstrance-road is here referred, because it seems better adapted to illustrate the subject of the present obscrvations than any other instance which could be adduced. In many parts of Greece it is considered as a sort of punishment aftor death, for some heinous crime committed whilst in existence, that the deceased is not allowed to vampyrise, but compelled to confine his infernal visits only to the beings he loved most while upon earth—those to whom he was bound by ties of kindred and affection.—A proposition alluded to in the "Gospel."
But first on earth, as Vampyre sent, your corse shall from it be rent; Then gaily baunt the native place, and suck the blood of thy race; There from thy daughter, sister, wife, at midnight drain the stream of life; Yet loath the bariquet which perforce must feed the living corse, Thy victims, ere they yet expire, shall know the demon for their sire; As cursing thee, thou cursing them, Thy flawers are withered on the stem. But one that has committed this crime must be forgiven. The youngest, he who is beloved of all, shall bless them with a sister's name. That word shall wright thy heart in flame! Yet thou must end thy task and mark her cheek's last twinge, her eye's last spark, and the last gloopy glonce must view which frozes of its lifeless blue; thy allowed hand shall tear the tresses of her yellow hair, of which, in lock and lock, her former Affection's fondness was strong; But now is bound away by thee Memorial of their agony! Yet with your best hood shall drip; Thy gnashing tooth, and haggard lip; Then stalking to thy sullen grave, go; and with Gouls and Angles rave, Till these horror spirits shrink away from spectacles more accursed than they are.
Mr. Southey has also introduced in his collection a wild but beautiful poem of "Thrice," the vampyre character of the Arabian maid Oneiza, who is represenled as having relurned from the grave for the purpose of tormenting him she best loved whilst in existence. But this could not be supposed to have resulted from the sinful nature of her life, she being devout throughout the whole. The tale as a perfect typo of purity and innocence. The verocious Tournefort gives a long account in his travels of some of the most astonishing cases of vampyrism, to which he pretended to have been an eyewitness; and Courtenay, in his great work upon this subject, besides a variely of anecdoles, and traditionory narratives illvstrative of its facts, has put forth some learned dissertations, tending to prove it to be a classical, as well as a barbarian error.
Many curious and interesting notices on this singularly horribbulous superstition might be added; though the present may suffice for the limits of a treat, they must be necessary devoled to explanation, and which may now be concluded by merely remarking, that though the term Vampyre is the one in most general acceptance, there are several other terms synonymous with it, made use of in various parts of the world: as Vraucoloeha, Vardoulacha, Gouin, Broucoloka, &c.
THE VAMPYRE.
IT happened that in the midst of the deliberations attendant upon a London writer, there appeared at the meetings of the leaders of the ton a nobleman, more remarkable for his singularities, than his rank. He gazed upon the mirth around him, as if he could not participate therein. Approximately, the light laughter of the woman only attracted his attention, that he might by a look quell it, and throw fear into those breasts where thoughtlessness reigned. Those who felt this sensation of awe, could not explain whence it arose: some attributed it to the discoloured grey eye, which, fixing upon the object's face, did not seem to penetrate, and at one glance to pierce through to the inward workings of the body; but fell upon the cheek with a leaden weight which weighed upon the skin it could not pass. His peculiities caused him to be invited to every house; all wished to see him, and those who had been accustomed to violent outrage, and now felt the weight of ennui, were pleased at having something in their presence capable of engaging their attention. In spite of the deadly hue of his face, which never gained a warmer tirit, whether from the blush of modesty, or from the strong emotion of passion, though its form and outline were beautiful, many of the female hunters after him have attempted to win his attentions, and have, at least, left marks of what they might term affection: Lady Mercer, who had been a mockery of every monster shewn in drawing-rooms since her marriage, threw herself in his way, and did all but put on the dress of a mountebank, to attract his attention: but in fact, when she stood before him, though his eyes were apparently fixed upon her's, still it seemed as if they were unperceived; even her unappalled impudence was baffled, and she left the field. But though the common adultress could not influence ever the judgment of his eyes, it was not that the female sex was wholly indifferent to him: yet such was the apparent oaution with which he spoke to the virtuous wife and innocent daughter, that few knew he ever oddrossed himself to females. He had, however, the reputation of a winning tongue; and whether it was that it even overcame the dread of his singular character, or that they were moved by his apparent hatred of vice, he was as often among the females who form the boast of their sex and their domestic virtues, as among those who sully it by their vices.
About the same time, there came to London a young gentleman of the name of Aubrey: he was an orphan lad with an elder sister in the possession of real wealth, by parents who died while he was yet in childhood. He was also protected by guardians, who thought it their duty merely to take care of his fortune, while they entrusted the more important part of his affairs to the care of military subalterns, he cultivated more imagination than his judgment. He had, however, that high romantic feeling of honour and candour, which daily ruins so many manufacturers' apprentices. He believed all to sympathise with virtue, and thought that vice was thrown in by Providence merely for the picturesque effect of the scenes we see in romances: he thought that the intimacy of a cottage merely consisted in the vesting of clothes, which were as warm, but which were better adapted to the painter's eye by the irregular folds and variuse coloured patches. He thought, in fine, that the dreams of poets were the riches of life. He was handsome, frank, and rich: for these reasons, upon his enthronement into the gay circles, many mothers surrounded him, striving which should describe with least truth their languishing or romping favourites: the daughters at the same time, by their brightening countenances when he approached, and by their sparkling eyes, when he opened his lips, so led him into false certitudes of his talents and his merit. Attached as he was to the romance of his solitary pursuits, he was surprised at finding, that, except in the tallow and wax candles that flickered, not from the presence of a fire, but from the effects of snuffing, there was no foundation in his life for any of the composes of pleasing pictures and descriptions contained in those volumes, from which he had formed his tastes. Finding, however, some compensation in his gratified career, he was about to relinquish his dreams, when the extraordinary being we have now described, crossed him in his career.
He watched him; and the very impossibility of forming an idea of the character of a man entirely absorbed in himself, who gave few other signs of his observation of external objects, than the tacit assent to their existence, implied by the avoidance of their contact: allowing his imagination to capture every thing that flattered his prapensity of ideas, he soon formed this object into the hero of a romance, and determined to obscure the offspring of his fancy, rather than the person before him. He became acquainted with him, paid him attentions, and so far advanced upon his notice, that his preferment was always recognised. He gradually learned that Lord Ruthven's friends were embarrassed, and soon learned, from the manner of preparation in Baker's Street, that he was about to travel. Desire of gaining some information respecting this singular character, which, until now, had only whetted his curiosity. He hinted to his guardians, that it was time for him to stop the tour, which for many years has been thought necessary to enable the young to take some rapid steps in the care of vice towards putting themselves up to an equality with the aged, and not allowing them to appear as if fallen from the sky, whenever scandalous intrigues are mentioned as the subjects of plea or of praise, according to the degree of skill shewn in carrying them on. He consented, and Aubrey immediately communicating his intentions to Lord Ruthven, was surprised to receive from him a proposal to join him. Flattered by such a mark of esteem from him, who, apparently, had been in company with other men, he gladly accepted it, and in a few days they had passed the circling watch.
Hilbert Aubrey had no opportune of studying Lord Rulhven's character, and now he found, that, as many more of his actions were exposed to his view, the results offered different corollaries from the apparent motive of his conduct. His company was profuse in his generosity; the idle, the vagabond, and the beggar, received from his hand more than enough to relieve their immediate wants. But Aubrey could not avoid remarking, that it was not up to the virtuous, reduced to indigence by the misfortunes attendant even upon him, that he gave his alms; these were sent from the door with hardly suppressed sneers; but when the profligate came to ask something, not to relieve his wants, but to allow him to wallow in his lust, and sink him still deeper in his iniquity, he was rewarded away with rich charity. This was, however, attributed by him to the greater importunity of the vicious, which generally revails over the retributive goodness of the virtuous indigent. There was no circumstance about the charity of his Lordship, which was more impressed upon his mind: all those upon whom it was bestowed, inevitably found that there was a wound upon them, for they were all either led to the scaffold, or sunk to the lowest and the most abject rags. At Brussels and other towns through which they passed, Aubrey was surprised at the apperent eagerness with which his companion sought for the centres of all fashionable vice; there he entered into all the spirit of the faro table: he betted, and always gambled with success, except where the known sharper was his antagonist, and then he lost even more than he gained; but it was always with the same unchanging face, with which he generally watched the society around: it was not, however, so when he encountered the rash youth of a novice, or the luckless father of a numcrous family; the latter his only wish seemed foreign's law—this apperent obstractedness of mind was laid aside, and his eyes sparkled with more fire than that of the cat lying with the broken mouse. In every town, he left the former affluent youth, torn from the company he adorned, curfing, in the solitude of a dungeon, the fate that had drawn him within the reach of this fiend; whilst many a fatber sat frantic, amidst the speaking looks of mute hungry children, without a single farthing of his late immense wealth, wherewith to be even sufficent to satisfy their present craving. Yet he took no money from the gambling table; but immediately lost, to the ruiner of any, the last gilder he had just snatched from the convulsive grasp of the innocent: this might but be the result of a certain degree of knowledge, which was not, however, capable of combing the acquaintance of the more experienced. Aubrey often wished to represent this to his friend, and beg him to resign from that charity and pleasurable which proved the ruin of his life, and did not tend to his own profit; but he always delayed it, for each day he hoped his friend would make some opportunily of speaking frankly and openly to him; however, this never occured. Lord Ruthven in his carriage, and amidst the most wild and rich sceries of nature, was always the same: his eye fpoke less than his lip; and though Aubrey was near the object of his curiosity, he obtained no greater gratification from it than the constant excitement of vainly wishing to break that story, which in his exalted imagination began to assume the appearance of something supernatural.
They soon arrived at Rennes, and Aubrey for a time lost sight of his companion; he left him in daily attendance upon the morning circle of an Italian countess, whilst he went in search of the memories of another almost destroyed city. Whilst he was thus engaged, letters arrived from England, which he opened with eager impatience.
The first was from his sister, breathing nothing but affection; the others were from his guardians, the latter astonished him; if it had before entered into his conviction that there was an evil power resented in his companion, these seemed to give him sufficient support for the belief. His guard insisted upon his immediately leaving his friend, and recommended, that his character was dreadfully vicissitudes, for that the possession of irresistible powers of seduction, rendered his licentious habits absolutely dangerous to society. It had been discovered, that his contempt for the adullress had rioted in hatred of her companion; but that he had required, to cancellance his gratification, that her lover, the partner of his gullt, should be hurled from the pinnacle of unsullicd virtue, down to the lowest abyss of infamy and degradation: in fine, that all the females whom he had sought, apparently on account of their virtue, had, since his departure, thrown even the mask aside, and had not scrupled to expose the whole deformity of their vices to the public gaze.
Aubrey discharged upon leaving one, whose character had not yet shown a single bright spot on which to rest the eye. He resolved upon some plausible pretext for abandoning him altogether, purposing, in the mean while, to watch him more closely, and to let no slight circumstances pass by unnoticed. He entered into the same circle, and witness stated, that his Lordship was endeavouring to work upon the inexperience of the daughter of the lady of the house he chiefly frequented. In Italy, it is customary that an unmarried female is met with in saciety; he was therefore compelled to carry on his plans in secret; but Aubrey's eye followed him in all his windings, and soon discovered that an assignation had been appointed, which would most likely end in the ruin of an innocent, though thoughtless girl. Losing no time, he entered the apartment of Lord Ruthven, and immediately asked him his intentions with respect to the lady, informing him at the same time that he was aware of him being about to meet her that very night. Lord Ruthven answered that his intentions were such that he supposed all would have occasion on such an occasion; and upon being pressed whether he intended to marry her, merely laughed. Aubrey retired; and immeditated suicide.
Upon writing a letter, to say, that from that fact he must decline accompanying his Lordship in the remainder of their proposed tour, he ordered his servant to seek other apartments, and calling upon the mother of the lady, informed her of all he knew, not only with regard to her daughter, but also concerning the character of his lordship. The assignation was prevented. Lord Ruthven next day merely ordered his serjeant to give his complete assent to a separation; but did not hold any suspicion of his plans having been foiled by Aubrey's interposition.
Having left Rome, Aubrey directed his steps towards Greece, and crossing the Poninsola, soon found himself at Athens. He then fixed his residence in the house of a Greek; and there occupied himself in tracing the faded records of immense glory upon monumerits which apparently, ashamed of chronicling the deeds of freemen and before slaves, had hidden themselves beneath the sheltering soil or many lichen. Under the same roof as him, existed a being, so beautiful and delicate, that she might have formed the model for a painter wishing to pour tray on canass the promised hope of the falthful in Mahomel's parodise, save that her eyes spake too much mind for any one to think they could belong to those who had no souls. When she danced upon the plain, or tripped along the mountain's side, one would have thought the gazelle a poor type of her beauties; for who would have exchanged her eye, apparently the eye of animated nature, for that sleepy sullen look of the creature suited but to the taste of an epicure. The light step of Ianthe often accompanied him.
Aubrey in his search after antiquities, and often would the unconscious girl, engaged in the pursuit of a Kashmere butterfly, show the whole beauty of her farm, floating as it wore upon the wind, to the eager gaze of him, who forgot the letters he had just decamped up an almost effaced tablet, in the contemplation of her sylph-like figure. Often would her tresses falling, as she flitted around, exhibit in the sun's ray such delicately brilliant and swiftly developing hues, it might well excuse the forgetfulness of the antiquary, who let escape from his mind an object he had before thought of vital importance to the proper interpretation of a passage in Papyrus. But why attempt to describe charms which all feel, but none can appreciate?–It was innocence, youth, and excitement, unaffected by crowded drawing-rooms and glittering balls. When first he drew those remains of which he wished to preserve a memory for his future hours, she would stand by, and watch the magic effects of his pencil, in tracing the history of her native place; she would then describe to him the circling dance upon the open plain, would paint to him in all the glowing colours of youthfulness, the marriage pamp she remembered viewing in her infancy; and then, turning to matters that had evidently made a greater impression upon her mind, would tell him the supernatural tale of her nurse. Her earnestness and apparent belief of what she narrated, excited the interest even of Aubrey; and often as she told him the tale of the living vampyre, who had passed years amidst his friends, and dearest ties, forced every year, by feeding upon the life of a lovely female to prolong his existence, and the ensuing month's, his blood would run cold, whilst he attempted to laugh her out of such ludicrous and horrible fanatics; but she gave him the names of old men who had at last detected one living among themselves, after several of their near relatives and children had been found marked with the stamp of the fiend's appetite; and when she found him so incredulous, she begged of him to believe her, for it had been remarked, that those who had dared to question their evidence, always had some proof given, which obliged them, with grief and heartbreaking, to confess it was true. She detailed to him the traditional appearance of these monsters, and his horror was increased, by hearing a pretty accurate description of Lord Rulven; he, however, persisted in persuading her that there could be no truth in her fears, although at the same time he wondered at the many coincidences which had all tended to excile a belief in the fupernatural power of Lord Ruthven.
Aubrey began to attach himself more and more to her; her innocence, so contrasted with all the affluence of the women among whom he had sought for his vision of romance, won his heart; and while he ridiculed the idea of a young man of English habits, marrying an uneducated Greek girl, he found him becoming increasingly and more attached to the lady before him. He would tear himself at times from her, and, forming a plan for some antiquarian research, he would depart, promising not to return until his object was attained; but he always found it impossible to fix his attention upon the ruins around him, whilst in his mind he retained an image that regarded alone the rightful possessor of his thoughts. She was unconscious of his love, and was ever the same frank infantile creature he had first known. She seemed to part from him with reluctance; but it was of little use for she had no one with whom she could visit her favourite haunts, whilst her guardian was occupied in sketching or uncovering some fragment which had yet escaped the destructive hand of time. She had appealed to her parents on the subject of Vampyres, and they, with several present, affirmed their existence, pale with horror at the very thought. Soon after, Aubrey determined to proceed upon one of his excursions, which was to detain him for a few hours; when he heard the name of the place, they all at once begged of him not to return at night, as he must necessarily pass through a wood, where no Greek would over remain, after the day had closed, upon any consideration. They described it as the resort of the vampyres in their nocturnal orgies, and denounced the most heavy evils as impending upon him who dared to cross their path. Aubrey made light of their representations, and tried to laugh them out of the idea; but when he saw them shudder at his daring thus to mock a superior, infernal power, the very name of which apparently made their blood sreeze, he was silent.
Next morning he set off upon his excursion unencumbered; he was surprised to encounter the melancholic face of the hos, and was concurred to find that his words, mocking the belief of those horrible fiends, had inspired them with such terror. When he was about to depart, she came to the side of his horse, and earnestly begged him to return, as night allowed the power of these beasts to be put in action; he promised. He was, however, so occupied in his research, that he did not perceive that day-light would soon end, and that in the horizon there was one of those specks which, in the warmer climates, rapidly gather in a tremendous mass, and pour all their rage upon the devoured country. He at last, though, mounted his horse, determined to make up by spoiled for his delay: but it was too late. Twilight, in the southern climes, is a most unknown; immediately the sun sets, the storm begins: and although he had advanced far, the power of the storm was tremendous–the echoing thunder had scarcely an interval of rest–and thick beavy rain forced its way through the canopying foliage, whilst the blue forked lashing seemed to fountain and radiate at his very feet. Suddenly his horse took fright, and he was carried with dreadful rapidity through the entangled forest. The animal at last, through fatigue, stopped, and he found, by the glare of lightning, that he was in the neighbourhood of a hovel that hardly lifted itself up from the masses of dead leaves and brushwood which surrounded it. Dismounting, he approached, hoping to find someone to guide him to the town, or at least trusting to obtain shelter from the pelting of the storm. As he approached, the thunders, for a moment silent, allowed him to hear the furious shrieks of a woman mingling with the stifled, exultant mockery of a laugh, continued in an almost inhuman sound; he was startled; but, roused by the thunder which again rolled over his head, he, with a sudden effort, forced open the door of the hut. He found himself in utter darkness: the sound, however, guided him. He was apparently unperceived; for, though he struggled, still the sounds continued, and no notice was taken of him. He found himself in contact with someone, whom he immediately seized; but then a voice cried, "Again baffled!" to which a loud laugh succeeded; and he felt himself grappled by one whose strength seemed superhuman: determined to save his life as dearly as he could, he struggled; but it was in vain: he was lifted from the ground and hurled with enormous force against the ground: his assailant threw himself up upon him, and kneeling upon his breast, had placed his hands upon his throat—wherhe glare of many torches penetrating through the hole that gave light in the day, disturbed him; he immediately rose, and, following his prey, rushed through the door, and for a moment the crunching of the branches, as he broke through the wood, was no longer heard. The storm was still; and Aubrey, incapable of moving, was so heard by those without. They entered; the light of their torches fell upon the mud walls, and the torch loaded on every individual straw with heavy flakos of soot. At the sight of Aubrey they searched for her who had attracted him by her charms; he was again left in darkness; but what was his horror, when the light of the torch once more burst upon him, to perceive the airy form of his fair cousin brought in a lifeless condition. He shut his eyes, hoping that it was but a vision arising from his disturbed mind; but he again saw the same form, when he unclosed them, stretched by his fingers. There was no colour upon her cheek, not even upon her lip; yet there was a stillness about her face that seemed almost as attaching as the life that once dwelt there:–upon her neck and breast was blood, and upon her throat were the marks of teeth having opened the vein:–to this the men pointed, crying, simultaneously struck with horror, "A Vampyre!" "A Vampyre!" A litter was quickly formed, and Aubrey was laid by the side of her, who had lately been to him the object of so many bright and foiry visions, now fallen with the flower of life that had died from her. He knew not what his thoughts were–his mind was benumbed and seemed to shudder, and take refuge in vacancy–he held almost unconciously in his hand a naked dagger of a particular construction, which had been found in the hut. They were soon met by different parties who had been engaged in the search of something a mother had missed. Their lamentable cries, as they approached the house, forewarned the parents of some dreadful catastrophe. –To describe their grief would be impossible; but when they identified the cause of their child's death, they looked at Aubrey, and pointed to the corse. They were unmarried; both died broken-hearted.
Aubrey being put to bed was seized with the most violent fever, and was often delirious; in these intemperate moments he would call upon Lord Ruthven and upon Ianthe–by some unaccouritable combination he seemed to beg of his former companion to spare the being he loved. At other times he would imprecate maladies upon his head, and curse him as her destroyer. Lord Ruthven, chanced at this time to arrive at Athens, and, without any provocation, upon hearing of the death of Aubrey, immediately placed himself in the same house, and became his constant attendant. When the latter recovered from his delirium, he was horrified and started at the sight of him whose image he had now combined with that of Vampyre; but Lord Ruthven, by his kind words, expressing almost repentance for the fault that had caused their separation, and even more by the attention, anxiety, and care which he showed, soon reconciled him to his presence. His lordship seemed quite changed; he no longer appeared the apathetic being who had so astounded Aubrey; but as soon as his convalescence seemed to be rapid, he again gradually retired into the same state of mind, and Aubrey perceived no difference from the former, except that at times he was surprised to see his gaze fixated intently upon him, with a smile of malicious exultation paying upon his lips: he knew not why, but this smile haunted him. During the last stage of the invalid's recovery, Lord Routhven was apparently engaged in watching the tideless waves raised by the cooling breeze, or in morking the progress of those orbs, circling, like our world, the moveless sun;—indeed, he appeared to wish to avoid the eyes of all.
Aubrey's mind, by this shock, was greatly weakened, and that elasticity of spirit which had so distinguished him now seemed to have fended for ever. He was now as much a lover of solitude and silence as Lord Ruthven; but much as he wished for solitude, his mind could not find it in the neighbourhood of Athens; if he sought it amid the ruins he had formerly frequented, Anthea's form stood by his side—if he searched in the woods, her light step would appear lurking amidst the underwood, in the presence of the modest violet; then suddenly turning round, would show, to his wild imagination, her pale face and wounded throat, with a meek smile upon her lips. He determined to destroy every scene, every aspect of which created such bitter assizes in his mind. He proposed to Lord Ruthven, to whom he held himself bound by the tremendous care he had taken of him during his illness, that they should visit those parts of Greece neither had yet seen. They travelled in every direction, and sought every spot to which a recollection could be attached: but though they thus passed from place to place, they seemed not to heed what they gazed upon. They heard much of robbers, but they gradually began to slight these reports, which they imagined were only the invention of indviduals, whose interest it was to excite the generosity of those whom they protected from pretended dangers. In consequence of their neglecting the advice of the inhabitants, on one occasion they travelled with only a few guineas to serve as guide and as a defence. Upon entering, through, a narrow passage, at the bottom of which was the bed of a torrent, with great masses of ruck brought down from the neighbouring provinces, they had resolved to repent their negligence; for scarcely were the whole of the party engaged in the narrow pass, when they were startled by the sudden firing of bullets close to their heads, and the echoed report of several guns. In an instant their guards had left them, and, placing themselves behind rocks, had begun to fire in the direction whence the repart came. Lord Ruthven and Lord Aubrey, following their example, retired for a moment behind the shoring line of the regiment, but ashamed of being thus detained by a foe, who with jovial spirits made them advance, and being exposed to ambush.
As a matter of fact, if any of the robbers should climb above and take them in the rear, they ceased at once to march forward in fear of the enemy. Hardly had they lost the hold of the rock, when Lord Rutbven received a shot in the shoulder, which brought him to the ground. Aubrey hastened to his assistance; and, no longer heedning the contest or his own peril, was soon surprised by seeing the robbers' faces around him–his guards having, upon Lord Ruthven's being wounded, immediately thrown up their arms and surrendered.
By promise of great reward, Avrey soon induced them to convey his wounded brother to a neighbouring cabin; and having agreed upon a ransom, he was no more disturbed by their present presence–they being content merely to guard the entrance till their colleague should return with the promised sum, for which he had an order. Lord Ruthven's strength rapidly declined; and two days mortification ensued, and death seemed advancing with hasty sleps. His conduct and appearance had not changed; he seemed as unconcious of pain as he had been of the objects about him: but towards the close of the last evening, his mind became apparently vengeful, and his eyes often fixed upon Aubrey, who was induced to offer his assistance with more than usual earnestness—"Assist me!" You may save me–you may do better than that–I mean not my life, I heed the death of my once as little as the passing day; but you may save my honour, your father's honour. "How? Tell me how? "I would do any thing," replied Aubrey. "I need but little–my life ebbs apace–I cannot explain the whole–but if you would conceal all you know of me, my life were free from stain in the world's mouth–and if my whereabouts were unknown for some time in England–I—I–but life. "It shall not be known." "Swear!" cried the dying man, raising himself in exultant violence, "Swear that all your soul reveres, by all your nature fear; swear that, for a year and a day you will not impart your knowledge of my crimes or death to any living being in any way, whatever may happen, or whatever you may see. His eyes seemed bursting from their sockets: "I swear!" He sunk laughing upon his pillows, and breathed no more.
Aubrey retired to rest, but did not sleep; the many circumstances atlending his acquaintance with this man rose upon his mind, and he knew why; when he remitted his oath a cold feeling came over him, as if from the presontinent of something horrible awaiting him. Rising early in the morning, he was about to enter the room in which he had found the corpse, when a robber met him, and informed him that it was no longer there, having been conveyed by him and his comrades, upon his retiring, to the pinnacle of a neighbouring mount, according to a promise he had given his lordship, that he should be exposed to the first cold ray of the moon that rose after his death. Aubrey astonished, and taking several of the men, determined to go and bury the body upon the spot where it lay. But, when he had reached to the summit he found no trace of the corpse or the clothes, though the rabbers swore they pointed out the identical rock on which they had laid the body. For a time his mind was bewildered in conjunctions, but he at last returned, convinced that they had buried the corpse for the sake of the clothes.
Weary of a country in which he had had to contend with such terrible misfortunes, and which all apparently conspired to hoighten that superstitious melancholy which had seized upon his mind, he resolved to leave it, and soon arrived at Smyrna. While waiting for a vessel to take him to Otranto, or to Naples, he occupied himself in arranging the effects he had wit him belonging to Lord Ruthven. Amongst other things there was a case containing several weapons of offence, more or less adapted to ensure the death of the victor.
There were several daggers and arrows. Whilst turning them over, and examining their curious forms, what was his surprise at finding a sheath apparently ornamented in the same style as the dagger discovered in the fatal hut–he shuddered–hastening to gain further proof, he touched the weapon, and his horror may be imagined when he discovered that it fitted, though peculiarly shapcd, the sheath he held in his hand. His eyes seemed to need no further certainty–they seemed gazing to be bound to the dagger; yet still he wished to disbelieve; but the particular form, the same varying tints upon the blade and sheath were identical on both, and left no room for doubt; there were also drops of blood on each.
He left Smyrna, and on his way home, at Rome, his first inquiries were upon the lady he had attempted to snatch from Lord Ruthven's seduction arts. Her parents were in distress, their livelihood ruined, and she had not been heard of since the departure of her lordship. Aubrey's mind became almost overwhelmed under so many repeated horrors; he was afraid that this lady had fallen a victim to the destroyer Hanthe. He became morose and silent; and his only occupation consisted in urging the speed of the proceedings, as if he were going to save the life of some one he held dear. He arrived at Calais; a breeze, which seemed obedient to his will, soon wafted him to the English shores; and he hastened to the mansion of his fathers, and there, for a moment, appeared to lose, in the embraces and caresses of his sifter, all memory of the past. If she had formerly, by her infantine careſses, had gained his affection, now that the woman began to appear, she was still more attaching herself to him than before.
Mr. Aubrey had not that winning grace which gains the gaiety and applause of the drawing-room attendants. There was none of that light brilliancy which only exists in the beated atmosphere of a crowded place. Her blue eye was never lit up by the levity of the mood beneath. There was a melancholy character about it which did not seem to arise from misfortune, but from some feeling within, that appeared to occupy a soul confcious of a brighter realm. Her step was not that light footing, which sometimes strays where a butterfly or a colour may approach; it was sedate and perisive. When alone, her face was never brightened by the smile of joy; but when her brother breathed to her his affection, she would in her mind forget those horrors. She knew destroyed his reputation, who would have exchanged her smile for that of the voluptuary? It seemed as if those eyes were then playing in the light of their own native sphere. She was yet only eighteen, and had not been presented to the world, it having been thought by her guard more fit that her presentation should be delayed until her brother's return from the continent, when he might be her protegee. It was now, therefore, resolved that the next drawing-room, which was fast approaching, should be the occasion of her entry into the "busy scene." Aubrey would rather have remained in the manion of his fathers, and fed upon the malignancy which overpowered him. He could not feel interest about the frivolities of fashionably strangers, when his mind had been so torn by the events he had witnessed; but he resolved to sacrifice his own comfort to the protection of his sister. They soon arrived in town, and prepared for the next day, which had been adapted as a drawing-room.
The crowd was extraordinary–a drawing-room had not been held for a long time, and those who were anxious to bask in the smile of royalty, crowded thither. Aubrey was there with his sister. While he was standing in a corner by himself, hoedles of all around him, engaged in the remembrance that the first time he had seen Lord Ruthven was in that very place—he felt himself suddenly seized by the arm, and a voice he recognized too well, sounded in his ear—"Remember your oath." He had hardly time to turn, fearful of seeing a spectre that would frighten him, when he pereceived, from a little distance, the same figure which had attracted his notice on this spot on his first entry into society. He gazed till his limbs almost refusing to bear their weight, he was obliged to take the hand of a friend, and forcing a passage through the crowd, he threw himself into the carriage, and was driven home. He paced the room with rried steps, and fixed his hands upon his head, as if he were afraid his thoughts were bursting from his brain. Lord Ruthven again before him–circumstances started up in a dreadful array–the defendant–his oath–He roused himself, he could not believe it possible–the dead rise again!–He thought his imagination had conjured up the image his mind was resling upon. It was impossible that he could be real–he determined, therefore, to get again into society; for though he attempted to ask concerning Lord Ruthven, the name hung upon his lips, and he could not succeed in gaining admission. He went a few nights after with his sister to the assembly of a regiment. Leaving her under the prolection of a matron, he retired into a recess, and there gave himself up to his own devouring habits. Perceiving, at once, that some men were leaving, he removed himself, and entering another room, found his sister surrounded by several, apparently in earnest conversation; he attempted to pass through and get near her, when one, whom he requested to move, turned round, and revealed to him those features he most dreaded. He sprang forward, seized his sister's arm, and, with a hurried step, forded towards the passage: at the door he found himself impedod by the crowd of servants who were waiting for their lords; and while he was engaged in passing them, he heard a voice whisper close to him—"Remember your oath!"–He did not dare to turn, but, hurrying his sister, soon reached home.
Aubrey became extremely distracted. If before his mind had been absorbed by one subject, how much more completely was it engaged, now that the certainty of the monster's living again pressed upon his thoughts. His sister's concerns were now heard, and it was in vain that she induced him to explain to her what had caused this abrupt occurrence. He only uttered a few words, and those infuriated her. The more he thought, tho more he was bewildered. His oath started him; was he then to allow this monster to roam, bearing ruiri upon his breath, amidst all he held dear, and not arrest its progress? His very sister must have been terrified of him. But even if he were to break his oath, and close his chambers, who would believe him? He thought of employing his own hand to free the world from such a wretch; but deal, he remembered, had been already mocked. For days he remained in this state; shul up in his room, he saw no one, and ate only when his sister came, who, with eyes streaming with tears, besought him, for her sake, to support her. At last, no longer capable of bearing stillness and solitude, he left his house, roamed from place to place, anxious to fly that image which had possessed him. His dress became loose, and he wandered, as of course exposed to the noonday sun as to the midnigh damps. He was no longer to be recognized; at first he returned with him to the house; but at last he laid him down to rest wherever fatigue overtook him. His sister, anxious for his safety, employed people to follow him; but they were soon distanced by him who fled from a pursuer swifter than any—from thought. His character, however, suddenly changed. Struck with the idea that he left by his absence the whole of his friends, with a fiend amongst them, of whose presence they were unconscious, he determined to entice him again into society, and watch him closely, anxious to forewarn him, in spite of his oath, a man whom Lord Russell opproached with intimacy. But when he entered into a room, his haggard and fuspicious eyes were so striking, his inward shudderings so visible, that his sister was at last compelled to beg of him to abstain from seeking, for her sake, the society which affected him so strongly. When, however, remonstrance proved unavailing, the guardians thought proper to interpose, and, fearing that his rurid was becoming alionated, they thought it high time to resume the restrictions which had been before imposed on them by Aubrey's parents.
Desired of saving him from the injuries and sufferings he had daily encountered in his wandering, and of preventing him from expositing to the general public those marks of what they considered folly, they engaged a physiologist to reside in the house, and take constant care of him. He hardly appeared to notice him, so completely was his mind absorbed in one terrible crime. His incoherence became at last too great, and he was confined to his chair. There he would often lie for days, incapable of being roused. He had become emaciated, his eyes had attained a glassy lustre; the only sign of affection and recollection having displaced itself upon the entry of his sister; then he would sometimes start, and, seizing her hands, with looks that severely afflicted her, he would desire her not to follow him. "Oh, do not touch him! If your love for me is aught, DO not go near him!" When, however, she inquired to whom he referred, his only answer was, "True!" Again he went into a state, whence not even she could rouse him. This lasted many months: gradually, however, as the year was passing, his incohercences became less frequent, and his mind threw off a portion of its gloom, whilst his friends observed, that several times in the day he would count upon his fingers a finite number, and then smile.
The time had nearly elapsed, when, upon the last day of the year, on the occasion of his guardian entering his room, began to communicate with his physician on the melancholy circumstance of Aubrey's being in so melancholy a situation, when his sister was going next day to be married. Instantly Aubrey's attention was attracted; he asked anxiously to whom. Glad of this mark of returning in good conduct, from which they feared he had been deprived, they mentioned the name of the Earl of Marsden. He was a young Earl whom he had acquainted with in society, and he seemed pleased, and excited them even more by his expressing his intent to be present at the nuptials, and desiring to see his sister. They answered not, but in a few minutes his sister was with him. He was apparently again capable of being affected by the insluence of her lovely smile; for he pressed her to him, and kissed her cheek, wet with tears, flowing at the thought of her brother's being once more alive to the feelings of affection. He began to speak with all his wonted warth, and to congratulate her upon her marriage with a person so distired for rank and every accomplishment; when he suddenly perceived a locket upon her chest; opening it, what was his surprise at beholding the features of the monster who had so long occupied his life. He seized the purse in a paroxysm of rage, and trampled it under foot. Upon her asking him why he thus destroyed the resemblance of her future husband, he looked as if he did not understand her–then seizing her hands, and gazing on her with a frantic expression of countenancy, he bade her swear that she would never wed this morister, for he– But he would not advance–it seemed as if that prosecutor again bade him remember his oath–he turned suddenly round, thinking Lord Ruthveri was near him but saw no one. In the meantime the guardians and physician, who had heard the whole, and thought this was but a return of his disorder, intervened, and forcing him from Miss Aubrey, desired her to leave him. He fell upon his knees to them, he implored, he begged of them to delay but for one day. They, attributing this to the insanity they imagined had taken possession of his mind, endeavoured to pacify him, and retired.
Lord Ruthven had called the morning after the drawing-room, and had been refused with every one present. When he heard of Aubrey's ill health, he readily understood himself to be the cause of it; but when he earned that he was deemed insane, his exultation and pleasure could hardly be concealed from those among whom he had gained this insult. He bore to the house of his former companion, and, by constant attendance, and the pretence of great affection for the brother in the most unfortunate fate, he successfully won the ear of Miss Aubrey. Who could resist his power? His language had dangers and toils to recount: could speak of himself as of an individual having no sympathy with others being on the crowded earth, save with her to whom he addressed himself; could toll how, since he knew her, his existence, had begun to seem worthy of preservation, if it were merely that he might listen to her soothing accents; or fine, he knew so well how to use the serpents's art, or such was the will of fate, that he gained her affection. The title of the elder branch falling at length to him, he received an important embassy, which served as an excuse for having the marriage, (in spite of his brother's deranged state,) which was to take place the very day before his departure for the continent.
Aubrey, when he was left with the physician and his guardians, attempted to bribe the servants, but in vain. He asked for pen and paper; it was given him; he wrote a letter to his sister, conjuring her, saying she valued her own happiness, her own honour, and the honour of those now in the grave, who once held her in their arms as their hope and the hope of their house, to delay but for a few hours that marriage, on which he denounced the most heavy curses. The witnesses promised they would deliver it; but giving it to the physician, he thought it better not to harass any more the mind of Miss Aubrey by, what he considered, the ravings of a maniac. Night passed with no rest to the busy inmates of the house; and Arnold heard, with a horror which may more easily be conceived than described, the noise of breaking preparation. Marning came, and the sound of chains brake upon his ear. Aubrey grew almost frantic. The curiosity of the servants at once overcame their vigilance, they produced a knife, and stole away, leaving him in the custody of an helpless woman. He seized the opportunity, with one blow was out of the room, and in a moment found himself in the apartment where all were nearly assembled. Lord Ruthven was the first to perceive him: he immediately approached, and, taking his arm by force, hurricd him from the room, seething with rage. When on the staircase, Lord Ruthven whispered in his ear—"Remember your oath, and know, if not my bride to day, your sister is dishonoured. Women are frail!" So saying, he directed him towards his attending officers, who, accompanied by the old woman, had come in search of him. Aubrey could no longer support himself; his rage not finding vent, had broken a carriage-vessel, and he was conveyed to bed. This was not mentioned to his sister, who was not present when he entered, as the physician was afraid of agitating her. The engagement was solemnised, and the bride and bridegroom left Lorond.
Aubrey's weakness induced; the constriction of blood produced symptams of the near approach of death. He desired his sister's guardians might be called, and when the midnight hour had passed, he related composedly what the reader has perused–he died immediately after.
The guardians hastened to protect Miss Aubrey; but when they arrived, it was too late. Lord Ruthven had disappeared, and Aubrey's sister had glutted the thirst of a VAMPYRE!
EXTRACT OF A LETTER, CONTAINING AN ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE IN THE ISLAND OF MITYLENE.
ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE, &c.
"The world was all before him, where he could choose his place of rest, and regulate his direction."
IN Sailing across the Gregoian Archipelago, on board one of His Majesty's vessels, in the year 1812, we came into the harbour of Mitylene, the island of the same name. The fame of this place, and the constant supply of cattle and vegetables always to be had there, induce many Brits to visit it—both men of war and merchantmen; and though it lies rather out of the track for ships hound to Smyrna, bounties amply repay for the deviation of a voyage. We landed, as usual, at the bottom of the bay, and while the men were employed in watching, and the purser barging for cattle with the natives, the clergyman and myself took a ramble to the cave called Hamer's School, and other places, where we had been before. On the brow of Mount Ida (a small mountain so named) we met with and engaged a young Greek lad, our guide, who told us he had come from Scio with an English lord, who left the island four days previous to our arrival in his country. "He engaged me as a pilot," said the Greek, "and would have taken me with him; but I did not choose to quit Mitylene, where I am likely to get married. He was an odd, but a very good man. The cottage over the hill, facing the river, belong to him, and he has left an old man in charge of it: he gave Dominick, the wine-trader, six hundred zeroes for it, (about £250 English value,) and has resided here about fourteen months, though not constantly; for he sails in his canoe very often to the different islands."
This account excited our curiosity very much, and we wasted no time in hastening to the house where our countryman had resided. We were kindly received by an officer, who directed us over the mansion. It consisted of four apart rooms on the ground-floor—an entrance hall, a drawing-room, a sitting parlour, and a bedroom, with a spacy closet annexed. They were all plainly decorated:plain green-stained walis, marble tables on either side, a large window in the centre, and a small fountain beneath, which could be made to play through the bronches by moving a spring fixed in the side of a small bronze Venus in a leaning posture; a large cushion or sofcloth complemented the furniture. In the hall stood half a dozen English cane chairs, and an empty book-case: there were no mirrors, except a single painting. The bed chamber had merely a large mattress spread on the floor, with two stuffed cotton quilts and a pillow—the common bedstead in Greece. In the sitting-room we obserued a marble shelf, formerly, the old man told us, filled with books and papiers, which were then in a large seaman's box. In the closet. It was open, but we did not think ourselves justified in examining the contents. On the tablet of the recorders lay Voltoire's, Shakspeare's, Boileau's, and Rousseau's works complete; Volney's Ruins of Empires; Zimmerman, in the Grecian languange; Klopstock's Messiah; Katzebue's novels; Schiller's play of the Robber; Milton's Parodise Lost, an Italian edition, printed at Peking in 1891; several small pamphlets from the Greek press at Constantinople, much torn, but no English book of any description. Most of these books were filled with marginal notes, written with a pencil, in Italian and Latin. The mantle was literally scrawled all over, and marked with slips of paper, on which also were remarks.
The old man said: "The lord had been reading these books the evening before he sailed, and forgot to place them with the others; but," said he, "there they must lie until his return; for he is so particular, that were I to move on without orders, he would frown upon me for a week together; he is otherways very good." I once did have a serjeant; and I haue the produce from this farm for the trouble of taking care of it, except twenty shillings which I pay to an aged Armerian who residces in a small coltage in the wood, and whom the lord brought here from Adrianople; I don't know for what purpose."
The appearance of the house externally was pleasing. The portico in front was fifty paces long and fourteen broad, and the fluted marble pillars wit black plinths and fret-work cornices, (as it is now customary in Grecian architecture,) were considerably higher than the roof. The roof, surrounded by a light stone coping, was covered by a fine Turkoy carpet, beneath an awning of strong coarse linen. Most of the house-tops are thus furnished, as upon them the Greeks pass their hours smoking, drinking light spirits, such as "lachryma christi," catching fire, and enjoying the evening breeze.
On the fourth and as we entered the house, a small streaking bird glided away, grapes, oranges and limes were cluttering together on its borders, and under the shade of two largo myrtle bushes, a marble seat with an omamental wooden back was placed, on which we were told, the lord passed many of his evenings and nights till twelve o'clock, reading, writing, and talking to himself. "I suppose," said the old man, "praying" for he was very devout, "and always attended our church five days a week, besides Sundays."
The view from this seat was what may be termed "a bird's-eye view." A line of rich vineyards led the eye to Mount Calcla, covered with olive and myrtle trees in bloom, and on the summit of which an ancient Greek temple appeared in majestic decay. A small stream running through the ruins descended in broken cascades, until it was lost in the woods near the mountain's base. The sea smooth as glass, and an horizon unshadowed by a single cloud, terminates the view in front; and a little to the left, through a vista of lofty chesnut and palm-trees, several small islands were distinctly observed, studding the light blue wave with spots of emerald green. I seldom enjoyed a cigar more than I did this; but our inquiries were fruitless as to the name of the person who had resided in this romantic solitude: none knew his name but Dominick, his banker, who had gone to China. "The Armenian," said our conductor, "could tell, but I am sure he will riot,"—"And cannot you tell, old fart?" I said, "If I can," said he, "I dare not." We had not time to visit the Armenian, but on our return to the town we found several personal letters of the learned lord. He had portioned some young girls when he was last upon the island, and had danced with them at the nuptial feast. He gave a cow to one man, horses to others, and cotton and silk to the girls who live by weaving these articles. He also bought a new boat for a fisher man who had lost his own in a gale, and he often gave Greek Testaments to the parish clergy. In short, he appeared to us, from all we collected, to have been a very eocentric and benevolent character. One circumstance we learnt, which our old friend at the cottage thougbt proper not to disclose. He had a well-behaved daughter, with whom the lord was often seen walking on the secl-shore, and he had bought her a piano-forte, and taught her himself the use of it.
Such was the information with which we departed from the peaceful Isle of Mitylene; our imaginations all on the rack, guessing who this rambler in Gee could be. He had money it was evident: he had philanthropy of disposition, and all those eccentricities which mark peculiar men. Arrived at Palermo, all our doubts were dispelled. Falling out of company will be Mr. FOSTER, the architect, a pupil of WYATT'S, who had been on travelling in Egypt and Greece, "The individual," said he, "about whom you are anxious, is Lord Byron; I met him in my travels on the island of Tenedos, and I acquainted him at Messina." We had never then heard of his lordship's fame, as we had been some years away; but "Childe Horolde" being put into our hands we recognised the recluse of Calcla in every way. Deeply did we regret not having been more careful in our researches at the cottage, but we consoled ourselves with the idea of returning to M'Ilene on some future day; but to know that day will never return. I make this statement, believing it not quite uninteresting, and in jest to his lordship's good name, which has been grossly slandered. He has been discharged.
He regarded himself as of an unfeeling disposition, averse to associating with human nature, or contributing in any way to its sorrows, or odd to its pleasures. The fact is direct the reverse, as may be plainly gathered from these little anecdotes. All the finer feelings of the heart, so elegantly deplored in his lordship's poems, seem to have their seat in his bosom. Tendernities, sympathy, and charity appear to guide all his actions: and his courting the repose of solitude is an additional reason for marking him as a man on whose heart Religion hath set her seal, and over whose head Benevolence has thrown her mantle. No man can read the preceding pleasing "traits" without feeling proud of him as a counsellor. With respect to his loues or pleasures, I do not assume a right to judge his opinion. Reports are ever to be received with caution, particularly when directed against man's moral integrity; and he who dares justify himself before that awful tribunal where all must appear, alone may censure the errors of a fellow-man. Lord Byron's character is testimony of his genius. To do good in secret, and shun the world's applause, is the surest testiment of a virtuoso mind and self-approving conscience.
